heading: Trade Mark
Infringement of
HeadNote.description:
Trade Mark - Infringement of - Plaintiff and defendant manufacturing and marketing tobacco under trade mark 'AFZAL' and 'KUBER' respectively - Particular part thereof cannot be considered in isolation - It is relevant to consider whether there is any visual similarity between label of plaintiffs and that of defendants - While doing so it will not be permissible to compare it by keeping them side by side - Factors like nature of commodity, class of purchasers and other surrounding circumstances would also have to be taken into consideration - Contention that Court to consider only words 'AFZAL' and 'KUBER' while comparing marks of plaintiff and defendant, liable to be rejected.

AIR 1951 Bombay 147, AIR 1984 Bombay 218, 2004 (28) PTC 83 (Bom) Ref. to. 			 [Para 11,14]

heading: Trade Mark
Infringement of
HeadNote.description:
Trade Mark - Infringement of - Contention that disclaimer and descriptive matter on label cannot be looked into - Disclaimer is to define right of proprietor under registration - It is to avoid possibility of unauthorised claims being made on basis of registration of trade mark - Despite disclaimer action of passing off could be taken if plaintiff establishes that by long use of trade mark he has acquired any rights in disclaimer part.

AIR 1955 SC 558 Ref. to. 	 [Para 15]

heading: Trade mark
Infringement of
HeadNote.description: Trade mark - Infringement of - Plaintiff and defendant manufacturing and marketing tobacco under trade mark 'AFZAL' and 'KUBER' respectively - Colour scheme, dimensions of packaging, text is almost identical - Comparison of both products and applying test 'as judged by eye' - It is possible that defendant's product being passed as that of plaintiff's - Injunction granted to plaintiff. 			(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Trade mark
Infringement of
HeadNote.description: Trade mark - Infringement of - Plaintiff and defendant manufacturing and marketing tobacco under trade mark 'AFZAL' and 'KUBER' respectively - Perusal of registration certificate of defendant reveal that artistic work as adopted on label of defendants is totally different that one which is being used on packaging - Advertisement on record showing that product advertised is totally having different label on packaging - Defendants not given any explanation as to how it has adopted label identical to plaintiff - Label used by defendants is deceptive imitation of plaintiff's label - Injunction granted against defendants. 			(Para 20)

heading: Trade mark
Infringement of
HeadNote.description: Trade mark - Infringement of - Plaintiff and defendant manufacturing and marketing tobacco under trade mark 'AFZAL' and 'KUBER' respectively - Plaintiffs have earned goodwill and good reputation in market over decades together - If defendants are permitted to pass off their product as of plaintiffs and if product is of inferior quality, it may harm reputation of plaintiff - Tests of balance of convenience and irreparable injury are in favour of plaintiffs - Injunction granted in favour of plaintiff. 	(Para 21)

heading: Licence
Revocation of
Notice

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Sale and delivery of prepaid SIM cards
HeadNote.description:
Sale and delivery of prepaid SIM cards - Joint Expert Committee directed to be constituted to examine issues on which TRAI has given opinion divergent to that given by DOT.

Following are the points of divergence that require examination by the Joint Expert Committee :

(a) Whether re-verification should be undertaken by the service provider/licensee, the DoT itself or any other central body?

(a) Whether re-verification should be undertaken by the service provider/licensee, the DoT itself or any other central body?

(c) Whether delivery of SIM cards may be made by post? Which is the best mode of delivery of SIM cards to provide due verification of identity and address of a subscriber?

(d) Which of the application forms, i.e., the existing one or the one now suggested by TRAI should be adopted as universal application form for purchase of a SIM card?

(e) In absence of Unique ID card, whether updating of subscriber details should be the burden of the licensee personally or could it be permitted to be carried out through an authorized representative of the licensee?

(f) In the interest of national security and the public interest, whether the database of all registered subscribers should be maintained by DoT or by the licensee and how soon the same may be made accessible to the security agencies in accordance with law?     [Para 20]

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Licence for providing basic telecom services
HeadNote.description: Licence for providing basic telecom services - Defects in the system installed by appellant - Unable to commence services on date accepted by it in the package signed and accepted unconditionally - Liquidated damages amounting to '8/- crores deposited by it without any demur - Held unconditional acceptance of terms of package and benefit which appellant derived under the same will estop appellant from challenging recovery of dues or process of its determination, appellant could not be allowed to approbate and reprobate. 2009(3) ALL MR 947 (S.C.), 1981(1) SCC 537 - Ref. to.	(Paras 13, 18)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Counter claim
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of Telecom Disputes Settlement & Appellate Tribunal (TDSAT) - Counter claim - Normally, a right to make a claim would also include a right to make a cross claim or counter claim in the sense that the Central Government could always make an independent claim on matters covered under the Act and such a claim will have to be entertained by the TDSAT - TDSAT has jurisdiction to entertain a counter claim in the light of S.14(1) and 14-A of the Act.

Section 14-A of the Act gives the right to the Central Government, or to the State Government to approach TDSAT on its own. Going by the definitions in the Act, both Governments could be "service providers". The Central Government could also be the licensor. Thus, either as a licensor or a service provider, the Central Government could make an application to TDSAT seeking an adjudication of any dispute between it and the licensee or between it and another service provider or between it and a group of consumers. It has actually to make its claim in TDSAT. There is no reason to whittle down the right given to the Central Government to approach the TDSAT for an adjudication of its claim which comes under Section 14(1) of the Act. Normally, a right to make a claim would also include a right to make a cross-claim or counter claim in the sense that the Central Government could always make an independent claim on matters covered under the Act and such a claim will have to be entertained by the TDSAT. This the Central Government could do even while it is defending a claim made against it in TDSAT, by way of a separate application. If a subject matter is capable of being raised before the TDSAT by the Central Government or the State Government by way of a claim by making an application under Section 14 of the Act, it would not be logical to hold that the same claim could not be made by way of a counter claim when the other side, namely, the licensee or consumers, had already approached the TDSAT with a claim of their own and the Central Government is called upon to defend it. It is, therefore, not possible to accept an argument that a counter claim by the Central Government or State Government cannot be entertained by the TDSAT. Held, the TDSAT has jurisdiction to entertain a counter claim in the light of Section 14(1) and 14-A of the Act.  [Para 12]

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Recommendation of TRAI
HeadNote.description: Recommendation of TRAI - Not binding on Central Govt. even though it deserves to be given due weightage - Final decision rests with Central Govt. alone - Of course, such a decision, especially a decision relating to frame a policy for inviting tender has to be in accord with norms of Article 14 of Constitution. 2014 ALL SCR 1981 Rel. on. 	(Paras 51, 52)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading:
Functions of the Authority.

Section 11 (which occurs in Chapter III) enumerates the functions of TRAI. The Section authorises the authority to make recommendations either suo motu or on requests made by the LICENSOR on the various matters enumerated therein. Relevant among them are: (i) terms and conditions of licence to a service provider; (ii) measures to facilitate competition and promote efficiency in the operation of telecommunications services so as to facilitate growth in such services; (iii) efficient management of available spectrum; and (iv) ensure compliance of terms and conditions of licence, are some of the functions of the Authority.      [Para 61]

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Stipulating terms and conditions to a service provider
HeadNote.description: Stipulating terms and conditions to a service provider - Government must consult and seek recommendations of Authority - It is mandatory. (Para 69)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Obligation on Government of India to consult TRAI
HeadNote.description: Obligation on Government of India to consult TRAI - Arises only in case of "new license" - Not in renewal/extension of existing license. (Para 76)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Spectrum management
HeadNote.description: Spectrum management - Government is required to keep in mind efficient utilization, optimal revenue growth, sufficient competition to avoid monopoly in telecom market - Decision to conduct actions cannot be said to be totally irrational or irrelevant consideration. (Paras 76, 77)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - Wording of O.7, R.11 is in the passive voice - The plaint is liable to be rejected in the cases enumerated under that rule - The rule, therefore, does not require essentially any application to be made by any party - The Court itself can reject the plaint if any one of the six cases enumerated in the said rule is seen.	(Paras 4, 5, 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Termination/preponement of de-monopolisation
HeadNote.description:
Termination/preponement of de-monopolisation - Package offered by Government for preponement - Court adjudicating such a dispute would require to bear in mind the worldwide technical advances in the field of telecommunications as well as the economic development of India in that regard to determine how much, if at all, the package to be given by the Government would be required to be enhanced or compensation of a particular extent be awarded to the plaintiff.

Under Section 14(a) the Appellate Tribunal established under the Telecom Act is required to adjudicate any dispute inter alia between the licencor and a licencee. The Plaintiff has made out a dispute as a licencee of the Defendant under the licence dated 22nd January, 1999. The Plaintiff's dispute is with regard to the preponement of monopolisation under the licence. The Plaintiff's dispute is also with regard to the extent and content of the package offered by the Government in consideration of such preponement which the Plaintiff claims is insufficient compensation for the loss suffered by the Plaintiff upon having acted pursuant to the promise by the Defendant. The case of the promissory estoppel made out by the Plaintiff is sought to be compensated by additional compensation claimed in addition to the package offered by the Government. It would have to be seen whether the Defendant was without its rights to have modified licence of the Plaintiff by preponement of its monopolisation under the package and whether such modification was in the interest of general public or for the proper conduct of telegraphs. The Court adjudicating upon such a dispute would require to bear in mind the worldwide technical advances in the field of telecommunications as well as the economic development of India in that regard to determine how much, if at all, the package to be given by the Government would be required to be enhanced or compensation of a particular extent be awarded to the Plaintiff.  [Para 18]

It may be mentioned that the arbitration clause in the terms and conditions of the licence agreement can also be invoked by the parties so as to have their dispute decided by a skilled adjudicator who would take into consideration the causes and effects of the policy of the Defendant resulting in preponement of the monopolisation of the Plaintiff. It may also be mentioned that the rejection of the package offered by the Defendant as insufficient compensation by the Plaintiff itself requires creation of further options in the interest of both the parties to mitigate the loss, if any, by the demonopolisation of the Plaintiff which can be achieved best by the mode of mediation. This itself shows and suggests that the dispute between the parties if adjudicated upon would require its adjudication by a specialised tribunal which will be better equipped to handle various aspects for considering the adequacy or otherwise of the additional compensation claimed by the Plaintiff. It is for such cases that the jurisdiction of the Civil Courts is expressly barred under Sections 15 and 27 of the Telecom Act. 2007 ALL SCR 2834 - Ref. to.  [Para 23]

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Appeal under
HeadNote.description:
Appeal under - Has to be confined to only substantial questions of law arising out of the order of the Tribunal.

(2003) 3 SCC 186 Rel. on. 	(Para 24)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Difference between TRAI and Central Govt. about term or condition of license granted under S.4(1)
HeadNote.description: Difference between TRAI and Central Govt. about term or condition of license granted under S.4(1) - Decision of Central Govt. will be final and binding. 	(Para 31)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Functions of TRAI under clause (a) are recommendatory while functions under clauses (b), (c) and (d) are not recommendatory
HeadNote.description: Functions of TRAI under clause (a) are recommendatory while functions under clauses (b), (c) and (d) are not recommendatory - Recommendations under Cl.(a) have to be given due weightage by Central Govt. though they are not binding on it. (Para 32)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Word 'any'
HeadNote.description:
Word 'any' - Cannot widen jurisdiction of Tribunal to decide a dispute between a licensor and a person who has not become a licensee. 

A dispute between a licensor and a licensee referred to in Section 14(a)(i) of the TRAI Act, is a dispute after a person has been granted a license by the Central Government or the Telegraph Authority under sub-section (1) of Section 4 of the Telegraph Act and has become a licensee and not a dispute before a person becomes a licensee under the proviso to sub-section (1) of Section 4 of the Telegraph Act. In other words, the Tribunal can adjudicate the dispute between a licensor and a licensee only after a person had entered into a license agreement and become a licensee and the word "any" in Section 14(a) of the TRAI Act cannot widen the jurisdiction of the Tribunal to decide a dispute between a licensor and a person who had not become a licensee.      [Para 33]

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Word 'Means'
HeadNote.description: Word 'Means' - Indicates that definitions of licensor and licensee are exhaustive and would not have any other meaning.        (Para 33)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: License agreement
HeadNote.description:
License agreement - Definition of Adjusted Gross Revenue - Having accepted license agreement licensee cannot approach Tribunal for alteration of definition of adjusted gross revenue incorporated in the license agreement.

The incorporation of the definition of Adjusted Gross Revenue in the license agreement was part of the terms regarding payment which had been decided upon by the Central Government as a consideration for parting with its rights of exclusive privilege in respect of telecommunication activities and having accepted the license and availed the exclusive privilege of the Central Government to carry on telecommunication activities, the licensees could not have approached the Tribunal for an alteration of the definition of Adjusted Gross Revenue in the license agreement.     [Para 34]

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Computation of Adjusted Gross Revenue
HeadNote.description: Computation of Adjusted Gross Revenue - Dispute about between licensor and licensee - Can be raised by licensee when a particular demand is raised on the licensee by the licensor. 	(Para 42)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Migration package
HeadNote.description: Migration package - Unconditional acceptance of by appellant - Appellant giving up all disputes relating to Licence Agreement for period upto 31-7-1999 - It was not open to it to turn around and agitate any dispute after availing of the package.	(Para 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Unit call rate
HeadNote.description: Unit call rate - Effect of any revision - Limiting of any such revision is confined to increase only - Not applicable in case of fluctuation resulting in decrease in rate.	(Para 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Migration package
HeadNote.description: Migration package - Levy of penal interest - Telecom Authority is not only entitled to recover out standing licence dues but also interest due on the same for the period of default.	(Para 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Telegraph Act (1885), S.4(1)
HeadNote.description: Telegraph Act (1885), S.4(1) - Relief to consumers for call drops - Validity of 2015 Regulations - Impugned Regulations making the telecom companies liable to credit the account of calling consumer with one Rupee for each call drop - Not referable to Section 11(1)(b)(i) and (v) of TRAI Act - It neither seeks to enforce terms and conditions of license u/S.4(1) of Telegraph Act nor does it lay down any standard of quality of service to be provided to consumers - Even though impugned Regulation framed in exercise of powers u/S.36 of TRAI Act, it does not carry out purpose of the Act - Rather, it seeks to protect interest of consumers at the cost of interest of service providers - Impugned Regulation held ultra vires the TRAI Act. 	(Paras 24, 38)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Transparency in procedure
Obligation of TRAI
HeadNote.description: Transparency in procedure - Obligation of TRAI - Before enacting Regulations of 2015 and making service providers liable for call drops, all stakeholders were consulted - However, it was not considered that call drops may also occur due to fault of consumers - Impugned Regulation lacks transparency. 	(Para 75)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Power to make regulations
HeadNote.description:
Power to make regulations - Nature of.

The power vested in the Authority under Section 36(1) of Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act to make regulations is wide and pervasive. The exercise of this power is only subject to the provisions of the Act and the Rules framed under Section 35 thereof. There is no other limitation on the exercise of power by the Authority under Section 36(1). It is not controlled or limited by Section 36(2) or Sections 11, 12 and 13.     [Para 45]

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Exclusive privilege of Central Government about telecommunication activities
HeadNote.description: Exclusive privilege of Central Government about telecommunication activities - Government, however, can part with this privilege by granting a license - Grant of license creates a contract between licensor and licensee - Provisions of TRAI Act do not alter the contractual nature of the license granted under S.4(1). (Paras 29, 30)

HeadNote.act_name: Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act (1997)
heading: Powers of Telecom Disputes Settlement Appellate Tribunal (TDSAT)
HeadNote.description:
Powers of Telecom Disputes Settlement Appellate Tribunal (TDSAT) - TDSAT cannot entertain challenge to regulations framed under S.36 - Aggrieved person can challenge regulations by filing appropriate petition before High Court.

In exercise of the power vested in Telecom Disputes Settlement Appellate Tribunal (TDSAT) under S.14 (b) of Telecom Regulatory Authority of India Act , TDSAT does not have the jurisdiction to entertain the challenge to the regulations framed by the Authority under S.36 of the Act, As a corollary, the contrary view taken by TDSAT and the Delhi High Court does not represent correct law. At the same time, the aggrieved person shall be free to challenge the validity of the regulations framed under Section 36 of the Act by filing appropriate petition before the High Court.         [Para 64,65]

By virtue of Section 37, the regulations made under the Act are placed on par with the rules which can be framed by the Central Government under Section 35 and being in the nature of subordinate legislations, the rules and regulations have to be laid before both the Houses of Parliament which can annul or modify the same. Thus, the regulations framed by the Authority can be made ineffective or modified by Parliament and by no other body.     [Para 44]

heading: Rejection of
HeadNote.description: Requisition for supply of energy - Rejection of - Ground of non-deposit of registration fee of Rs.50/- - Application submitted in December 2010 was returned in March 2011 for absence of signature of Village Administrative Officer - At that time it was not informed that registration fee of Rs.50/- was not deposited - Said defect informed only on resubmission of application after curing earlier defect - Authority failed to discharge its obligation to indicate defect and return same - Authority cannot take benefit of its inaction and reject application - Rejection of application, improper. 		(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Requisition for supply of energy
HeadNote.description: Requisition for supply of energy - Consideration as to date of submission of application - Application submitted in December 2010 was returned in March 2011 for absence of signature of Village Administrative Officer - Application was resubmitted after curing defect in March 2011 - Application would be considered from date of resubmission i.e. from March, 2011. 	(Paras 17, 18)

HeadNote.act_name: Tamil Nadu Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act (1960)
heading: Condonation of delay
Hence, delay condoned
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 604 days in filing appeal against decree of eviction - Decree passed on basis of compromise deed allegedly entered into between parties - Appellants tenants contending that compromise deed was signed by them under pressure exerted by Police - In cases where there is reasonable doubt that police may have forced a party to enter into compromise, process of court ought to weigh in favour of party alleging to be victim of such pressure - Hence, delay condoned - However, looking to fact that delay is of more than 600 days, appellants directed to pay cost of Rs.50,000/- to respondent.	(Paras 7, 15)

heading: Transplantation of human organs
HeadNote.description:
Transplantation of human organs - Registration of Hospitals is necessary - However, individual surgeons are not required to be authorized by appropriate authority.

 The provisions of Transplantation of Human Organs Act (1994) and Rules framed there under clearly highlight the importance of a properly equipped hospital for undertaking surgical operations for transplantation of human organs. An elaborate procedure is prescribed for registration of a hospital. Unless such registration for a hospital is secured a surgical operation of transplantation of human organs there is not permissible. The Act and the Rules however do not provide individual surgeons who would undertake the surgical operations, are required to be specifically authorized by the appropriate authority. The Rules of (1995) do not prohibit an expert who is member of a team of experts of a registered hospital, from performing transplantation operation in any other registered hospital. At the same time in view of the rules referred to above an expert who is not member of a team of any registered hospital, no matter, how much experience he has in this field, is not permitted to perform transplantation operation in any registered hospital.  [Para 7,10,11]

The position that emerges is that if an expert in this field as defined under rule 9-C is recognized as member of team of experts in a registered hospital, he would be able to perform surgical operations involving transplantation of kidney in any other registered hospital. The registered hospital has to ascertain as to whether such expert is a member of a team of experts in any other registered hospital. On ascertainment of this information, a registered hospital is able to permit such expert who is not member of their own team to perform transplantation operations in their hospital. The appropriate authority can not raise any objection to this practice.  [Para 11]

heading: Kidney transplant
HeadNote.description: Kidney transplant - Petitioner advised transplantation as early as possible - After prolonged waiting kidney donor found where kidney matched with petitioner - Test conducted and affidavit filed by donor - Clinic reluctant to forward proposal to Authorization Committee as donor was unrelated to patient - Court strongly disapproved callous disregard and directed it to forward proposal to Authorization Committee promptly. 			(Paras 11 to 13)

heading: Removal of organ for donation
HeadNote.description:
Removal of organ for donation - Prior approval of Authorisation Committee of State - Jurisdiction to entertain application - Application has to be made to Authorisation Committee of State to which the donor and donee belong and not to Authorisation Committee of State in which recipient intends to undergo treatment.

The object of the Statute is crystal clear that it intends to prevent commercial dealings in Human Organs. The Authorisation Committee is, therefore, required to satisfy that the real purpose of the donor authorizing removal of the organ is by reason of affection or attachment towards the recipient or for any other special reason. Such special reasons can by no stretch of imagination encompass commercial elements. Above being the intent, the inevitable conclusion is that the Authorisation Committees of the State to which the donor and the donee belong have to take the exercise to find out whether approval is to be accorded. Such Committee shall be in a better position to ascertain the true intent and the purpose for the authorisation to remove the organ and whether any commercial element is involved or not. They would be in a better position to lift the veil of projected affection or attachment and the so-called special reasons and focus on the true intent. The burden is on the applicants to establish the real intent by placing relevant materials for consideration of the Authorisation Committee. Whether there exists any affection or attachment or special reason is within the special knowledge of the applicants, and a heavy burden lies on them to establish it. Several relevant factors like relationship if any (need not be near relationship for which different considerations have been provided for), period of acquaintance, degree of association, reciprocity of feelings, gratitude and similar human factors and bounds can throw light on the issue. It is always open to the Authorisation Committee considering the application to seek information/materials from Authorisation Committees of other States/State Governments, as the case may be, for effective decision in the matter. In case any State is not covered by the operation of the Act or the Rules, the operative executive instructions/Government orders will hold the field. As the object is to find out the true intent behind the donor's willingness to donate the organ, it would not be in line with the legislative intent to require the Authorisation Committee of the State where the recipient is undergoing medical treatment to decide the issue whether approval is to be accorded. 	 [Para 12]

heading: Object of statute
HeadNote.description:
Donation of human organ - Object of statute - Is to rule out commercial dealings in human organs - Amendment of rules to provide for disclosure of incomes and vocations suggested.

Since the object of the Statute is to rule out commercial dealings, it would be desirable to require the donor and recipient to give details of their financial positions and vocations. It would be appropriate for the Legislature to accordingly amend the Rules and the Form I, so that requirement for disclosing incomes and vocations for some previous financial years (say 3 years) gets statutorily incorporated. This would help the Authorisation Committees to assess whether any commercial dealing is involved or not. Until legislative steps are taken, all Authorisation Committees shall, in terms of this judgment require the applicants to furnish their income particulars for the previous three financial years and the vocations.  [Para 14]

heading: Constitution of Authorisation Committee
HeadNote.description:
Constitution of Authorisation Committee - Presence of Administrative Official would be helpful in deciding issues effectively.

In certain States administrative officials are nominated as members of the Authorisation Committee. That appears to be the proper course as the Authorisation Committee has to decide both on the medical angle regarding need for transplantation, and the existence or otherwise of the essential ingredients to be established under sub-section (3) of Section 9 of the Act. Presence of an administrative official in the Authorisation Committee would be helpful in deciding the issues more effectively. [Para 15]

heading: It would be appropriate for States which have not yet adopted the Act, to do so immediately.	(Para 17)
HeadNote.description: It would be appropriate for States which have not yet adopted the Act, to do so immediately.	(Para 17)

heading: Government of a State
HeadNote.description:
Government of a State - Cannot be synonymous to the name of a place.

A person is prohibited from using in his trade activity any name or emblem specified in the schedule. Clause 4 of the schedule contemplates that name, emblem or official seal of the Government of India or of any State or any name which may suggest patronage of the Government of India or the State Government cannot be used by a person. Name of a place, thus, is not even mentioned in the schedule. It is the name, emblem or seal of Government of any State which cannot be used by any person in his trade activity. This is permissible, provided previous permission of the Government or such officers specified by the Government is taken by the person concerned. Court is also unable to understand the argument that the use of the word 'Goa' is capable of being understood as if the product was having the patronage of the State Government. The Government of a State cannot be synonymous to the name of a place. The contention is based upon misconception of law, and no principles of interpretation can be applied to substantiate this contention.  [Para 8,9]

heading: Premature release
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Penal Code (1860), Ss.302, 376 - Premature release - Order of High Court holding respondent-convict entitled for being considered by Advisory Board - Challenge - Respondent convicted u/S.302 and sentenced to R.I. for life and also u/S.376 and sentenced to R.I. for 7 yrs. - Sentence u/S.376 has been served out by respondent - High Court also considered opinion of Inspector General of Police based on G.O. (Ms) No.1762, dt.20th July, 1987 - That if a convicted prisoner undergoing imprisonment for life for offence u/S.302 is also convicted and sentenced to undergo minor imprisonment under ineligible sections of IPC (Ss.376, 396), and both the sentences were ordered to run concurrently and if convict had served out sentence under ineligible sections, said ineligible sections will not prevent premature release of the convict in respect of life sentence - Such convict would be entitled for consideration for premature release under Prison Rules in force - View expressed by Inspector General coupled with view adopted by High Court presents more reasonable understanding of the provisions - No interference in order of High Court to that extent. 	(Paras 4, 5, 10, 11)

heading: Premature release
HeadNote.description: Premature release - Scope of exercise of power by High Court - Apart from dealing with case of petitioner before it, cases of all life convicts who have completed 14 yrs. of custody, ordered to be reopened - High Court not justified in extending directions beyond parties before it - Therefore, Impugned order set aside to that extant. 	(Para 12)

heading: Premature release
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Penal Code (1860), Ss.302, 376 - Premature release - Order of High Court holding respondent-convict entitled for being considered by Advisory Board - Challenge - Respondent convicted u/S.302 and sentenced to R.I. for life and also u/S.376 and sentenced to R.I. for 7 yrs. - Sentence u/S.376 has been served out by respondent - High Court also considered opinion of Inspector General of Police based on G.O. (Ms) No.1762, dt.20th July, 1987 - That, if a convicted prisoner undergoing imprisonment for life for offence u/S.302 is also convicted and sentenced to undergo minor imprisonment under ineligible sections of IPC (Ss.376, 396), and both the sentences were ordered to run concurrently and if convict had served out sentence under ineligible sections, said ineligible sections will not prevent premature release of the convict in respect of life sentence - Such convict would be entitled for consideration for premature release under Prison Rules in force - View expressed by Inspector General coupled with view adopted by High Court presents more reasonable understanding of the provisions - No interference in order of High Court to that extent. 	(Paras 4, 5, 10, 11)

HeadNote.description: Premature release - Scope of exercise of power by High Court - Apart from dealing with case of petitioner before it, cases of all life convicts who have completed 14 yrs. of custody, ordered to be reopened - High Court not justified in extending directions beyond parties before it - Therefore, Impugned order set aside to that extant.
