If during the pendency of such application, the applicant's cause of complaint does not survive or his grievance does not subsist due to his own action or the applicant has waived his right or he has lost his interest for any other reason, there may not be any justification for rectification as the registered trade mark cannot be said to operate prejudicially to his interest.   [Para 33]

heading: Rectification of register
Discretionary jurisdiction
HeadNote.description:
Rectification of register - Jurisdiction of a Registrar - Discretionary jurisdiction - Construction of the provisions.

Sub-S.(1) of S.46 confers a discretionary jurisdiction on the Registrar. The jurisdiction may be exercised if any application is filed by a person aggrieved. Such application has to be filed in the manner prescribed therefor. Whence it is found that application is filed by a person aggrieved in prescribed manner, grounds which would be available to Registrar for exercise of its discretionary jurisdiction are stated in Cls.(a) and (b) of Sub-S.(1), S.46. Cls.(a) and (b) are disjunctive and not cumulative. Recourse may be taken to either of them or both of them. A combined application even under Ss.46 and 56 of the Act is permissible in law.  Whereas Cl.(a) refers to bona fide use of the trade mark; Cl.(b) stipulates the period upto a date of one month before the date of application, a continuous period of 5 years or longer elapsed during which the trade mark was registered and during which there was no bona fide use thereof in relation to those goods by any proprietor thereof for the time being. Sub-S.(3) postulates an exclusion clause as regards application of Cl.(b) of Sub-S.(1) of S.46 if any non-use of a trade mark which is shown to have been due to special circumstances in the trade or not to any intention to abandon or not to use the trade mark in relation to the goods to which the application relates. The purpose for which Cls.(a) and (b) of Sub-S.(1) of S.46 on the one hand and Sub-S.(3) thereof, vis-a-vis S.56 of the Act on the other have been enacted are different purposes. Cls.(a) and (b) operate in different fields. Sub-S.(3) covers a case falling within Cl.(b) and not the Cl.(a) thereof. Had the intention of the Parliament been that Sub-S.(3) covers cases falling both under Cl.(b) and Cl.(a), having regard to the similarity of the expressions used, there was no reason as to why it could not be stated so explicitly. Moreover, in cases of intermittent use, Cl.(b) shall not apply. Cl.(a) of Sub-S.(1) of S.46 takes within its sweep a situation where registration has been obtained without any bona fide intention on the part of the registrant that it should be used in relation to those goods by him and that there has, in fact, been no bona fide use. Cl.(a), therefore, provides for more than one contingency. Both the preconditions laid down therein are required to be fulfilled and not the contingency which is contemplated by Cl.(1). [Para 31,33,35,38,39]

heading: Trade and merchandise
Registration of mark
Rectification of register
Circumstances for non-use
HeadNote.description:
Trade and merchandise - Registration of mark - Rectification of register - Circumstances for non-use - Non-user for a temporary period may be due to any exigency including a bar under a statute, or a policy decision of Government or any action taken against the registrant.

There may be a case where owing to certain special circumstances, a continuous use is not possible. The trade mark for which registration is obtained is used intermittently. Such non-user for a temporary period may be due to any exigency including a bar under a statute, or a policy decision of the Government or any action taken against the registrant.						 [Para 37]

heading: Trade mark
Registration
Intention
HeadNote.description:
Trade mark - Registration - Intention - Intention to use trade mark must be genuine and real.

The intention to use a trade mark sought to be registered must be genuine and real. When a trade mark is registered, it confers a valuable right. It seeks to prevent trafficking in trade marks. It seeks to distinguish the goods made by one person from those made by another. The person, therefore, who does not have any bona fide intention to use the trade mark, is not expected to get his product registered so as to prevent any other person from using the same. In that way trafficking in trade mark is sought to be restricted.   [Para 41]

heading: Trade mark
Registration
'Person aggrieved'
Concept
HeadNote.description: Trade mark - Registration - 'Person aggrieved' - Concept - The concept of the term 'person aggrieved' is different in the context of Ss.46 and 56 - S.46 speaks of a private interest while S.56 speaks of a public interest.	(Para 42)

heading: Trade mark
Registration
Rectification
HeadNote.description:
Trade mark - Registration - Rectification - Appeal and cross objections, maintainability.

Cls.(a) and (b) of Sub-S.(1) of S.46 are in two different water tight compartments. It confers, therefore, two remedies. The ingredients to establish that a case has been made out for removal of the registration of the appellant from the register, thus, are on separate grounds. If the High Court has refused to consider one of the grounds, its right was affected to urge the applicability of Cl.(b) being separate and distinct from the grounds on which contention can be raised for applying the ingredients of Cl.(a) being wholly distinct and different, the principles of O.XLI, R.33 of Code, would not be applicable. The causes of action for invoking Cls.(a) and (b) are different. When a composite application is filed, only different causes of action are joined together. If one cause of action fails, the remedy by way of appeal thereagainst must be availed. The original application filed by respondent was maintainable on three counts: [1] Application of S.46, both under Cls.(a) and (b); [2] Application of S.56; and [3] the common law principle that he had been served with a legal notice by appellant desisting from using word TOSIBA. It is difficult to hold that only because respondent had not been able to prove one ground, viz. applicability of S.56, it loses its locus also. It would continue to be a person aggrieved even within purview of S.46 as it was slapped with a notice of action and it had a cause of action. It had a remedy. It invoked jurisdiction of Registrar on a large number of grounds. One of it was accepted, others were not. The petition, therefore, which was maintainable, did not cease to be so.   [Para 47,51]

heading: Trade mark
Registration
Rectification
Jurisdiction
Discretion
HeadNote.description:
Trade mark - Registration - Rectification - Jurisdiction - Discretion - Appellate jurisdiction-Powers.

Sub-S.(2) of S.109 provides for an appeal from any order or decision of the Registrar under the Act or Rules made thereunder. An appeal is to be heard by a Single Judge, a further appeal is provided before a Division Bench in terms of Sub-S.(5) of S.109 of the Act. Appellate jurisdiction of High Court is not restricted or limited. Sub-S.(6) of S.109 stipulates that High Court shall have the power to make any order which Registrar could make under the Act. In other words if Registrar exercises a discretionary jurisdiction, High Court while exercising its appellate jurisdiction would continue to do so. High Court having a plenary jurisdiction was not only entitled to take into consideration materials placed on record as also finding of Registrar, but it could also arrive at its own finding on basis of materials on record.  						      [Para 52]

heading: Trade mark
Registration
Rectification
Jurisdiction
Discretion
Balancing act
HeadNote.description:
Trade mark - Registration - User and non user - Rectification - Jurisdiction - Discretion - Exercise of discretionary powers - Balancing act - The balancing act between the user of registered trade mark and non-user should be such which leads to the possibility of neither of the parties being injured.

Trade mark in this case was registered in 1971. Appellant did not use it, no collaboration agreement with an Indian company nor did it grant any licence to any person to use the trade mark. In 1985 it had issued an advertisement before any controversy arose. It renewed the registration every seven years, validity extended upto 2016 A.D. It had been maintaining service centers in India in respect of washing machines though they weren't in a position to manufacture washing machines or spin dryers or market them because of ban imposed by Central Government. It had been rendering services to those who imported the machines. Though appellant had not been using its registered trade mark effectively, there was a finding by Registrar and High Court that it did not intend to abandon the said right, it intended to enforce its right as against respondent and suit was filed in 1990. There has been no injunction as against respondent. It was free to market its products in the name of TOSIBA. It had also, however, not been manufacturing washing machine and spin dryers. A finding of fact has been arrived at by Single Judge, which has not been overturned by Division Bench that respondent never had any intention to manufacture said goods. The balancing act between the user of registered trade mark and non-user should be such which leads to the possibility of neither of the parties being injured. Respondent in order to show how he is a person aggrieved has not shown how he in any possible way may be damaged or injured if the Appellant's Trade Mark is allowed to stand. This aspect of the matter was missed by the High Court. On this short ground impugned judgment cannot be sustained. Appeal allowed. High Court was requested to consider desirability of disposing of the Appellant's suit expeditiously.   [Para 53,59]

heading: Suit for infringement of copyright, jurisdiction of Court
HeadNote.description:
Suit for infringement of copyright, jurisdiction of Court - Suit for infringement of registered trade mark and for passing off trade mark similar or identical with or deceptively similar to that of holder of Registered trade mark, being based on different causes of action, Court can exercise jurisdiction only in the event it otherwise has jurisdiction in respect of cause of action wherefor the suit has been brought - Composite suit would not entitle a court to entertain a suit in respect whereof it has no jurisdiction, territorial or otherwise.

In this case civil suit in Delhi High Court filed by appellant seeking permanent injunction (i) against infringement of registered trade mark and (ii) against passing off trade mark similar or identical with or deceptively similar to their mark, was dismissed as the defendant was resident of Andhra Pradesh and that Delhi Court had no jurisdiction in passing orders regarding passing off trade mark. Order upheld in appeal. Supreme Court in further appeal held that provisions of O.2, Rr.2 and 3 of the Civil Procedure Code, 1908 (CPC) deals with pecuniary jurisdiction, which, however, can be used only in the event the court has otherwise jurisdiction in respect of the cause of action wherefor the action has been brought. Delhi Court has jurisdiction to adjudicate and decide upon relief of infringement of copyright, but not in respect of its action for passing off and confirmed the order directing return of plant for filing in the proper court. It further held under CPC claims arising under a statutes governing substantive or procedural law, a number of remedies can be combined. The Court may grant an order of injunction even in passing off action. Where the court has jurisdiction or power to adjudicate, it will necessarily have incidental power therefor. It may, however, be different if the court may have exercised a power which is not provided for as a supplemental proceeding. Thus, whereas incidental power is inherent in the court, a supplemental power may also be exercised, keeping in view the ultimate relief which may be granted by it. Incidental provisions inserted in S.62(2) of the 1957 Act to remove impediment, the court could be entitled to pass an interim order, but the same can not be extended to a cause of action which is founded on a separate set of facts as also rights and liabilities of a party under a different Act. Appeal dismissed with costs.  AIR 2004 SC 1682 - Dist. Copyright Act (1957), S.62.		        [Para 5,6,16,18,26,28,29,30]

heading: Term 'trade mark'
Includes 'business name'
HeadNote.description:
Term 'trade mark' - Includes 'business name' - Act covers all passing of actions whether based on trade marks or trade names - Nexus between mark and the person claiming the right to use it must be established.
1987 (1) Bom C.R.34 Relied on. (Para 9)

heading: Passing off action
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade mark - Passing off action - Petitioners and defendants doing business in sale of bed sheets, mattresses etc. - Both parties having same surname 'Saboo' - Plaintiff running business in name of 'Saboo Textiles', "Saboo Decopride" and "Saboo Sons" - Defendants also doing business in similar goods under name of 'Saboo Fab', 'Saboo Furnishing, 'Saboo Collections' etc. - Held, that the defendants were not using word 'Saboo' as a trading style but using it as trade sign and such user was not permissible - Plaintiffs are entitled to temporary injunction.

The law relating to passing off is fairly well-settled.  The principle underlying the action is that no one is entitled to carry on his business in such a way as to lead to the belief that he is carrying on the business of another man or lead to belief that he is carrying on or had any connection with the business carried on by another man.		 [Para 10]

In the instant case, from the documents on record such as letters, bills, receipts, invoice forms, octroi receipts, cash-memos, etc., prima facie, it appears that the appellants' trade names, i.e. 'Saboo Sons' and 'Saboo Decopride (P) Ltd.' were widely advertised and gained wide reputation and user of similar or identical trade names, i.e. 'Saboo Collections' by the defendants respondents caused deception and created confusion in the minds of the customers as well as other dealers.  It could not be contended that the surname of respondents being 'Saboo', the respondents are entitled to adopt and use it because in the case in hand from the documents on record prima facie it appears that the respondents are not using the word "Saboo' as a trading style but are using it as a trade sign and such user is not permissible.				 [Para 13,14]

heading: Appeal against conviction
HeadNote.description: Murder and causing fire by mischief - Appeal against conviction - FIR lodged alleging that there was a gruesome carnage in which 35 persons belonging to Bhumihar Community were killed and 7 persons were injured - Name of appellant accused not mentioned in FIR - Injured witness though stating that he had seen accused persons slitting throats but failed to identify appellant in court - No specific role attributed to appellant by any of witnesses - Appellant deserves acquittal. 	(Para 29)

heading: Infringement of trade-mark
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade-mark - Suit for permanent injunction and damages - Can be maintained by unregistered firm.

An unregistered partnership firm can maintain a suit for permanent injunction and damages and seek relief against infringement of a registered trade-mark and for passing off and section 69(2) of the Partnership Act, 1932 does not bar such a suit. (2003)3 SCC 250 - Rel. on.  [Para 18]

heading: Suit for declaration
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration - To extent that plaintiff’s trademark “ISKCON” is well-known trade mark - Term “ISKCON” did not exists prior to plaintiff’s adoption and use of same - Since it is coined trade mark which is associated exclusively with plaintiff, it undoubtedly deserves highest degree of protection - Material on record shows that plaintiff’s trademark “ISKCON” has wide acceptability - Popularity of it extends not only in India but in other countries as well - Plaintiff is using its trade mark “ISKCON” openly, widely and continuously since beginning - Plaintiff has taken several actions and succeed against various infringers in past - Thus, plaintiff’s trade mark ISKCON satisfies requirements and tests of ‘well-known trade mark’ as contained in S.11(6), 11(7) - Suit decreed accordingly. (Paras 8, 9)

headline: Trademark having wide acceptability, popularity of it extends not only in India but in other countries also and party using it openly, widely and continuously since beginning, satisfies tests of ‘well-known trade mark’.

heading: Bar under S.45 of Trade Marks Act
HeadNote.description: Bar under S.45 of Trade Marks Act - S.213 of Succession Act bars establishment of a right as an executor or legatee in absence of a probate of Will under which right is claimed - S.45 of Trade Marks Act does not contain a bar to the establishment of a right as a registered proprietor - Held, it merely bars the receipt of the document in evidence which may indeed have its own consequences. (Para 21)

heading: Additional documents
Permission to file
HeadNote.description: Additional documents - Permission to file - Petitioner objected registration of trade-mark of respondent - Petitioner only referred all their registered trade-marks as Registrar maintains record of documents - Petitioner sought permission to file these documents of registered trade-mark in appeal - Permission rejected as that petitioner wants to bring on record new case by filing additional documents for 1st time in Appeal - Rejection to file additional documents is liable to be set aside. (1954)1 WLR 1489 and (1996) RPC 233 - Ref. to.			 (Paras 10, 11)

heading: Res judicata
HeadNote.description: Banking Regulation Act (1949), Ss.6(1), 6(2), 8, 46(2) - Res judicata - Subsequent suit of 2008 raises issue different from that contained in earlier suit filed by same party in 2004 - Earlier decision declared valid, a transaction, assignment which is prohibited by law - Said deed of assignment of trade mark in order to repay dues of bank, clearly hit by S.6(2) and 8 r.w. S.46(2) of Banking Regulation Act (1949) - Cannot be sanctified by plea of res judicata when reliance on said assignment deed is prohibited by law.			(Paras 38, 39, 40, 41)

heading: Infringement of trade mark and copyright
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark and copyright - Trade-mark "Glucon-D" and its distinctive packaging used by Glaxo since 1940 - Word "Glucose-D" had been in use since 1989 only - Both contain glucose and there is remarkable phonetic similarity in the two words - Packaging can easily confuse a buyer - Small changes made time and again only to mislead purchaser and make it more and more difficult for appellants to protect their mark - Respondents restrained from using their mark pending suit.	(Paras 11, 13)

heading: Amendment of plaint
HeadNote.description:
Amendment of plaint - Suit for infringement of trademark - Suit was filed 5 years after cease and desist notice - It does not in any manner make suit lacking bona fides - Nothing indicates that plaintiff was aware of defendant's mark being registered - There was no suppression of fact - If defendant disputes contents of amendment, it is open to do so after amendment is allowed - Adjudication of, on merits of proposed amendment cannot be asked for - Chamber summons for amendment allowed.

1976 (4) SCC 320, 1998 (1) SCC 9, 2005(3) ALL MR 481, 2006(5) ALL MR 185 (S.C.), 2006(5) ALL MR 107 (S.C.) Disting. 			 [Para 10]

heading: Temporary injunction
Application for
HeadNote.description: Temporary injunction - Application for - Suit against infringement of trade mark - Defendants infringed trade mark of plaintiff which is prior in use by plaintiff - Defendants have not bothered to take search in office of Registrar of trade marks before using trade mark - If defendants adopted an identical mark and in any case deceptively similar to plaintiff's mark, defendants did so at its own risk and cannot claim any equity on basis of such user - Plaintiff had made out prima facie case for grant of temporary injunction - Balance of convenience also lies in favour of plaintiffs - Temporary injunction entitled to be granted. (Paras 20, 21)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description:
Rejection of plaint - Infringement of trade mark - Plaintiff is registered proprietor of mark - There is no statement in plaint on basis of which it can be held that suit is barred by law - Plaint itself does not refer to defendant's label mark being registered - Hence even assuming that suit is barred in view of S.29, suit is liable to be maintained - Plaint not liable to be rejected under O.7 R.11.

2004(5) ALL MR 360 (S.C.) Rel. on.  (Para 12)

heading: Inherent jurisdiction
Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Inherent jurisdiction - Rejection of plaint - Maintainability of action of infringement as defendant's mark is registered - Defendant's label mark is registered would not affect plaintiff's action for infringement on basis of its registered mark - Powers under S.151 not liable to be exercised by rejecting plaint - Suit is maintainable.  (Para 16)

heading: Suit for infringement of Trade Mark
HeadNote.description:
Suit for infringement of Trade Mark - Trial judge has to exercise sound judicial discretion in the matter of grant or refusal of interim relief of injunction.

In a suit for infringement of Trade Mark, the Trial Judge has to exercise sound judicial discretion in the matter of grant or refusal of interim relief of injunction. It is well known that due to huge pendency of cases in High Court on its original side, suit reaches for hearing after a long time. Even if interim injunction is not granted, there is an option for the trial Court to award monetary compensation to the plaintiffs who may be successful at the end of trial. But interim injunction when granted may have devastating effect on the business of the defendants as the defendants may be deprived of an opportunity to carry on their business in competition which is otherwise lawful. Interim injunction, if wrongly granted in favour of the plaintiffs, may destroy the business of the defendants irreparably, resulting in to uncompensatable disadvantage for the defendants.  [Para 17]

heading: Res-judicata
HeadNote.description: Res-judicata - Case of infringement of trade mark and passing off - Dismissal of suit filed in Court at Bombay, sought on count that Court at Indore passed decree against plaintiffs in suit filed by defendant in respect of same cause of action - Plea of plaintiffs that defendant had obtained decree in previous suit by playing fraud or forgery - For deciding that, factual inquiry as to what was material which formed part of plea before Indore Court, was available with plaintiffs, when material came to knowledge of plaintiff on which plea of fraud is made and how is new material qualitatively different from material available in prior suit so as to warrant new plea of fraud or forgery, requires to be done - Thus, issue of res-judicata is not pure question of law which can be framed as preliminary issue under O.14 R.2 - Suit cannot be dismissed. AIR 1972 Bom 228, (2004) 1 SCC 551, AIR 1991 ALL 89 (FB) Rel. on. 			(Paras 8, 16, 17)

heading: Passing off
Injunction
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), O.39 Rr.1, 2 - Infringement of copy right - Passing off - Injunction - Plaintiff, manufacturer of cigarettes since long - Adopted designed (2012) and redesigned (2016) artistic work including boomerang device for its FLAKE REFINED TASTE cigarette pack - Defendant in departure of its earlier mark, adopted mark for its impugned cigarette pack for SELECT FLAKE PREMIUM, launched in 2019 in same market, where plaintiff cigarette pack is immensely popular - From boomerang device and color scheme adopted by defendant, it appears to be substantial replication/copy of plaintiffs FLAKE REFINED TASTE pack - Adoption of stylized 'S' to denote SELECT clearly substantial copy of boomerang device of plaintiff - Even crest device of plaintiff and defendant appear to be almost identical - Thus, there is overall similarity in cigarette packs of plaintiff and defendant - Held, plaintiffs made out prima facie case for injunction for restraining defendant from infringing its copy right - And also for injunction against passing off the products of defendant as that of plaintiff - Further, balance of convenience also lies in favour of plaintiff and grave prejudice would be caused to it if said interim relief not granted. 	(Paras 31, 32, 33, 35)

heading: Infringement of copyrights and passing off trade mark
Civil P.C. (1908), S.20
HeadNote.description:
Civil P.C. (1908), S.20 - Interpretation of S.62 and 134(2) - Purposive interpretation has to be adopted - Rule of convenience of the parties is behind provisions of S.62, 134(2) and S.20 of CPC - Intention is that plaintiff should not go to far flung places in order to deprive defendant of a remedy and harass him by dragging to distant place - Sections must be interpreted to avoid mischief.

The provisions of section 62 of the Copyright Act and section 134 of the Trade Marks Act have to be interpreted in the purposive manner. No doubt about it that a suit can be filed by the plaintiff at a place where he is residing or carrying on business or personally works for gain. He need not travel to file a suit to a place where defendant is residing or cause of action wholly or in part arises. However, if the plaintiff is residing or carrying on business etc. at a place where cause of action, wholly or in part, has also arisen, he has to file a suit at that place.  [Para 47]

Considering the very language of section 62 of the Copyright Act and section 134 of the Trade Marks Act, an additional forum has been provided by including a District Court within whose limits the plaintiff actually and voluntarily resides or carries on business or personally works for gain. The object of the provisions was to enable the plaintiff to institute a suit at a place where he or they resided or carried on business, not to enable them to drag defendant further away from such a place also as is being done in the instant cases. The expression "notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Civil Procedure" does not oust the applicability of the provisions of section 20 of the Code of Civil Procedure and it is clear that additional remedy has been provided to the plaintiff so as to file a suit where he is residing or carrying on business etc., as the case may be. Section 20 enables a plaintiff to file a suit where the defendant resides or where cause of action arose. Section 20(a) and section 20(b) usually provides the venue where the defendant or any of them resides, carries on business or personally works for gain. Section 20(c) of the Code of Civil Procedure enables a plaintiff to institute a suit where the cause of action wholly or in part, arises. The Explanation to Section 20 C.P.C. has been added to the effect that Corporation shall be deemed to carry on business at its sole or principal office in India or in respect of any cause of action arising at any place where it has subordinate office at such place. Thus, 'corporation' can be sued at a place having its sole or principal office and where cause of action wholly or in part, arises at a place where it has also a subordinate office at such place.	 [Para 12]

If the interpretation suggested by the appellant is accepted, several mischiefs may result, intention is that the plaintiff should not go to far flung places than that of residence or where he carries on business or works for gain in order to deprive defendant a remedy and harass him by dragging to distant place. It is settled proposition of law that the interpretation of the provisions has to be such which prevents mischief. According to the mischief rule, four points are required to be taken into consideration. While interpreting a statute, the problem or mischief that the statute was designed to remedy should first be identified and then a construction that suppresses the problem and advances the remedy should be adopted.  [Para 22]

In the instant cases, the principal place of business is, admittedly, in Mumbai and the cause of action has also arisen in Mumbai. Thus, the provisions of section 62 of the Copyright Act and section 134 of the Trade Marks Act cannot be interpreted in a manner so as to confer jurisdiction on the Delhi court in the aforesaid circumstances to entertain such suits. The Delhi court would have no territorial jurisdiction to entertain it.	    [Para 23]

heading: Copyright and trade-mark
Infringement of
HeadNote.description: Copyright and trade-mark - Infringement of - Appellant found using respondent's word mark on their goods - Ratio in judgment (1901)3 Bom.L.R. 220 cited by appellant denies person relief in respect of mark or artistic work which are copies of another - Ratio in said judgment not only applies to infringement of copyrights but also to infringement of trade-mark and passing off. (1901)3 Bom.L.R. 220 - Ref. to. 7 Ch.Ap. 628, 11 ER 1435 : (1865)XI HLC 521, 4 De. G.J. & S. 136 - Rel. on.	(Para 7)

heading: Copyright and trade-mark
Infringement of
HeadNote.description: Copyright and trade-mark - Infringement of - Appellant found using respondent's word mark on their goods - Relief is denied to person in respect of mark or artistic work which are copies of another - Contention that respondents themselves are not owners of mark - Proprietor of trade-mark has not initiated any action and hence appellants cannot do so in their behalf - Contention is liable to be rejected. (1901)3 Bom.L.R. 220 - Rel. on.	(Paras 7, 11, 12)

heading: Copyright and trade-mark
Infringement of
HeadNote.description: Copyright and trade-mark - Infringement of - Appellant found using respondent's word mark on their goods - No evidence produced that third party has created and used mark prior to respondents - Conclusion cannot be reached that respondents themselves have infringed trade-mark belonging to another - Contention in this regard is liable to be rejected.	(Para 15)

heading: Copyright and trade-mark
Infringement of
HeadNote.description: Copyright and trade-mark - Infringement of - Appellant found using respondent's word mark for their playing cards - Contention that respondents themselves have infringed trade-mark belonging to renowned cigarettes - Cigarettes and playing cards may sufficiently cause deception by application of deceptively similar marks on products - This is mixed question of law and fact - Appellants have not produced any evidence and pleadings are insufficient to hold that goods cause deception - No infringement of trade-mark of another by respondent's is established.	(Para 16)

heading: Copyright and trade-mark
Infringement of
HeadNote.description: Copyright and trade-mark - Infringement of - Appellant found using respondent's word mark for their playing cards - Freelance artist has designed labels and respondents have paid him for that - Respondent's have certificate from artist in regard to his work done - Even if it is contract for service said artist has assigned his rights to respondents - Contention that respondents are not owners of mark is liable to be rejected.			(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Principle of issue estoppel
HeadNote.description: Principle of issue estoppel - If the question of passing off is raised in opposition proceedings and is decided by the Registrar and the decision has attained finality, it may be open to the registered proprietor to raise the question of issue estoppel in other proceedings between the same parties invoking the principle of issue estoppel - Such a defence would be restricted to the very issue that is decided - Held, there is no principle of constructive issue estoppel.	(Para 22)

heading: Quashing of FIR
HeadNote.description: Quashing of FIR - Offence of falsely applying trade mark - Accused alleged to have falsely applied trade mark of Sakal group in two articles authored by him and published on news portal Newslaundry - Articles authored by accused and published in news portal Newslaundry neither qualify as goods nor as service as defined u/Ss.2(j) and 2(z) of Act of Trade Marks Act - There was no suggestion that said news portal was that of complainant-Sakal - Merely because online search for word Sakal led to articles of accused published on news portal Newslaundry, does not mean that registered trade mark of Sakal Media Group was falsely applied to goods or services by accused - At the most it can be subject matter of injunction suit which is civil dispute and which suit is already filed by complainant and is pending - Ingredients of offence u/S.103 not made out - FIR liable to be quashed. (Paras 16, 17, 18, 20, 21)

heading: Issuance of process
HeadNote.description: Penal Code (1860), Ss.419, 420 - Issuance of process - Complaint against applicant u/Ss.419, 420 r/w. S.34 IPC and S.104 r/w S.114 of Trade Marks Act, 1999 - Allegation that accused used domain names deceptively similar to its domain name and thereby caused huge loss and made wrongful gain - Dishonest intention of accused to deceive prospective user of domain name and that act of accused was in violation of Trade Marks Act 1999 was also alleged - By cheating various internet users by impersonating domain name, accused allegedly committed offence u/ S.419 IPC - Thus, material placed on record prima facie attract offences alleged - Plea that complaint is trade rivalry, can be looked into by Trial Court - Thus, order issuing summons by Magistrate to accused, not liable to be interfered with. 	(Paras 16, 17, 19)

heading: Pharmaceutical product
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade mark - Pharmaceutical product - When a trade mark is found from the common generic name, no single proprietor can claim absolute monopoly in such name or trade mark.

When two trade marks are coined from the same generic drug or ingredient, there are bound to be similarities between the two and in such a case, even if the differences between the two trade marks are minor or small, then also at least at the prima facie stage no injunction can be granted.  In such a case, the first user cannot claim exclusivity in his trade mark or in the name which is derived from the generic drug. At the most such proprietor can claim exclusivity in those added features which differentiates his trade mark from the name of the generic drug or ingredient.	  [Para 11]

Held that the trade mark of the Respondents NETMICIN is admittedly registered, and therefore, the Respondents have statutory right to use that trade mark. The Appellants have adopted their trade mark NETROMYCIN from the generic drug name Netilmicin.  It has come on record that the other manufacturers and traders of medicinal goods have also adopted trade marks with prefix NET to indicate the drug name  Netilmicin Sulfate and the suffix MICIN/MYCIN is common to pharmaceutical trade. Both the trade marks are used in respect of Netilmicin Sulfate and both the trade marks owe their origin to the said medicine name. Since there is commonality in origin, ingredient, composition and purpose, even if one drug is consumed for the other, there cannot be disastrous consequences. Also, it is to be noted that the Respondents goods are purchased in bulk by the hospitals and not by the common consumers, they are not sold over the counter. Whereas the Appellants goods are sold over the counter to the consumers. The manner in which the drug is administered and that the product of the Respondents is used only in the hospitals by the Doctors after carrying out sensitivity culture test, is enough to rule out any possibility of any confusion as the chemical used in both the products is same. Even if by mistake one is used for the other, no injury is likely to be suffered by the consumer or patient. Therefore, this circumstance coupled with the circumstance that both the trade marks are registered and that from the year 2003 the Respondents have been using its trade mark uninterruptedly dis-entitles the Plaintiffs-Appellants to interim injunction restraining defendants respondents from using is trade mark. 		 [Para 11,12]

So far as the complaint in relation to the product insert is concerned, admittedly, the Respondents have changed the contents of the product insert. 			 [Para 13]

heading: Trade mark
Deceptively similar
HeadNote.description: Trade mark - Deceptively similar - Terms VIVA and VIVACITY - The term VIVA can neither be treated as descriptive nor it is generic - The two terms VIVA and VIVACITY are so close to each other that the term VIVACITY can be treated as deceptively similar as that of VIVA. 	(Para 20)

heading: Infringement of Trade Mark
HeadNote.description: Infringement of Trade Mark - Knowledge of plaintiff about products of defendants - Advertisement of products by defendants, held, cannot be used to impute knowledge to the plaintiffs about the product of the Defendants on the day when the advertisement was published. 	(Para 22)

heading: Infringement of Trade Mark
HeadNote.description: Infringement of Trade Mark - Once the Court comes to the conclusion that the trade mark used by defendants is deceptively similar as that of the plaintiffs, the prima facie case for infringement of the trade mark is made out by the plaintiffs - Similarly, prima-facie case for passing off of the plaintiffs mark is made out - Merely because in a particular year the plaintiffs have not been able to sell their goods would not take away the protection. 1990 (Supp) SCC 727 - Ref. to. (Para 24)

heading: Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Application for stay of proceedings filed under S.124 - Maintainability - Suit in question primarily based on passing off action filed under S.134(1)(c) and not for infringement of Trade Mark - Therefore S.124 which is applicable only in a suit filed for infringement of trademark was not attracted - Order granting stay would be without jurisdiction and liable to be set aside.		(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Word "2win"
HeadNote.description:
Registration and ad-interim relief - Word "2win" - Cannot be said to be a distinctive trade mark or domain name of plaintiff - Defendant using the said word bona fide - Merely because plaintiff has been using the trade mark in earlier point of time "in India", cannot be the sole basis to grant ad-interim relief as prayed - Only a person having proprietary right can apply for registration - However, in fact, whether such person has a proprietary right as claimed will be adjudicated in those proceedings.

Only a person having proprietary right can apply for registration. There can be no dispute with the proposition that only a person having proprietary right can apply for registration. However, in fact, whether such person has a proprietary right as claimed will be adjudicated in those proceedings. Merely because the plaintiff has applied for registration of word "2win", that by itself does not lead to conclusion that the plaintiff has proprietary right in that word.  [Para 12]

Merely because the plaintiff has been using the trade mark in earlier point of time "in India" cannot be the sole basis to grant ad-interim relief as is prayed. On the other hand, prima facie, Court finds substance in the assertion of the defendant that the plaintiff intentionally did not disclose the relevant dates on which the registration applications were procured and submitted by it in relation to its products covered by items specified at sr. nos.28 and 38. The said registration applications have been submitted only after the defendant had launched its programme "Bid2Win" in India on 7.5.2006. Moreover, in the present case, the word "2win" cannot be said to be a distinctive trade mark or domain name of the plaintiff coupled with the fact that the defendant is using the said word bona fide and that it is in common use world-wide, the question of granting any ad-interim relief does not arise. Accordingly, the prayer for grant of ad-interim relief will have to be rejected and is, accordingly, rejected. 1990 RPC 341 and 2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 817 - Ref. to.			 [Para 14,16]

heading: Suit for injunction restraining passing off the goods under any mark deceptively similar to plaintiffs' Trade Mark "Manikchand"
HeadNote.description:
Suit for injunction restraining passing off the goods under any mark deceptively similar to plaintiffs' Trade Mark "Manikchand" - Plaintiff admitting that he was user of trade mark "Manikchand" in respect of tobacco product only from 1961 - Defendant claimed user of trade mark "Manikchand" from 1959 - By amendment plaintiff wanted to alter case of user of trade mark from 1961 to 1958 - Amendment of plaint rejected as it sought to defeat vested right of defendant.

The plaintiffs have by making averments in the plaint as made in paragraphs 5, 6 and 22 of the plaint has admitted that the user of the trade mark "Manikchand" in respect of the tobacco product was only from 1961. Once the said averment is made, it is not open for the plaintiff to go back on the said averment and thereafter now contend that it is not from 1961 but much prior thereto. This is significant because the proposed defendant No.2 in a suit filed in District Court, Mandaleshwar, in State of Madhya Pradesh has specifically made a plea that the user by them is from 1959 i.e. prior in point of time than the user by the plaintiff herein. In light of the averments made by the proposed defendant No.2, the plaintiffs in the present case are seeking to amend the suit by going further back in time to 1958. Such an amendment cannot be granted in favour of the plaintiffs in view of the admission on the part of the plaintiffs that they are using the mark from 1961. The statement made in the plaint on oath is the statement on solemn affirmation and it is treated as a statement of fact which is an admission of the particular set of facts by the plaintiff in the plaint and it is this case which is required to be proved by the plaintiff at the trial of the suit and the defendants are required to meet. Once substitution of the paragraph which contains admission that the user of the mark was from 1961 is permitted then obviously the plaintiff will be entitled to go back to 1958 and defeat the right which is created in favour of the proposed defendant No.2 to contend that they are prior user of the mark in point of time. Hence, the plaintiff cannot be permitted to amend the chamber summons as set out in the schedule thereto insofar as paragraphs 5 and 6 thereof are concerned.  [Para 20]

heading: Infringement and passing off Trademark
HeadNote.description: Infringement and passing off Trademark - Plaintiff registered proprietor of mark "Café Madras" since 2005 in classes 16 and 42 - Plaintiff using this mark continuously, openly, extensively since 1951 - Defendant using this mark "Café Madras", on a device of a banana leaf - Plaintiff sending cease and desist notice to defendant - Defendant thereafter applying for registration of mark "Café Madras" - Held, mark as whole has to be looked into - Defendant's mark is deceptively similar to plaintiff's mark - Confusion, deception are inevitable - Plaintiff having considerable good will and high reputation - Rat found in food served by defendant's establishment - Incident widely reported in several leading news papers - Clippings referring to offending establishment only as "Café Madras" - Notoriety and disrepute directly affecting plaintiff - Defendant restrained from using trade mark "Café Madras". 			(Paras 27, 29, 30, 32, 45, 46, 49, 54, 57)

heading: Use of word "RAMAYAN" as a trade mark for sale of incense sticks
HeadNote.description:
Use of word "RAMAYAN" as a trade mark for sale of incense sticks - Held, appellant cannot claim use of word "RAMAYAN" as a trade mark for his goods - Moreover, respondent was found to be using artistic mark prior in point of time to that of appellant.

There are many holy and religious books like Quran, Bible, Guru Granth Sahib, Ramayan etc., to name a few. The answer to the question as to whether any person can claim the name of a holy or religious book as a trade mark for his goods or services marketed by him is clearly 'NO'.

Moreover, the appellant has not been able to establish that the word "RAMAYAN" for which he has applied the trade mark had acquired a reputation of user in the market inasmuch as, there are more than 20 traders in the city using the word "RAMAYAN" as a mark for the similar products and also in different parts of the country. moreover respondent was using the artistic mark (BADSHAH RAMAYAN) earlier in point of time to that of appellant herein. [Para 18,19,21]

heading: Temporary injunction
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark and passing off action - Temporary injunction - Grant of - Allowing defendants to use of word 'MALABAR' with mark 'BAROMA' for selling biryani rice with different get-up - Plaintiff using mark 'MALABAR' for selling biryani rice from 2001 claiming exclusive right over it - Plaintiff alleging that mark 'MALABAR GOLD' used by defendants for selling biryani rice is deceptively similar to mark 'MALABAR' - Plaintiff is registered owner of label mark in Class-30 - However, disclaimer in said registration shows that plaintiff has no right over exclusive use of word 'MALABAR' - Plaintiff cannot claim exclusive right over use of word 'MALABAR' - Also there is no deceptive similarity in labels of parties - Grant of injunction, proper. 	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Interim relief
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), O.39 R.1 - Infringement of trade mark and passing off - Interim relief - Appellant using registered trade mark "DEXORANGE" in respect of medical and pharmaceutical preparations - Respondents also using similar and identical trade mark "HEPPORANGE" - Both are using word "orange" because their products have orange flavour - Respondents agreed to use their mark as "HEPP-ORANGE" and not "HEPPORANGE" in suit filed in 2005 - In 2006, Single Judge declined injunction to appellant on count that respondents had taken enough steps to avoid possibility of confusion in mind of purchaser, thereby permitting them to use trademark "HEPPORANGE" - Thereafter, appellant had not agitated issue of injunction any further for more than 11 years - Respondents have been using same uninterruptedly till this date - No case made out for granting interim relief. 	(Paras 11, 12, 13, 14)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Grant of temporary injunction - Plaintiff manufacturing chemical substance Sodium Hypochlorite Solution claimed infringement of his trade mark by defendants - Plaintiff using trade mark 'JEEVANDROP' whereas defendants using trade mark 'JALDROP' for similar product - Plaintiff and defendants have not invented chemical substance which can be used as 'water disinfectant' - Colour of bottles and design on label of bottles of plaintiff and defendants are different - Names of manufacturers are also different - ISO certificate number is written on bottles of defendant whereas no such certificate obtained by plaintiff - Appearance of bottle of defendants is different from plaintiff - Goods of defendants can be distinguished from that of plaintiff - No strong prima facie case made out by plaintiff for grant of temporary injunction - Grant of temporary injunction, improper. 	(Paras 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31)

heading: Rectification proceedings
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Rectification proceedings - Expunction of trade mark of petitioner from register - Challenge - Plea of "honest and concurrent use" taken by petitioner - Petitioner therefore bound to provide satisfactory evidence in that regard - Petitioner company claims to be in use of trade mark "Creative" from the year 1979, however, material produced by it pertain to year 1998 and onwards - In fact, there is a letter on record, sent by Registrar to petitioner, advising it to choose some other mark as "Creative" is already in use of another company - Plea of "honest and concurrent use" not established - Figures shown and success acquired by petitioner is not enough to establish said plea - Respondent company was established in year 1977 with trade mark "Creative" registered under erstwhile Act of 1958 - Order of expunction, justified - However, imposition of costs of Rs.10,000/- not justified.  	(Paras 37, 38, 39, 40, 42, 43, 44, 45)

heading: Letters Patent, Cl.14
HeadNote.description: Letters Patent, Cl.14 - Infringement of trade mark and passing off - Leave petition for clubbing both causes of action before one Court - Plaintiff has its registered office and its trade mark is also registered within jurisdiction of Court at Mumbai - Defendant has its office and business in Andhra Pradesh - As a result, cause of action for passing off falls outside jurisdiction of Court at Mumbai - Plaintiff's suit for infringement of trade mark does not appear to be malafide or abuse of law and Court - Defendants have also not filed any affidavit showing cause as to why leave is not to be granted - Therefore, question of dragging defendants to Court at Mumbai does not arise - If leave is granted, it will also be convenient to defendants - Otherwise, defendants will have to defend action for infringement of trade mark in Court at Mumbai and for passing off in Courts of Andhra Pradesh - Leave is granted. (2001) 5 SCC 73, 2016(7) ALL MR 390, 2013(4) ALL MR 47 Ref. to. 			(Paras 10, 13, 14, 15)

heading: Trade mark "Parle"
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade mark - Trade mark "Parle" - Plaintiff not having a registered trade mark "parle confi" - Hence, held, the use of that mark by the Defendant cannot per se be forbidden.

The Plaintiff does not have a registered trademark "Parle Confi". Hence the use of that mark by the Defendant cannot per se be forbidden. It will have to be seen whether the use of the word "Parle Confi" (which includes the word Parle for confectionery items) would amount to any misrepresentation by the Defendant. Misrepresentation, if any, would result if the undiscerning public who would buy the Defendant's toffees, at best, think that it is of the Parle Group of Companies who manufacture confectioneries such as toffees, but under a different product name. The Plaintiff's sale of the confectioneries, even of toffees, would not be affected adversely by virtue of the Defendant selling its toffees under two other names.

If a third party were to manufacture toffees and include on its label the word "Parle" in any font he would, at once, be restrained by the Court from doing so. The Defendant's manufacture of the toffees coming from the Parle family as it does, is quite another matter. The Defendant certainly cannot use the precise mark of the Plaintiff since it is a separate legal entity. However only a reference to the word Parle, the trademark that which both the parties enjoyed due to their lineage from the family of Parle, as has been done by the Defendant, is "stating no more than the truth". Since the Defendant's product's name is entirely different, the words "Parle Confi" would at best include the additional truthful information that it is a division, which is confectionery division, of the Defendant which is otherwise a beverage manufacturing Company. As in the case of Anderson the words "Parle Confi" has merely the reference to the parent Company which the Defendant calls a house name. But the fact that the corporate name of the Defendant is Parle Agro Private Limited, it makes it clear that it does not refer to the Plaintiff or the Plaintiff's businesses.

There are, therefore, two concepts i.e. the "product name" or the "brand name" and the "house name". The parties' house name is Parle. Their various products have separate and distinct identification names and marks for each of their products. It is justifiably argued on behalf of the Defendant that a customer who walks into the store cannot ask for "Parle" to be sold. He will have to ask for Glucose, Monaco, Buttercup, Mintrox, etc.  (1989) R.P.C. 124 - Rel. on.  (1999) RPC 117 and 1998 PTC (18) - Ref. to. 			 [Para 14,15]

heading: Interlocutory relief
HeadNote.description:
Interlocutory relief - Suit for declaration, permanent injunction on basis of infringement of trade marks, passing off - Interlocutory remedy is intended to preserve status quo, the rights of parties which may appear on a prima facie case - Tort of passing-off involves a misrepresentation made by a trader to his prospective customers calculated to injure, as a reasonably forseeable consequence, the business or goodwill of another which actually or probably, causes damages to the business or goods of the other trader - Plaintiff succeeding in establishing a prima facie case - Held, plaintiffs are entitled to the relief of temporary injunction.

Perusal of the wrappers also shows that the entire colour scheme, the design, the wording, its placement on the wrapper is exactly the same as that of plaintiff no.2. The ordinary customers are, therefore, impressed to believe that they are purchasing the products of the manufacturers which are one and the same. The imitation is so calculated that it may appear to be only a printing error between the words "Ashok" and "Ashik"; in fact and in reality it is not an error but a well-designed and well calculated strategy thought of by the defendant No.1. The phonetical similarity and the manner and the ink in which the competing letters and the words are written is also the same. A man of average intelligence with imperfect recollection is bound to be deceived, in a given case even an intelligent person is also likely to be mislead and may fall prey to passing off the goods of defendants as if they are the goods of the plaintiff.

In view of these aspects and circumstances and taking into account the reasoning adopted by the learned trial Judge, the plaintiff has succeeded in establishing a prima facie case.

The interlocutory remedy is intended to preserve in status quo, the rights of parties which may appear on a prima facie case. The Court also, in restraining a defendant from exercising what he considers his legal right but what the plaintiff would like to be prevented, puts into the scales, as a relevant consideration whether the defendant has yet to commence his enterprise or whether he has already been doing so in which latter case considerations somewhat different from those that apply to a case where the defendant is yet to commence his enterprise, are attracted.  It must be remembered that an infringement action is available where there is violation of specific property right acquired under and recognised by the statute. In a passing-off action, however, the plaintiff's right is independent of such a statutory right to a trade mark and is against the conduct of the defendant which leads to or is intended or calculated to lead to deception. Passing-off is said to be a species of unfair trade and competition or of actionable unfair trading by which one person, through deception, attempts to obtain an economic benefit of the reputation which another has established for himself in a particular trade or business. The action is regarded an action for deceit. The tort of passing-off involves a misrepresentation made by a trader to his prospective customers calculated to injure, as a reasonably foreseeable consequence, the business or good-will of another which actually or probably, causes damages to the business or goods of the other trader. In view of this legal position applicable to the present set of facts, there is no doubt whatsoever that the plaintiffs are entitled to the  relief of temporary injunction and the learned trial Judge has rightly allowed the application while dismissing the similar application filed on behalf of the defendants.  1990(Supp) SCC 727 - Ref. to.	 [Para 18,19,21,23]

heading: Passing off
Ad-interim relief
HeadNote.description: Passing off - Ad-interim relief - Genuine Trade marks are used as one's own distinguishable mark in business - They are not registered for sale - Defendant's admitted use of plaintiff's trade mark, held, brings his case within the mischief of the Trade Marks Act. (2001)5 SCC 73 and (2000)5 SCC 573 - Ref. to.			(Paras 24, 25)

heading: Protection under
HeadNote.description:
Protection under - Prior user of trade name in Hotel business by defendant - Also registration of defendant was in class 30 while plaintiff has been granted registration in class 42 - In said circumstances plaintiff cannot seek injunction.

The concept of registration trade mark in classes covering goods available under Schedule IV of the Trade Marks Act (1999) and concept of registration of trade mark in classes covering services available under Schedule IV to the said Act is required to be appreciated and there cannot be mixing of registration of trade mark for goods with service or mixing of services with goods. If the legislature intended to mix the said activity, there would not have been distinction as goods and services in Schedule IV.  In the instant case the Plaintiff has been granted registration in class 42 on the basis of order dated 25th August, 2008. However, the present Suit is filed on the basis of the registered trade mark held by the Plaintiff under class 30 and in the plaint there are no averments to show that the present suit is filed by relying upon the registration granted in favour of the Plaintiff vide class 42 by order dated 25th August, 2008. It is, in these circumstances, the stand taken by Defendant No.5 that activity of Defendant No.5 falls in class 42 and it cannot be compared with activity falling in class 30 is required to be accepted. On this principle even if the title of business of the Plaintiff, title of Defendant No.5 is Bhagat Tarachand, injunction sought by the Plaintiff cannot be granted. This point also covers the case of Defendant No.6.  The plea of the plaintiff that if certain proceedings are pending before the appropriate authority under the Act, the Court cannot extend the benefit of Section 34 is unsustainable, because irrespective of the proceedings which may be pending before the appropriate authority, it is open for the Court to consider the defence put up by a party as regards prior user of the trade name as that of the Plaintiff and if the case is made out and injunction can be refused.  [Para 30,32,36]

Thus, Reading the language of Section 34 as a whole, there is no prohibition on the Court to test the defence of the prior user. [Para 33]

In the instant case, Defendant No.5 has come out with a specific case that Defendant No.5 started business in the name of Bhagat Tarachand in the year 1978. Defendant No.5 has relied upon various particulars/documents for the purposes of making out the case of prior user since about 1978. A close perusal of these documents would clearly go to show that Defendant No.5 has been carrying on hotel business since 1978 in the name and style of Bhagat Tarachand. Surely, the documents which have been placed before the Court by Defendant No.5 cannot be disputed by the Plaintiff and at the stage of hearing and disposal of the Notice of Motion it is required to be seen as the one making out the case by Defendant No.5 viz. Defendant No.5 has been carrying on business in the name of Bhagat Tarachand since 1978. All this will clearly make out the case that stand taken out by Defendant No.5 that he is entitled to protection under Section 34 is required to be accepted.  [Para 35,36]

Moreover, if the Plaintiff was serious in protecting her trade mark, nothing prevented the Plaintiff from instituting the present Suit at an early date. It is true that normally delay in approaching the Court is no ground to refuse injunction. However, in the present case, there is one more additional factor to hold against the Plaintiff on the ground of delay as Defendant Nos.5 and 6 have been carrying on their respective activity definitely prior to 1999 and the Plaintiff has approached the Court for injunction against Defendant Nos.1 to 6. If the Plaintiff would have approached the Court against Defendant No.1 alone, the question of delay would not have gone against her. The aforesaid discussion would clearly go to show that Defendant No.5 and Defendant No.6 were entitled to use the term Bhagat Tarachand, Radhomal Bhagat Tarachand or Rodhomal Bhagat Tarachand Bhojanalaya in accordance with the provision of Section 34 of the said Act. If this is so, Defendant No.5 and Defendant No.6 could grant licence as regards said user of the term Bhagat Tarachand in favour of a third party. In view of the licence granted in favour of Defendant No.1, Defendant No.1 is justified in using the said trade name and carry on the business. The argument advanced by the learned Counsel for Defendant Nos. 5 and 6 that if an injunction is not granted against Defendant Nos.5 and 6, injunction cannot be granted against Defendant No.1 who is carrying on business under the licence from Defendant No.5 and/or Defendant No.6 is required to be accepted.  For the reasons mentioned aforesaid, the Plaintiff has failed to make out the prima-facie case for grant of injunction prayed in Notice of Motion.		 [Para 49,50]

heading: Permanent injunction
HeadNote.description: Infringement and passing off - Permanent injunction - Trade mark "LNZ" registered in the name of plaintiff - Defendant using trademarks "LNZ-5" and "LNZ-2.5" - Both trademarks used in respect of pharmaceutical products - Mark used by defendant is phonetically, visually and structurally similar to registered mark of plaintiff - Members of public and traders are bound to get confused - Adverse result of drugs cannot be ruled out - Plaintiff's mark is promoted on a very large scale throughout India - Defendant is trading on good will and reputation of plaintiff - Plaintiff entitled to permanent injunction against defendant - Considering nature of infringement, punitive damages of Rs.50,000/- also imposed on defendant.(Paras 7, 8, 9, 13)

heading: Due to non-renewal
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Removal of trade mark - Due to non-renewal - Validity - Before removing trade mark from register, notice in Form O-3 required to be issued to registered  proprietor - Mere issuance of public notice does not constitute compliance with S.25(3) - No notice in Form O-3 issued prior to removal of trade mark - Removal of trade mark, not proper. 
2013(54) PTC 165 (Del.) Foll. (Paras 8, 10, 11)

heading:
Disting.

1998 PTC 18
HeadNote.description:
Registration of Trade mark - Plaintiff's trade mark registered prior to impugned mark being used by defendant - Not only plaintiff is entitled to injunction against infringement but he can never be restrained from using its trade mark.

In this case, On 19th October, 1992, the plaintiff applied for registration of its mark "ROFOL" under class 5. The application was made on the basis of its proposed use of the mark. On 14th August, 1995, the defendants applied for registration of the mark "PROFOL" under class 5 also on the basis of its proposed use of the mark. The defendants started using the impugned mark "PROFOL" from April, 1998. The plaintiffs started using the mark "ROFOL" from about 16th October, 2004, i.e. after the plaintiff's mark was registered. On 14th September, 2001, the plaintiffs application for registration of the mark "ROFOL" was allowed. The registration of the plaintiffs mark is, however, as of the date of the application i.e. 19th October, 1992. On 13th October, 2006, the plaintiff filed an opposition to the defendants application for registration of the impugned mark, which is pending. The main question, therefore, is whether the plaintiff is, by virtue of it's mark having been registered prior to the impugned mark being used by the defendant, entitled to an injunction against infringement although it used it's mark after the defendants started using the impugned mark.

Held the applicant's entitlement to registration of a trade mark has to be decided with reference to the facts as on the date of the application for registration and that the evidence of user by the opponents subsequent to the said date cannot be relevant and will not entitle them to put forward the plea of user in answer to the earlier application for registration.

(2007) 109 BLR, AIR 1958 Bom. 58, 2011(7) ALL MR 721, 2011 (4) Mah.L.J.71 - Rel. on.

AIR 1965 Bom. 35 - Disting.

1998 PTC 18 - Explained.  [Para 15]

The defendants explanation for adopting the mark is less than convincing. It is averred that the defendants or their predecessor in April, 1998, introduced the molecule propofol in India. Thus, it is not as if the defendants discovered the molecule. The molecule was known throughout the world. By the time the defendants allegedly introduced the molecule to India, the plaintiff had already applied for registration of its mark. If the defendants had taken a search of the register, they would have come to know of the plaintiff's mark. Their adoption despite the same would then be dishonest. If they took no search, their adoption would be negligent. Either way then, they must suffer an injunction.  [Para 26]

The mere fact that the mark was not used until 2004 does not establish either that the plaintiff abandoned the same or that it never had any intention on the date of the application of using it. A mere delay in the use of a mark does not ipso facto warrant a conclusion to this effect. This is not a case where the registration was renewed mechanically with no intention of ever using it. It is only upon the facts of each case that the Court can decide whether by reason of the non-user the plaintiffs mark loses its distinctiveness or if the trade drops out of its use or the mark has been allowed to die for non-user. In the facts of the present case, these requirements are not satisfied.  [Para 63]

The non-user of a mark pending registration cannot, at least, normally be held against the proprietor for any reason. It accounts for good business sense for a party to use a mark only after it is registered. The proprietor may understandably not want to run the risk of using the mark if it is ultimately not Neon Laboratories Limited Vs. Medical Technologies Ltd. registered. The reasons are obvious. The use of a mark involves enormous time, effort and expenses. The proprietor may understandably not want to incur the same unless he is certain that there is no impediment to its registration. This he can be at least reasonably certain of only upon the mark being registered.  [Para 64]

Further, often a mark is not used till the product to which it is to be applied is ready to be marketed. The ability to market a product is dependent upon a variety of events and requirements not the least of which are market research and development. Many large organizations have independent research and development divisions. The entitlement to market a product is also dependent upon a variety of factors such as obtaining statutory clearances and approvals. The trademark can well be thought of in contemplation of the sale of products or the provision of services under such marks. Thus, the mark would be applied to the products and in respect of services after some time.  [Para 65]

The submission that the plaintiff intended trafficking in the mark requires merely to be stated to be rejected. The above facts establish that the plaintiff always intended using the mark and, in fact, started using the same. There is nothing on record which even remotely suggests that the plaintiff intended trafficking in the mark. The plaintiff is a well established pharmaceutical company which uses several marks.  [Para 68]

heading: Infringement of registered trade mark "SAMRAT"
HeadNote.description: Infringement of registered trade mark "SAMRAT" - Word 'SAMRAT' is common name as "king" - Marks used by appellant and respondent not structurally similar either phonetically or visually - No case of confusion in the mind of customers made out - Name of manufacture written in bold - Delay and laches apart from acquiescence by appellant and long use by respondent also cannot be overlooked - Held, not a case of perversity and illegality. (Paras 6, 9, 10, 12)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - 1st Plaintiff and 1st defendant used to manage business jointly before separation by arbitral award - Material on record prima facie indicate that 1st defendant used mark much prior to registration of mark by 1st plaintiff and thereafter - A defence under S.34 is established - Interim relief not liable to be granted to plaintiff. AIR 1995 SC 2372, (1994)2 SCC 448, 1998 PTC (18) - Ref. to.		(Para 8)

heading: Registration of trade mark
HeadNote.description:
Registration of trade mark - Held, the registration under one class, in any event, does not extend to goods or services under another Class. 

The registration under one class, in any event, does not extend to goods or services under another class. This is clear from section 28 itself. Section 30(2)(b) refers to conditions or limitations placed by the Registrar in respect of the registration granted by him which is in respect of a specific class or classes.

 When the Registrar considers an application for registration, he does so vis-a-vis the class under which the registration is sought. He then decides whether with respect to the goods or services falling under that class,the registration ought to be allowed and if so, whether it should be subject to any condition or limitation. The limitation or condition, if imposed, would then be with respect to the goods or services that fall under that class. The Registrar does not consider whether the registration of a mark sought under one class ought to be subject to a limitation or condition in view of the effect of the registration on goods or services under another class. This also follows from the fact that the exclusive right under section 28 to the registered proprietor of the trademark, inter-alia, to use the trademark is in relation to the goods or services in respect of which the trade mark is registered.  [Para 15,16]

heading: Passing off action
HeadNote.description: Passing off action - Plaintiff registered user of trade mark "Ultratech Cement The Engineer's Choice" since 2004 - Defendant using word mark "Ultratuff" - Plaintiff giving details of sales volume, sales turn over and advertisement expenses - Defendants not having substantial sales, amounts invested towards advertising or marketing not substantial - In fact invoices relied upon by defendants were fabricated and word Ultratuff was superimposed on invoices - Held even though words "Ultra" or "Ultratech" were not subject matter of separate application, case was covered by S.17(1) and similarity between marks used by plaintiff and defendant being quite close both visually and phonetically average Indian consumer would be confused. (Paras 18-20)

heading: Appointment of court receiver
HeadNote.description: Appointment of court receiver - For taking possession and control of goods - Suit for passing off - Documents on record shows that there is deceptive similarity between two cartons and there is clear likelihood of descendant's good being confused with those of plaintiffs - No adequate explanation on part of defendant in adopting particular trade dress including colour scheme and distinctive feature of plaintiffs' carton in its own carton - Plaintiff made out case for appointment of court receiver - Court receiver ordered to be appointed. (Paras 5, 7)

heading: Registration of trade mark
HeadNote.description: Registration of trade mark - Petitioner sought to register its trademark Royal Orchid and Royal Orchid Hotels in class 42 - Petitioner was not first user of logo/mark 'Royal orchid' - Mark 'Orchid' was registered by respondent and using it from anterior date - Further marks of petitioner and respondent were largely similar - Notwithstanding class of customers services by parties, it cannot be said that two logos would not give rise to confusion amongst customers using hotels - Order refusing to register trade mark of petitioner, proper. 		(Paras 10, 14)

heading: Infringement of trade mark and passing off
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark and passing off - Plaintiff using registered trade mark 'L-CIN 250' and 'L-CIN 500 in respect of medical and pharmaceutical preparations and substances - Defendant using nearly identical and deceptively similar trademark ELZCIN-OZ - Plaintiff selling its product with said trade mark since 2002 openly, continuously, extensively and exclusively on a growing scale, and acquired great reputation and good will which deserves to be protected - Nothing on record militating anything averred in plaint and deposed by plaintiff - Evidence showing defendant has copied essential features of plaintiff's trade marks - Hence, punitive damages awarded to plaintiff. (Paras 6, 8, 9, 12)

heading: Infringement of trade mark and passing off
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark and passing off - Both plaintiff and defendant are in business of selling and manufacturing Ayurvedic massage oil - Plaintiff using label "NAGEENA SUKOON OIL" whereas defendant using mark "HEENA SUKOON OIL" - Registration certificate of mark produced on record showing that plaintiff had obtained registration of mark using it since 1993 - Defendant applied for registration of mark recently in 2013 claiming user since 2012 - Also rise in sale of plaintiff's product from Rs.29,208/- in 2002-03 to extent of Rs.1.52 Crores in 2014-15, gives reasonable cause to plaintiff - Hence, strong case of infringement of a trade mark and passing off, made out against defendant. 1999 SCC On Line Del 27, 2002(1) ALL MR 673 (S.C.), 2012(1) ALL MR 599 Ref. to. (Paras 12, 13, 17, 18)

heading: Interlocutory injunction
Prayer for
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark and passing off action - Interlocutory injunction - Prayer for - Use of word "Kalpataru" in business of building construction and development by both plaintiff and defendants - Difference in word 'Kalptaru' as used by defendants and word 'Kalpa-taru' or 'Kalpataru' as used by plaintiff - However, use of hyphen in between "Kalpa" and "Taru" in device mark 'KALPA-TARU' or stylized manner of writing is hardly distinguishing feature - So also, different spelling, namely 'Kalpataru' in plaintiff's mark and 'Kalptaru' in defendants' - There is a high degree of phonetic and visual similarity as well as similarity in idea conveyed - Customers are likely to be deceived or at any rate, confused - Say of defendants that word 'Kalpataru' is generic and that many traders use it as part of their trade name - Not acceptable as they themselves obtained registration of trademark 'Kalptaru' - Since plaintiff hold registration of use of word 'Kalpataru' in class 37, prima facie case is in favour of plaintiff - Balance of convenience is in favour of plaintiff - Plaintiff is likely to suffer irreparable prejudice if injunction is not granted - Defendants can deal with real estate developed by it in any other name of its choice - Hence, injunction granted. 1991-PTC-204 Disting. 	(Paras 8, 10, 16)

heading: Suit against
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Suit against - Alleged infringement of plaintiff's registered trademark " Ultratech" by using word "Ultra" in defendant's trade mark as "Dalmia Ultra" - Word "Dalmia" Prima facie associated with defendant's trade name and reputation built over the years - Same is sufficient to put purchasing public to notice of distinctive origin of defendant's goods - No likelihood of anyone being deceived or any confusion ensuing in minds of purchasing public or traders - No prima facie case of infringement or passing off, made out. (Paras 18, 19)

heading: Infringement of trade mark and passing off
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark and passing off - Prayer for temporary injunction - Plaintiff is registered proprietor of trade mark "LIVE IN" and has established substantial reputation and goodwill in field of jeans, apparel and clothing in India over last more than 20 years - Defendant used identical mark on its products and advertising it as "LIVE IN LEVI'S" - Case of defendant that words "LIVE IN" are generic and descriptive - Though apparel companies generally use words "LIVE IN" alongwith their product name, that does not mean words "LIVE IN" are generic or descriptive - In India where public are accustomed to plaintiff's existing registered trade mark, display words "LIVE IN", even if be along with defendant's own trade mark "LEVI'S", is clearly likely to cause confusion, if not deception - Use of word "LIVE IN" with or without trade mark "LEVI'S" would constitute infringement and also passing off - Plaintiff has made out case for grant of interim relief - Balance of convenience and irreparable loss weigh in favour of plaintiff - No real loss is likely to be caused to defendant if it is injuncted from using said words - Injunction granted. 1988 PTC 39, 2008 (36) PTC 168 (Del.) Disting. 	(Paras 5, 9, 11, 12, 13)

heading: Infringement and passing off
HeadNote.description: Infringement and passing off - Plaintiff using registered trade mark "AMPILOX" for its pharmaceutical product - Impugned mark "Ampilox" of defendant is phonetically, visually and structurally identical and deceptively similar - Adoption of said mark by defendant is deliberate, dishonest and fraudulent to capitalize and trade upon the good will and reputation of plaintiff's product - Punitive damages of Rs.1 lac awarded to plaintiff against defendant. 	(Paras 7, 8, 9, 13)

heading: Perpetual injunction
HeadNote.description: Perpetual injunction - Two similar trade marks registered - Whether one can get injunction against another - Both parties use trademark "Godwa" - Circumstances in which both got registered is matter of trial - Registration gives entitlement to owner to use trademark against whole world - Use of registered trade marks by honest concurrent user cannot be treated as "infringement" - At interim stage, one registered owner cannot be prevented against another - Principles of injunction such as prima facie case, irreparable loss and equity cannot be used against statute - Prayer of injunction not maintainable. 	(Paras 5, 6, 9)

heading: Additional evidence
Production of
HeadNote.description: Additional evidence - Production of - Dispute about registration of trade mark - Some of documents in list could not have been in possession of petitioner - Production of those documents could be secured with aid of Right to Information Act - Production of public documents should have been allowed with aid of O.47, R.27 - Rejection of application to produce documents by Appellate Forum is liable to be set aside - Order accordingly.		(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Infringement of trademark
Temporary injunction
Rejection of
Validity
