HeadNote.description: Infringement of trademark - Temporary injunction - Restraining respondent from using trademark deceptively similar to that of appellant - Rejection of - Validity - Respondent allegedly using trademark deceptively similar to that of appellants which is likely to create confusion in minds of people - Trademark of appellants is “atmantan be transformed” and trademark of respondent is “TanMan” - Registered trademark of appellants and respondent are quite distinct, different and dissimilar in all aspects - No question of common man getting confused - Appellants also have not quoted any incident as to how and when customers or clients were confused by trademark of respondent - Moreover, appellant is running resort whereas respondent is running Ayurvedic research centre - Clients of appellants and respondent are different - Prima facie no sane man would say that there is infringement on part of respondent in respect of words “Tanman” and “atmantan be transformed” - Order rejecting temporary injunction, proper. 	(Paras 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 34)

heading: Deceptively similar
HeadNote.description: Infringement of Trade Mark - Deceptively similar - Use of the mark VIVACITY by defendants - Use solely with a view to create an impression in the mind of customer that VIVACITY is equal to VIVA and the said use was not bonafide - Held, the use of the mark VIVACITY is patently deceptively similar as that of the mark of VIVA. 1994 Supp (3) SCC 215 and 2008(37) PTC 468 (Del.) (DB) - Ref. to. 	(Para 19)

heading: Registration of assignments
Protection under Act
HeadNote.description: Registration of assignments - Protection under Act - Issue of title in registered trade mark vests in assignee after assignment and before registration, and whether he is entitled to exercise right under S.28 as registered proprietor - Plaintiff notwithstanding being not registered, held, is entitled to exercise rights as a registered proprietor of trade mark. 2007(6) LJSOFT (URC) 171 & AIR 1988 Bom. 167 - Ref. to.		(Para 13)

heading: Defendant using LETHYROX
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade mark - Prayer for interim injunction against manufacturing and marketing of defendant's product - Plaintiff using marks THYROX and ANTI THYROX - Defendant using LETHYROX - Said marks are used by parties in respect of their pharmaceutical products - Marks have been coined from the active ingredient "levothyroxine" - Therefore word "thyro" is publici juris over which no monopoly can be claimed - Prefix "LE" and "ANTI" in rival marks are clearly distinct - No likelihood of any confusion or deception - Ingredients of both drugs being same, there cannot be any disastrous consequences - Injunction declined.
2003 (28) PTC 193 (Bom), 2004 (28) PTC 456 (Del), 2003 (27) PTC 234 (Del), 2005 (30) PTC 14 (Bom) (DB) Disting.(Paras 30, 32, 33)

heading: Interpretation of statute
HeadNote.description: Interpretation of statute - Suit for infringement, etc. to be instituted before District Court - Provisions of S.134 (2) are mandatory - It is not open to High Court to question the legislative policy by reading into the mandatory provisions, a qualification which is expressly excluded by the terms of the section. MIPR 2009 (176) - Not agreed with.	(Para 9)

heading: Registration Certificate
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Registration Certificate - Challenge to - Court would not allow a genuine claim to be defeated on a technicality especially at the interlocutory stage.	(Para 14)

heading: Saving for vested rights
HeadNote.description: Saving for vested rights - Where a mark is registered without opposition from a party filing an action for passing off, the order of Registrar does not and cannot affect the party nor bind the court from considering the question of passing off - To hold otherwise would be contrary to provisions of the Act - It would render S.34 redundant.	(Para 23)

heading: Infringement of Trade Mark
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of Trade Mark - Mere use of a word mark as an independent part of the impugned mark will not ipso facto constitute infringement - Marks must be considered as a whole and not in fragments.

Mere use of a word mark as an independent part of the impugned mark will not ipso facto constitute infringement. It would depend on a variety of factors such as the number of words in the impugned mark, the placement of the mark said to be infringed in the impugned mark and the prominence given to the mark said to be infringed in the impugned mar. This flows from the principle that marks must be considered as a whole and not in fragments.(1970) 2 SCR 222 - Ref. to.	 [Para 28]

heading: Application for Registration of Trade Mark
HeadNote.description: Application for Registration of Trade Mark - Registration predicates either use or the proposed use of a mark as is evident from S.18 (1) of the Act.	(Para 33)

heading: Use of one of associated or substantially identical trade marks equivalent to use of another
HeadNote.description: Use of one of associated or substantially identical trade marks equivalent to use of another - Held, S.55 is not mandatory.	(Para 38)

heading: Rectification of
HeadNote.description: Registration of trade mark - Rectification of - Applicant having obtained registration for one mark cannot make false statements that the modified label is also registered under it - Said act of the applicant only goes to show the dishonest intentions of the applicant - Order dismissing application for rectification of registered trade mark is proper. 	(Para 12)

heading: Trade Mark
HeadNote.description:
Trade Mark - Expression includes 'shape of goods'.

Under Trade Marks Act, 1999 shape of goods is now statutorily recognized as being constituent element of trade mark.  S.2(zb) of said Act defines expression 'trade mark' no mean capable of being represented graphically and which is capable of distinguishing goods or services of one person from those of others and to include "shape of goods, their packaging and combination of colours".  Parliament has therefore, statutorily recognized that shape in which goods are marketed, their packaging and combination of colours form part of what is described as trade dress.  A manufacturer who markets a product may assert distinctive nature of goods sold in terms of unique shape through which goods are offered for sale.  [Para 13]

heading: Passing off
HeadNote.description: Passing off - Defendant has adopted deceptive variation of shape of vodka bottle of plaintiff - Ability of consumer to discern is not related to social class or economic status - Argument that purchasers of plaintiff's product are educated and affluent, they have discerning capacity which renders possibility of deception unlikely - Argument liable to be rejected. (2001)5 SCC 73, 1889 R.P. Design 531 - Ref. to.	(Para 24)

heading: Determination of
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Question whether defendant's mark is deceptively similar to the mark of the plaintiffs - Determination of - Court must assess each matter from the position of a purchaser "who must be looked upon as an average man of ordinary intelligence" - For it is such a purchaser whose reaction to a particular trade mark has to be considered and what association he would form, by looking at the trade mark and in what respect he would connect the mark with the goods he would be purchasing. AIR 1953 SC 357 and AIR 1960 SC 142 - Ref. to.	(Para 10)

heading: Medicinal preparations
Stricter standard
HeadNote.description:
Medicinal preparations - Stricter standard - As a matter of principle, it would be inappropriate to apply a stricter standard only to a particular class of medicinal preparations - If the court were to do this, it would have to make artificial distinctions from case to case based on whether or not the court considers that a confusion arising out of the medicinal product in issue may or may not have disastrous effects on health and life - Such an approach is impermissible.

As a matter of principle, it would be inappropriate for the Court to apply a stricter standard only to a particular class of medicinal preparations. If the Court were to do this, it would have to make artificial distinctions from case to case based on whether or not the Court considers that a confusion arising out of the medicinal product in issue may or may not have disastrous effects on health and life. Such an approach is impermissible. An ostensibly innocuous medicinal preparation taken for an affliction which is not life threatening may yet result in a serious danger to life and health, where the drug is not manufactured under correct conditions. A consumer who desires to obtain a medicine even for an ordinary ailment is entitled to be sure that the drug that he purchases is of an assured character and quality. A manufacturer builds up a reputation for quality and standards assiduously over a length of time and an established mark assures to the consumer that the medicine which he has purchased is of a requisite quality that is associated with the mark. A less than strict standard cannot be applied on the hypothesis that the ailment which the drug is intended to treat is not life threatening, nor for that matter can the application of a lower standard be justified merely on the ground that the composition of the Plaintiff's product is the same as that of the Defendant and the confusion caused by mistaking one for the other would not result in a danger to health. Undoubtedly, where the competing drugs are meant to cure the same ailment but the compositions are different, mistaking one for the other may result in deleterious consequences. But, merely because the two competing marks are used for drugs with the same composition that would not justify applying a lower standard of scrutiny. For, even in such a case, the public interest lies in protecting the consumer against an unwary purchase of a deceptively similar product. The consumer must be protected against a reasonable possibility of confusion arising out of a deceptively similar mark.   [Para 14]

heading: Expression "deceptively similar"
HeadNote.description:
Expression "deceptively similar" - Trademark FOLVITE & word FOL-V - In considering question of deceptive similarity, two marks have to be considered as a whole - The structure of the mark visually and phonetically must be borne in mind - The image which court must have is that of the quintessential common man.

In considering the question of deceptive similarity, the two marks have to be considered as a whole. The structure of the mark visually and phonetically must be borne in mind. The image which the Court must have is that of the quintessential common man. When the Judge looks at phonetics, the sound which accompanies the pronunciation of the mark is the sound of the mark to an ordinary purchaser bereft of the niceties of language. Structurally and phonetically FOL-V falls within that perilous zone where approximation to the mark of the Plaintiffs is close enough to be deceptively similar. It is, no answer to state that the Plaintiffs intend that the VITE in their mark is to be so pronounced as to rhyme with 'Vite' while the Defendant intends that the "V" in their mark has to be so pronounced as to rhyme with the 'V' in 'victory' and to then make a distinction between VITE and the V. The ordinary customer goes to a small shop of a Chemist and to him the distinction between FOLVITE on the one hand and FOL-V on the other is so thin as to almost be lacking in significance. It may well be that the manner in which the mark of the Plaintiffs is written in Devnagari may make the VITE in the mark resemble 'white'. But every customer in a multi lingual country such as India is not conversant with that script. An average consumer who asks for FOLVITE would fail to gauge the distinction when he is given a strip of tablets of FOL-V and that is what matters on the question of deceptive similarity.

The contention of the Defendant is that the mark FOLVITE is a combination of FOL which stands for folic acid and VIT which is an abbreviation for Vitamin. The theory propounded by the Defendant is that the Plaintiffs cannot assert a monopoly over folic acid on the one hand and Vitamin on the other by adding an "e" to an abbreviation of the two words. This argument of the Defendant clearly misses the point and there are several reasons why it cannot be accepted. First and foremost, the word FOLVITE has absolutely no meaning in the English language. It is an invented word. As the Supreme Court observed in Cadila, it is not right to take a part of a word and compare it with a part of another. Each word must be taken as a whole and compared as a whole with the other: "It is not right to take a portion of the word and say that because that portion of the word differs from the corresponding portion of the word in the other case, there is no sufficient similarity to cause confusion."

Secondly, it is a settled principle of law that so long as a mark continues on the Register, it is not open to the Defendant in an action for infringement to question the validity of the registration.   [Para 17,18,19]

heading: Validity of registration
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Validity of registration - Challenge to - Validity of registered trade mark cannot be challenged in action for infringement.	(Para 19)

heading: Onus of proof
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Onus of proof - Before an applicant can assert the presence of a number of marks having one or more common features in the trade, he has to prove that these marks had acquired a reputation by user in the market - The onus of establishing this lies on him who asserts the existence of such other mark. AIR 1960 SC 142 - Rel. on.	(Para 20)

heading: Letters Patent (Bombay), Cl.14
HeadNote.description: Letters Patent (Bombay), Cl.14 - Suit for infringement of trade marks filed u/s.134 - Leave petition filed in suit subsequently under Cl.14 of Letters Patent to combine cause of action for passing off along with that  of infringement of trademarks - On ground that same set of facts have given rise to both cause of actions - Deserves to be allowed - Defence plea that since original jurisdiction of this court for entertaining suit for infringement of trademark has not been conferred upon court under Cl.13 of L.P. but u/s.134 of Act, 1999, court cannot combine cause of action - Not tenable, in view of  law laid down in AIR 2004 SC 1682. (Paras 17, 18, 20)

heading: Object and applicability
HeadNote.description: Letters Patent (Bombay), Cls.14, 12 - Civil P.C. (1908), S.20 - Non-obstante clause contained in sub Cl.(2) of S.134 - Object and applicability - Provision of said clause is to ensure that scope of S.134(2) cannot be curtailed by reference to S.20 of C.P.C. or Cl.12 of L.P. - However S.134(2) has no role to play while considering cl.14 of L.P. - It cannot, therefore be said that leave under cl.14 to combine several causes of action cannot be sought when plaintiff had invoked jurisdiction of court u/s.134(2). 			(Paras 18, 20)

heading: Trade mark
Registrability of
HeadNote.description: Trade mark - Registrability of - Depends on degree of its capability to distinguish goods of one trader from goods of others. 	(Para 4)

heading: Trade mark
HeadNote.description:
Trade mark - Goods which are liable to be registrable as trade mark - Stated.

	As a matter of general principle, registrability of, and also corresponding protection afforded to, a trade mark depends on the degree of its capability to distinguish the goods of one trader from the goods of others. A generic or common descriptive term is one which is used as the name or description of  the kind of goods. It obviously cannot become a trademark under any circumstances, since it fails altogether in distinguishing the goods of one trader from those of another. A merely descriptive term specifically describes one or other characteristic or ingredient of goods. Such a term is also ordinarily not registrable as trademark, unless it has, by acquiring a secondary meaning, i.e. becoming distinctive of the goods of the applicant for registration, become a valid trade mark. A suggestive term, unlike a descriptive term, suggests rather than describes an ingredient or characteristic of the goods. It still requires the observer or listener to use his own imagination and perception to determine the nature of the goods. Such a term is capable of being registered without proof of a secondary meaning. The Registrar may, however, put the applicant to certain terms as regards the user, or require a disclaimer from the latter, so far as a permissible descriptive or suggestive term is concerned. An arbitrary or fanciful term such as an invented word enjoys the fullest protection along the spectrum. It is most likely to distinguish the goods of the applicant from the goods of others and is the best placed of all terms as regards registrability. It is next to be noted that if a trademark, for which protection is sought to be claimed, lies at a particular place along the spectrum of trademarks referred to above, the applicant cannot successfully claim to alter that place (and put it on a higher end of the spectrum) by simply using a phonetic equivalent, say by misspelling it. A generic or common descriptive word, say 'table', cannot be misspelt as 'tabel' so as to rid the word of its quality of being a common descriptive or generic word. 	 [Para 4,5]

heading: Trade mark
Infringement of
HeadNote.description: Food Safety and Standards Act (2006), S.3(1)(x) - Trade mark - Infringement of - Trade mark "cheri" and "Multi cheri" - Plaintiff's goods "Cheri" are 'drugs' within meaning of Act (1940) - They are meant to be therapeutic in nature and basically used in pharmaceutical preparations - They are to be used "as directed by physician" - Defendant's products "Multi Cherry" are 'proprietary food' covered under Act (2006) and not 'drugs' as per Act (1940) - They are avowedly "not for medicinal use" - They are to be used 'as directed by dietician' - Prices of two products are different and so are their end uses - There is no concrete likelihood of deception or confusion in minds of user - No case made out of infringement of trade mark.			(Paras 8, 12)

heading: Passing off action
HeadNote.description: Passing off action - Application for interim injunction - Plaintiffs claiming to be user of descriptive mark "LEAKGUARD" since 1999 - While defendants claiming use of same mark from 2005 - Rival marks were used in relation to solvent cements, chemicals and compound - Defendants produced evidence of promotional materials and expenses incurred by them in promoting their products - Materials on record indicate that defendants used the mark exclusively, advertising it, promoting it and making no attempt to lead anybody to believe that their products were in any way connected to that of plaintiffs - Even though plaintiffs' user is prior in time, it is not shown to be consistent - Plaintiffs sometimes used the mark alone, sometimes along with other expressions, sometimes only indicating "LG" and sometimes using it as two words "LEAK GUARD" - Whereas defendants user is consistent as one word "LEAKGUARD" - No prima facie case made out by plaintiffs - Plaintiffs not entitled to injunction. 			(Paras 12, 23)

heading: Passing off action
HeadNote.description: Passing off action - In case of descriptive mark - It is not enough for plaintiff to show prior user alone - It must be shown to be extensive, continuous and widely publicized as a consequence of which plaintiffs' product had achieved some sort of secondary distinctive meaning. 			(Paras 13, 18)

heading: Passing off action
HeadNote.description: Passing off action - Acquiescence on part of plaintiff, plea taken by defendant - Identical marks "LEAKGUARD" used by plaintiffs and defendants - Defendants claimed to be using mark since 2005 as against plaintiffs who claimed user since 1999 - However, plaintiffs filed suit against defendants only in year 2010 - Use of said mark by defendants was open and without any attempt at concealment - Defendants have publicized and advertised their product not only through print material but also in TV, films and by participating in various trade exhibitions - Plaintiffs plea that they learnt of defendants user only in 2009 and therefore suit filed in 2010, not acceptable - Prima facie, acquiescence on part of plaintiffs shown. 	(Paras 23, 24)

heading: Trade mark
e-commerce
Domain name
RODNEY D RYDER
HeadNote.description:
Trade mark - e-commerce - Domain name - May possess all the characteristics of a trade mark - It can maintain action for passing off - Domain name has no geographical limitation and has universal connectivity - Hence domain name will be legally protected only to the extent possible under the national laws relating to passing off.

The original role of a domain name was no doubt to provide an address for computers on the internet. But the internet has developed from a mere means of communication to a mode of carrying on commercial activity. With the increase of commercial  activity on the internet, a domain name is also used as a business identifier. Therefore, the domain name not only serves as an address for internet communication but also identifies the specific internet site. In the commercial field, each domain name owner provides information/ services which are associated with such domain name. Thus a domain name may pertain to provision of services within the meaning of Section 2(z). A domain name is easy to remember and use, and is chosen as an instrument of commercial enterprise not only because it facilitates the ability of consumers to navigate  the internet to find  websites they are looking for, but also at the same time, serves to identify and distinguish the business itself, or its goods or services, and to specify its corresponding online internet location [Intellectual Property and the Internet - RODNEY D RYDER - Page 96 to 97].  Consequently a domain name as an address must, of necessity, be peculiar and unique and where a domain name is used in connection with a business, the value of maintaining an exclusive identity becomes critical.	 [Para 12]

An action for passing off, as the phrase 'passing off' itself suggests, is to restrain the defendant from passing off its goods or services to the public as that of the plaintiff's. It is an action not only to preserve the reputation of the plaintiff but also to safeguard the public. The defendant must have sold its goods or offered its services in a manner which has deceived or would be likely to deceive the public into thinking that the defendant's goods or services are the plaintiff's. The action is normally available to the owner of a distinctive trademark and the person who, if the word or name is an invented one, invents and uses it. If two trade rivals claim to have individually invented the same mark, then the trader who is able to establish prior user will succeed.   [Para 13]

The use of the same or similar domain name may lead to a diversion of users which could result from such users mistakenly accessing one domain name instead of another. This may occur in e-commerce  with its rapid progress and instant (and theoretically limitless) accessibility to users and potential  customers and particularly so in areas of specific overlap. Ordinary  consumers/ users seeking to locate the functions available under one domain name may be confused if they accidentally arrived at a different but similar web site which offers no such services. Such users  could well conclude that the first domain name owner had mis-represented its goods or services through its promotional activities and the first domain owner would thereby lose their customer. It is apparent therefore that a domain name may have all the characteristics of a trademark and could found an action for passing off.  [Para 16]

A trademark is protected by the laws of a country where such trademark may be registered. Consequently, a trade mark may have multiple registration in many countries  throughout the world. On the other hand since the internet allows for access without any geographical limitation, a domain name is potentially accessible  irrespective of the geographical location of the consumers. The outcome of this potential for universal connectivity is not only that a domain name would require world wide exclusivity but also that national laws might be inadequate to effectively protect a domain name.   [Para 18]

heading: Passing off action
HeadNote.description: Passing off action - Ingredients to be established - Two trade rivals claiming to have individually invented the same mark - Trader who is able to establish prior user will succeed - Innocent misrepresentation would be relevant only for the question of ultimate relief to be granted to plaintiff.

heading: Passing off action and infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description:
Passing off action and infringement of trade mark - Difference between the two.

A passing off action is based on the goodwill that a trader has in his name unlike an action for infringement of a trademark where a trader's right is based on property in the name as such. Therefore, unless goodwill can be established by the appellant by showing that the public associates its name with the services provided by the appellant, it cannot succeed.   [Para 26]

heading: Passing off action
HeadNote.description: Passing off action - Trade name "Siffy" and "Sify" - Plaintiff carrying on its business under domain name starting with word 'Sify' - Defendant subsequently starting its business under domain name "Siffynet" - Both words are visually and phonetically similar and both of them carrying similar e-commerce business - Plaintiff was prior in user and public associated word 'Sify' with plaintiff - Held defendant's use of "Siffy" was not bonafide.	(Paras 30, 35)

heading: Delay and laches
Defence of acquiescence
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Delay and laches - Defence of acquiescence - Essential ingredient of doctrine of acquiescence is that possessor of legal rights must have encouraged his adversary in expending money or in doing some other acts which he has done either directly or by obstaining from asserting his legal rights - It is necessary to establish that plaintiff stood by and knowingly allowed the defendant to proceed and to expend money in ignorance of the title of the plaintiff. (1994)2 SCC 448 and (1982) R.P.C. 1 - Ref. to.	(Paras 15, 20)

heading: Delay
Ref. on.			(Paras 18-20)
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Delay - In an action for infringement, delay by itself may not be a ground for refusing an injunction. Civil P.C. (1908), O.39, Rr.1, 2. (2006)7 SCC 726 and (2002)24 PTC 226 - Ref. on.			(Paras 18-20)

heading: Interim relief
HeadNote.description: Passing off and infringement - Interim relief - Plaintiff's registered trade mark BUFIN in wide use since 1972 or earlier alongwith its mark/label - In 2003 Defendant started identifying product by name BUFER - Defendant's label/mark consisting of deceptively similar device and get up - Held, plaintiff's have made out prima facie case for grant of injunction.	(Paras 21, 22)

heading: Notice of Motion
Temporary injunction
HeadNote.description:
Infringement and passing off - Notice of Motion - Temporary injunction - Claim by plaintiff that use of trade Mark ""PRESTIGE 5000" & "FOUR SQUARE 5000" by defendant is deceptively similar to trade mark "HAYWARDS 5000" - Numeral "5000" forms an essential feature - Numeral "5000" not disclaimed in registration records - Hence, plaintiffs have statutory rights to prevent defendants from using a deceptively similar mark with such numerals - Moreover, as defendant had admitted popularity and stability of plaintiff's brand - Plaintiffs would be entitled to temporary injunction as prima facie adoption of mark by defendant appeared to be dishonest.

In the instant case, the plaintiffs are seeking temporary injunction in an action for infringement and passing off by using a trademark "PRESTIGE 5000" and "FOUR SQUARE 5000" of which the numeral "5000" forms an essential feature deceptively similar to plaintiff's trademark "HAYWARDS 5000".

The trade-mark of the Petitioner "HAYWARDS 5000" is a registered trade-mark. Perusal of the registration shows that numeral "5000" is not disclaimed. What is disclaimed is the descriptive material on the label. Whenever numeral in the lable or trade mark is disclaimed, it is clear from the material available on record that it was specifically so mentioned, and therefore, it is clear from the material available on record that so far as the registration of the lable of "HAYWARDS 5000" is concerned, the numeral has not been disclaimed, and therefore, in view of the registration of the trade-mark and the lable, the Plaintiffs will have a statutory right to prevent the Defendants from using a deceptively similar mark.

Moreso, the Defendants have, while entering into an agreement with the Plaintiffs which are on record, admitted that the Brand "HAYWARDS 5000" is a well-known brand and that the Defendants have no right and are not entitled to question the popularity or the suitability of the brand.

From the material available on record it is clear that the Defendants were aware, when they adopted their brand about the popularity of the registered trade mark of the Petitioners, and therefore, it prima facie appears that the adoption of the impugned trade-mark by the Defendants was dishonest and they adopted the trade mark to take advantage of the popularity of the trade-mark of the Plaintiffs, and therefore, as there is no disclaimer of the numeral "5000" at the time of registration of the trade-mark and as the numeral "5000" is an essential part of the registered trade lable of the Plaintiffs, the Plaintiffs will prima facie have a statutory right to prevent the Defendants from using a deceptively similar trade lable and trade mark. The Plaintiffs would be entitled to a temporary injunction also because it prima facie appears that the adoption of the impugned mark by the Defendants appears to be dishonest.

Hence, inspite of the fact that the statement made in paragraph 3 of the plaint that on the date on which the suit was filed nobody else was using the numeral "5000" in respect of the beer is an incorrect statement made by the Plaintiffs.

But still for that reason alone the relief of temporary injunction cannot be denied to the Plaintiff, because an order of temporary injunction in a suit for infringement or passing off is to be made not only to protect the right of the Plaintiff, but also to protect the interest of the general public.

An order of temporary injunction is to be made so that the public who buys the goods involved is not deceived or misled. Therefore, had the purpose of granting temporary injunction been only to protect the interest of the Plaintiffs, then may be the temporary injunction could have been denied to the Plaintiffs, because the Plaintiffs have made an incorrect statement in the plaint. But as the purpose of granting temporary injunction in a suit for infringement of trade-mark or trade label is not only to protect the interest of the Plaintiffs, but also to protect the interest of the general public, denial of temporary injunction to the Plaintiffs merely because the Plaintiffs have made incorrect statement in the plaint would not be in the interest of justice. [Para 13]

heading: Temporary injunction
Scope
HeadNote.description: Infringement and passing off of trade Marks - Temporary injunction - Scope - Plea of defendant that a statement made in the plaint was incorrect - Order of temporary injunction in a suit for infringement or passing off is to be made not only to protect the right of plaintiff but also protect interest of general public - Thus, mere fact that plaintiffs have made an incorrect statement in the plaint would not be a ground for denial of temporary injunction in the interest of justice.	(Para 14)

heading: Application for
HeadNote.description: Registration of trade mark - Application for - Registry would, among other, consider as to whether trade mark as whole is likely to create confusion - If it is so, registry may refuse registration.	(Para 17)

heading: Registration of trade mark
HeadNote.description:
Registration of trade mark - Rights conferred by registration and interplay of Ss.27(2) and 28(3) of Trade Marks Act - Action for passing off remains undisturbed by any registration provided under the Act.

The registration under the Act is merely a recognition of the rights pre-existing in common law and in case of conflict between the two registered proprietors, the evaluation of the better rights in common law is essential as the common law rights would enable the court to determine whose rights between the two registered proprietors are better and superior in common law which have been recognized in the form of the registration by the Act.				    [Para 23]

In this case the respondent lady has been able to establish that the trade mark 'Iruttukadai Halwa' has been used of by her/her predecessors since the year 1900. The business in that name is carried on by her family. It has become a household name which is associated with the respondent/her family. The Court has also noted that the Halwa sold by the respondent's shop as 'Iruttukadai Halwa' is not only famous with the consumers living in Tirunelveli, but is also famous with the consumers living in other parts of Indiaand outside. Hence the conclusion reached by the court below is perfectly in order.	     [Para 24]

heading: Infringement of trademark
Suit against
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trademark - Suit against - Provisions under Ss.28, 29, 30 do not bar filing of suit if defendant's mark is also registered - S.124 also states that where defendant's trade mark is also registered plaintiff pleads invalidity of defendant's trademark. 	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Infringement of trademark
Suit for
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trademark - Suit for - Suit is not barred because defendant's mark is also registered - Contention of defendant that suit was barred and therefore cause of action for passing off, which was at time of filing of suit was outside Mumbai, cannot be clubbed with suit for infringement - Contention liable to be rejected. 	(Para 9)

heading: Infringement of trade mark and passing off
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark and passing off - Goodwill and reputation of mark - Establishment of, by plaintiff - Sales invoices duly certified by Chartered Accountants relied upon by plaintiff - It shows increasing sale of product - Also export of product to various countries - Sale invoices not disputed by defendants - Held, plaintiffs have satisfactorily established goodwill and reputation on trademark. 			(Para 4)

heading: Infringement of trade mark and passing off
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade mark and passing off - There is difference of only one letter between mark of defendant and plaintiff - Person of average intelligence and imperfect recollection is unable to distinguish between two marks - Further product manufactured by parties are also same - Held, there is deceptive similarity between marks of defendant and plaintiff.

Contention that added material in defendant's mark are sufficient to indicate different trade origin and distinguish goods of parties.  Similarity in two marks is so striking that added material does not distract from deceptive similarity.  Further firstly though defendant did it honestly and independently it would make no difference to grant of injunction for infringement or passing off once it is held that mark is deceptively similar.  Secondly it is difficult to accept that average consumer while purchasing product would be aware that letters in mark are symbolic of and an abbreviation and chemical symbol for haemoglobin and thereby distinguish defendant's product from that of plaintiffs.  It is law that test while determining similarity is one of possibility and not probability of confusion.  Moreover while comparing marks Court does not go into etymological meaning of rival words/marks.  Hence as there is deceptive similarity between defendant and plaintiff's mark, plaintiff's claim for action against defendant is maintainable.  AIR 1963 SC 449, 1993 IPLR 39  : 1993 PTC 309 (D.B.), 2002(3) ALL MR 18, (1963)2 SCR 484 : AIR 1963 SC 449, (2001)5 SCC 73 - Referred. 			 [Para 11,12,13,15,16,17,19]

heading: Infringement of trademark
Grant of injunction
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trademark - Grant of injunction - Contention that use by defendant was not dishonest - Plaintiff's marks were registered - Defendants had means to discover it by going through public record - Plaintiff's had proceeded against defendant's use of trade mark - Plaintiffs are liable to relief of injunction. AIR 1990 Delhi 19, 1994 IPLR 1, 2002(24) PTC 226 (Bom.), 2005(30) PTC 14 (Bom) - Referred. 	(Paras 23, 25)

heading: Infringement of trademark
Delay and latches
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trademark - Delay and latches - Plaintiffs opposed immediately to use of said mark by defendants in India and abroad - In criminal case against appellants goods were returned to defendants with condition that they would not sell it - Case was dismissed due to non service to accused - Plaintiffs opposed two applications for registration of trade mark by defendant - One application for registration was not opposed as it escaped plaintiff's attention - There is valid explanation to delay - Plaintiffs has not acquiescenced or waived their rights towards their marks. 2005(30) PTC 14, 1994 IPLR 1 - Referred. 	(Paras 30, 33C, 35, 40, 41)

heading: Infringement of trademark
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trademark - Interim relief to plaintiff - Statement that after defendant made application for return of goods in criminal case against it export of product was discontinued - Defendants contending that statement by plaintiff is false and opposing grant of interim relief - Documents relied by defendant does not mention names of countries to which goods were exported - Nothing shows that plaintiff had means to notice export of goods by defendants - Interim relief not liable to be denied to plaintiff on ground of acquiescence or waiver. 	(Para 43)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Plaint and notices show that cause of action is based on word and label mark - Merely because label mark was registered it does not prevent plaintiffs from basing cause of action on word which is predominant feature. 	(Para45)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Part of mark "TONE" is in common usage for similar products - Defendants did not produce any evidence as to their contention - Mere reliance upon register to indicate registration of marks with suffix "TONE" does not establish that it is common to trade - Interim relief not liable to be denied to plaintiff. AIR 1960 SC 142, 1994 IPLR 1, 1993 IPLR 39 - Referred. 	(Para 48)

heading: Trade mark
HeadNote.description: Trade mark - Infringement and passing off - Trade Mark is being applied in India and goods are exported and sold outside India by defendants - It constitutes use of trade mark in India as per S.56 - Impugned mark is applied to defendant's goods within meaning of S.56 - Proprietor of mark and general public require protection in respect of goods to be exported from India bearing infringing mark - Moreover mark is being exposed to manufactures of labels, cartons, containers, transporters during process of quality control, inspection etc. - S.56 is applicable to infringement and passing off even though goods with impugned mark are not sold in India. 	(Paras 51, 53, 55, 56)

heading: Passing off
Dual actionability
HeadNote.description: Passing off - Dual actionability - Contention that plaintiff must prove that country to which goods are exported recognizes action of passing off and factum of passing off in that country - Language of S.56 does not warrant application of principle of dual actionability - Contention of defendant in this regard is liable to be rejected.			(Paras 57, 58)

heading: Registration of trade mark
HeadNote.description:
Registration of trade mark - Decision date is the date of registration - Person who started using mark first but subsequent to date of registration by rival contender, cannot be protected.

It is the date of registration which is the decisive date and the rival contender though started using the mark first, but subsequent to the date of registration cannot be protected on the basis of the principle of who entered the field first based on common law principle that the proprietary right can be acquired by use of mark and the first user of the mark is the proprietor.

1977 IPLR 83 (Mad) Rel. on.  [Para 35]

heading: Effect of registration
HeadNote.description: Effect of registration - Respondent got its trade mark ROFOL registered on 19-10-1992 and started its use in 2004 - Petitioner claiming use of trade mark PROFOL from April 1998 - Petitioner cannot claim superior rights based on common law principle of first use of the mark.  (Paras 37, 38)

heading: Application for rectification
HeadNote.description: Application for rectification - Application filed nine months before completion of statutory period of five years and three months - Application being premature no relief can be granted under S.47(1)(b).  (Para 39)

heading: Saving for vested rights
HeadNote.description: Saving for vested rights - In order to avail benefit of S.34, use of trademark by a person other than registered proprietor must be prior to date of use by registered proprietor or date of registration, whichever is earlier. (Para 10.2)

heading: Infringement of trademark
Suit against
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trademark - Suit against - Plea of adjournment/staying of suit by defendants - For staying of suit it is incumbent upon defendants to plead that plaintiff's trademark is invalid - No written statement filed by defendants nor raised such plea - Suit cannot be adjourned/stayed.	(Para 16)

heading: Injunction
HeadNote.description:
Injunction - Plaintiffs praying for injunction against defendants from using marks 'ITM' - Plaintiff and defendant both are running educational institutions - Words 'ITM' and 'University' are common in marks of parties - Prima facie it is seen that mark used by defendant would not deceive or cause confusion - Students seeking higher education, making investment would make enquiries of credentials of institution - Students cannot be misguided - Injunction if granted would prejudice career of students who are bonafide taking education in defendant institute approved by UGC, Government, AICTE, Bar Council etc - Further, plaintiff can be compensated monetarily if damages are sustained - Therefore injunction against defendant institute not liable to be granted.

Plaintiffs and defendants have applied for registration of trade mark as 'ITM University'. Application by plaintiff was filed after defendants. If plaintiffs are of opinion that they are absolute owners of trademark 'ITM University', then there was no necessity on behalf of plaintiff to make application for registration. Further if injunction is not granted plaintiffs can always be compensated in monetary terms if they establish that they have sustained damages due to defendant's use of trade mark. In any case perusal of advertisement by defendants clearly state 'We have no other branch or campus in India'. Defendants have declared that they do not have relationship with educational institute having similar name. Hence interest of plaintiff is sufficiently safeguarded.  
1969 (2) SCC 727, AIR 1965 SC 980, 2005 (5) SCC 420, 1994 PTC 14-260 :1994 SCC Supp (3) 215, AIR 1984 Bom. 218:1984 PTC 155, AIR 1955 SC 558, 2008 (37) PTC 413 SC 			           [Para 18,19,20,23]

heading: Bar on suit
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade mark - Bar on suit - Ss.29, 30 do not bar filing of suit - S.124 recognizes action of infringement even if defendant's mark is registered - Registration of defendant's trade mark does not bar filing of suit for infringement against him.

Even in absence of section 124, it would make no offence. Once it is held that Court has jurisdiction to entertain such action, hearing on applications for interlocutory reliefs or even suit can always be adjourned pending rectification proceedings.  [Para 10,11]

heading: Passing-off
Ad-interim relief
Pharmaceutical product
HeadNote.description: Passing-off - Ad-interim relief - Pharmaceutical product - Plaintiff is the registered proprietor of word mark "SUSTEN" - Defendant is registered proprietor of impugned mark "SUSTINEX" - Considerable difference in the colour, size and shape of both capsules and entire get up of packaging - Impugned mark is also phonetically not similar to plaintiff's mark - Hence marks are not deceptively similar - Interim relief denied on that ground.  (Paras 11, 12)

heading: Passing-off action
Essential pre-requisite
HeadNote.description:
Passing-off action - Essential pre-requisite - It is the misrepresentation by defendant which is actionable in a passing-off action - There can be no misrepresentation unless the impugned mark is put to use by defendant - Therefore, it follows that it is the date of use of impugned mark which furnishes cause of action and not the date of registration/adoption.

In an action for passing off, the plaintiff must demonstrate a misrepresentation by the defendant to the public leading or likely to lead the public to believe that the goods or the services offered by him are the goods or services of the plaintiff. The plaintiff must establish that it has suffered or is likely to suffer by the misrepresentation. It is the misrepresentation to the public that the defendant's goods are actually those of the plaintiff that is actionable and an essential pre-requisite in a passing off action. A plaintiff is not likely to suffer damages merely by the defendant adopting a deceptively similar mark. There can be no misrepresentation as required in a passing off action unless the mark is put to use. It is the use thereof in the course of trade that constitutes to misrepresentation which in turn results in damage to the plaintiff. It follows then that the mere adoption of a mark by a party does not furnish a cause of action to seek a relief against the tort of passing off.  [Para 14,15]

heading: Passing off action
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of registered trade mark - Passing off action - Alleged user by defendant for long time is immaterial - Passing off action is maintainable even if goods and services being dealt in by parties are not similar. 

2010(5) ALL MR 679 - Rel. on. (Para 24)

heading: Passing off action
HeadNote.description: Companies Act (1956), S.20 - Infringement of trade mark - Passing off action - Registration of a company under a particular name under the provisions of S.20 of Companies Act does not preclude a party from maintaining an action for infringement or passing off - Neither the Companies Act nor the Trade Marks Act, 1999, contain or even suggest such a prohibition - Held, mere registration of a mark under the Trade Marks Act, 1999, does not by itself prohibit or affect an action for passing off. (Para 34)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade mark - Plaintiffs' mark is registered mark and defendants' mark is not registered mark - Plaintiffs would be entitled to use their mark to exclusion of others whose mark is not registered - Plaintiffs may not be entitled to order of injunction against persons having identical registered trademarks - However plaintiffs is entitled to enforce right against persons whose trade mark is unregistered as if plaintiffs were sole proprietor of their registered trademark. 
AIR 2001 SC 1952, 2002(3) ALL MR 18, 2008(2) ALL MR 405, 2011(4) ALL MR 152, 2011 (6) Bom.C.R. 82, 1974 (74) Bom. L.R. 146 Ref. to. 	(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Material on record shows that Plaintiff no. 1 and 2 are sister concerns - Question as to whether licence between plaintiff no. 1 and 2 is valid is matter between them - Both plaintiffs have jointly filed this suit - Contention that trademark is registered under name of plaintiff no. 2 and license issued by plaintiff no. 2 to 1 is bogus - Contention liable to be rejected. 	(Para 16)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade mark - Contention that trademark of plaintiffs is derived from generic term of medicines which are used in product - Defendants only produced similar labels - Defendants have not produced any material to show that product on which he is relying have acquired reputation by user in market - Hence contention is liable to be rejected.
AIR 1960 SC 142 Ref. to. 	(Paras 17, 18)

heading: Injunction application
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade mark - Injunction application - Defendant's mark is phonetically similar to registered trade mark of plaintiff - Carton of defendant is imitation of carton of plaintiff which is registered under Copyrights Act - Perusal of 2 cartons shows great possibility of consumer being confused - Statutory rights of plaintiff are being infringed - Balance of convenience and irreparable injury also tilts in favour of plaintiff - No prejudice would be caused to defendant if injunction is granted to plaintiff - Injunction is liable to be granted to plaintiff.
2003(3) ALL MR 421, 3 BLR 220, 2010(6) ALL MR 679, 2002 (24) PTC 510 Disting.
AIR 1998 Delhi 126 Ref. to.		 	(Paras 28, 29)

heading: Name of Company
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Name of Company - If name of the company of which registration is sought resembles to a registered trade-mark, then the registration of the company in that name can be refused on an information being given by Registrar of Trade-Mark - A person who is owner of the registered trade-mark also has been given a remedy of getting the registration of such a company with such a name being cancelled. Companies Act (1956), Ss.20, 22.	(Para 11)

heading: Scope of S.29
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade mark - Scope of S.29 - If the defendant was the registered trade-mark as a part of his trade-name, but he does not deal in the same goods in respect of which the trade-mark is registered, then it does not amount to infringement for the purpose of Trade Marks Act.

In order to claim that use of a registered trade-mark as part of trade-name by the Defendants amounts to infringement, the Plaintiffs have to establish that the Defendants are dealing in the goods in respect of which the mark is registered. In other words, if the Defendants are not dealing in goods in respect of which the trade-mark is registered, then the use of the registered trade-mark as a part of trade-name by the Defendant would not amount to infringement. In the present case admittedly the Defendants are not dealing in the goods in respect of which the trade-mark of the Plaintiffs is registered and therefore, there is no question of the Plaintiffs being entitled to any temporary injunction.  [Para 14]

heading: Interpretation of Statute
HeadNote.description:
Interpretation of Statute - Generalia Specialibus non derogant is a cardinal principle of interpretation - General provision will always yield to a special provision.

Use of a registered trade-mark as a part of trade-name was a known phenomena. Passing off action was initiated in such cases. A special provision has now been made to deal with that situation by incorporating sub-section 5 of Section 29 and therefore, so far as subject of using of registered trade-mark as a trade-name is concerned, provision is contained in sub-section 5 of Section 29 and therefore on that subject no other provision would apply. Generalia Specialibus non derogant is a cardinal principle of interpretation. It means that the general provision will always yield to a special provision. Construed in accordance with the fundamental principle, a special provision governing cases of a defendant using a registered mark as a part of his trade-name is incorporated in Section 29(5) and therefore, that subject will be governed only by that provision and therefore reliance on any other provision including Section 29(4) is ruled out.  [Para 14]

heading: Jointly owned trade marks
HeadNote.description: Jointly owned trade marks - Prima facie, if the certificate of registration of a trade mark is in the name of a firm or in the names of persons as partners of a firm, it would be deemed to include the names of all the partners of the firm from time to time.            (Para 19)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade mark - Use of a registered trade mark would constitute an infringement if it indicates a connection in the course of trade between the person and his goods or services irrespective of his intention.

The intention to use a mark as a trademark is not the only factor that constitutes infringement. A registered trademark is infringed by a person if he uses it in such a manner as to render the use of the mark likely to be taken as a trademark. In other words the use of a registered trademark would constitute an infringement if it indicates a connection in the course of trade between the person and his goods or services irrespective of his intention.                 [Para 25]

heading: Discriptive sub-brand
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of registered trade mark - Discriptive sub-brand - A sub-brand does not fall outside the ambit of a trade mark if it is used as a mark - In fact, a reference to it as a sub-brand would indicate that it is a brand name/mark.

A sub-brand does not fall outside the ambit of a trademark if it is used as a mark. In fact, a reference to it as a sub-brand would indicate that it is a brand name/mark.

The test is not whether a person terms the use of a mark as a brand name or a sub-brand. If the use of a mark is to distinguish or is capable of distinguishing the goods or services of a person, it is a trademark amenable to the provisions of the Act. That, it is a sub-brand makes no difference. A view to the contrary would virtually erode, not merely the value of trademarks, but their very existence by the simple expedient of an infringer adding to his "main brand" any embellishment constituting it then as a "sub-brand". The Act knows no such thing as a sub-brand.               [Para 30,38]

heading: Temporary injunction
Grant of
Challenge
HeadNote.description: suit for infringement of trade mark - Temporary injunction - Grant of - Challenge - Plaintiffs using trade name 'City Collection' whereas defendant using trade name 'Orange City Mobile Collection' - Plaintiffs claimed to have suffered loss in business and reputation due to deceptive similarity in trade names - No material produced by plaintiffs to prove said loss - Not a single instance pleaded to show that customers were misled or deceived by use of similar trade name by defendant - Further, plaintiffs are carrying on business of sale of mobile phones, cameras, perfumes, etc. - Whereas defendant is dealing with mobile phones only - Use of word 'mobile' by defendant in his trade name can be considered as distinguishing feature in both names - Defendant also willing to increase fonts of words 'Orange' and 'Mobile' in its logo to make entire trade name conspicuously visible - No prima facie case made out by plaintiffs for grant of interim relief - Order of injunction, quashed with direction to defendant to increase font size in its trade name. 			(Paras 15, 16, 17, 18)

heading: Injunction
Prayer for
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Injunction - Prayer for - Plaintiff alleged that defendant had been using trade mark similar to that of plaintiff - Packaging of both products were almost similar, having same logo, same colour in background and same artistic work - Only difference that plaintiff's packaging discloses "Kaveri Mehandi Kone" whereas packaging of defendant discloses "Kaberi Mehandi Kone" - User of plaintiff's trademark and copyright is not only prior in point of time but registration of copyright itself is prior in time to that of defendant - Trademark of defendant is not even registered - Defendant had been deliberately using name "Kaberi" with view to mislead and confuse public at large - Infringement of trademark and copyright of plaintiff made out - Hence, injunction granted against defendant from committing further infringement of trademark and copyright of plaintiff. AIR 1991 Bombay 76, 2011(7) ALL MR 514 Rel. on. 			(Paras 32, 33, 36, 37, 41, 45, 56)

heading: Descriptiveness or generic
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Descriptiveness or generic - Plaintiff alleged that defendant had been using trade mark "Kaberi Mehandi Kone" almost similar with that of plaintiff's mark "Kaveri Mehandi Kone" - Submission made that word "KAVERI" is generic word and cannot be exclusively used by plaintiff as trademark - Not acceptable - Defendant himself had applied for registration of trademark containing word "Kaberi" - Therefore, he cannot be allowed to urge that word "KAVERI" is descriptive or generic term. 1997 PTC (17) 540) Ref. to. 	(Para 48)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade mark - Suit for action for infringement and passing off - Suit filed on basis of deed of assignment executed in favour of plaintiff - Suit filed by assignee pending application for registration, held, is maintainable.

Section 45 does not confer title to the trade marks assigned or acquired by transmission. The registration granted by the Registrar under section 45 is proof of title to the trade mark of the assignee or the person who acquires the same by transmission. Thus a person who has acquired title to a trade mark by assignment or transmission cannot be non-suited for want of title per se on the ground that the assignment or transmission is not entered on the register. This is clear from the plain language of section 45 (1). The opening words : "Where a person becomes entitled by assignment or transmission to a registered trade mark ..." posit the acquisition of title thereto by assignment or transmission. This is further clear from sub-section (1) which requires the Registrar to register the title of a person who acquires the trade mark by assignment or transmission "on proof of title". Thus the acquisition of title to a trade mark by assignment or transmission precedes and is essential to an application under section 45. There is a distinction between an unregistered document not affecting the property which is the subject matter thereof and such a document not being inadmissible in evidence. It is important to note that section 45 does not provide that a document of the nature referred to in sub-section (2) does not affect the trade mark acquired by assignment or transmission. This is in contrast to section 49 of the Registration Act which provides that no document required to be registered under section 17 thereof or under the Transfer of Property Act shall "affect" any immovable property comprised therein.  [Para 14,15]

heading: Documents requiring registration
HeadNote.description: Documents requiring registration - S.45 of Trade Marks Act grants discretion to Court to receive a document in evidence even though in respect thereof no entry was made in the Register. (Paras 15 to 18)

heading: Scope of S.134
HeadNote.description: Suit for infringement of trade mark - Scope of S.134 - S.134 does not deal with the question as to who can file a suit for infringement - Held, S.134 of the Act deals essentially with question of jurisdiction and the Court within the territorial jurisdiction in which an action for infringement may be filed. 2001(2) ALL MR 592 - Ref. to. (Para 31)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Delay in initiation of proceedings - In absence of acquiescence mere delay is never a defence - Notice of motion taken up for final hearing after six years - Plaintiff cannot be denied relief merely because interim relief application could not be heard earlier.		(Para 28)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Trade mark "EVANOVA" for medical product for treatment of menopause and defendants trade mark "ECONOVA" for treatment of bacterial vaginosis - Both visually and phonetically both marks are similar - Likelihood of confusion is extremely high in view of illiteracy amongst women in villages - Even while writing prescription two words 'VA' and 'CO' in the middle may not be easily decipherable resulting in confusion of pharmacists - Person buying drug would not know what the price or packaging of one drug shall be as distinguished to the other. 			(Paras 16, 18, 20, 23, 25)

heading: Deceptively similar marks
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Deceptively similar marks - Before adopting mark defendant had taken search in the office of Registrar of Trade Marks - He had also applied for registration before using the mark - Bonafides of defendant and honesty of adoption is completely irrelevant.	(Para 26.2)

heading: Jurisdiction under S.134
HeadNote.description: Letters Patent (Bombay), Cl.12 - Infringement of trade mark - Jurisdiction under S.134 - S.134 conferring jurisdiction makes only reference to place of plaintiff's business - S.134 confers jurisdiction in addition, independently of S.20 of CPC and Clause 12 of Letters Patent - Issue is required to be considered by reading provisions of S.134 of Act alone - Plaintiff can file suit at place where he carries business - This is without reference to cause of action - Defendant's interpretation of S.134 that cause of action must arise at corporate office of plaintiff for plaintiff to be able to file suit, is liable to be rejected.(Paras 25 to 29)

heading: "District Court"
HeadNote.description:
"District Court" - District Court as contemplated by S.134 of Trade Marks Act is not synonymous to District Judge as a Persona Designeta - Judicial functions of District Judge and Additional/Ad-hoc District Judge are concurrent in generic.

(a)	If scheme of provisions of Goa Civil Courts act is discretely seen, it would reveal that baring that there shall be only one register (file) for entire District Court.

(b)	Judicial functions of District Judge and Additional/Ad-hoc District Judge are concurrent in generic.

(c)	Only distinction is that Additional District Judge has to hear cases made over to him by the District Judge.

(d)	District Court as contemplated by Section 134 of Trade Marks Act is not synonymous to District Judge as a Persona Designeta.

(e)	Reading Section 134 in order to mean to exclude one and all Judges already exercising the powers of District Court from the definition of District Court would mean imputing word "Court" to mean "judge" or substitute the term "District Court" by the term "Principal District Judge" or first amongst the District Judges of the District Court.

(f)	Such substitution does not appear to be the intention of legislature. Such act of judicial substitution would mean legislating upon legislation distinct from judicial function of interpretation. 				 [Para 22,23]

heading: Clash between registered trade mark user and unregistered contender
HeadNote.description:
Clash between registered trade mark user and unregistered contender - Registered user has a prima facie strong case against unregistered user particularly when prior use is proved.

Present is a case of clash between a registered trade mark user and unregistered contender, and the defendants have proved from documentary evidence their invention, use and registration, all prior in time than the plaintiffs. Registered user has a prima facie strong case against unregistered user particularly when prior use is proved.

It is proved that plaintiffs' claim is based on absolute right to use and hence a claim in nature of passing which action would ordinarily be maintainable even in the absence of registration, however plaintiffs have to prove :-

(i)	Own invention before use which plaintiffs have failed to show.

(ii)	Antecedent use.

Plaintiffs have failed to prove strong case of prior invention and use both as required for interim relief. Plaintiffs have not demonstrated any grounds as to how they dismantle the defendants' right recognized under a statute. 2005(1) ALL MR 758 - Ref. to.							 [Para 25,26,27]

heading: Interim injunction
HeadNote.description: Interim injunction - Appellant as prior user of word "skyline" seeking restraint order - Appellant running business school with prefix "Skyline" but its institute neither recognized by AICTE/UGC nor affiliated to any university - Respondent's College recognized by AICTE and had admitted 240 students in five years Course - Appellants' claim that word "Skyline" is not a generic word belied by factual data that it was being used by thousands of persons and institutions in different countries as part of their trading names and business activities - Held refusal of temporary injunction was proper and direction to respondents not to start new courses and to append note to advertisement that respondent institute is not related to appellant was liable to be set aside.	(Paras 18, 19, 20, 22, 23)

heading: Registration of trade mark
HeadNote.description: Registration of trade mark - Actual use of mark - Held, the right to have a mark registered is not dependent upon the actual use of the mark at the time of registration. (1911) 28 RPC 512 - Ref. to. (Paras 8 to 11)

heading: Interpretation of Statute
Meaning of
HeadNote.description:
Interpretation of Statute - The expression "date of registration" - Meaning of - Held, the expression "date of registration in S.34(b) of the Act must mean the date of the application for registration. 	
1977 IPLR 83 - Rel. on. (Paras 14, 15)

heading: Infringement of Trade Mark
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of Trade Mark - If strong prima facie case of infringement of Trade Mark is not made out, one cannot ignore the policy of law e.g. the Competition Act, 2003 to promote healthy competition amongst traders and sustain it for industrial growth - Held, the plaintiffs must demonstrate that due to use of the Trade Mark by defendants, the sale of the plaintiffs' product have diminished.

No prima facie case is made out to establish that due to the defendants selling drinking water in the trade name "OXYCOOL" in the market since June, 2009 has in any way diminished the extent of sales of the plaintiffs/respondents' product "MANIKCHAND OXYRICH" packaged drinking water sold in bottles. If strong prima facie case of infringement of Trade Mark is not made out, one cannot ignore the policy of law e.g. the Competition Act (12 of 2003) to promote healthy competition amongst traders and sustain it for industrial growth by controlling monopolies, preventing practices having adverse effect on competition and to serve social and economic justice, changing policy of law may be relevant to decide motion for injunction by exercise of sound judicial discretion. Likelihood of confusion or deception in the present case is ruled out as buyers of packaged drinking water belong to a class of its own, mostly belonging to middle or upper class, fairly educated using due diligence, knowing what he or she is going to buy, but may not have clear recollection as to which product he or she had bought earlier or what had been advertised for sale of drinking water in packaged bottles. The terms "Oxygen" is common and is known as H2O in Chemistry and consequently the plaintiffs cannot claim any exclusive title to use the word "OXY" by reason of their having partly used it for labeling their product since the registration of the Trade Mark. Phonetic and visual similarity or dissimilarity will play pivotal role to distinguish one mark from the other. Reading and comparing getup and variations of the script style, arrangement of words, fonts on labels used by the plaintiffs and the defendants would certainly overrule the possibility of any average buyer from being deceived in to assuming connection between the "OXYRICH" and "OXYCOOL" on assuming that they enumerated from same source. Label of defendants is good and distinctly indicate that packaged drinking water do not originate from the plaintiffs but have been produced by the defendants giving their detailed address and ISI mark for quality. Two marks when placed side by side may exhibit various differences on comparison. Marks are remembered by general or some significant details than by photographic recollection of the whole. The plaintiff No.1 must prima facie demonstrate that the Trade Mark owned by him has acquired goodwill and reputation attached to the term "MANIKCHAND OXYRICH" (in this case) in the mind of the purchasers and furthermore that the defendants goods have misrepresented or confused such purchasers leading them to believe that "OXYCOOL" packaged drinking water offered by the defendants is same as that manufactured and supplied by the plaintiffs. The plaintiffs must also demonstrate that due to use of the Trade Mark "OXYCOOL" by defendants, the sale of the plaintiffs' product have diminished since the defendants started selling "OXYCOOL".						 [Para 12]

heading: Infringement of Trade Mark
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of Trade Mark - Order of interim injunction for infringement of a Trade Mark can be passed only when plaintiffs have made out a strong prima facie case in their favour to the effect that if interim injunction is not granted as prayed against defendants, it would cause irreparable damage to the plaintiffs - Held, the defendants are entitled to claim benefit of even small variations in their Trade Mark from that of the plaintiffs' Trade Mark to plead that there would be no confusion in the mind of prospective buyers nor deception, as claimed.

The order for interim injunction for infringement of a Trade Mark can be passed only when plaintiffs have made out a strong prima facie case in their favour to the effect that if interim injunction is not granted as prayed against defendants it would cause irreparable damage to the plaintiffs. There must be relevant prima facie material to support the exercise of discretion of granting interim injunction. The plaintiffs/respondents have not brought to our notice any document indicating diminishing profits in their account due to the alleged infringement and user of their Trade Mark by the defendants. Unless it is prima facie shown that the plaintiffs have suffered actual losses due to the alleged unlawful acts of the defendants using or infringing their Trade Mark, grant of interim injunction can not be justified as speculative or unproven damages can not be considered. No prima facie case is made out to establish that the defendants have infringed the copyright of the artistic work titled as "MANIKCHAND OXYRICH HEALTHY DRINKING WATER" by using "OXYCOOL" Trade Mark to sell mineral water/packaged drinking water in view of the distinguishing features between the Trade marks claimed by the plaintiffs and the defendants respectively. By obtaining the Trade Mark in the name as "MANIKCHAND OXYRICH" the word "OXY" can not be claimed as exclusively belonging to the plaintiffs. The word "OXY or OXYGEN" is used frequently without any reference to the plaintiffs or their product. The plaintiffs can not claim monopoly of such generic term. The Court cannot readily infer that use of word like "OXY" by a rival in the business as part of his trade name would be likely to deceive or create confusion. The defendants are entitled to claim benefit of even small variations in their Trade Mark from that of the plaintiffs' Trade Mark to plead that there would be no confusion in the mind of prospective buyers nor deception, as claimed. (1993)3 SCC 161 - Ref. to.						 [Para 18,19]

heading: Infringement of trade mark and passing off
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark and passing off - Prayer for permanent injunction - Notice of motion of plaintiff pending for nine years - Held, simply because Court has not taken up matter expeditiously, plaintiff cannot be denied a relief to which he might be otherwise entitled. (Para 8)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Locus standi to file suit - Plaintiff claimed to be proprietor of trade mark with word "Datamatics" - Deed of assignment shows that original proprietor of trademark "Datamatics Ltd." was merged into "Datamatics Technologies Ltd." which was former name of plaintiff company - Certificate of Registrar of Companies shows change of name of plaintiff company into "Datamatics Global Services Limited." which was unregistered - No legal bar on Court from recognizing or giving effect to assignment or transmission where subsequent proprietor of trademark has not been registered - Plaintiff, being successor of original proprietor of registered trademark by virtue of merger, entitled to file suit for infringement of trade mark. 	(Para 6)

heading: Descriptiveness
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Descriptiveness - Plaintiff claimed that defendant used word "Datamatics" as part of its trading name - Defendant took defence that word "Datamatics" is common in field of computer, internet and worldwide web - Submission made that defendant itself has applied for registration of mark with word "Datamatics" as part of it - However, defendant has not applied for registration of mark "Datamatics", but mark "Royal Datamatics Pvt. Ltd.", which is distinct from former mark - Materials on record enough to show that several companies are using word "Datamatics" as part of their trading name and style - Defence of descriptiveness of word "Datamatics", established. 	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Honest and concurrent user - Defendant using word "Datamatics" as part of its trading name for past more than 19 years - Prima facie, nothing shows that defendant has opted word "Datamatics" dishonestly to earn profit or trade on, on reputation or goodwill of plaintiff - Material on record shows that many similar service providers were actually using word as part of their trade names - Adoption of word "Datamatics" by defendant, was bonafide and honest, prima facie believable. 			(Para 9)

heading: Suit for injunction
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Suit for injunction - Plaintiff was successor of original proprietor of registered trademark "Datamatics Ltd." by virtue of merger - Defendant allegedly used word "Datamatics" as part of its trading name namely, "Royal Datamatics Pvt. Ltd." - Defence of honest and concurrent user - Tenable, as defendant using word "Datamatics" for last more than 19 years - Denial to defendant of use of its own trading  name while providing services is likely to cause greater harm to defendant than corresponding harm to plaintiff - injunction not granted. 			(Paras 6, 7, 8, 9, 11)

heading: Application for injunction
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Application for injunction - Plaintiff claimed that defendant has been using trade mark similar to that of plaintiff in business of manufacturing, trading and dealing in plaster, lime, mortar, limestone, cement, wall putty, wall coating etc - Trade mark used by plaintiff is titled as "MOR CHHAP" whereas mark used by defendant is "SUPER MOR CHHAP" - Trade mark of plaintiff is not only registered but user of said mark is also prior in point of time to that by defendant - Device of picture of Peacock, writing of words "MOR CHHAP" and colour combination of label of defendant are similar to that of plaintiff - Mark of defendant is structurally phonetically and visually similar to registered mark of plaintiff and is likely to cause confusion in minds of customers - Defendant has ex facie committed infringement of trade mark of plaintiff knowing well registration of same since long and that plaintiff have raised objection for registration of trade mark of defendant - No material produced on record that any hardship is caused to defendant if injunction is granted to plaintiff - Plaintiff is entitled to protection u/S.29 - Defendant is at liberty to manufacture and sell his product by using any other different mark. 			(Paras 21, 24, 25, 27, 28, 31, 33, 34, 35)

heading: Plea of descriptiveness
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Plea of descriptiveness - Case of plaintiff that defendant had been using mark "SUPER MOR CHHAP" similar to plaintiff's registered mark "MOR CHHAP" - Defendant took plea that two word "MOR" "CHHAP" are very common in nature and are fully used by public - Not acceptable as defendant himself has applied for registration of impugned mark containing words "MOR CHHAP". 	(Para 28)

heading: Grant of injunction
Plea of delay
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trade mark - Grant of injunction - Plea of delay - Defendant had been using offending mark "SUPER MOR CHHAP" similar to plaintiff's registered mark "MOR CHHAP" since 20th Feb 2008 - However, plaintiff filed suit belatedly for declaration and injunction against defendant on 17th July, 2015 - Defendant was fully aware of registration of trade mark of plaintiff and his objection raised in application filed by defendant for registration of his trade mark - In spite of that, he continued to use offending mark - Mere delay in bringing action is not sufficient to defeat grant of injunction if it prima facie appears that adoption of mark was itself dishonest - Therefore, plea of delay, not acceptable. (2004) 3 SCC 90 Rel. on. 	(Paras 30, 31)

heading: Infringement of trade mark
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of trade mark - Difference between applicability of sub-section (4) and (5) of Trade Marks Act - Sub-section (4) applies when a mark is used during course of trade in relation to dissimilar goods or services - Whereas sub-section (5) applies specifically to case where registered trade mark is used as a part of business/corporate name provided business of infringer is of dealing with goods or services in respect of which trade mark is registered - Thus, sub-section (4) applies in "Trade Mark versus Mark" situation - Whereas sub-section (5) applies to Trade Mark versus Trade/Corporate/Business name" situation - Interpretation of both the sub-sections given.

	Sub-Section (5) applies when a person uses a registered trade mark as his trade name or part of his trade name or name of his business concern or part of the name of his business concern provided his trade or business is of dealing with goods or services in respect of which the trade mark is registered. If both the conditions are satisfied, it is not necessary to prove anything further for establishing the infringement. It is not necessary to prove that the use of trade mark as a trade or business name is likely to cause any confusion on the part of the public. It is not necessary to prove that such user takes unfair advantage or such use is detrimental to the distinctive character of the registered trademark or its repute.
