HeadNote.act_name: Tamil Nadu Prevention of Dangerous Activities of Boot Leggers Drug Offenders Forest Offenders Gundas Immoral Traffic Offenders and Slum Grabbers Act (1982)
heading: Detention
HeadNote.description:
Detention - Habeas Corpus petition, seeking quashment of detention order - Question of making a representation to the Advisory Board arises only after the order of detention had been passed and served on the detenu - High Court clearly in error in quashing the order of detention - Appeal partly allowed.

In this case the detention order passed on 09.07.1999 and on 06.07.1999 the mother of the detenue sent representation to the Chief Minister, a copy of which was marked to the Director General of Police (DGP), the Advisory Board and Chief Justice of the High Court. The High Court found that since two of the authorities had received representation it must be presumed that the DGP would have received the representation in the usual course. A presumption was drawn that DGP had been served the representation and accordingly it was held that the DGP must have received the representation and since that was not taken note of, there was violation of Art.22(5) of the Constitution. Accordingly, order of detention was quashed. Further appeal, held the question of making a representation to the Advisory Board arises only after the order of detention had been passed and served on the detenu. High Court, therefore, was clearly in error in quashing the order of detention. Appeal partly allowed.   [Para 2,5]

heading: Transplantation of kidney
HeadNote.description:
Transplantation of kidney - Donor and donee are not "near relatives" but are closely related to each other - Existence of objections of relatives of donor and fact that other relatives of donor have not come forward with proposal for transplantation - Conclusion cannot be drawn that bond of love and affection could not be established.

Both the Act and the Rules, seek to bring about a healthy balance between the need for transplantation of human organs and tissues in order to save lives on the one hand and the public interest in ensuring that this does not become a facade for exploitation or for trafficking in human organs and tissues. The views of the next of kin are entitled to deference but this is not to suggest that the Authorization Committee, once a disagreement is expressed, would have no power to take an independent decision based on the best interest of the donor and the donee. Ultimately, the Authorization Committee has to take a judicious decision after considering all the facts and circumstances.

In the present case, the admitted position is that the donor and the donee are not 'near relatives' as defined in Section 2(i) of the Act. The Authorization Committee took note of the fact that the donor and the donee are cousins. The fact that other relatives of the donor including his brother and his two minor children who have objected to the proposed transplant have not disputed the relationship between the donor and the donee, is a matter of some significance. The Authorization Committee has erred in coming to the conclusion that a bond of love and affection could not be established. The Authorization Committee seems to have formed that view on the basis that : (i) the elder brother and the minor daughters of the donor had opposed the donation of a kidney by the donor to the donee; and (ii) the donee has his own relatives who have not come forward to donate a kidney. The existence of the objections of the relatives of the donor and the fact that other relatives of the donee have not come forward with a proposal for transplantation, would not, displace a case of affection and attachment between the donor and the donee. These circumstances which were borne in mind by the Authorization Committee are relevant to the ultimate decision which the Authorization Committee has to take on whether to grant its approval. The Authorization Committee however, erred in holding that the circumstances on which it relied upon did not establish a bond of love and affection between the donor and the donee. In the circumstances, that it would be necessary for the Authorization Committee to have a fresh look at the entirety of the proposal having regard to the provisions of the Act and the Rules. 			 	  [Para 11,13,15]

heading: Transplantation of human organs
HeadNote.description:
Transplantation of human organs - Registration of Hospitals is necessary - However, individual surgeons are not required to be authorized by appropriate authority.

 The provisions of Transplantation of Human Organs Act (1994) and Rules framed there under clearly highlight the importance of a properly equipped hospital for undertaking surgical operations for transplantation of human organs. An elaborate procedure is prescribed for registration of a hospital. Unless such registration for a hospital is secured a surgical operation of transplantation of human organs there is not permissible. The Act and the Rules however do not provide individual surgeons who would undertake the surgical operations, are required to be specifically authorized by the appropriate authority. The Rules of (1995) do not prohibit an expert who is member of a team of experts of a registered hospital, from performing transplantation operation in any other registered hospital. At the same time in view of the rules referred to above an expert who is not member of a team of any registered hospital, no matter, how much experience he has in this field, is not permitted to perform transplantation operation in any registered hospital.  [Para 7,10,11]

The position that emerges is that if an expert in this field as defined under rule 9-C is recognized as member of team of experts in a registered hospital, he would be able to perform surgical operations involving transplantation of kidney in any other registered hospital. The registered hospital has to ascertain as to whether such expert is a member of a team of experts in any other registered hospital. On ascertainment of this information, a registered hospital is able to permit such expert who is not member of their own team to perform transplantation operations in their hospital. The appropriate authority can not raise any objection to this practice.  [Para 11]

heading: Removal of organ for donation
HeadNote.description:
Removal of organ for donation - Prior approval of Authorisation Committee of State - Jurisdiction to entertain application - Application has to be made to Authorisation Committee of State to which the donor and donee belong and not to Authorisation Committee of State in which recipient intends to undergo treatment.

The object of the Statute is crystal clear that it intends to prevent commercial dealings in Human Organs. The Authorisation Committee is, therefore, required to satisfy that the real purpose of the donor authorizing removal of the organ is by reason of affection or attachment towards the recipient or for any other special reason. Such special reasons can by no stretch of imagination encompass commercial elements. Above being the intent, the inevitable conclusion is that the Authorisation Committees of the State to which the donor and the donee belong have to take the exercise to find out whether approval is to be accorded. Such Committee shall be in a better position to ascertain the true intent and the purpose for the authorisation to remove the organ and whether any commercial element is involved or not. They would be in a better position to lift the veil of projected affection or attachment and the so-called special reasons and focus on the true intent. The burden is on the applicants to establish the real intent by placing relevant materials for consideration of the Authorisation Committee. Whether there exists any affection or attachment or special reason is within the special knowledge of the applicants, and a heavy burden lies on them to establish it. Several relevant factors like relationship if any (need not be near relationship for which different considerations have been provided for), period of acquaintance, degree of association, reciprocity of feelings, gratitude and similar human factors and bounds can throw light on the issue. It is always open to the Authorisation Committee considering the application to seek information/materials from Authorisation Committees of other States/State Governments, as the case may be, for effective decision in the matter. In case any State is not covered by the operation of the Act or the Rules, the operative executive instructions/Government orders will hold the field. As the object is to find out the true intent behind the donor's willingness to donate the organ, it would not be in line with the legislative intent to require the Authorisation Committee of the State where the recipient is undergoing medical treatment to decide the issue whether approval is to be accorded. 	 [Para 12]

heading: Object of statute
HeadNote.description:
Donation of human organ - Object of statute - Is to rule out commercial dealings in human organs - Amendment of rules to provide for disclosure of incomes and vocations suggested.

Since the object of the Statute is to rule out commercial dealings, it would be desirable to require the donor and recipient to give details of their financial positions and vocations. It would be appropriate for the Legislature to accordingly amend the Rules and the Form I, so that requirement for disclosing incomes and vocations for some previous financial years (say 3 years) gets statutorily incorporated. This would help the Authorisation Committees to assess whether any commercial dealing is involved or not. Until legislative steps are taken, all Authorisation Committees shall, in terms of this judgment require the applicants to furnish their income particulars for the previous three financial years and the vocations.  [Para 14]

heading: Constitution of Authorisation Committee
HeadNote.description:
Constitution of Authorisation Committee - Presence of Administrative Official would be helpful in deciding issues effectively.

In certain States administrative officials are nominated as members of the Authorisation Committee. That appears to be the proper course as the Authorisation Committee has to decide both on the medical angle regarding need for transplantation, and the existence or otherwise of the essential ingredients to be established under sub-section (3) of Section 9 of the Act. Presence of an administrative official in the Authorisation Committee would be helpful in deciding the issues more effectively. [Para 15]

heading: Not necessary
HeadNote.description:
Prior consent of Central Govt. - To maintain a proceeding u/S.9 or u/S.7 of IBC - Not necessary - Stipulation of prior consent is provided u/S.16G of Tea Act which deals with winding up or liquidation of tea estates - However, proceeding u/S.9 of IBC is not limited to winding up which is only a last resort - Primary focus is to ensure revival of corporate debtor through a corporate insolvency resolution process - Provisions of IBC have overriding effect - Condition of S.16G of Tea Act, not applicable.

	Section 16G(1)(c) refers to the proceeding for winding up of such company or for the appointment of receiver in respect thereof. Therefore, as such, the proceedings under Section 9 of the IBC shall not be limited and/or restricted to winding up and/or appointment of receiver only. The winding up/liquidation of the company shall be the last resort and only on an eventuality when the corporate insolvency resolution process fails. The primary focus of the legislation while enacting the IBC is to ensure revival and continuation of the corporate debtor by protecting the corporate debtor from its own management and from a corporate debt by liquidation and such corporate insolvency resolution process is to be completed in a time-bound manner. Therefore, the entire "corporate insolvency resolution process" as such cannot be equated with "winding up proceedings". Therefore, considering Section 238 of the IBC, which is a subsequent Act to the Tea Act, 1953, shall be applicable and the provisions of the IBC shall have an overriding effect over the Tea Act, 1953. Any other view would frustrate the object and purpose of the IBC. If the submission that before initiation of proceedings under Section 9 of the IBC, the consent of the Central Government as provided under Section 16G(1)(c) of the Tea Act is to be obtained, in that case, the main object and purpose of the IBC, namely, to complete the "corporate insolvency resolution process" in a time-bound manner, shall be frustrated. The sum and substance of the above discussion would be that the provisions of the IBC would have an overriding effect over the Tea Act, 1953 and that no prior consent of the Central Government before initiation of the proceedings under Section 7 or Section 9 of the IBC would be required and even without such consent of the Central Government, the insolvency proceedings under Section 7 or Section 9 of the IBC initiated by the operational creditor shall be maintainable. 	 [Para 7.4]

heading: Necessity
HeadNote.description: Consent of Central Govt. u/S.16G - In winding up petition - Necessity - Notification u/S.16E issued authorizing Tea Board to take over management and control of tea estates - However, due to pending litigations, actual management could not be taken over - Actual taking over is sine qua non - In its absence, conditions of Sec.16G would not apply. heading: Insurance policy covering claim against fire etc.
HeadNote.description: Insurance policy covering claim against fire etc. - Claimants claiming amount towards loss/damages in view of suspension of their business due to terrorist activities in Jammu & Kashmir - Said insurance policy having been assigned in favour of bank; in view of Ss.130 and 135 of Transfer of Property Act, Bank is entitled to the amount directly from Insurance Company - Bank need not file suit and obtain decree in its favour. (1996)11 SCC 23 - Rel. on.			(Paras 31, 38 to 43)

heading: Expression "unauthorised occupation" under S.2(g)
HeadNote.description:
Expression "unauthorised occupation" under S.2(g) - It connotes occupation by any person of the "Public Premises" defined under S.2(e) of the Act without authority for such occupation - Government Company or Corporation must not act as a private landlord and their act while determining authority to occupy public premises and seeking eviction of the occupant therefrom must be informed by reason and guided by the public interest.

The expression "unauthorised occupation" under section 2(g) connotes occupation by any person of the "public premises" defined under section 2(e) of the Act without authority for such occupation.  It implies occupation by a person who has entered into occupation of any public premises without lawful authority as well as occupation which is permissive at the inception but has ceased to be so.  It also covers any person, whose legal authority to remain in the public premises has been determined by the landlord for committing breach of the terms and conditions of the contract or tenancy as case may be.  In other words, an "unauthorised occupant" is one whose tenancy has come to an end by efflux of time or has been terminated by giving notice as provided in law.  Such occupant would have no further statutory protection from being evicted under the Rent Act or where tenancy has been determined on the ground of creating unlawful sub-tenancy by giving notice under section 106 and which is not protected under section 108 of the T.P. Act.  The requirement in law for eviction under the provisions contained in the Act is that the occupation of public premises should be unauthorised within the meaning of section 2(g).  It is also necessary that the Government company or the corporation must not act as a private landlord and their act while determining authority to occupy public premises and seeking eviction of the occupant therefrom must be informed by reasons and guided by the public interest.

Insofar as present case is concerned, the submissions advanced by the learned counsel for the parties were centered around the provisions contained in Sections 106 and 108 of the T.P. Act.  It was submitted that the notice issued under section 106 of the T.P. Act, in the present case, cannot be sustained since the sub-tenancy of respondent no.2 in the premises was perfectly legal and was protected under section 108 of the said Act.  Section 108 of the T.P. Act provides for rights and liabilities of the lessor and the lessee and clause (j) thereof provides for the lessee to transfer absolutely or by way of mortgage or sub-lease the whole or any part of his interest in the property, and any transferee of such interest or part may again transfer it subject to a contract, if any, to the contrary.  The lessee does not, by reason only of such transfer, cease to be subject to any of the liabilities attaching to the lease.  It further provides that nothing in this clause shall be deemed to authorise a tenant having an untransferable right of occupant to assign his interest as tenant or lessee.  In short, in the absence of a contract to the contrary the lessee has a right to transfer absolutely or sub-lease the whole or part of his interest in the property.  AIR 1981 SC 670 - Referred to. [Para 10,11]

heading: Agreement to sell property
HeadNote.description:
Agreement to sell property - Plaintiff acquiring possession under S.53A - Suit simpliciter without claiming relief of specific performance - Not maintainable.

A suit simpliciter to protect the possession on the basis of principles laid down under Section 53A of the Transfer of Property Act, without claiming the relief of specific performance of contract or agreement is not tenable in law and naturally, therefore, the Court is not supposed to pass any interim reliefs or interlocutory reliefs in favour of the plaintiff in such a suit.

AIR 1988 Bom. 296 (Single Judge) not good law in view of 1986(1) Bom C.R. 533 (Double Bench).  [Para 6]

heading: Effect
HeadNote.description: Decree of specific performance - Absence of stipulation in agreement of sale about delivery of possession upon execution of transaction - Effect - Contention that while granting decree, giving direction for delivery of possession to buyer would amount to reading something more than what has stated in agreement, cannot be accepted - As per S.54 of TP Act, when parties entered into agreement of sale of immovable property, obligation of seller to deliver possession of property which is subject matter of agreement, upon execution of sale deed is built in - Therefore, unless contrary appears in agreement to sale, it has to be deemed that seller has agreed to deliver possession of property to purchaser upon execution of sale deed.  AIR 1924 Madras 360, AIR 1983 Calcutta 166 Ref. to. 	(Paras 9, 10, 12, 14)

heading: Agreement of Sale
HeadNote.description:
Agreement of Sale - Suit for specific performance of - Two days after filing suit sale of same property by owner to second purchaser - Principle of lis pendens will apply - Second sale will not have overriding effect on first sale.

The question in this case is what is the effect of the lis pendens on the subsequent sale of the same property by the owner to the second purchaser. Section 19 of the Specific Relief Act clearly says subsequent sale can be enforced for good and sufficient reason but in the present case, there is no difficulty because the suit was filed on 3.5.1975 for specific performance of the agreement  and the second sale took place on 5.5.1975. Therefore, it is the admitted position that the second sale was definitely after the filing of the suit in question. Had that not been the position then we would have evaluated the effect of Section 52 of the Transfer of Property Act. But in the present case it is more than apparent that the suit was filed before the second sale of the property. Therefore, the principle of lis pendens will govern the present case and the second sale cannot have the overriding effect on the first sale.  Normally, as a public policy once a suit has been filed pertaining to any subject matter of the property, in order to put an end to such kind of litigation, the principle of lis pendens has been evolved so that the litigation may finally terminate without intervention of a third party. This is because of public policy otherwise no litigation will come to an end. Therefore, in order to discourage that same subject matter of property being subjected to subsequent sale to a third person, this kind of transaction is to be checked. Otherwise, litigation will never come to an end.  [Para 3]

heading: Civil P.C. (1908), O.1 R.10, O.22 R.10
HeadNote.description:
Civil P.C. (1908), O.1 R.10, O.22 R.10 - Suit for specific performance - Transferee pendente lite having notice and knowledge about pendency of suit and order of injunction - Can be impleaded as party under O.1 R.10 on basis of sale deed executed in its favour.

Per M.Y. Eqbal, J. :-

From the bare reading of the provision, it is manifest that sub-rule (2) of Rule 10 gives a wider discretion to the Court to meet every case or defect of a party and to proceed with a person who is a either necessary party or a proper party whose presence in the Court is essential for effective determination of the issues involved in the suit. A contract for specific performance may be enforced against the parties to the contract and the persons mentioned in section 19. Clause (b) of Section 19 makes it very clear that a suit for specific performance cannot be enforced against a person who is a transferee from the vendor for valuable consideration and without notice of the original contract which is sought to be enforced in the suit. There is no dispute that such transfer made in favour of the subsequent purchaser is subject to the rider provided under Section 52 of the Transfer of Property Act and the restrain order passed by the Court.

1992 (2) SCC 524, (1971) SC 1238, (1973) SC 655 Rel. on. 		    [Para 28,31,37]

Per T.S. Thakur, J. (Concurring) :-

The appellant is not a bona fide purchaser and is, therefore, not protected against specific performance of the contract between the plaintiffs and the owner defendants in the suit.

The transfer in favour of the appellant pendente lite is effective in transferring title to the appellant but such title shall remain subservient to the rights of the plaintiff in the suit and subject to any direction which the Court may eventually pass therein.

Since the appellant has purchased the entire estate that forms the subject matter of the suit, the appellant is entitled to be added as a party defendant to the suit.

The appellant shall as a result of his addition raise and pursue only such defenses as were available and taken by the original defendants and none other.

2012(4) ALL MR 481 (S.C.), (1983) 1 SCC 18, 2005(5) ALL MR 458 (S.C.), (1976) 1 SCC 103 Rel. on. 			    [Para 58]

heading: Decree of possession
HeadNote.description:
Decree of possession - Setting aside in first appeal - Defendant purchaser avoided to execute sale deed on ground of bar under Urban Land Ceiling Act - However, defendant took possession of property, made construction - Defendant could not establish that he took possession in part performance of contract - Defendant could not show he was continuously and bonafide ready and willing to perform his part - Defendant did not choose to institute suit for specific performance of contract - Defendant cannot get advantage of his wrong conduct - Defendant must deliver back possession to plaintiff. 
2011 ALL SCR 1800, 1995 (5) SCC 115, 2012 (2) Civil L.J. 81, 2002(2) ALL MR 267 (S.C.), 2004(4) ALL MR 380, 2006(3) ALL MR 129 (S.C.) Ref. to. (Paras 17, 18)

heading: Right of redemption
Invocation by appellant-guarantor
Permissibility
HeadNote.description:
Right of redemption - Invocation by appellant-guarantor - Permissibility - Right of redemption stands extinguished when auction sale is complete and sale deed is registered.

	In the present case, the appellant failed to comply with the provisions of Section 13(8). The statute mandates that it is only where the dues of the secured creditor are tendered together with costs, charges and expenses before the date fixed for sale or transfer that the secured asset is not to be sold or transferred. The appellant was aware of the proceedings initiated by the bank for asserting its right to recover its dues by selling the property. The appellant moved the DRT in Securitization Application 176 of 2015. During the pendency of those proceedings, orders were passed by the Tribunal on 1 February 2016 and 3 February 2016. The appellant moved the Allahabad High Court which by its order dated 9 March 2016 restrained the bank and the auction purchaser from executing the sale deed until 15 March 2016. The stay was extended till 28 March 2016 by which date the appellant was to deposit an amount of Rs 7,00,000. The balance was required to be deposited by 30 April 2016. While appellant deposited an amount of Rs 7,00,000 with the bank, he failed to deposit the balance in accordance with the provisions of Section 13(8). Even after the writ proceedings before the High Court was withdrawn, the appellant did not deposit the balance due together with the costs, charges and expenses. The sale was confirmed, a sale certificate was issued and a registered sale deed was executed on 12 April 2016. The appellant failed to ensure compliance with Section 13(8). The right to redemption stands extinguished on the execution of the registered sale deed. This is also the view which has been expressed in the judgment in Mathew Varghese 2015 ALL SCR 776. 2015 ALL SCR 776 Rel.on.	 [Para 6]

heading: Entitlement
HeadNote.description:
Specific performance of agreement - Entitlement - Relief of specific performance sought by way of counter claim - Gross delay in filing counter claim - Defendant claimed to have been put in possession of suit premises towards part performance of agreement - However, no material adduced to show his readiness or willingness to pay balance amount - Relief of specific performance is discretionary - In view of delay and failure of defendant to show readiness and willingness, Courts below justified in not exercising their discretion. 
2009(1) ALL MR 389, AIR 1982 SC 989 Ref. to.(Para 10)

heading: Suit for declaration
HeadNote.description:
Suit for declaration - Suit by plaintiff that defendant is trying to disturb possession on basis of sale-deed - Defendant got document executed from plaintiff on basis of mis-representation - Cancellation of sale-deed is not required as it is not real transaction - Suit for declaration that sale-deed was sham and nominal is maintainable under S.31.

Plaintiff executed sale-deed as security for loan taken from defendant.  Plaintiff never parted with possession even after execution of sale-deed.  Sale-deed is void.  Nominal and sham sale-deed need not be cancelled.  Plaintiff was not claiming any relief on basis of said sale-deed but was only seeking declaration that same was nominal and sham.  Suit for declaration without claiming cancellation of sale-deed is maintainable under S.31. (2006)5 SCC 353 - Rel. on.  AIR 1977 Karnataka 99, AIR 2007 SC 1499, 2000(3) Civil Law Journal 214 - Ref. to.						  [Para 10]

heading: Reference proceedings
Contempt petition against
Fine imposed accordingly
HeadNote.description: Reference proceedings - Order dt.8/5/2014 restraining company to alienate its assets without taking permission of court - Alleged alienation of certain property of company in violation of order dt.8/5/2014 - Contempt petition against - Contemnor contends that conveyance deed was executed on 4/4/2013 i.e. prior to said order, therefore transfer of property not in violation of said order - However, record showing that documents presented for registration in April 2013 were not accepted for want of adequate stamp and registration fees - Registration duly effected only on 2/7/2014 - Thus, property was transferred in teeth of order dt.8/5/2014 and ex facie there is violation of order dt.8/5/2014 - Therefore, company and its directors held guilty of violating order dt.8/5/2014 - Fine imposed accordingly - However, looking to fact that transferee company and its directors were neither party to said proceedings nor served with order dt.8/5/2014 - Transferee also parted with full consideration way back on 4/4/2013 - Therefore, effect of registration of document not invalidated.  	(Paras 18, 25)

heading: Grant of
HeadNote.description: Specific performance of agreement to sell - Grant of - Plaintiffs claiming that after partition of suit property co-owners of property agreed to sell their share to him - Material on record showing that owners of suit property transferred entire possession of property to plaintiffs after agreement to sale as part performance of contract - Plaintiffs entitled to benefit of S.53A of TP Act - Grant of decree of specific performance, proper. 	(Paras 12, 14, 15, 16)

heading: Suit for possession and injunction
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession and injunction - Plaintiff having charge over suit field by virtue of decree of maintenance in her favour and subsequently she had purchased suit field in auction sale - Defendants claiming benefit of S.100 of TP Act as at time of purchase of suit field from husband of plaintiff they were not aware about charge of plaintiff - On date of sale of suit field to defendants, husband of plaintiff was not having any marketable and saleable title with him as property was already sold in auction sale to plaintiff - Defendants not entitled to benefit of S.100 - Further, in village of which defendants are residents sale proclamation was done by beating drums and publishing notice - Defendants cannot say that they were not having knowledge about auction sale - Auction sale was also confirmed by competent court - Plaintiff entitled to decree of possession and injunction. 			(Paras 10, 11, 12, 13)

heading: Entitlement
HeadNote.description: Specific Relief Act (1963) - Suit for specific performance - Benefit of S.53A of T.P. Act - Entitlement - Parties entered agreement of sale of suit field for consideration of Rs.25,000/- - Possession handed over immediately after amount of Rs.24,000/- was paid - Since permission of Competent Authority for transfer of suit field was necessary, fresh document was executed and balance amount was paid that time - Transferee had performed her part of contract - Since, transferor neither obtained necessary permission nor executed sale deed, suit for specific performance of contract was filed - Decree for specific performance was not granted in absence of necessary permission from Competent Authority - Instead, protection of possession u/S.53A T.P. Act was granted - Agreement was in writing and duly signed by transferor - Transferee in part performance of contract was put in possession and entire agreed consideration paid by her - Transferor made no counter claim seeking possession - Transferee has complied with all necessary ingredients to seek protection of her possession u/S.53A, T.P. Act. 1993 ALLMR ONLINE 1772, 2004(4) ALL MR 380 (F.B.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 8, 9, 10, 11)

heading: Auction of land belonging to industrial unit
HeadNote.description: Auction of land belonging to industrial unit - Intending auction purchaser i.e. highest bidder depositing some amount as earnest money - State financial corporation not disclosing important fact that said industrial unit had no approach road/passage and hence not suitable for a manufacturing unit - Subsequent action of corporation inving fresh tenders and forfeiture of earnest money was invalid - Said action of corporation taking advantage of its own wrong cannot be saved by invoking S.55 of T.P. Act as auction purchaser has not failed to comply with conditions of sale - S.29 of State Financial Corporation Act cannot also be invoked; because auction purchaser in the instant case cannot be confused with defaulting unit. 1994(1) SCC 575 and (2009)4 SCC 660 - Disting.			(Paras 17 to 21 and 23)

heading: Maharashtra Rent Control Act (1999), S.1
HeadNote.description:
Maharashtra Rent Control Act (1999), S.1 - Objective of SARFAESI Act coupled with T.P. Act and Rent Act - Reconciliation of.

	The objective of SARFAESI Act, coupled with the T.P. Act and the Rent Act are required to be reconciled herein in the following manner:

a) 	If a valid tenancy under law is in existence even prior to the creation of the mortgage, the tenant's possession cannot be disturbed by the secured creditor by taking possession of the property. The lease has to be determined in accordance with Section 111 of the TP Act for determination of leases. As the existence of a prior existing lease inevitably affects the risk undertaken by the bank while providing the loan, it is expected of Banks/Creditors to have conducted a standard due diligence in this regard. Where the bank has proceeded to accept such a property as mortgage, it will be presumed that it has consented to the risk that comes as a consequence of the existing tenancy. In such a situation, the rights of a rightful tenant cannot be compromised under the SARFAESI Act proceedings.

b) 	If a tenancy under law comes into existence after the creation of a mortgage, but prior to the issuance of notice under Section 13(2) of the SARFAESI Act, it has to satisfy the conditions of Section 65A of the T.P. Act.

c) 	In any case, if any of the tenants claim that he is entitled to possession of a secured asset for a term of more than a year, it has to be supported by the execution of a registered instrument. In the absence of a registered instrument, if the tenant relies on an unregistered instrument or an oral agreement accompanied by delivery of possession, the tenant is not entitled to possession of the secured asset for more than the period prescribed under Section 107 of the T.P. Act. 						 [Para 25]

heading: Recovery proceedings
Tenability
HeadNote.description:
Maharashtra Rent Control Act (1999), S.1 - Recovery proceedings - Stay application by tenant of secured asset i.e. flat - Tenability - Bank sought physical possession of secured asset i.e. flat of borrower-landlord - Tenant claimed to have entered into oral agreement of tenancy before mortgage deed in respect of suit flat was entered into between bank and borrower - However, no evidence produced by tenant to establish tenancy, except xerox rent receipts - Claim about bona fide tenancy, not tenable - S.13(13) bars entering into such tenancy beyond 2012 - Since notice u/S.13(2) was issued on 30-4-2011, subsequent reckoning of tenancy, is barred - Person occupying premises, when tenancy has been determined, can only be treated as "tenant in sufferance" - Such tenants are akin to trespassers - Operation of Rent Act cannot be extended to them.

	In the instant case, at the time when the SARFAESI Act proceedings were pending, the factum of tenancy was never revealed by the parties. The earlier order dated 09.03.2012, passed by the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, directing the Assistant Registrar to take over the possession of the secured asset, is silent about any existing encumbrance over the secured asset. It was only after passing of the aforesaid order of the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, that the appellant-tenant started agitating his rights before the Small Causes Court based on a completely different fact scenario, without a whisper of the alleged tenancy under the concluded Section 14, SARFAESI Act proceedings. The borrower/landlord did not even respond to the claims of the appellant-tenant. The bank has produced multiple records to substantiate their claim that the tenant was nowhere to be seen earlier and that this tenancy was created just to defeat the proceedings initiated under the SARFAESI Act. On the contrary, the appellant-tenant has failed to produce any evidence to substantiate his claim over the secured asset. In such a situation, the appellant-tenant cannot claim protection under the garb of the interim protection granted to him, ex parte, by solely relying upon the xerox of the rent receipts.

	The stay application of the appellant-tenant seems to be an afterthought. It is clear that the respondent no. 2-borrower/landlord never intimated the respondent no. 1-bank about the alleged tenancy. In light of the above, the claim of bona fide tenancy of the appellant-tenant, cannot be accepted.

	In any case, considering the counterfactual pleaded by the appellant-tenant himself, that he was a tenant who had entered into an oral agreement, such tenancy impliedly does not carry any covenant for renewal, as provided under Section 65A of T.P. Act. Therefore, in any case, Section 13(13) SARFAESI Act bars entering into such tenancy beyond January, 2012. As the notice under Section 13 (2) SARFAESI Act was issued on 30.04.2011, subsequent reckoning of the tenancy is barred. Such person occupying the premises, when the tenancy has been determined, can only be treated as a 'tenant in sufferance'. Such tenants do not have any legal rights and are akin to trespassers.

	The operation of the Rent Act cannot be extended to a 'tenant-in-sufferance' visavis the SARFAESI Act, due to the operation of Section 13(2) read with Section 13(13) of the SARFAESI Act. A contrary interpretation would violate the intention of the legislature to provide for Section 13(13), which has a valuable role in making the SARFAESI Act a self-executory instrument for debt recovery. Moreover, such an interpretation would also violate the mandate of Section 35, SARFAESI Act which is couched in broad terms.

1995 ALLMR ONLINE 1321 (S.C.), 1981 ALLMR ONLINE 22 (S.C.), AIR 1997 SC 2690 Ref. to.	 [Para 31,32,33,36]

heading: Suit for specific performance of agreement
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance of agreement - Plaintiff builder entering into oral commercial collaboration agreement to develop property - Suit filed after 3 years of agreement and without seeking interim relief - Pending suit created cloud on right of defendant to deal with property - Court passed a direction to plaintiff to agree to pay damages of Rs.25 lakhs in event of losing suit - Such a direction is unjustified and unsustainable - Apex Court substituted it by conditional order exempting property from operation of S.52 T.P. Act.			(Paras 14, 21, 26)

heading: Subsequent purchaser
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Subsequent purchaser - Entitlement to be impleaded - Petitioner subsequent purchaser, prima facie proved to have no knowledge at the time of execution of sale deed in his favour, either of pendency of suit or of passing of decree in favour of third person - Petitioner appeared to have been caught in trap laid by respondent - Respondent had already accepted total consideration from petitioner - Petitioner, held, entitled to participate in proceedings of appeal - Merely because petitioner came to know late about passing of decree - No ground to drove him out of the court. (Para 11)

heading: Specific performance
Not illegal
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), S.115 - Specific performance - Family settlement between three brothers - Clause giving preferential right to one purchase share in property of other brother/brothers - Written concurrence of three brothers, necessary for sale - Defendant intending to sale his share, made offer to plaintiff/appellant - Appellant and first defendant did not insist a written concurrence for sale - Appellant failed to act upon offer made to him and other brother have not disputed sale intended to be made to second defendant - Thus, sale of his share by first defendant in favour of second defendant at price which appellant had also described as reasonable - Not illegal - To enforce said clause in family settlement, appellant would be estopped from raising plea of absence of written consent - Grant of decree of specific performance in favour of appellant on basis of clause in family settlement, without anything more embodied a contract for sale of immovable property, not proper - Further, it cannot be said that assignment in favour of second defendant was vulnerable as it does not involve fragmentation under provisions of Capital of Punjab (Development and Regulation) Act 1952. 	(Paras 36, 52, 63, 65)

heading: Effect of S.213
HeadNote.description:
Partition Act (1893), S.4 - Effect of S.213 - It bars 'establishment' of right under will unless probate is obtained - However, it does not bar legatee from laying his claim under the will even without probate certificate - Passing of decree without probate certificate is barred and not entertainment of claim itself.

AIR 1962 S.C. 1471 Relied on.	(Para 6)

heading: Defendants's rights
HeadNote.description: Defendants's rights - Suit for specific performance of agreement for sale of land - Transfer of land during pendency of suit - Held, as suit for specific performance was pending, transfer of land during pendency of suit was bad in view of S.52 of T.P. Act and is of no effect.  1997 (Supp.) Bom. C.R. (S.C.) 53 - Ref. to.	(Para 8)

heading: Decree for specific performance
HeadNote.description:
Decree for specific performance - Whether assignment of such decree amounts to transfer of actionable claim.

A decree for specific performance of contract in respect of immovable property is in the nature of a debt, which is a movable property. It is a "chose in action", providing not a right to ownership of corporeal property, but it is the beneficial interest to obtain right to ownership of incorporeal property. It creates beneficial interest in the movable property which can be enforced by action of law. A claimant is entitled to knock the door of the Court and the Court would recognize the claim for granting relief. It is heritable and assignable by executing a deed of conveyance. It is not a right to sue but something more than that and something less than the right of ownership of immovable property. It does not require any consideration, which is apparent from the provisions of Section 130 of the Transfer of Property Act itself. The assignment is to be effected by executing an instrument in writing signed by the transferee or his authorized agent and it is complete and effectual upon the execution of such an instrument. Thus, a deed of assignment of a decree for specific performance of contract, merely gives a cause of action to a claim for specific performance of contract of assignment and nothing more. The Deed at Exhibit 178 conforms to all such requirements and hence it can be characterised as the transfer of an actionable claim and the absence of evidence regarding consideration cannot be a ground to hold that the deed of conveyance is not enforceable. Hence, no consideration is required to be shown to transfer/assignment of a decree for specific performance of contract, which is an actionable claim.  [Para 37,38]

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), S.101 - Suit for possession - Plaintiff purchased suit house by registered sale-deed in his favour - Defendants rely upon sale-deed in their favour - Sale-deed in favour of defendants executed after 6 months of sale-deed in favour of plaintiff - Plaintiff contending that seller had no saleable title to property when he sold suit house to defendants - Plaintiff stating defendants are gratuitous licencees - Licence of defendants duly terminated after issuing notice - Defendants failed to disprove evidence of ownership in favour of plaintiff - Defendants could not establish better title to suit house - Concurrent judgment of Trial and First Appellate Court by which suit is decreed is liable to be upheld - Second appeal by defendants is liable to be dismissed.	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Suit for specific performance
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Defendant is in possession of property by virtue of document of lease from previous owner - Property was given on lease for 10 years on unregistered document - As per S.107 of T.P. Act if period of lease exceeding one year, registered intrument is compulsory - Thus, transaction itself is invalid in view of S.107 - Specific performance of contract cannot be granted. (Para 28)

heading: Probate
HeadNote.description: Probate - Disposition of property made by Executor of will in favour of Developer during pendency of probate - Agreement for sale entered into by executor son of third wife of testator in favour of Developer during lifetime of testator - Consideration was received by testator - Conveyance deed also executed during life time of testator - Developers demolished old building and constructed a multistorey building - They got freed property from all encumbrances - Other heirs could not be said not to have knowledge of these events - Nothing to suggest that conveyance deed was incompatible with administration of the estate of testator - Held Developer was a bona fide purchaser for value and subsequent alienation effected by Developer in favour of bona fide purchasers for value without notice was valid.			(Paras 54, 55, 59, 60)

heading: Mortgage
Principle underlying
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage - Principle underlying - Mortgage once created, the right to redeem the same at any time before it is transferred in accordance with law, subsists.

	Sub-section (8) of Section 13 of the Act has made it very clear that if the dues of the secured creditor together with the costs, charges and expenses are tendered at any time before the date fixed for sale or transfer, in such an event, the secured asset shall not be sold or transferred by the secured creditor and no further steps shall be taken for transfer or sale of that secured asset. Thus what has been provided for under sub-section (8) of Section 13 of the Act is the well established principle that a mortgage once created, the right to redeem the same at any time before its title is transferred in accordance with law, subsists. Therefore, Section 13 of the Act has provided for a great balancing act between the interests of the secured creditors as well as the borrowers. 	 [Para 13,23,24]

A mortgage is a security given by a person for ensuring or facilitating the fulfilment of some obligation undertaken by him. Usually the obligation for which security is offered relates to repayment of a debt. While a simple debt of money confers on the creditor a jus in personam, a right which is enforceable against a determinate individual debtor. Such a simple debt of money is realizable by obtaining a money decree and then brining the property of the debtor to sale in execution of such a decree. If, in the meantime, the debtor alienates his property, the creditor cannot ordinarily follow such a property as the alienee in the meantime acquires certain other rights in the same property, in which case a creditor can only proceed against the individual debtor and his interests can sometimes be jeopardized inasmuch as, the remaining assets of the debtor could be insufficient to discharge the debt in full. For this reason, creditors require security to be furnished in the shape of a real property, the value of which the creditor can safely rely and in case of necessity, turn the same into money. Most importantly the creditor can follow the property even when it was lying in the hands of some other third parties pursuant to it's alienation by the debtor. A mortgage is, thus a security which confers upon the creditor some right in rem. It is a right in re aliena for it exists in regard to property of which the ownership is in another person. The very definition of a mortgage, as per Section 58 of Transfer of Property Act, shows that it is nothing more than a transfer of an interest in a specified immovable property and all that the mortgagee gets is not the legal ownership of the property but merely an interest in immovable property. While a relationship of a debtor and a creditor subsists in case of mortages, but most importantly, the right to redeem remains with the debtor. The equity of redemption is singularly significant in that a mortgage shall always be redeemable and a mortgagor's right to redeem shall neither be taken away nor can be limited by any contract between the parties. 		 [Para 15,19]

Thus, the mortgagor's right to redeem the mortgage even after the specified time lapsed subsists and still the mortgagor can claim to redeem the property. Hence, this right of the mortgagor has come to be known as "Equity of Redemption". The rule against clogs on the equity of redemption is that, a mortgage shall always be redeemable and a mortgagor's right to redeem shall neither be taken away nor be limited by any contract between the parties. The doctrine of equity of redemption came to be expressed in the maxim 'Once a mortgage, always a mortgage'. And this principle has taken now a firm footing in the form of Section 60 of the Transfer of Property Act. So long as the mortgagor had a right to redeem the mortgage, he can always pay off the debt together with interest to the mortgagee and get back possession of the mortgaged property. This position would continue so long as the property is not sold under a final decree of sale brought about in accordance with the provisions of Order XXXIV C.P.C or any other law providing therefore. 				 [Para 19,21]

heading: Enforcement of security interest
HeadNote.description:
Enforcement of security interest - Rights of lessee/tenant of borrower - Conflicting with enforcement right of secured creditor u/Ss.13 and 14 - Held, if the property was leased out to tenant prior in time than its mortgage to the secured creditor, lessee/tenant will have the right to enjoy property so leased to him - There is no mention in S.13(4) that such prior lease could stand determined by the measures u/s.13 initiated by secured creditor. 

A 'secured asset' has been defined in Section 2(zc) of the SARFAESI Act to mean the property on which the security interest is created. In case of an immovable property, a security interest is created in a secured asset by way of a mortgage in favour of the secured creditor. There may be cases where before the mortgage is created in respect of an immovable property, the borrower had already leased out the immovable property in favour of a lessee either as the owner or as a person competent or authorised to transfer the immovable property in accordance with Section 7 of the Transfer of Property Act. If such a lease is made, by virtue of Section 8 of the Transfer of Property Act, the lessee will have the right to enjoy the leased property in accordance with the terms and condition of the lease irrespective of whether a subsequent mortgagee of the immovable property has knowledge of such a lease or not.      [Para 11]

One of the measures mentioned in clause (a) in sub-section (4) of Section 13 of the SARFAESI Act is to take possession of the secured assets of the borrower including the right to transfer by way of lease. Where, however, the lawful possession of the secured asset is not with the borrower, but with the lessee under a valid lease, the secured creditor cannot take over possession of the secured asset until the lawful possession of the lessee gets determined. There is, however, no mention in sub-section (4) of Section 13 of the SARFAESI Act that a lease made by the borrower in favour of a lessee will stand determined on the secured creditor deciding to take any of the measures mentioned in Section 13 of the said Act.     [Para 15]

heading: Enforcement of security interest
HeadNote.description:
Enforcement of security interest - Bar against lease of property after receiving  notice u/s.13(2) - Bar created by S.13(13) of SARFAESI Act override S.65A of T.P. Act.

Sub-section (13) of Section 13 of the SARFAESI Act, provides that after receipt of notice referred to in sub-section (2) of Section 13 of the SARFAESI Act, no borrower shall lease any of his secured assets referred to in the notice, without the prior written consent of the secured creditor. This provision in sub-section (13) of Section 13 of the SARFAESI Act and the provisions of the Transfer of Property Act enabling the borrower or the mortgagor to make a lease are inconsistent with each other. Hence, sub-section (13) of Section 13 of the SARFAESI Act will override the provisions of Section 65A of the Transfer of Property Act by virtue of Section 35 of the SARFAESI Act, and a lease of a secured asset made by the borrower after he receives the notice under sub-section (2) of Section 13 from the secured creditor intending to enforce that secured asset will not be a valid lease.     [Para 15]

heading: Possession of secured assets
HeadNote.description: Possession of secured assets - Not to be ordered when same is possessed by a lessee under a valid lease - Therefore, when a creditor moves an application u/s.14 he must state in his affidavit that secured asset is not possessed by lessee/tenant under a valid lease or u/s.65A or that the lease has been determined in terms of S.111 of T.P. Act.(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Provisions u/s.13 of SARFAESI Act
HeadNote.description: Provisions u/s.13 of SARFAESI Act - Override provisions of Ss.69 and 69A of T.P. Act - However, said S.13 does not override those provisions of T.P. Act which relate to a lease created prior to notice u/s.13(2) of SARFAESI Act.(Para 25)

heading: Temporary injunction
HeadNote.description: Temporary injunction - Respondents claiming ownership on basis of partition deed - Contention that appellants got their land released from acquisition proceedings by relying upon partition deed - Order of Commissioner states that land was released as it was not in command area - Further respondents sought entry of their names in record of rights after 22 years of alleged partition - Appellants made out prima facie case of their possession - Respondents liable to be restrained from disturbing peaceful possession of Appellants - Protection against creating 3rd party interest is already given under S.52 - Appellants can register lis putting 3rd parties to notice that property is in dispute - Appeal is liable to be partly allowed.	(Paras 14, 15, 16)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Intervention in execution proceedings - Rejection of application by purchasers pendente lite - Validity - Petitioners who purchased property during pendency of suit, had no independent right to property and decreeholder shall be put in possession of property - Such petitioners were presumed to be aware of pending litigation in competent court and they cannot be said to be purchasers without notice - Plea of petitioners that such presumption was rebuttable, cannot be accepted - As said presumption is not presumption in sense of it being rebuttable but is situation where transferee pendente lite is deemed to be aware of pending litigation pertaining to property in question - Such transferee cannot claim right to show evidence that he was actually not aware or put to notice about pendency of litigation - Rejection of application, proper. (Paras 9, 10, 11, 13)

headline: Civil P.C. (1908), O. 21, Rr. 98, 100 proviso – Transfer of Property Act (1882), S. 52 – Purchasers pendente lite had no independent right to property and cannot claim right intervene or obstruct execution proceedings.

heading: Attachment of property
Objections to
HeadNote.description: Attachment of property - Objections to - Judgment debtor getting his self acquired property mutated in favour of his minor son to evade attachment - Mutation entry effected without any document of title - Transfer not being valid son cannot raise any objection to attachment - Judgment debtor directed to pay costs of petition quantified at Rs.10,000/-. (Paras 14,17)

heading: Suit for partition
Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition - Second appeal - Plaintiffs claiming half share in suit property - On ground that suit property was purchased in joint name of predecessors of plaintiffs and defendants who were brothers - Construction of house was done by predecessor of defendants from his own funds and not from joint family funds - Predecessor of plaintiff never raised claim for share in property till death of his brother or till his own death - Plaintiffs since date of purchase of suit property has never resided in suit property or incurred any expenditure on it - Mere failure of defendants to adduce satisfactory evidence that their predecessor had paid entire consideration - Would not absolve plaintiffs of their duty to establish their own claim in accordance with law to substantiate presumption u/S.45 of TP Act sought to be relied upon - Plaintiffs not entitled to decree of partition - Interference by High Court with concurrent findings of court below in exercise of powers u/S.100 of CPC and allowing plaintiffs suit, erroneous. 	(Paras 8, 9, 12)

heading: Usufructuary mortgage
Redemption of
Suit for
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Limitation Act (1963), Art.137 - Usufructuary mortgage - Redemption of - Suit for - Application for final decree - Limitation - Application for final decree can be made only by usufructuary mortgagor and not by usufructuary mortgagee - Limitation for drawing up final decree does not run until deposit is made - Application if made within three years from date of deposit is within limitation.

O.34, Rr.7 and 8 do not confer any right upon the usufructuary mortgagee to apply for final decree which is conferred on mortgagee on other types of mortgages. By reason of sub-rule (1) of Rule 8 of Order XXXIV, a mortgagor is entitled to make an application for final decree at any time before a final decree debarring the plaintiff from all rights to redeem the mortgaged property has been passed or before the confirmation of a sale held in pursuance of a final decree passed under sub-rule (3) of this rule. No such application is again contemplated at the instance of the usufructuary mortgagee. By reason of sub-rule (1) of Rule 8 of Order XXXIV, a right of redemption is conferred upon the mortgagor of a usufructuary mortgage. Such a provision has been made evidently having regard to the right of redemption of a mortgagor in terms of Section 60 of the Transfer of Property Act and further having regard to the fact that a usufructuary mortgagee would be entitled to possess the property in question till a final decree of redemption is passed.  [Para 21]

The right of redemption of mortgagor being a statutory right, the same can be taken away only in terms of the proviso appended to Section 60 of the Act which is extinguished either by a decree or by act of parties. Admittedly, in the instant case, no decree has been passed extinguishing the right of the mortgagor nor such right has come to an end by act of the parties.	 [Para 22]

Sub-rule (1) of Rule 8 shows that only a mortgagor can apply to the Court to pass a final decree on payment of the amount found or declared due under the preliminary decree on making this deposit and upon filing the application as provided for in sub-rule (1) of Rule 8 the mortgagor can request the Court to order the mortgagee to put him in possession of the properties which were the subject-matter of the mortgage. The amount determined by the Court which the mortgagor is liable to pay to the mortgagee can be deposited before the right to redeem is lost. It may be noticed that even sub-rule (2) of Rule 7 of Order XXXIV does not apply to the usufructuary mortgage. It may be noticed that by reason of the amendment introduced in 1929 the right conferred earlier on a usufructuary mortgagee to bring the property to sale in case of the mortgagor not making the payment within the time fixed in the decree was taken away. As sub-rule (2) of Rule 7 is applicable only in a case of mortgages other than the usufructuary mortgages, a usufructuary mortgagor is not entitled to seek extension of time and in that view of the matter the fact that such an application made by the first respondent herein was rejected becomes irrelevant.	 [Para 25]

heading: Maharashtra Rent Control Act (1999), S.3(1)(b)
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Rent Control Act (1999), S.3(1)(b) - Relationship of landlord and tenant - Merely because rent was not accepted that itself is not sufficient to hold that the relationship was ended. 2007 ALL SCR 193 - Ref. to.			(Para 29)

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Concurrent finding of courts below - Courts below justified in holding that there was no agreement for sale between parties - No substantial question of law in Second Appeal on that count - Second appeal dismissed.			(Paras 9, 12)

heading: Kerala Amendment, S.97(1)
HeadNote.description:
Kerala Amendment, S.97(1) - Right of redemption is a substantive right of Mortgagor which has accrued to him to be exercised under O.34, R.5 of C.P.C. when the decree was passed which - Cannot be taken away by the amendment of O.34 made after passing of decree.

In the instant cases, decrees were passed at a time when the Code was in force in the State of Kerala and the amendment in 1974 so far as the State of Kerala is concerned was not operative.  Composite decrees were passed in both under O.34, Rr.4, 5 together.  Those were the provisions in regard to enforcement of mortgages, and whatever may be the wording of the decree, they shall be deemed to be passed under O.34, R.5 as it stood at the time of the passing of the decree.  It is not necessary that all the clauses mentioned in the provisions under which the decree is passed should be incorporated in the decree.  While interpreting such a decree, it must be read as if all the provisions threin are incorporated in the decree.  The Court may not at the time of passing of the decree, be aware as to which contingency will happen in future.  Each of the decrees was under O.34, R.5 of the Code as it stood before 20-11-1990.  The effect of S.97(1) of the Amendment Act is that all the local amendments made to any of the provisions of the Code which were inconsistent with the Code as amended by the Amendment Act stood repealed irrespective of fact whether the corresponding provision of the Code had been amended or modified by the Amendment Act and that was subject only to what was found in sub-s.(2) of S.97.  That being so, the Kerala amendment was not effective from 1-2-1977 till 20-11-1990.  Right of redemption of a mortgage is a substantive right of mortgagor which was accrued to him to be exercised under O.34, R.5, C.P.C. when the decree was passed which cannot be taken away by the amendment of O.34 of the Code which was made only after the decree in this case.  The right of the mortgagor to redeem the property is available to him till the confirmation of the sale in pursucance to the decree.  Application under O.34, R5 is maintainable until final determination of proceedings to set aside the sale under O.34 either by way of appeal or revision.		 [Para 11,16,17]

heading: Joinder as plaintiff
Rejection of application
HeadNote.description: Joinder as plaintiff - Rejection of application - Ground that applicant became owner of suit property only during pendency of suit - And that transfer during pendency of suit, being hit by lis pendens, presence of applicant in adjudication of suit is not necessary - Ground of rejection, improper - Held, transfer during pendency of suit cannot operate as bar to powers under O.1 R.10(2) - Court can add subsequent purchaser as plaintiff. 	(Para 4)

heading: Immovable property
HeadNote.description: Immovable property - Transferee pendente lite as defendant, impleadment of - If any defendant is impleaded subsequently proceedings as against him shall be deemed to have begun only from the date of service of summons - Same is of course subject to S.21 of the Limitation Act, 1963 - Said provision does not in any way dilute significance of the expression 'shall be deemed to have begun only on the service of the summons' in O.1, R.10(5).	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Second appeal
Sale transaction
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Sale transaction - Challenge to - Sale transaction between husband and wife - Transaction not registered at a place where it ought to have been registered normally, but, got registered at a distant place - Appellate Court disbelieving the evidence - Due care and discretion exercised by lower appellate Court, held, just and proper - View of lower appellate Court cannot be labelled either as erroneous or perverse - No interference in second appeal.(Paras 8, 10)

heading: Maintainable
HeadNote.description:
Execution of eviction decree - Petition by subsequent purchaser who was not original party - Maintainable - Subsequent purchaser acquires right to execute decree - No necessity of assignment of decree by the decree holder in favour of subsequent purchaser - S.109 of TP Act is also not a bar as execution is sought for recovery of possession and not for recovery of arrears of rent.

Bare reading of section 109 of the Transfer of Property Act shows the right of purchaser for recovery of previous rent is subject to the terms and conditions of sale deed/conveyance. Section 146 of the Code of Civil Procedure shows that if the rights are purchased by third party after passing the decree, they have right to file execution application for the fruits of the said decree but same depends upon which type of decree was passed by the court. If the decree is in the nature of personal right then that cannot be executable. But if it is in respect of immovable property, that can. Not only that even bare reading of Order XXI Rule 16 of the Code of Civil Procedure shows that subsequent purchaser / owner can execute the decree in respect of immovable property. The reading of Explanation to said Rule 16 also shows that it is not necessary that the decree holder should assign the decree in favour of subsequent purchaser. The subsequent purchaser who purchases the said property in respect of which decree has been passed, acquired the right to execute the decree.

In the present proceeding, the respondents purchased the suit property on 14.7.1985 and they stepped into the shoes of the decree holder. That decree is passed on the ground of arrears of rent. The respondent gets right to recover the possession in view of subsequent development and section 146 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The objection raised by the petitioner that in view of section 109 of the Transfer of Property Act, respondents could not get right to execute decree is not sustainable in law. Section 109 of Transfer of Property Act is very clear that subject to the terms and condition of instrument/sale deed/conveyance, the transferee gets right to recover the rent. In the present proceeding in hand, it is crystal clear from Execution Application filed by respondent that, they asked the assistance of the Court for executing the decree for possession and not for recovery of arrears of rent or any other relief.

AIR 1969 PATNA 13, 1993 (3) BCR 305 Disting.      [Para 12,13,14]

heading: Impleadment as defendant
HeadNote.description: Impleadment as defendant - Application by alienee pendente lite - Objection raised that he is not bonafide purchaser - Held, alienee pendente lite would always be bound by verdict of Court in suit - Defendant who has sold property may not desire to defend his non-existing interest which he would have otherwise defended - Possibility that alienee would be precluded from espousing his cause and would be left to mercy of such defendant - Therefore, he is impleaded as defendant in suit. 2005(5) ALL MR 458 (S.C.) Rel. on. (Para 11)

heading: Suit for eviction or recovery of arrears of rent as well as for future mesne profit
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction or recovery of arrears of rent as well as for future mesne profit - Suit between lessor and lessee - Interim relief in nature of deposit of rent or compensation by the lessee - Provisions of law which are attracted in the matter is Order 15-A and not Order 39, R.10 of C.P.C. - Order passed under order 15-A, not appellable.

In a suit for recovery of money or anything which is capable of being delivered and further when the opposite party admits that the money or such things is held by the said opposite party as trustee or that it belongs to or is due to another party, the Court is empowered to issue direction to deposit money or such thing or to deliver such thing to the party on whose behalf such money or thing is held as trustee or to whom admittedly such money or thing belong to.  For due performance of such order, the Court can also issue further directions as may warrant in a given case including the direction for furnishing security whenever occasion arises for such direction.  Being so, in case of a suit for the claim of damages, if an application for interim relief is filed, the Court would not be debarred from exercising the power under the provisions of law contained in Order 39 rule 10 of CPC.  However, to ascertain whether such an exercise in the case in hand was permissible and/or warranted, it is not sufficient merely to refer to Order 39 rule 10 of CPC and it would also be necessary to take into consideration Provisions of Order XV-A of the C.P.C.  [Para 7]

Bare reading of the provisions of order XV-A of C.P.C., would disclose that in a suit filed by the lessor or licensor against the lessee or licensee either for the eviction or for the recovery of arrears of rent as well as for future mesne profit, the Court can direct the defendant in the suit to deposit such amount as Court may direct on account of arrears of rent as well as may direct to continue to deposit further rent or license fees during the pendency of the suit and in case of failure to comply with such order, the Court may after hearing the parties, if dis-satisfied with the explanation given for non compliance thereof, may order striking off the defence.  Being so, it is aparent that in the suits between the lessor and lessee or licensor and licensee specific provision is made under order XV-A to ensure the recovery of the amount of arrears as well as amount arising during the pendency of the suit for the possession of the premises by way of eviction of the licensee or the lessee therefrom.  It is well settled law that when specific provisions are made for specific purposes in the CPC, the Courts are expected to take resort of those provisions of law and not to exercise their jurisdiction under some other provision of law.  Undoubtedly, Order 39 rule 10 empowers the Court to direct delivery of the money or the property or thing held by the defendant as trustee for the plaintiff or admitted to be belonging to the plaintiff or due to the plaintiff and pass an appropriate order in that regard in a suit where the subject matter is either the money or relating to thing capable of delivery; at the same time in relation to the suits between the lessor and lessee or licensor and licensee specific provisions are made under order XV-A to deal with the matters pertaining to the payment or deposit of the amount accruing during the pendency of the suit either as rent or as license fees or even as mesne profit and therefore,it is difficult to agree with the respondent's contention that in the present case wherein the suit was undoubtedly for eviction of the firm who was inducted as the lessee and from whom possession was sought for and similarly claim for compensation/damages is made on account of continuation of occupation of the leased premises by the petitioners after the expiry or the alleged termination of lease by the respondents, the trial court could have granted the interim relief for payment of monthly amount or arrears in exercise of powers vide Order 39 Rule 10, when specific provisions of law for grant of such interim relief are available under Order XV-A of C.P.C. Undoubetedly, such a relief can be availed under order XV-A and therefore, it was not permissible to the Court to take resort to the other provisions in such cases and therefore, the contention sought to be raised on behalf of the petitioners is well founded that the interim application which was filed by the respondents was in terms of order XV-A of CPC and not in terms of order 39 rule 10 of CPC.  [Para 9]

Considering the fact that order dated 28.2.2002 was passed by the trial court in exercise of powers under order 15A and the provisions relating to appeal against the orders passed by the Courts in terms of the provisions of CPC, it is aparent that the orders passed under 15A are not appelable.  Being so, the petitioners are justified in contending that the appellate bench of the Small Causes Court had no jurisdiction to entertain the Appeal against the order dated 28.2.2002.  On that count itself, the petition is bound to succeed and the impugned order is liable to be set aside. AIR 1985 Bom 4(DB) and 1983 MLJ 88 (DB) - Referred to.  [Para 13]

heading: Doctrine of "lis pendens"
HeadNote.description: Doctrine of "lis pendens" - A defendant cannot, by alienating property during pendency of litigation, venture into depriving the successful plaintiff of fruits of the decree - In case of an assignment, creation or devolution of any interest during pendency of any suit, O.22, R.10 of C.P.C. confers a discretion on the Court hearing the suit to grant leave for the person in or upon whom such interest has come to vest or devolve to be brought on record - Held, bringing of a lis pendens transferee on record is not as of right but in the discretion of the Court - Though not brought on record the lis pendens transferee remains bound by the decree. 2004 AIR SCW 470 - Ref. to.			 (Para 12)

heading: Temporary Injunction
Prima facie case
Sub-lease
Grant of
HeadNote.description:
Temporary Injunction - Prima facie case - Sub-lease - Grant of - Defendant permitted use of premises by tenant - Landlord had given his no objection for tenant creating sub-tenancy in respect of suit premises - In absence of any written contract between tenant and defendant - Prima facie no sub-tenancy can be said to be created in defendant's favour.

Transfer of Property Act (1882), S. 105.

heading: Sub-lease
HeadNote.description: Sub-lease - Defendant not found to be plaintiff's sub-lessee but was mere user with permission - Relation between plaintiff and defendant was of client and Advocate - Dispute essentially with respect to extent of use of premises - Plaintiff permitted use of premises but no court receiver appointed.

heading: Attachment before judgment
Plaintiff's application for
Money suit
HeadNote.description: Attachment before judgment - Plaintiff's application for - Money suit - Property sought to be attached already transferred to third party before filing of suit - Normally such property cannot be attached - But when plaintiff contended that sale being collusive to avoid creditors was hit by S.53 of Property Act - Such property can still be attached if it is shown that sale was hit by S.53.	(Para 11)

heading: Right of redemption
HeadNote.description:
Tamil Nadu District Municipalities Act (1920), S.88(4) - Constitution of India, Art.142 - Payment of property taxes, liability of - Right of redemption - Suit could be filed by Municipality apart from taking recourse for realisation of dues as land revenue.

Section 55(1)(g) of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882 envisages payment of taxes in respect of the property by the vendor up to the date of sale. The liability of the vendee to pay the property tax arises only from the date of sale. However, Sections 85 and 88 of the 1920 T.N. District Municipalities Act provide that in the event, the factum of sale is not communicated, the liability of the vendor shall continue. Consequently a statutory charge is created on the property. A person having an interest in the property, therefore, might have a right of redemption. A suit for realisation of the dues in respect of a property in respect whereof a statutory charge is created, a suit could also be filed by the Municipality, apart from taking recourse to the procedure provided for realisation of the said dues as land revenue.						 [Para 12]

heading: Separate agreement alleged
HeadNote.description: Sale deed not having reconveyance condition - Separate agreement alleged - Facts properly considered by appellate court - No reason to interfere the well reasoned order on this point - Second appeal dismissed. 	(Para 22)

heading: Pending second appeals
HeadNote.description: Addition of a party - Pending second appeals - Applications for substitution by appellants who were transferees pendente lite - Order of High Court rejecting application treating the same as additional parties and thereby rendering appellants non-suited - Is erroneous and liable to be set aside.	(Paras 17, 18)

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Substantial question of law - Dispute as to whether relationship between parties is that of lessor-lessee or licensor-licensee - Contention that substantial question of law should be whether last agreement entered between the parties creates relationship of lease or licence - Substantial question of law formulated at the time of admission of appeal was concerning with interpretation of first agreement and subsequent renewals - The same was reformulated accepting the said contention. 	(Paras 14, 18)

heading: Attachment of property
Application for
Chamber Summons
HeadNote.description: Attachment of property - Application for - Chamber Summons - Applicant who has sought to raise attachment, must show her separate and independent title to the attached premises - Instead of filing a separate suit for establishing her right in respect of immovable property claimed by her, held, she is entitled under provisions of O.21, R.54 of Civil P.C. to maintain her action in law by way of a Chamber Summons - Such application is, therefore, in the nature of a plaint - The onus lies entirely on the applicant to prove her claim.	(Para 5)

heading: Sale of share in dwelling house to stranger
HeadNote.description: Sale of share in dwelling house to stranger - Prayer for interim mandatory injunction restraining transfer of possession - Agreement to sell showing that transferee knew about transferor's limited right to transfer the property - That apart, Commissioner's report showing that transferee's articles were only in process of being brought into house - He did not vacate his earlier permanent residence - On the other hand, plaintiff had to leave from portion of house on account of the stranger entering the house - Refusal to grant interim injunction would cause irreparable injury to plaintiff - Balance of convenience also in favour of plaintiff - Hence, injunction granted. (Para 27)

heading: Mesne profit
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Mesne profit - Grant of - Court moulding relief of possession into one of partition and possession - Mesne profit can be granted not from the date of filing of suit, but from the date of decree till actual possession.			(Para 26)

heading: Execution proceedings
Maintainability
