HeadNote.description: Execution proceedings - Obstruction to delivery of possession of premises sold in auction - Maintainability - Applicant obstructionist allegedly not occupying suit premises by implied surrender of lease - Evidence on record showing that even after expiry of lease deed applicant continued to be in possession of demised premises - No new lease deed produced so as to show implied surrender - Express surrender of lease already absent for want of mutual agreement between applicant and lessor in this regard - Defendant auction purchaser failed to prove alleged non-occupation - Hence, obstruction under O.21 R.97, maintainable. 	(Paras 14, 18)

heading: Interim relief
HeadNote.description: Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest Act (2002), S.13(4) - Interim relief - Property is mortgaged by respondent no.2 for loan availed from appellant - Appellant initiated action under SARFAESI Act against Respondent no. 2 - Respondent no.1 lessee in property of respondent no.2 apprehended of dispossession - Interim injunction granted to respondent no.1 - Relief granted to respondent no.1 on assumption that appellant is served however not filed reply - Such observation cannot be sustained. (Para 8)

heading: Preliminary decree
Finality
HeadNote.description: Preliminary decree - In suit for partition - Finality - At a stage when preliminary decree already passed, respondent claimed title in part of suit property on basis of pendente lite sale deed - As per preliminary decree, person who sold the property to respondents, was entitled to only 14/104th share in it - Respondents would be bound by preliminary decree with respect to shares so determined - Issue of entitlement cannot be re-opened at the time of final decree.  AIR 1963 SC 992, (1995) 6 SCC 150 Ref. to.	(Paras 37, 39)

heading: Execution of decree
Transferee pendente lite
HeadNote.description: Execution of decree - Suit for specific performance of contract - Transferee pendente lite - Transfer of property from judgment debtor during pendency of suit - Such persons cannot claim any independent right. 	(Paras 10, 11, 17)

heading: Gift deed
HeadNote.description: Gift deed - Concurrent finding of Courts below that a document is a gift-deed - Cannot be interfered with while exercising jurisdiction under S.100 of Civil P.C.	(Para 13)

heading: Doctrine of lis pendens
HeadNote.description:
Doctrine of lis pendens - Scope and applicability of - Doctrine of lis pendens would not apply to sales after a suit is dismissed and before it is restored. (Per S. J. Vazifdar, J.).

Firstly, it is necessary to distinguish between a dismissal of a suit on merits and the filing of an appeal therefrom, from a dismissal of a suit for default and the restoration thereof pursuant to an application for the same after the period prescribed for such an application. An appeal is a continuation of the suit. The Appellant has a statutory right of appeal if it is filed within the prescribed period. Once an application for restoration is made, different considerations would apply. But, between the period of the dismissal of a suit and an application for restoration, the provisions of section 52 and principles analogous thereto cannot apply. During this period, there is no suit at all. There is no proceeding in existence. The language of section 52 indicates that it must be during the pendency of the proceedings. That a suit is deemed to have been pending throughout upon its being restored on an application is irrelevant. That is to avoid consequences such as of limitation and court fees. This view would affect the rights of third parties for no fault of theirs. Indeed, such a view would leave a clog on the title of the suit property permanently, forever. It is possible for a plaintiff to apply for restoration even after years. Indeed, our records are full of such cases where courts have, albeit for good reason, restored cases after many years. When then does the clog on title disappear ? Theoretically, never. This is irrespective of the merits of the suit or proceeding for once it is filed and dismissed, the title to the subject matter of the suit can never be clear, it is always under a cloud for an application for restoration can be made at any time. To expect innocent third parties to then adopt proceedings challenging orders of restoration is only to invite a multiplicity of proceedings. Such a view would keep the doors to fraud open permanently by the simple expedient of a person filing a suit in respect of the Defendant's property, having the same dismissed for default and then sitting back doing nothing till the plaintiff chooses to make an application for restoration. For if it is restored even after many years, all transactions between the date of its dismissal and the date even of an application for restoration, would be affected by the doctrine of lis pendens. AIR 1959 Bombay 475 - Not agreed with.  [Para 85,88]

heading: Restoration of suit
HeadNote.description:
Doctrine of lis pendens - Scope and applicability of - Restoration of suit - Restoration brings about restoration of status-quo ante which existed on the dismissal of the suit for default - The 'lis', therefore continues between the period of dismissal of a suit and restoration upon an application made under O.9, R.4 of the Civil P.C.. (Per U. D. Salvi, J.).

The Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, has provided corrective mechanism under Order 9, Rule 4 for restoration of the suit dismissed for default and for that purpose has envisaged full-fledged judicial enquiry to understand the circumstances in which the suit was dismissed for default and then to come to a conclusion regarding the material question as to whether such circumstances warranted the dismissal of the suit or not. In short, the judicial enquiry envisaged under the said provision is for examination of the legitimacy of the dismissal of the suit for the alleged default. Once the court comes to a conclusion either way the question of legitimacy of 'dismissal of the suit for default' is clearly answered. If it is found that the circumstances did not warrant the dismissal of the suit for default, such dismissal is no longer legitimate and has no existence in law. It is only in such circumstances, the suit stands restored. Restoration of the suit, therefore, brings about restoration of status-quo ante which existed on the date of the dismissal of the suit for default. In my considered opinion, the 'lis' therefore, continues between the period of dismissal of a suit and its restoration upon an application made under Order 9, Rule 4 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908. AIR 1959 Bombay 475 - Agreed with.  [Para 136,137,138]

heading: Execution
Dismissal
Legality
HeadNote.description:
Execution - Objection by transferee pendente lite - Dismissal - Legality - Evidence on record show that petitioner/transferee had knowledge of pending litigation regarding suit property - Even in 7/12 record, pendency of proceedings was mentioned - Not even a case that petitioner issued any public notice before purchasing suit property - Claim of his vendor was already rejected by court - Petitioner cannot have a better title - Petitioner was not a purchaser for value without notice - As against him, respondent/decree holder, contesting the matter for last 35 yrs. is having a better title - Dismissal of petitioner’s objection, proper.
(1998) 3 SCC 723, 2018 (6) Mh.L.J. 18 Ref. to. (Paras 17, 19, 22, 23, 24, 25)

heading: Impleadment
HeadNote.description:
Impleadment - Of pendente lite buyer - Challenge on ground of S.52 of TP Act, not tenable - Said S.52 does not absolutely prohibit transfer pendente lite - Such transfer is only subject to outcome or order of court.
	it is evident that Section 52 of the TP Act does not contain any prohibition for transfer of property pendente lite. All that Section 52 provides is that in any suit or proceeding (which is not collusive) and in which any right to immovable property is directly and specifically in question, the property cannot be transferred or otherwise dealt with by any party to the suit or proceeding “so as to affect the rights of any other party thereto”, under any decree or order which may be made therein, except under the authority of the Court and on such terms as it may impose. It can thus be seen that the transfer pendente lite governed by Section 52 of the TP Act is subject to the decree or order passed in the suit or proceeding and such transfer cannot affect the rights of any other party to the suit. There is a clear distinction between a transfer pendente lite governed by Section 52 of the TP Act and a transfer which is in breach of any prohibitory order passed by the Court. These two transfers clearly differ in so far as their effect is concerned. In the prior case, governed by Section 52, the transfer is only subject to the outcome or the order or the decree passed in the suit or proceeding as the case may be.	(Para 39)

heading: Attachment before judgment
Plaintiff's application for
Improper
HeadNote.description:
Attachment before judgment - Plaintiff's application for - No mode for avoiding voidable sale provided in Property Act - Plaintiff can avoid such sale in application for attachment before judgment and need not file separate suit - Court must decide such issue in application for attachment itself - Rejection of application merely on ground that transferees not joined as Defendants to suit - Improper - Plaintiff not required to bring fresh suit or implead transferees as party.

Vol. XV Calcutta Law Journal 649, AIR 1925 Bom. 287, AIR 1955 Pat. 270, (1867) 2 HL 325 (D), AIR 1963 SC 1150, AIR 1920 Mad. (FB) Rel. on.	(Para 18)

heading: Sub-tenancy
HeadNote.description: C.P. and Berar Letting of Houses and Rent Control Order (1949) - Sub-tenancy - Can be created only with written permission of landlord - Mere consent of landlord is not sufficient - Requirement of written permission is mandatory. 1990 Mh.L.J. 18 - Ref. to.	(Para 5)

heading: Repudiation of contract
HeadNote.description: Repudiation of contract - Property in Cantonment area - Agreement for sale of - Fact that Cantonment authorities empowered to resume land known to buyer - Sale permission by authorities on condition that purchaser would not object to resumption of property - Repudiation sought contending that condition prevented purchaser to resist illegal resumption - No valid reason exists for repudiation - Purchaser not entitled to refund of earnest money.

heading: Agreement of sale
HeadNote.description: Land Acquisition Act (1894), S.4(1) - Agreement of sale - Forfeiture of earnest money - Notification under S.4(1) of Land Acquisition Act issued after Agreement of Sale was executed - Earnest money/Advance paid to respondent by appellant, directed to be refunded to appellant on ground that parties were aware that unless and until notification was set aside, Agreement for sale, in the aforementioned situation, cannot be enforced by either of them - Held, the respondent could not have forfeited the amount of advance - Apex Court, however, agreed with High Court that enforcement of agreement for sale would be inequitable.		 (Paras 12 & 13)

heading: Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Termination of tenancy - Notice under S.106 of T.P. Act - Proof of service of notice - Held, initial burden is upon person sending notice to show that he did all that was necessary to get notice served upon other side in normal circumstances - Once he establishes this, the burden shifts to other side to show that Postal endorsements like - "Not-claimed" or "unclaimed" or "not found" are incorrect because it was never tendered to him or to his authorized representative - He has to enter witness box and prove this before court - He may also examine postman for that purpose - Mere taking stand of denial of service or incorrectness of remark in written statement is not sufficient in law. 2001(2) ALL MR 415, AIR 1989 SC 630 and 2002(7) SCC 531(2) - Ref. to.	(Para 12)

heading: Lease agreement
Renewal and termination
HeadNote.description: Registration Act (1908) S.17 - Lease agreement - Renewal and termination - Lease agreement entered in 1965 for 10 years - Option of renewal open to lessee for 3 more terms - Original lessee exercised that option in 1975 under registered deed - Successor lessee i.e. Central Govt. continued in possession for next two terms by sending letters to lessor - No fresh deed executed or registered - Option of renewal cannot be said to be exercised - Lease deed was effective only up to 1985 - However, in view of S.7(3), period up to 1995 can be taken as statutory continuation - Lease stood terminated thereafter. (1994) 4 SCC 450 Ref.to. 			(Paras 10 to 14)

heading: Effect
HeadNote.description: Contract for sale of property - Incorrect drafting of agreement - Effect - Held, the wrong and/or incorrect drafting of the agreement and/or vagueness in the agreement even if any, with regard to the transfer of share and/or payment or non-payment of TDS that itself cannot be the reason to overlook the other clear terms of the contract for sale of the property. 	 (Para 19)

heading: Validity of transfer of property by gift to a minor
HeadNote.description:
Validity of transfer of property by gift to a minor - Presumption as to its acceptance - Revocability of gift deed - Gift made by mother to her minor son - It was revoked by donor after lapse of 25 years - Mean while minor who had attained majority had not repudiated the gift - Held revocation is not valid.

Under the Transfer of Property Act read with the Indian Contract Act the acquisition of property being generally beneficial, a child can take property in any manner whatsoever either under intestacy or by Will or by purchase or gift or other assurance inter vivos, except where it is clearly to his prejudice to do so. A gift inter-vivos to a child cannot be revoked. There is a presumption in favour of the validity of a gift of a parent or a grandparent to a child, if it is complete. When a gift is made to a child, generally there is a presumption of its acceptance because express acceptance in his case is not possible and only an implied  acceptance can be expected.   [Para 21]

Where a gift is made in favour of a child of the donor, who is the guardian of the child, the acceptance of a gift can be  presumed to have been made by him or on his behalf without any overt act signifying acceptance by the minor. In the instant case, mother who is the natural guardian gifted the property to her minor son in the  year 1945. The donee was an educated lad of 16 years of age, capable of understanding and living jointly with the donor. Knowledge of the execution of the gift would have  been derived in normal circumstances, by the minor, being beneficiary, sooner or later after its execution. Knowledge of gift deed to both the parents as natural guardians  and the donee is sufficient to indicate acceptance of gift by the minor himself or on his behalf by the parents. The gift deed was revoked by the mother much after its  execution as late as in the year 1970. By that time, the donee had become major and he never repudiated the gift. Non-  delivery of possession of the gifted property, non-exercise of any rights of ownership over it, and failure by the donee, on attaining majority, in getting his name mutated in  official records are not circumstances negativing the presumption of acceptance by the minor during his minority or on his  attaining majority. The donor had reserved to herself, under the terms of gift deed, the right to manage, possess and enjoy the  property during her lifetime. Since the possession and enjoyment of the property including management of the school were  retained by the donor during her life time, the acceptance of the ownership of the  property gifted could be by silent acceptance. Such acceptance is confirmed by its non- repudiation by his parents and by him on attaining majority.						      [Para 25]

In the case of a minor donee receiving a gift from her parents, no express acceptance can be expected  and is possible, and acceptance can be implied even by mere silence or such conduct of the minor donee and his other natural guardian as not to indicate any disapproval or repudiation of it.   [Para 30]

Therefore, the Trial Court and the High Court were wrong in coming to the conclusion that there was no valid acceptance of the gift by the minor donee. Consequently, conclusion has to follow that the gift having been duly accepted in law and thus being complete, it  was irrevocable under Section 126 of the Transfer of Property Act. Section 126 prohibits revocation of a validly executed  gift except in circumstances mentioned therein. The gift was executed in 1945. It remained in force for about 25 years during which time the donee had attained majority and had not repudiated the same. It was therefore, not competent for the donor to  have cancelled the gift and executed a Will in relation to the property.   [Para 31]

heading: Sale of land
HeadNote.description: Sale of land - Society sold land purchased for scheme - Agreement between Society and purchaser was executed for protection of purchaser - Purchaser can give up protection and release money in favour of society - Conveyance is not contrary to agreement.		(Para 5)

heading: Cancellation of letter of acceptance
HeadNote.description: Cancellation of letter of acceptance - Plaintiff received letter of acceptance of bid for development of 'Garment Park' - Letter of acceptance was cancelled as plaintiff could not pay installment of development fees within extended period - Plaintiff ready to make payment subject to defendant clarifying about existing claims, measurements, demarcation etc. of land - Plaintiff itself raised question of discharge of various obligations by defendant - Hence contention of plaintiff that validity of order of cancellation of acceptance letter has to be judged on sole reason stated in order of cancellation is unsustainable - Defendant can defend its action on other grounds also.		(Para 16)

heading: Letter of acceptance of bid
HeadNote.description:
Letter of acceptance of bid - What right it creates in favour of successful bidder/plaintiff - Payment of development fee in installment and furnishing bank guarantee as performance security within stipulated time by Plaintiff - These are 2 pre-conditions for execution of development agreement as per letter of acceptance - Failure to comply with these conditions by plaintiff resulted in cancellation of letter of acceptance - Plaintiff has no right to seek specific performance of execution of Development Agreement.

Inspite of extension of time to pay first installment of development fees plaintiff failed to make payment.  Plaintiff also did not furnish bank guarantee as performance security. As per clauses in letter of acceptance failure to fulfill these conditions would result into forfeiture of bid security, rejection of bid, withdrawal of letter of acceptance.  Contention that plaintiff is ready and willing to make payment subject to defendant clarifying position about existing claims, litigations, measurement, demarcations etc. regarding land.  But there is no specific condition in bid document that compliance of two conditions by plaintiff is subject to discharge of any obligation on part of defendant.  Plaintiff has failed to comply with conditions. Plaintiff has prima facie no right to get specific performance of execution of Development Agreement.	 [Para 20,21]

heading: Letter of acceptance of bid
HeadNote.description: Letter of acceptance of bid - Contention that letter of acceptance grants development rights including execution of sell agreement, formation of society etc. to plaintiff and is specifically enforceable - Development agreement is not executed due to failure to comply with conditions i.e. payment of development fees and furnishing of bank guarantee - No concluded contract is there and no rights and duties of parties are stated in letter of acceptance - Plaintiff/developer has no development rights as development agreement is not executed. 2007(3) Mh.L.J. 402, 2009(1) Mh.L.J. 611 - Distinguished.			(Paras 22, 24, 26)

heading: Doctrine of fairness
HeadNote.description: Execution of development agreement - Doctrine of fairness - Contention that defendant/public authority without clarifying about existing claims, measurements, and demarcation etc. of land cannot insist upon fulfillment of conditions in letter of acceptance - Defendant being public authority cannot act arbitrarily - Terms of letter of acceptance are accepted by plaintiff - If commercial venture doctrine of fairness and reasonableness for altering terms of Contract or question of public law based on Art.14 of Constitution have no role to play - As plaintiff has failed to fulfill conditions in letter of acceptance, it has no right to get development agreement executed. 2002(3) Mh.L.J. 530 - Followed.	(Para 28)

heading: Agreement of development of 'Garment Park'
HeadNote.description: Agreement of development of 'Garment Park' - Plaintiff/developer to pay development fees and bank guarantee as performance security to get development agreement executed - Contention that it is implied obligation on defendant to get land measured and demarcated etc. before asking plaintiff to fulfill conditions - Failure of plaintiff to fulfill conditions - Agreement of development not executed - No implied obligations are there on defendant.			(Para 29)

heading: Letter of acceptance of bid
HeadNote.description: Letter of acceptance of bid - Project of developing 'Garment Park' - Payment of development fees and furnishing bank guarantee was pre-condition for plaintiff to get development agreement executed - Various communications were issued by defendant to state exact area and boundaries of land - Pre-bid meeting was held by defendant to clarify all doubts of plaintiff - Communications issued to facilitate plaintiff in advance in development of project - Communications do not alter terms of acceptance letter by stating measurement, demarcation, sanctions etc. are pre-conditions to comply with letter of acceptance.	(Paras 30, 31)

heading: Eviction suit of landlord settled by compromise out of court
HeadNote.description: Eviction suit of landlord settled by compromise out of court - Under the compromise, Landlord permitted tenant to remain in suit premises upto certain time on payment of Harjana i.e. damages/mesne profits - Such compromise does not create fresh tenancy.		(Para 10)

heading: Undue influence
HeadNote.description: Undue influence - Gift of property to son out of love and affection - Father cannot subsequently turn around and say that son was to fulfill a promise - It is one thing that execution of deed is based on aspiration or belief but it is another thing to say that same constituted an onerous gift.	(Para 23)

heading: Suit for eviction
Splitting of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - Rights of lessor transferee - Splitting of tenancy - Splitting of tenancy and eviction of tenant from portion purchased by landlord is not prohibited - Held, because of transfer and operation of S.109 of T.P. Act, severance is brought about automatically and apportionment of rent is not "sine qua non" for seeking such permission. AIR 1963 Pat 85 and AIR 1968 SC 438 - Ref. to.			 (Para 19)

heading: Sale of leasehold rights
HeadNote.description:
Sale of leasehold rights - Company under liquidation and winding up order passed - Occupant is in possession of property and claiming to have paid consideration towards purchase of leasehold rights of company - Occupant could not prove that transaction is in interest of company - Burden cannot be put on official liquidator to plead and prove that transaction was fraudulent - Official liquidator has limited resources and limited access to relevant records - Contention in this regard is liable to be rejected.

1992 (75) Com. Cas. 89,  AIR 1963 SC 1150, 1986 (60) Com.Cas. 746, 2008 (5) Bom. CR. 112 Ref. to. 	 [Para 22]

heading: Sale of leasehold rights
HeadNote.description:
Sale of leasehold rights - Company under liquidation and winding up order passed - Occupant is in possession of property and claiming to have paid consideration towards purchase of leasehold rights of company - There is no agreement entered into between Company and occupant - How occupant was put in to possession of property, is unclear - Occupant merely relies on letter addressed by Company to MIDC seeking their no objection for transfer of said property to occupant - Such letter would not constitute agreement in writing for purpose of S.53 A - Reliance placed by occupant on S.53 A is of no assistance - Argument in this regard is liable to be rejected.

2004 (8) SCC 614, AIR 1943 Bom. 406 Ref. to.   	 [Para 23]

heading: Estoppel
HeadNote.description: Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest Act (2002), S.2(zd) - Estoppel - Principle of approbate and reprobate - Appellant-company initially staking claim for being substituted as secured creditor under SARFAESI Act consequent to assignment of debt to it by IFCI - Company Judge rejected said claim - After rejection of claim appellant submitting that it has never sought substitution as secured creditor and it had simply desired to be adjudged as transferee from IFCI of an actionable claim u/S.130 of TP Act - Appellant cannot take such plea after rejection of claim, in view of principle of approbate and reprobate.  (Paras 8, 10, 11, 12)

heading: Licence or lease
Intention of
Parties
HeadNote.description:
Licence or lease - Intention of - Parties - Word "Licence" used in heading of agreement - This is an additional circumstance which could be considered as to what was the intention of the parties at the time of execution of the agreement - In deciding whether the agreement creates a lease or license, the test of exclusive possession though not decisive is of singnifcance.

It must be seen that in deciding whether a grant amounts to a lease or is only a licence, regard must be had to the substance of the agreement.  Intention of the parties to an agreement examined in the light of the surrounding circumstances.  The description given by the parties may be evidence of the intention, but it is not decisive.  Mere use of the words appropriate to the creation of a lease will not preclude the agreement operating as a licence.  A recital that the agreement does not create a tenancy is also not decisive.  The crucial test in each case is whether the instrument is intended to create or not to create an interest in the property. If it is in fact intended to create an interest in the property, it is a lease. If it does not, it is a licence.  In deciding whether the agreement creates a lease or a licence the test of exclusive possession, though not decisive, is of significance. [Para 19]

The word 'licence' used in the heading of the agreement is an additional circumstances, which could be considered, as to what was the intention of the parties at the time of the execution of the agreement.  The validity of the agreement was only for the period of one year i.e. from 14th September, 1972 to 13th September, 1973. Though the plaintiff continued to be in possession after the expiry of the period of one year, by no stretch of imagination, it could be said that the licence granted to him could be converted into lease. 1988 SCC 155, AIR 1970 SC 1201 and AIR 1976 Bom. 417 - Referred to.  [Para 25]

heading: Execution of gift deed
HeadNote.description:
Execution of gift deed - Examination of attesting witness - Not mandatory, unless execution of gift deed specifically denied by the other party.

	The appellants challenged the gift deed on account of probabilities as the witnesses were not related to the family or the friends or that the gift was not for religious or charitable purposes. The other challenge was on the ground of forgery or fabrication. The entire reading of the plaint does not show that there was any specific denial of execution of the gift deed. 

	Order VI Rule 4 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 warrants that in all cases in which allegation of any misrepresentation, fraud, breach of trust, willful default, or undue influence, the necessary particulars are required to be stated in the pleadings.

	The appellants went to trial on the basis of fabrication of gift deed. The appellants have admitted the execution of the gift deed but alleged the same to be forged or fabricated. However, the appellants have not been able to prove any forgery in the execution of the gift deed.

	In the absence of any evidence of any forgery or fabrication and in the absence of specific denial of the execution of the gift deed, the Donee was under no obligation to examine one of the attesting witnesses of the gift deed. 

1984 SCC OnLine Ker 174 Ref. to. 2000(4) ALL MR 587 (S.C.), 2009 ALL SCR 1289 Disting. 	 [Para 31,36,38,41]

heading: Lapse of tenancy
Notice
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Rent Control Act (1999) - Lapse of tenancy - Notice - Status of tenant after lapse of tenancy period is practically that of an unauthorised occupant - Notice u/s.106 of T.P. Act would not be necessary - Possession of such a tenant is without any legal right - Hence, held, appellant does not get any protection under the provisions of Maharashtra Rent Control Act, 1999. AIR 1981 SC 1550 - Rel. on.	(Para 24)

heading: Tenant's estoppel
Applicability of
HeadNote.description: Tenant's estoppel - Applicability of - Suit for eviction on ground of forfeiture of tenancy - Plea of tenant that he could not be held liable for eviction on ground of forfeiture of tenancy - Tenant lost suit in which he claimed declaration that landlady was not owner - He also objected rent control application on ground that landlady not being owner, application was not maintainable - Said objection was upheld by Rent Controller - On one hand tenant took specific objection about maintainability of application before Rent Controller on ground that she was not landlady - On other hand claimed that he could not be held liable for eviction on ground of forfeiture of tenancy - Tenant blew hot and cold - Tenant's act of denial of derivative title of landlady was malafide and false and tenant's estoppel will apply.	(Paras 7, 8, 12)

heading: Doctrine of estoppel
HeadNote.description:
Testamentary disposition by a Mohammedan - Doctrine of estoppel - Scope and applicability of - Claim of share by heir expectant - Doctrine of estoppel is attracted so as to prevent a person from receiving an advantage for giving up of his/her rights and yet claiming the same right subsequently - Being opposed to public policy, the heir expectant would be estopped under the general law from claiming a share in the property of the deceased.

A testamentary disposition by a Mohammedan is binding upon the heirs if the heirs consent to the disposition of the entire property and such consent could either be express or implied. Thus, a Mohammedan may also make a disposition of his entire property if all the heirs signified their consent to the same. In other words, the general principle that a Mohammedan cannot by Will dispose of more than a third of his estate after payment of funeral expenses and debts is capable of being avoided by the consent of all the heirs. In effect, the same also amounts to a right of relinquishment of future inheritance which is on the one hand forbidden and on the other accepted in the case of testamentary disposition. Having accepted the consideration for having relinquished a future claim or share in the estate of the deceased, it would be against public policy if such a claimant be allowed the benefit of the doctrine of spes successionis. In such cases, the principle of estoppel would be attracted.

The doctrine of estoppel is attracted so as to prevent a person from receiving an advantage for giving up of his/her rights and yet claiming the same right subsequently. Being opposed to public policy, the heir expectant would be estopped under the general law from claiming a share in the property of the deceased, as was held in Gulam Abbas's case (supra). A.I.R. 1973 SC 554 - Rel. on.  [Para 24,25]

heading: Benami transaction
Evidence
Adverse inference
HeadNote.description: Benami transaction - Evidence - Adverse inference - Property purchased in wife's name - No apparent motive for benami purchase brought out - Plaintiff-daughters deposing that father acknowledged mother's title - Defendant himself not witness nor examining persons knowing facts, adverse inference drawn.	(Paras 5, 33, 37, 39)

heading: Title of landlord
Challenge
Bar also
HeadNote.description: Title of landlord - Challenge - Bar also - Members of plaintiff Housing Society claiming tenancy in respect of tenements occupied by them - Thus having accepted Housing Society as their landlord, tenants cannot challenge title of landlord in respect of said tenaments - Challenge to title of landlord by members of Housing Society, clearly attract S.111(9) of T.P. Act 1882. 	(Para 90)

heading: Evidence Act (1872)
Unregistered lease agreement
Admissibility
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872) - Unregistered lease agreement - Admissibility - Non-registration of document would not come in way of Court to hold that relationship of "Landlord and Tenant" between parties is established, if other evidence available on record - Such unregistered document can be used for collateral purposes and hence, admissible in evidence. (2000) 6 SCC 394 Ref. to. 	(Para 12)

heading: Acquiescence and estoppels
HeadNote.description: Acquiescence and estoppels - Vested right is established such as ownership - It can be divested only by sale or gift - Mere latches or standing by itself may not be sufficient to extinguish title - Merely saying that a person has abandoned his property, does not lead to extinguishing of such vested right. 	(Para 79)

heading: Sale of agricultural land
HeadNote.description: Sale of agricultural land - Will have to be held as governed by conditions prescribed under Tenancy Act - Special provisions in Tenancy Act will prevail over those in T.P. Act.	(Para 60)

heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction - Issue of notice to tenant under S.106 of Transfer of Property Act - Is a mere surplusage and not necessary.

For the eviction of a tenant under any State Rent Control Act it is not necessary to give notice under Section 106 Transfer of Property Act.  Determination of lease in accordance with the Transfer of Property Act is unnecessary and a mere surplusage because the landlord cannot get eviction of the tenant even after such determination.  The tenant continues to be so even thereafter.  Making out a case under the Rent act for eviction of the tenant by itself is sufficient and it is not obligatory to found the proceedings on the basis of the determination of the lease by issue of notice in accordance with Section 106 Transfer of Property Act.	 [Para 5]

Even if the category of tenant which is stated in Section 5(11)(b) of Bombay Rent Act which says that even after the termination of tenancy the person continues to be a tenant, is not included in the Maharashtra Rent Control Act, when the tenant cannot be evicted unless the grounds are made out and the conditions laid down under Section 16 of the Maharashtra Rent Control Act are fulfilled, there would be no dual requirement one of the issuance of notice under section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act and then making out a ground under that section for eviction.  Of course, a special provision can be made in a Rent Act requiring the issuance of a notice under Sec.106 Transfer of Property Act, as it was there in C.P. & Berar Letting of Premises and Rent Control Order 1949.  But in Maharashtra Rent Control Act there is no such provision.  In view of the above discussion the notice under Section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act was not necessary in the present case.  The counsel for defendant/revision petitioner vehemently argued that the notice under Section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act was actually issued by the plaintiff/respondent and thereafter the rent was accepted which amounts to waiver.  However, when the notice itself was redundant there was no question of any waiver.  AIR 1979 SC 1745 and 2003(3) ALL MR 201 - Followed.	   [Para 17,18]

heading: Registration Act (1908), Ss.17(1)(d), 49
HeadNote.description:
Registration Act (1908), Ss.17(1)(d), 49 - Lease of plot for five years - Lease deed not registered - Cannot be admitted in evidence but can be taken into consideration for collateral purposes.

In the present case, the lease for any period exceeding one year was compulsorily registrable document requiring the registration charges and the stamp duty in accordance with law. The Court was, no doubt, wrong to admit the document of lease into evidence when it was compulsorily registrable according to the law in view of the provisions in Section 55 of the Maharashtra Rent Control Act read along with Section 17(1) (d) of the Registration Act and further read along with Section 107 of the Transfer of Property Act. But then, the document can be taken into consideration for collateral purposes, for proving the nature and character of possession of the tenant and ascertaining whether the purpose of lease was residential or not and for ascertaining the commencement of possession, rate of rent etc.  [Para 15]

heading: Eviction proceeding
Employee expired
HeadNote.description:
Eviction proceeding - Agreement of sale between a Trust and Municipal Corporation - Corporation making part payment, put in possession of property including suit premises, service quarter - Premises in dilapidated condition - Employee expired - Trust representatives not objecting to absolute possession by Corporation - Suit premises qua LRs. of deceased employee cannot be said to be not 'corporation premises' - Ownership or title may be relevant qua Trust - Order of eviction upheld. 
1994 Mh L. J. 497 Ref. to.
(1973) 1 SCC 51, AIR 1980 Bom. 48 Dist.
AIR 1982 Bom.443, AIR 1965 SC 1923 Rel. on. 	(Paras 12, 16)

heading: Gift
Legality
HeadNote.description:
Muslim Law, Ss.149, 150(3) - Registration Act (1908), Ss.17, 49 - Civil P.C. (1908), O.8, R.1-A - Gift - Document of, filed by defendant - Court refused to exhibit the same for want of registration - Legality - Perusal of document shows that it is a Gift or Hiba under Mohamaden Law - Not being a gift u/s.123 of Transfer of Property Act it is not compulsorily registerable - S.150(3) of Mulla's principles also states that a gift made by Mohammedan donor in writing is not compulsorily registerable - Court ought to have exhibited the document concerned.

A bare perusal of document in question prima-facie shows that it is not a gift made u/s.123 of Transfer of Property Act, as the Mohammaden denor in this case has merely made a statement before the panchas in regard to the gift and the same was incorporated in writing and got signed by five panchas. It prima facie appears to be a gift under Mohammaden Law.  Merely because, there is no mention in application filed by defendant that gift was one under Mohammaden Law, it cannot be said that the gift was compulsorily registerable.  It was necessary for Court to fist consider that document concerned.

U/s.149 of Mulla's Principles of Mohammaden Law, there are only 3 essential conditions of a valid gift and those are 1) declaration of gift by donor 2) acceptance of gift, express or implied, by or on behalf of the donee, and 3) delivery of possession of subject of gift by the donor to the donee.  It is stated in S.150 that if these conditions are complied with, the gift is complete.  In fact sub-sec. (3) provides that if it is proved by oral evidence that gift was complete as required by law, it is immaterial that the donor has also executed the deed of gift, but the deed had not been registered as required by Registration Act u/s.17.  Thus u/s.150(3) of Mulla's Principles of Mohammedan Law a gift made by Mohammedan donor in writing is not compulsorily registerable.		 [Para 7,8]

heading: Suit for eviction
Change of user
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - Change of user - Premises let out for residence - Defendant storing cloth packages and bales of clothes and also used to store packages in common passage - During mango season defendant conducting business of storage and sale of mangoes to dealers and public - His activities resulting in damage, diminishing value and nuisance to co-tenants - Held, from concurrent findings of facts it was clear that user for residence was changed into commercial.			(Paras 31, 36, 37)

heading: Eviction u/S.15(2)
Challenge
HeadNote.description:
Eviction u/S.15(2) - Challenge - On ground that notice issued is not in compliance with S.106 of TP Act - Held, requirement of S.15(2) of Rent Control Act is only in respect of service of notice demanding arrears and not in relation to termination of tenancy - In absence of any requirement of terminating of lease, compliance with S.106, is not necessary.

2001 Law Suit (Guj) 17 Dissented from.

2009(5) ALL MR 144, 1979 Mh.L.J. 773 (SC) Rel. on. 	(Paras 6, 7, 8, 9)

heading: Lease
Definition
Scope
HeadNote.description:
Lease - Definition - Scope - The definition of the term “lease” under Section 2(n) of Stamp Act is distinct from the definition of the term “lease” under Section 105 of Transfer of Property Act - Under Section 2(n) of Stamp Act term is not restrictive - Besides a lease of immovable or movable property or both, any instrument by which tolls of any description are let is also included in the said definition - Term “let” in the context of rent legislation has a different connotation and the same would not be relevant in the present Context - In Black’s Law Dictionary, the word ‘let’ also means to allow or to Permit - A lease therefore would also include any instrument by which tolls of any description are let.
(2011) 4 SCC 575 Rel.on.
(1999) 5 SCC 708 Disting. (Paras 9, 10)

headline:
(1) Maharashtra Stamps Act, 1958 – S. 2(l), Sch. I, Art. 36 – Stamp duty – Determination of - Concession Agreement- Constructing party entitled to recover project cost by toll collection from vehicles
Concession agreement creates right in favour of Petitioner to recover fees from vehicles using bridge; is an “instrument” u/S.2(l) and chargeable w/stamp duty u/Art.36

(2) Maharashtra Stamps Act, 1958 – S.2(n) - Transfer of Property Act, 1882, S.105 -- Lease – Definition – Scope - Definition of term “lease” u/Section 2(n) of Stamp Act is distinct from definition of term “lease” u/Section 105 of Transfer of Property Act - For distinction, see headnote below.

heading: Waiver of termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Waiver of termination of tenancy - Cannot be presumed by mere acceptance of rent unless it is done deliberately or intentionally. (Para 13)

heading: Scope
Mortgaged lands
HeadNote.description: Restriction on transfer, sub-division, etc. of land in notified area - Scope - Mortgaged lands - Held, restoration of possession of mortgagor does not amount to transfer U/S.12.	(Para 8)

heading: Sale
HeadNote.description: Sale - Property mortgaged with bank - Plaintiff sold property without prior permission of bank - Restriction is imposed only to safeguard loan amount - Defendant purchaser has paid entire outstanding loan amount - Sale transaction is not void ab initio - Second appeal liable to be dismissed. 2004(4) ALL MR 746, AIR 1997 SC 3479 - Ref. to.	(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Sale
HeadNote.description: Sale - Property mortgaged with bank - Plaintiff sold property without prior permission of bank - Recitals in sale-deed that property is free from encumbrances - Also that if there is any encumbrance plaintiff will be responsible - Prior permission of bank though not obtained - Plaintiff is estopped from challenging validity of sale.	(Para 12)

heading: Sale
HeadNote.description: Sale - Property mortgaged with bank - Plaintiff sold property without prior permission of bank - Sale transaction void only to extent of bank with which property is mortgaged prior to sale in favour of defendant.	(Para 14)

heading: Civil P.C. (1908), S.9
HeadNote.description:
Civil P.C. (1908), S.9 - Suit for recovery of "open plot" - Jurisdiction of Civil Court - Landlord can (after 31-3-2000) recover possession of "open plot" by a suit in accordance with general law - Held, permission under Rent Control Order was not necessary prior to the date of institution of suit.

Earlier the landlord of "open plot" was required to approach the Rent Controller for permission to initiate recovery suit as the word "House" was replaced by the word "premises" with effect from 21.7.1989 and clause 13-A was added to the Rent Control Order on 26.10.1989. It was statutory disability of the Landlord of "open plot" included in definition of 'premises' due to restriction introduced as above in the Rent Control Orders which was removed by the Maharashtra Rent Act, 1999 with effect from 31.3.2000. Thus, landlord became free to enforce his right under section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882 and to terminate tenancy. Jurisdiction of the Civil Court to pass decree of eviction and execute it, is restored and hence, landlord can (after 31.3.2000) recover possession of 'open plot' by a suit in accordance with general law.						 [Para 16]

When the legislature brought into force the Maharashtra Rent Control Act, 1999, provisions of new Rent Act gave option for the Landlord to continue with the proceedings before the Rent Controller under the old Repealed Rent Control Order if he so desires or to institute a fresh proceeding under the new Act or to recover "open plot" of land not included in the definition of "premises" under the new Maharashtra Rent Act, the landlord has remedy w.e.f. 31.3.2000 under the General Law i.e. Transfer of Property Act, 1882 to recover possession of open plot by approaching the competent Civil Court. Under this changed legal scenario, landlord of the "open plot" cannot be compelled to start a fresh proceedings before the Rent Control Authority under the repealed Act to obtain permission to initiate legal proceedings against Tenant. In the present case, learned Counsel for the Appellant (defendant-tenant) could not point out any provision to urge that the landlord was restricted by the then prevalent Rent Control Order from exercising his right under the General Law and approaching the competent Civil Court on the basis of notice to quit issued under Section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1992 at the time when the suit was instituted on 3.10.1988 in the trial Court. Therefore, the conclusions by the Courts below were based upon the evidence led, the admissions given and the settled position of law as then existing and conceded to. The Courts below, therefore, were right to hold that permission under the Rent Control Order was not necessary prior to the date before institution of suit in this case. (1990)7 SCC 303 & 2008(6) Mh.L.J. 482 - Ref. to.  [Para 17]

heading: Open land
HeadNote.description: Scope and applicability of Rent Control Act - Open land - Suit for recovery of possession  of open land - Held, Maharashtra Rent Control Act is not applicable to the open land - Parties to the suit would be governed by the Transfer of Property Act.  2006(2) ALL MR 133 - Rel. 		(Paras 15 and 16)

heading: Suit for eviction
Bar on filing
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction - Bar on filing - Statutory obligation upon the landlord - Issuance of notice in writing of the demand of standard rent - Service of it and expiration of the period of ninety days - Compliance of conditions precedent for institution of suit for recovery of possession - Landlord would be permitted to proceed.

Sub-section (2) of Section 15 of the said Act creates a bar for institution of the suit for recovery of possession by a landlord against the tenant on the ground of non-payment of standard rent or permitted increases due, until the expiration of ninety days next after the notice in writing of the demand of the standard rent or permitted increases has been served upon the tenant in the manner provided in Section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882. If the notice, as contemplated by sub-section (2) of Section 15 of the said Act, is not issued, then the suit for recovery cannot be instituted. So the issuance of the notice in writing, service of it upon the tenant in the manner provided in Section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act and expiration of the period of ninety days are only the conditions precedent for institution of the suit for recovery of possession. This, however, does not mean that if compliance of sub-section (2) of Section 15 of the said Act is shown, the suit cannot be instituted. This provision merely creates certain statutory obligation upon the landlord and upon compliance of it, permits the landlord to proceed to institute a suit and it has no other effect.	 [Para 4]

heading: Necessity
HeadNote.description:
Registration Act (1908), S.49 - Notice u/s.164 MCS Act - Necessity - Suit for possession of immovable property - Plaintiff purchased property from Liquidator of Society in public auction - Defendant tenant is still in possession of property - Transaction is not touching business of Society - Notice under S.164 is not necessary. 
2002(3) Mh.L.J. 837, 2005(1) ALL MR 556 Disting. (Para 39)

heading: Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Termination of tenancy - Contention that provision of Transfer of Property Act are excluded from operation to tenancies governed by Tenancy Act - Notice issued mentions provision u/S.106 T.P. Act and also S.19 of Tenancy Act - Order of Tahasildar granting 3 months time for payment of arrears - On failure to make payment, tenancy is terminated - It shows that Tahasildar has exercised jurisdiction u/S.30(1) - Contention that notice issued as per TP Act, cannot be sustained. 1980 Mh.L.J. 699, 1983 SC 537 Ref. to. 			(Paras 4, 7)

heading: Service of statutory notice on tenant
HeadNote.description:
Service of statutory notice on tenant - Notice by registered post - Proof of endorsement "intimation given" - Not necessary for landlord to examine postman to prove intimation.
2003 (4) Bom CR 612, 2005 (4) Mh.L.J. 577 Rel.on.
2001 (2) MhLJ 342, 2004 (4) MhLJ 873 Not foll.(Paras 37, 40)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Occupancy Class II land - Restriction on transfer of - Applicability - Word 'transfer' nowhere defined in MLRC - Analogy as per provisions of S.5 of TP Act have to be applied to expression 'transfer' under MLRC - For purpose of S.29(3)(a) of MLRC transfer by executing Will is not prohibited as testamentary disposition would not amount to transfer - Restriction u/S. 29(3)(a) will not be applicable to transfer by execution of Will. 		(Para 9)

heading: Lease of sick sugar factory
HeadNote.description: Lease of sick sugar factory - Consent of recognized Union of workers, with willingness of workers to curtailment of their dearness allowance - Condition of written consent of recognized union of workers before giving the sick sugar factory to be run on lease - Condition must be treated as a mandatory requirement. Securitization and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest Act (2002), Ss.13(2), 13(13). 		(Para 19)

heading: Eviction
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Ground that condition of tenancy is broken - It is not necessary for plaintiff-landlord to issue prior notice of termination u/s.106 of T.P. Act - Such a notice even if served, does not terminate tenancy which continues to be so. 

AIR 1979 SC 1745 Rel. on.  (Para 8)

heading: Transfer of property by senior citizen
HeadNote.description: Transfer of property by senior citizen - Condition as to provision for basic amenities and basic physical needs to senior citizen - Such condition has to be expressly stated in document of transfer, which transfer can only be one by way of gift or which partakes character of gift. (Paras 28, 29, 35, 51, 52)

heading: Transfer of property by senior citizen
HeadNote.description: Transfer of property by senior citizen - Claim for declaring transfer as void - Document is settlement deed wherein there is reservation of right of residence in residential building as also to take usufructs from standing coconut trees in property - But there is no express condition as to provision for basic amenities and basic physical needs to senior citizen stated in document - Life interest reserved in document, cannot also lead to such condition being implied or inferred - Transfer cannot be declared void - Order of Tribunal granting maintenance of Rs.2,500/-, proper. (Para 53)

heading: Suit for possession on ground of non-payment of rent
HeadNote.description:
Suit for possession on ground of non-payment of rent - Service of demand notice not proved - No decree for possession can be passed on ground of default.

In the instant case, the notice of demand dated 13th September, 1978 was posted on 15th September, 1978 as can be seen from the postal stamp on the postal money receipt. The panch witness has stated that the notice was affixed to the outer door of the suit premises on 28th September, 1978. No explanation is offered as to why the plaintiff felt the necessity of serving the notice by pasting on 28th September, 1978 i.e. 13 days after the notice was despatched by registered post. The respondent had not even made an enquiry with the post office as to whether the notice was delivered to the addressee before resorting to service by pasting. The respondent has not stated anything as to why he felt the need of service of notice by pasting. The panch witness who was examined to prove the pasting of notice has stated in the examination-in-chief that he knew both the plaintiff and the defendant.  He has further stated that at the time of pasting he himself, the plaintiff and the defendant and one witness were present. If the petitioner-defendant was personally present, when the notice was pasted to the outer door as alleged, the notice could very well have been tendered and personally delivered to the addressee (the petitioner) which is one of the modes of service prescribed under section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882.  Nobody has stated that the notice was tendered to the petitioner and was not accepted by him and therefore it was pasted. Therefore, case of the respondent that the notice was pasted to the outer door in presence of the petitioner-defendant is totally unbelievable. Even the appellate Court has not held that service of notice by pasting was proved. Thus, the respondent has not proved the service of notice either by pasting or by registered post A.D. Section 12 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates (Control) Act, 1947 requires a notice of demand to be issued before filing of the suit for possession on the ground of non payment of rent. A suit can be filed only after the expiry of 30 days of the notice of demand in writing. In the present case, the service of notice of demand is not proved. Therefore, the respondent was not entitled to file a suit for possession on the ground of default and no decree for possession could be passed on that ground.   [Para 7,8]

heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - Disclaimer of title of lessor - Defendant No.1 the lessee, getting his name entered not only in Revenue Record but also Grampanchayat record as an owner of the property while fully knowing the fact that he was mere lessee in the property and the property was owned by plaintiffs and other defendants - Conduct of defendant No.1 amounts to disclaimer of title of Plaintiffs - No formal notice is required to be given to defendant No.1 of determining the tenancy before filing suit.	(Para 7)

heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction - Suit filed by co-owner - Suit is maintainable in law - It is not necessary for a co-owner to show before initiating eviction proceedings before a Rent Controller that he had taken consent of the other co-owners.

Most of the States in India have enacted Rent Acts which prohibit eviction of tenants except on the grounds specified therein. Where a Rent Act giving protection to a tenant is not applicable, the rights of the parties are governed by the Transfer of Property Act, 1882. In a case where the rights are governed purely by the Transfer of Property Act, a co-owner can file a suit for eviction of a tenant by joining other co-owner, whether consenting or not, as party defendant to the suits. The need to file suit alone only by joining the other co-owner as party defendant to the suit may arise under various circumstances. In some cases a co-owner may not be available for signing of the plaint though he may have consented to the filing of the suit. In some cases, a co-owner may not agree to share the expenses of litigation and on that count may refuse to sign the plaint. In such cases the suit can be filed by joining the co-owner as a party defendant. In yet another case, a co-owner may collude with the tenant or for any collateral reason refuse to join the other co-owners in filing of the suit. In such a case, the other co-owners are not helpless. They can certainly file a suit against the tenant by joining the dissenting co-owner as party defendant to the suit. This is the position in law where a suit is governed by the Transfer of Property Act. 						 [Para 9]

heading: Claim of tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Claim of tenancy - Claim based on lease deed - Lease deed not executed by the landlord - No evidence given as to why landlord did not execute it, why his consent was not obtained, why he was not present at time of registration - Any of the attesting witnesses also not examined - Claim of tenancy cannot be accepted.

When the issue of tenancy came to be decided by the Tahasildar the tenants did not give any evidence as to when the agreement of lease or tenancy took place, with whom it took place, what was the nature of the agreement and what were the terms of the agreement. The tenants also did not give any evidence as to why he alone executed the lease agreement and why landlord was not present and why his consent in writing was not obtained and why he was not kept present at the time of registration. The tenants also did not examine any of the attesting witnesses to the said document. Even if the argument of Mr. Samant that the provisions of Transfer of Property Act, if they are inconsistent with the  Tenancy Act shall not apply to the tenancy matter, is accepted, the ease of the tenants regarding their tenancy right on the basis of such a document can not at all be accepted by the Court. 1957 Bom,L,R, 782 disting.  [Para 17,18]

heading: "Instrument of gift"
What is not
HeadNote.description: "Instrument of gift" - What is not - Instrument recording fact that gift was received and not recording any right or liability in respect of donee or donor - Instrument not "instrument of gift" - Instrument merely a receipt - Does not attract duty. (Paras 7,8)

heading: Suit for eviction
Mode of service
Presumption
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction - Notice of demand of arrears - Mode of service - Presumption - Registered letter returned to sender with remark "unclaimed" - Mere absence of tenant in premises cannot rebut the presumption of service of letter/notice - It is for tenant to make necessary arrangement to receive the notice/letter addressed to him in his absence at the suit premises - Failure on the part of tenant cannot enure to his benefit - Affixation of notice on door - Is permissible only when the tender or delivery of notice either by post or by tendering or delivering the same personally to the addressee is found to be impracticable.

Bombay General Clauses Act (1904), S.28.

General Clauses Act (1897), S.27.

Mere absence of the tenant in the premises cannot rebut the presumption arising under Section 28 of the Bombay General Clauses Act.  It is for the tenant to make necessary arrangement to receive the notice addressed to him in his absence at the suit premises and, failure on the part of tenant in that regard cannot enure to his benefit to contend that on account of his absence at the premises, the presumption of service would stand rebutted.  It is  further to be noted that postal endorsement is not of refusal to receive but to the effect that the letter was not claimed.  In other words, there was presumption not only regarding service of the notice but also regarding intimation of a letter having been received in the post office addressed to the tenant and failure to collect the same by the tenant as he was found absent in the premises at the time when postman approached the premises to deliver the same.  The presumption regarding intimation would arise under section 114 of the Evidence Act, as it is observed by the Apex Court, it is a general practice for the postman to intimate either orally or in writing about the letter having been received in the post office addressed to the tenant when the tenant is found absent in the premises at the time when the postman approaches to serve the same.  Undisputedly, there was no such effort made by the petitioner either to receive the notice at the address sent to him during his alleged absence nor any explanation forthcoming as to why arrangement was not made to collect the letter from the postal authorities on intimation thereof.  Being so, the presumption of service has not been rebutted.

As regards service of affixation on door as already observed above, the same is permissible when actual service by tendering notice to the tenant or by registered post is not practicable.  In that case, once a letter is received with postal endorsement that it was not claimed by addressee, it is obvious that though the presumption of service may arise under Section 28 of the Bombay General Clauses Act, the actual service was not practicable as far as the landlord is concerned.  The legal presumption arising from postal endorsement is different from the understanding of the factual situation to the landlord or understanding of the landlord regarding service of notice, and in that connection if the landlord makes another attempt to serve the notice by affixation of such notice to the suit premises and the same is effected in presence of any witness or factum of affixation at the door otherwise is established, the same can be considered as good service of notice in terms of Section 106 of Transfer of Property Act, and therefore service by affixation in the case in hand cannot be found fault with. AIR 1989 SC 630 - Followed. 2001(2) ALL MR 415 and AIR 1990 SC 1215 - Referred to.  [Para 18,19]

heading: Gift deed
HeadNote.description: Gift deed - Suit property orally gifted by deceased to her grandson - No formal gift deed - Procedure in S.123 of Transfer of Property Act not followed - Held, provisions of S.24 of the 1947 Act, do not exempt any donor from following the procedure prescribed under S.123 - Machinery provided under the Act of 1947 could not have been used for transfer of title to a person who was not owner of the land forming subject-matter of Consolidation scheme.	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Suit for eviction on ground of arrears of rent
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction on ground of arrears of rent - After filing suit landlord selling suit house - New landlords added as plaintiffs No.1 and 2 - Tenant accepting sale of property to added plaintiffs and attornment of tenancy in favour of new landlord - Tenant however contending that added plaintiffs have paid arrears of rent to transferor landlord - Held because tenant had accepted assignment of rent in favour of transferee, transferee can recover arrears of rent from the tenant. (2003)7 SCC 321 - Followed.	(Para 21)

heading: Transfer of land u/S.43
HeadNote.description: Transfer of land u/S.43 - Defendants defending their possession u/S.53A of T.P. Act - Defendants submit that agreement has been proved and they have established possession of suit land - Held, even if agreement is true and correct, in absence of permission of Collector u/S.43 of Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, transfer is impermissible - No steps taken by defendants from year 1973 till plaintiff filed suit in year 1978 to ask plaintiff to obtain such permission - Agreement not placed on record - On basis of agreement finding of possession cannot be recorded - Nothing on record to show defendants paid entire amount - Considering evidence of all witnesses possession not established - Appeal dismissed. (Paras 5, 6)

heading: Lease or license
HeadNote.description: Lease or license - If a document gives only a right to use the property in a particular way or under certain terms, while it remains in possession and control of the owner thereof, it will be a license - Licensee put in possession only for purpose of constructing a building - No interest in land conveyed - Agreement is not chargeable as a lease under Art.36.

heading: Distinguished.			(Paras 6,10,12)
HeadNote.description:
Applicability of Rent Act - Whether prospective or retrospective - Rent Act made applicable to area in which suit premises situated during pendency of appeal against eviction decree - Held, Rent Act not applicable to pending execution or appeal proceedings.

AIR (36) 1949 BOM 210 (FB), AIR 1951 SC 199, AIR 1974 BOM 245 (FB), AIR 1985 SC 709 - Rel. On.

AIR 1987 SC 248, AIR 1963 SC 358, AIR 1980 SC 299 - Distinguished.			(Paras 6,10,12)

heading: Revocation of sanction by Charity Commissioner
HeadNote.description: Revocation of sanction by Charity Commissioner - Developers claiming to be party respondents - They, however, not found to have any right or title in property, though they were in possession - They are neither a necessary nor proper party to proceedings under S.53-A. (Para 29)

heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), O.7, R.3 - Suit for eviction - Description of suit land - Description adequate and proper in view of demarcation shown in the plaint map - Due compliance of Order 7, Rule 3 of Civil P.C. - Held, the suit cannot be dismissed on technical ground that boundaries of the suit land are not shown in the plaint.	(Para 8)

heading: General Clauses Act (1897), Ss.27,28
HeadNote.description:
General Clauses Act (1897), Ss.27,28 - Evidence Act (1872), S.114 - Notice for eviction sent by registered post - Notice returned back with remark "not claimed" - Not duly served on tenant.

There is marked distinction between expression "not claimed" and "refused". In case of endorsement of "refused" there can be no dispute that the Court can legally presume that service has been duly effected on the addressee. However, the said legal presumption cannot apply to a case where the envelope has been returned with postal endorsement "not claimed". In this situation the non delivery of the envelope can be due to variety of reasons, but surely other than refusal. The service can be said to be effected only when there is a positive evidence that it is actually served through the modes permissible in law or even when the addressee refuses to accept the same; but in no case, if the packet is returned with postal endorsement "not Claimed", can the court presume that service has been effected on the addressee.  [Para 8]

heading: General Clauses Act (1897), Ss.27,28
HeadNote.description: General Clauses Act (1897), Ss.27,28 - Evidence Act (1872), S.114 - Notice for eviction sent under certificate of posting not received back by landlord - There is no presumption that it was delivered to the tenant particularly when tenant on oath denied receipt of such notice.	(Para 12)

heading: Eviction suit
Maintainability
Arrears of rent
Transferee of Landlord
Cannot be decreed.
HeadNote.description: Eviction suit - Maintainability - Arrears of rent - Transferee of Landlord - Is not entitled to arrears due before transfer - Transferee's suit for non-payment of such arrears - Cannot be decreed.

heading: Sale is invalid
HeadNote.description:
Sale of land by tenant in contravention of S.43 - Sale is invalid - Suit for repossession from vendee - S.29 does not apply.

One Hiralal was a tenant in respect  of some land.  He entered with agreement of sale with respondent in respect of the land for a consideration.  The agreement of sale was registered and possession of land was given to respondent.  Hiralal filed some proceeding before civil Judge claiming possession of said land from respondent.  When the suit was pending certificate of ownership under S.32G came to be issued in favour of Hiralal on 11-6-71.  The proceedings were dismissed solely on the ground that possession of respondent was protected under S.53A of  T.P.Act.

Held, that the agreement of sale in favour of respondent was illegal by virtue of S.43 (2) of Act and protection of S.53A of T.P. Act was not available.  [Para 9]

The provisions of Section 29(1) are attracted for claiming repossession of the suit land from the original landlord and the said provisions are not applicable when the repossession of the suit land is being sought from a third person.  [Para 6]

Section 43(1) of the Tenancy Act clearly lays down that the land purchased by a tenant U/s 32F shall not be transferred by sale etc. without the previous sanction of the Collector, whereas sub-section 2 of the said Section invalidates any such transfer which has been effected without the previous sanction of the Collector.  The contract for sale of such land of which the tenant has become the owner will be invalid in view of the provisions of Section 23 of the Contract Act, because it contravenes the provisions of Section 43(1) of the Tenancy Act.  It is therefore, clear that the agreement of sale is illegal by virtue of Section 43(2) of the Tenancy Act.  The Respondent is therefore, not entitled to protection of Section 53A of the Transfer of Property Act.  [Para 8,9]

In the instant case Hiralal was a tenant on the tiller's day.  A certificate of ownership U/s 32G of the Act was issued to him only on 11.6.71 and it is therefore, clear that Hiralal became the owner of the subject land only on 11.6.71, whereas the agreement of sale in favour of Respondent was signed on 16.3.61 and also the possession of the suit land was handed over to him in March/April 1961 itself.  This sale therefore was invalid.  Further the statutory mandate indicates that even after the ownership certificate is issued U/s 32G in favour of the tenant, the tenant is required to cultivate the land personally and his failure to do so results in his eviction from the said land.  The ownership vested in favour of the purchaser-tenant is thus not absolute but is conditional and Hiralal did not have an absolute right to enter into an agreement even after the certificate of ownership U/s 32G was issued to him.  [Para 7]

heading: Eviction suit
HeadNote.description: Succession Act (1925), S.63(c) - Eviction suit - Plaintiffs claiming ownership under Will of original landlady - Contention of tenant before trial court that he had no knowledge of existence of Will - Evidence of scribe, attesting witnesses and beneficiary of Will adduced by Plaintiff - Held Rent court not to decide question of genuineness and validity of Will - But rent court can examine factum of existence or non-existence of Will as incidental to decide whether a person was landlord of premises by virtue of such Will - In proceedings under Rent Act tenant cannot question genuineness and validity of Will - Where factum of execution and existence of Will established by such evidence tenant not entitled to question ownership of Plaintiff - Finding by trial court that Plaintiff had become owner under Will upheld. 1946 ILR 510 - Rel on.	(Para 7)

heading: Ground of default
HeadNote.description:
Ground of default - Arrears of rent prior to date of purchase of suit property - Held, purchaser of suit property is not entitled to recover rent prior to date of purchase in absence of contract to contrary.

The conclusion of the Courts below in the absence of the contract to the contrary the purchaser i.e. the petitioner was not entitled to recover arrears of rent prior to the date of it's purchase of the suit property is proper and in consonance with the provisions of section 55(4)(a) read with section 55(6)(a) of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882.  The further finding of the Courts below that the respondent had tendered the rent which was due within a month of one month from the date of the notice, is also a finding of fact well supported by the evidence on record.  The petitioner had declined to accept the money order sent by the respondent within one month of the notice of demand and so, the respondent could not be termed as a defaulter.  The Courts below also noted that during the pendency of the suit, the respondent had deposited the rent in the court regularly.  There is no reason to interfere in the concurrent finding of fact, that the respondent was not a defaulter.  [Para 3]

heading: Eviction
Service of notice
HeadNote.description: Eviction - Service of notice - Surname of tenant was wrongly written in notice - No much importance to be given to slight error in surname especially when address was substantially correct - In so far as addition of word "opposite cinema plaza" in notice, is concerned it did not make much difference as it specified only nearby landmark and if there was any error, notice would have returned back, which was not so - Having taken specific stand in written statement that notice was duly served, tenant could not contend that burden to prove service of notice was on landlord. 	(Para 4)

heading: Notice by landlord
Service of
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), S.114 - General Clauses Act (1897), S.27 - Notice by landlord - Service of - Notice by Regd. AD post, Under Certificate of Posting and by pasting on suit premises - Oral evidence by Plaintiff that he pasted notice after servant of Defendant refused to accept notice - In absence of evidence to contrary by Defendant - mere contradiction in Plaintiffs evidence as to time of pasting - Cannot result in dislodging his evidence - Especially so when Defendant gave evidence that 3 employees sat in suit shop one after another. (Para 31)

heading: Notice under
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), S.114 - Notice under - Service of _ Notice under certificate of posting - Postal Mark on receipts in respect of certificate of posting and Regd. A.D. identical - Nothing showing that notice not posted - Also notice not returned to sender by postal dept. - Inference that notice was sent under certificate of posting to addressee follows - Though tenant intimated about fact of issuance of notice he failed to address the same in his reply - In circumstances, presumption as to service of notice arose. (Paras 31, 32, 33, 34, 35)

heading: Lease
HeadNote.description:
Lease - Petitioner developer entered into agreement with respondent for development of complex - Recitals of agreement in its entirety show that it is for development - In order to have such development, petitioners were granted conditional right to enter into sale agreement of built up area of project site - There is no lease created in favour of project site and that would be created only on execution of lease deed - Imposing stamp duty as agreement of development is lease, not permissible. 

Clause of agreement grants development right only and parties have taken care to clarify that 'nothing in these presents contained shall be construed as demise in law of project site hereby agreed to be demised or any part thereof so as to confer upon developer any legal interest therein until lease hereby provided shall be executed'. Therefore, agreement between petitioner developer and CIDCO is not agreement of lease.              [Para 41,42]

heading: Lease
HeadNote.description: Lease - Petitioner developer entered into agreement with respondent for development of complex - Definition of lease under Stamp Act is not distinct than concept as understood by Transfer of Property Act - Various types of writings and instruments which are in nature of lease but without being named as such have been brought within purview of S.2(n) of Stamp Act - Argument that test of 'present demise' is not to be satisfied as definitions of lease under said two Acts are distinct - Argument liable to be rejected.            (Para 44)

heading: 'Agreement to lease'
HeadNote.description:
'Agreement to lease' - Test of present demise - There is clear distinction in law between lease and agreement to lease - Explanation III below Art.36, Sch.I agreement to lease shall not be chargeable as lease unless there is immediate and present demise - Explanation though has now been deleted, it does not mean that even if there is no immediate and present demise agreement to lease can straight away termed and construed as lease.

What explanation clarified was if Agreement does not create immediate and present demise, then it will not fall under Art. 36. Argument in this regard is not sustainable.
1994 (2) SCC 497 Ref. to.              [Para 47,48]

heading: Test of present demise
HeadNote.description:
Test of present demise - Petitioner developer entered into agreement with respondent for development of complex - If agreement is of lease - Argument that with assistance of definition of word 'instrument' and 'lease', test of 'present demise' is not required to be satisfied - Argument liable to be rejected.

Stamp Act defines term 'lease' and imposes stamp duty as per rate in Schedule I. By considering only meaning of term 'instrument' as defined in S.2(I), other provisions which are equally substantive in nature cannot be ignored. Thus if specific classes of instruments have been set out with reference and defined or their general meaning has to be adopted, then definition of term 'instrument' alone cannot be of any assistance. It will not be decisive.
AIR 1972 Delhi 171, 1994 (2) SCC 497, AIR 1959 SCC 620 Ref. to.              [Para 45,46]

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: Appeal against arbitral award - Arbitration proceedings initiated by mortgagee for monetary claim under contract of mortgage - Arbitrator adjudicated on liability of mortgagor regarding amount due and payable to mortgagee under contract - Challenge - On ground that in view of mortgage, mortgagee ought to have filed independent suit u/S.67 of T.P. Act and that arbitral proceeding could not be invoked - However, no legal basis has been pointed out for it - Issue before Arbitrator was not issue as regards mortgaged property nor same was raised by mortgagor before Arbitrator - Plea that Court Receiver was appointed u/S.9 of T.P. Act in respect of mortgaged property, not tenable as S.69A provides for appointment of Court Receiver at behest of mortgagee - Submission made that in view of MoU entered between parties and S.30(2) of Arbitration Act, arbitration proceedings ought to have been terminated - Not acceptable as Cl.7 of MoU provides that said MoU would not affect any proceedings initiated for monetary claim before Court or arbitral panel - Appeal dismissed. 	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Evidence Act (1872), Ss.62, 64
