HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), Ss.62, 64 - Suit for possession by landlord - Whether barred by limitation - Tenant claiming that suit is barred on basis of notice served by landlord in proceedings before reference court - Said notice was never produced in evidence in suit for possession either in form of primary or secondary evidence - Reference to such notice as starting point of limitation is clearly erroneous - Landlord has filed suit for possession on basis of determination of tenancy - Suit is governed by Art.67 - Landlord has filed suit within 12 years of determination of lease by efflux of time - Suit not barred by limitation. 	(Paras 28, 38, 39)

heading: Dismissal
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), Ss.62, 64 - Suit for possession by landlord - Dismissal - On ground of bar of limitation u/Arts.65, 66 - Tenant claiming adverse possession over suit property - However, failed to lead any evidence of hostile possession to knowledge of true owner - Tenant failed to prove adverse possession - Further, tenant has not proved forfeiture of tenancy prior to expiry of lease period - Dismissal of suit being barred by limitation u/Arts.65, 66, improper. 	(Paras 39, 41, 42)

heading: Plea of adverse possession and tenancy
HeadNote.description: Plea of adverse possession and tenancy - These two pleas cannot go hand in hand unless it is pleaded and proved by the defendants as to when they surrendered possession as tenant and commencement of date of possession by principles of adverse possession.	(Para 9)

heading: Usufructary mortgage
HeadNote.description: Usufructary mortgage - Right to redeem would accrue immediately on execution of mortgage deed - Mortgager has to file suit within 30 years from date of mortgage for redemption - On expiry of limitation mortgagee would become entitled to continue in possession as the full owner.	(Para 11)

heading: Limitation
Suit for recovery
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Suit for recovery - Mortgage by deposit of title deeds by respondent guarantors, proved - Provisions of Art.62 of Limitation Act read with S.96 of T. P. Act would be applicable.	(Para 35)

heading: Sustainability
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Reliance on deed of exchange - Sustainability - Prior to acquisition, claimant had exchanged his land admeasuring 475 sq.m. with the land of respondent admeasuring 7500 sq. m. - Exchange deed disclosing no agreement on market value of land, though entire transaction was valued at Rs.25,000/- for the purposes of stamp duty - Held, said exchange deed which is based on convenience of parties cannot be relied upon to ascertain market value of acquired land.  (Para 32)

heading: Plea of adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Plea of adverse possession - Not available to pendente lite purchaser - Because, to avail said plea, possession of party should be peaceful - If proceeding is pending, possession cannot be peaceful. (2004) 10 SCC 779 Ref. to. 	(Paras 41, 42)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgage - Limitation - Art.61(a) provides limitation of 30 years when right to redeem or recover possession accrues to mortgagor - Plaintiff executed mortgage deed in favour of defendant as security for loan and put him in possession of suit property for five years - Suit for redemption filed within 30 years after expiry of period of five years - Suit is not barred by limitation. 	(Para 34)

heading: Suit for specific performance
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Whether barred by limitation - Agreement for sale entered into on 20/2/1988 - No date fixed for performance, therefore limitation would be reckoned from date of refusal to perform - Averments in plaint showing that heirs of vendor executed development agreement dt.31/12/2007 and also a power of attorney in favour of D-1 in respect of suit land - Document in question i.e. agreement dt.31/12/2007 being registered, would constitute notice in terms of S.3 of TP Act - Thus, plaintiff had a notice of document being executed and consequentially refusal on part of heirs to complete transaction - Suit however filed in June 2011, barred by limitation.  2007 ALL SCR 1430 Rel. on. 	(Para 20)

heading: Termination of lease
HeadNote.description: Termination of lease - Suit by lessor for vacant possession of land only - Property under lease deed, however, included "land along with buildings" - Plaintiff not entitled to decree since premises are not properly described in plaint - Further, buildings were not erected by lessee - He therefore, could not remove existing buildings so as to surrender vacant possession of land. (2000) 5 SCC 646 Disting. 	(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Forfeiture of earnest money
HeadNote.description: Forfeiture of earnest money - Purchaser paying 10% of purchase price as earnest money - Unable to pay balance amount of Rs.63 Lacs. before due date - Earnest money was primarily for due performance of agreement and hence seller was entitled to forfeit Rs.7 Lacs received as earnest money. 	(Paras 17 to 19)

heading: Lis pendens
HeadNote.description:
Lis pendens - Doctrine applies only when disputes between parties pending before Court - No litigation pending when suit plot was transferred - Title to property proved by plaintiff - Possession must be given plaintiff.

Section 52 of Transfer of Property Act embodies a doctrine that any transfer of the suit property pending the hearing and disposal of the suit would be subject to the decree/judgment that may be passed in the suit.  Thus, any suit property while suit (not a collusive suit) is pending in a Court of law cannot be transferred unless the Court concerned has permitted the transfer pendente lite.  The Court while granting permission may authorize transfer pending the suit upon such terms as it may deem just.  In the instant case when special civil suit was decided by the trial Court no legal proceedings in respect of the suit property was pending.  The trial Court also failed to notice that the claim of  adverse  possession  in a pending proceeding on the date of the institution of the suit was based upon permissive possession which can never be termed as adverse possession.  Even otherwise, the effect of lis pendens is not annul the conveyance but only to make it subservient to rights of the parties to litigation.  The evidence of the plaintiff and her witnesses in the trial Court went unchallenged as the suit had proceeded further ex parte against the defendants.  Under these circumstances, possession ought to have followed the title which vested in the plaintiff under the registered sale deed and her name was also entered in the record as owner of suit plot pursuant thereto.	 [Para 7,8]

heading: Suit for eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction of tenant - Tenant challenged derivative title of landlord - Same has to be established in some form - Failure of landlord to establish claim of ownership of subject premises on basis of family arrangement after dissolution of firm, before first two courts - Attempt to adduce additional documents by landlord to establish his stand, rejected by High Court - Matter remanded to High Court for re-adjudicating rival claim and defence - Liberty granted to landlord to file application before High Court for producing additional evidence. 	(Paras 19, 20)

heading: Redemption of mortgage
HeadNote.description: Redemption of mortgage - Once document is treated as by way of security for a loan, trial court would be justified in passing decree for redemption after holding that the right of redemption is not extinguished. (Para 9)

heading: SLP against
HeadNote.description: Lease of premises to hotel owner - Question whether terrace was also leased out - Landlord claiming additional rent - Claim disallowed by High Court - SLP against - Apex Court directing tenant to deposit Rs.25,000/- per month in court - Question of legality of use of terrace to be decided at final hearing of suit after taking evidence.			(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Civil P.C. (1908), O.34, R.7(2)
HeadNote.description:
Civil P.C. (1908), O.34, R.7(2) - Mortgage by conditional sale - Deposit of amount after period stipulated in preliminary decree has expired - Held, in any eventuality, the Court could not have extended time for depositing the amount beyond the period of limitation prescribed under the Statute.

In the present case, considering the nature of transaction and considering the finding recorded by the trial court, while passing preliminary decree it cannot be said that the character of transaction as contended by the applicants is         of "usufructuary mortgage." However, the same has been construed as mortgage by conditional sale as defined in section 58(c) of Transfer of Properties Act. It was not open for the trial court to grant leave to the applicants to deposit the amount even after the period stipulated in the preliminary decree has expired. Exercise of powers under Order 34, Rule 7(2) by the executing court in accepting the amount was clearly arbitrary. There does not appear to be any good ground for extending the time for depositing the amount. Even otherwise, by harmoniously reading the provisions of Article 137 of the Limitation Act, in any eventuality, the court could not have extended time for depositing the amount beyond the period of limitation prescribed under the Statute.  AIR 1994 SC 191 - Ref. to.  [Para 8]

heading: Second appeal
Construction of document
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Substantial question of law - Leave and licence or lease - Construction of document - Document interpreted by trial court on basis of entire material on record - It does not give rise to substantial question of law - Document styled as leave and licence - Plea that document was intended to be lease - Trial Court interpreting it to be leave and licence - It cannot be a case of misconstruction of document. (Para 2)

heading: Suit for redemption of mortgage
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgage - Deed of mortgage registered and on the next day agreement for tenancy was executed - Held terms of registered deed of mortgage could not have been varied or altered by reason of an unregistered document of lease so as to change the status of parties from mortgagee to a lessee. AIR 2000 SC 2633, (1996)3 SCC 424 - Ref. to.	(Paras 13, 15)

heading: Possession handed over
HeadNote.description: Document whether sale with condition of repurchase or mortgage with conditional sale - Document described as a deed of sale - Source of title disclosed and what was sought to be conveyed was leasehold interest - Assignment of one half share in property - Possession handed over - Stipulation that vendor shall repurchase within a period of three years - No evidence of any relationship of creditor and borrower - Held this was not a mortgage with conditional sale.			(Paras 12, 17, 18)

heading: Sale of immovable property inheruted as adopted son and only heir of original owner
HeadNote.description: Sale of immovable property inheruted as adopted son and only heir of original owner - Plaintiff's natural father sold suit property when plaintiff was minor - Suit challenging alienation filed within three years of attaining majority - Neither property in question was joint family property of adoptive father and natural father nor his natural father was appointed as guardian under Guardians and Wards Act - Thus he had no authority to act for minor and to sell his property - Sale is void.	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Tenancy - Suit by management of school for possession of premises given to teacher who was required to look after the hostel in addition to his service in the school - His heirs contending that teacher was tenant and he could be evicted only by action under the Rent Act - Held teacher was not a tenant because Rent Act does not contemplate rent in kind, it has to be in the form of money.

Bombay Rents, Hotels and Lodging House Rates Control Act (1947), S.13(1)(f).

The provisions of Rent Act are quite clear.  If one looks into a number of provisions contained in the Act, it is very clear that the rent has to be paid through money.  If that was not so, a number of provisions of the Act relating to the arrears of rent, additions to the rent, standard rent etc., would become redundant.  The notice to be given by the landlord to the tenant calling upon him to pay the rent has also to be for payment in money and it cannot be in service.  Under these circumstances, the submission is required to be accepted that the provisions of Section 105 of the Transfer of Property Act, cannot be invoked for urban residential tenancy which are specifically covered under the Acts of the tenancy such as Bombay Rent Act.  [Para 5]

In the circumstances, stated above, it is very clear that the teacher was not required to pay any rent per month and was not a tenant of the first respondent institution.  His occupation was at the highest a personal privilege of occupation and not tenancy.  [Para 6]

heading: Eviction suit
HeadNote.description: Eviction suit - Defendant denying ownership of Plaintiff - Evidence that property owned by father of Plaintiff - No evidence that property a joint property of Plaintiff and his father - Also no Power of Attorney in favour of the Plaintiff - Merely because Plaintiff is a family member of owner does not confer right on Plaintiff to issue notice or to file eviction suit.			(Para 10)

heading: Deed of licence
HeadNote.description:
Deed of licence - Parties to document can show that what was intended was landlord and tenant relationship and deed was styled as a deed of licence.

Though a deed of licence may have been executed it is open for the parties to the document to show that the relationship which was agreed upon by the parties and was really intended to be brought into existence was that of a landlord and tenant though it was outwardly styled as a deed of licence to act as a camouflage on the Rent Control Legislation. 'Lease' is defined in Section 105 of the Transfer of Property Act 1882. Generally speaking the difference between a 'lease' and 'licence' is to be determined by finding out the real intention of the parties as decipherable from a complete reading of the document, if any, executed between the parties and the surrounding circumstances. Only a right to use the property in a particular way or under certain terms given to the occupant while the owner retains the control or possession over the premises results in a licence being created; for the owner retains legal possession while all that the licensee gets is a permission to use the premises for a particular purpose or in a particular manner and but for the permission so given the occupation would have been unlawful. (2002)5 SCC 361 Rel.   [Para 8]

User of the terms like 'lease' or 'licence', 'lessor' or 'licensor', 'rent' or 'licence fee' are not by themselves decisive of the nature of the right created by the document. An effort should be made to find out whether the deed confers a right to possess exclusively coupled with transfer of a right to enjoy the property what has been parted with is merely a right to use the property while the possession is retained by the owner. The conduct of the parties before and after the creation of relationship is of relevance for finding out their intention.   [Para 9]

In this case the premises were located in a busy commercial market. The appellant has exclusive possession over the premises and the owner neither can nor does interfere therein. A full fledged stationery shop and allied business activities have been carried on by the appellant in the premises ever since 1972. The appellant was in possession of the premises for about 20 years before the date of the deed of licence and in spite of the 'deed of license' of 1981 having been executed continued to possess use and enjoy the occupation of premises as before. Though the so-called licence expired in 1982 the respondent did not insist on the appellant putting back the respondent in possession of the premises but allowed him to remain in occupation and to continue to do so for a period of about seven years till the date of the institution of the suit. It is thus clear that the present one is not a case where the possession or control of the premises was retained by the respondent while the appellant was only permitted to make such use of the premises as would have been unlawful but for the permission given. Hence the parties were landlord and tenant and possession of appellant over the premises was that of a tenant. [Para 12]

heading: Adequacy of consideration
HeadNote.description: Fraudulent transfer of property - Adequacy of consideration - Cannot be the basis to judge the case of plaintiffs founded on S.53 of Transfer of Property Act. 2002(1) ALL MR (S.C.) 283 - Rel. on.	(Para 21)

heading: Doctrine of part performance
HeadNote.description:
Doctrine of part performance - Plaintiff respondent entering into agreement of sale with "P" - "P" in possession of suit land - Sale deed not executed - "P" executing a similar agreement in favour of "R" defendant appellant and putting him in possession - "R" did not care to ascertain title of "P" - "R" cannot claim benefit of equitable doctrine of part performance to protect his possession.

Protection provided under Sec.53-A of the Act to the proposed transferee is a shield only against the transferor. It disentitles the transferor from disturbing the possession of the proposed transferee who is put in possession in pursuance to such an agreement. It has nothing to do with the ownership of the proposed transferor who remains full owner of the property till it is legally conveyed by executing a registered sale deed in favour of the transferee. Such a right to protect possession against the proposed vendor cannot be pressed in service against a third party.  [Para 10]

Doctrine of part performance is rooted in equity and provides a shield of protection to the proposed transferee to remain in possession against the original owner who has agreed to sell to the transferee if the proposed transferee satisfies other conditions of Section 53-A. It operates as an equitable estoppel against the original owner to seek possession of the property which was given to the proposed vendee in part performance of the contract. Appellant being a third party and not a privy to the transaction on which the estoppel rests can take no advantage of it.

"P" did not have a transferable interest which he could convey to the appellant by entering into an agreement of sale with the appellant. The appellant under the circumstances does not have the equitable right to protect his possession as against the owner of the land, i.e. the respondent. Appellant is not the transferee within the meaning of Section 53-A. The appellant did not get the possessory of equitable title to the suit land through "P" as "P" himself did not have any right in the property. The only right possessed by the "P" under Section 53-A was to protect his possession as against his proposed vendee. He did not have conveyable interest in the property which he could transfer to a third party including the possession of the property.  [Para 14,15]

heading: Transfer pendente lite
HeadNote.description:
Transfer pendente lite - Mere pendency of suit does not prevent one of the parties from dealing with suit property - Section only postulates that alienation will not affect rights of other party under any decree that may be passed in the suit.

The principles specified in Section 52 of the T.P. Act are in accordance with equity, good conscience or justice because they rest upon an equitable and just foundation that it will be impossible to bring an action or suit to a successful termination if alienations are permitted to prevail. A transferee pendente lite is bound by the decree just as much as he was a party to the suit. The principle of lis pendens embodied in Section 52 of the T.P. Act being a principle of public policy, no question of good faith or bona fide arises. The principle underlying Section 52 is that a litigating party is exempted from taking notice of a title acquired during the pendency of the litigation. The mere pendency of a suit does not prevent one of the parties from dealing with the property constituting the subject matter of the suit. The Section only postulates a condition that the alienation will in no manner affect the rights of the other party under any decree which may be passed in the suit unless the property was alienated with the permission of the Court. It is a trite law that if a person is not a party to a suit, he decree does not affect him unless the judgments is in rem and not in personem.	  [Para 11,13]

heading: Extinguishment of right to property
HeadNote.description: Extinguishment of right to property - Notice of termination of tenancy - Suit for recovery of possession filed after 12 years dismissed - There is no bar under T.P. Act which can prevent or prohibit the landlord from filing successive suits on the basis of termination of notice because if the earlier notice is not legal and valid and has not legally terminated the tenancy as required by S.106 of T.P. Act, then the right of landlord is not lost for ever and he will give fresh notice and terminate the tenancy and file a suit - Right of plaintiff to institute the second suit is nowhere extinguished u/s.27 of Limitation Act - Even if purposes of the first suit and the second suit are common and the reliefs claimed are identical what makes a difference is the cause of action - Cause of action in second suit is fresh notice.			(Paras 13, 15, 16)

heading: Holding over
HeadNote.description: Lease of immovable property - Holding over - Lease for period of 20 years - After expiry of 20 years, lessee continues to hold the property and lessor accepts the rent in absence of registered instrument - Lessee intimating intention of renewal, but fails to take further necessary steps stipulated in Agreement - Held, it was "holding over" and not continuation of old tenancy on same terms and conditions. A.I.R. 1988 SC 1470 - Rel.on.	(Paras 9 & 10)

heading: Mortgage of tenanted premises to the tenant-Deed of mortgage providing for surrender of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Mortgage of tenanted premises to the tenant-Deed of mortgage providing for surrender of tenancy - Possession is only as Mortgagee - Concurrent finding of facts - Interference not warranted.   (Para 2)

heading: Lease or licence
HeadNote.description:
Lease or licence - To be determined on the basis of the intention of the parties - Lease in favour of the statutory tenant cannot empower the tenant to sublet the premises to third parties in the absence of such right conferred on him.

It is nowhere pleaded that the deed executed between the parties is a camouflage to evade the rigours of the provisions of the Rent Act nor is it stated that a sham document is executed for achieving some other purpose. In these set of circumstances, the intention of the parties is required to be gathered from the express words of various terms provided by them in the deed. For this purpose, clause 12 of the document is to be taken into consideration and due weight is required to be given to what parties have stated. It provides as under :

"12. It is hereby expressly agreed upon and declared by and between the parties that these presents shall not be treated or used or dealt with or construed by the parties in any way as a tenancy or lease or as a document within the purview of the West Bengal Premises Tenancy Act or any modification or amendment thereof or to confer any relationship as landlord and tenant between the parties hereto."

The aforesaid term of the document is not provided by an illiterate layman or poor person in need of some premises for his residence or business, but is executed by two companies, where it can be presumed that it is mentioned after full understanding and to avoid any wrong inference of intention. It specifically mentions that only a license was created and not a lease. The said clause is in positive as well as negative form providing that the agreement was a licence and should not be treated or used or dealt with or construed by the parties in any way as lease or to confer any relationship as landlord and tenants between the parties. When the parties which are capable of understanding their rights fully, expressly agreed and declared that document should not be construed in any manner as creating any relationship as landlord and tenant between them, it would be impermissible to conjecture or infer that their relations should be construed as that of landlord and tenant because of certain terms mentioned in the deed can have double intendment. As stated above, intention of the parties is the meaning of the words they have used and there could be no intention independent of that meaning. The learned single Judge of the High Court rightly, therefore, held that this clause stares in his face in construing it as a lease deed.

Secondly, parties to the document were fully aware that lease or sub-lease could not be granted and therefore, specific provision is made in the deed that if the consent of the tenant is obtained for creation of sub-lease, deed for the same would be executed on the terms and conditions which were set out in the document; detailed provisions are made in various clauses of the deed for obtaining permission and execution of lease deed. Parties were conscious that a lawful lease deed could be executed only after obtaining consent of the landlord and the document if treated as sub-lease, would be illegal

Thirdly, no contention was raised by the defendants to the effect that license deed is a camouflage to circumvent the provisions of law or to defeat the rights of owner or tenant who granted the licence and inducted and licensee in possession. Further, in cases where contract for licence is executed by handing over exclusive possession of the premises, the distinguishing line between the lease and licence is absolutely thin. In such cases, the terms of the document are to be read as they are and it would be unreasonable to draw inference that parties intended to create relationship of landlord and tenant despite express contrary terms in the deed which are binding between the parties.

heading: Sale with a condition of repurchase and mortgage by conditional sale
HeadNote.description:
Sale with a condition of repurchase and mortgage by conditional sale - Deed described as Mudat Kharedi Khat - On facts held it was sale with a condition of repurchase.

Held considering the surrounding circumstances transaction was intended by the parties to be a sale with a condition of repurchase in view of the following :-

(a) The possession was handed over to the appellant.

(b) A mutation entry was effected by the appellant in pursuance of this transaction.

(c) Though the document was executed in the year 1968 by the husband of the plaintiff, the husband did not make any attempt to "redeem" the property by "repayment of loan" till his death in 1978.

(d) In fact, it is clear from the evidence of the respondent that she has stated that her husband entered into a conditional sale and has not deposed anything about the fact that he was in need of money and, therefore, borrowed some money from the appellant.

AIR 1960 SC 301, AIR 1982 Bom. 437 Rel.On. 			 [Para 8]

heading: Doctrine of
Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Part performance of contract - Doctrine of - Applicability - Suit by Seller against Purchaser for recovery of land contracted to be sold - Purchaser ready and willing to perform his part of contract - Purchaser's suit for specific performance of a contract already dismissed on ground of limitation - Protection of doctrine of part-performance still available to Purchaser - Immaterial whether Purchaser's suit for specific performance was filed and dismissed or no such suit filed by him.

1994 Mh.L.J. 1145, AIR 1957 Bom. 138 - Rel. on. (Paras 12, 14, 15)

heading: Suit by mother
HeadNote.description:
Doctrine of feeding the estoppel - Property of plaintiff mother sold fraudulently by her son to appellant - Suit by mother - During pendency of appeal son died - Although his children did not succeed or inherit any interest in suit property, they were impleaded as legal representatives - During pendency of appeal mother also died - Her grand children acquiring interest in property - Held, doctrine of feeding estoppel would not come into operation as against grand children because their father transferor of property had never acquired any interest in it during his life time. 

Section 43 applies when the transferor having no interest in the property transfers the same but subsequently acquires interest in the said property, the purchaser may claim the benefit of such subsequent acquisition of the property by the transferor. Had it been a case where the son during his life time succeeded or inherited the property but died subsequently, then to some extent it could have been argued that his heirs who inherited the property on the death of their father would be bound by the principle of estoppel. In a case where a transferor never acquired by succession, inheritance or otherwise any interest in the property during his life time then the provision of Section 43 will not come into operation as against the heirs who succeeded the stridhan property of their grandmother. Hence the purchaser of the property would not be entitled to take the benefit of the doctrine of feeding the estoppel.      [Para 15]

heading: Gift
Validity
HeadNote.description: Gift - Validity - Gift of immovable property is possible only by registered instrument signed by or on behalf of donor and attested by two witnesses - It must also be registered and gift accepted by donee - Mere expression of intention to gift land is not sufficient. (Para 4)

heading: Lease
HeadNote.description:
Lease - Borrower owner has created mortgage of premises in favour of respondent bank - Petitioner has been permitted by original borrower to occupy mortgaged premises - Petitioner claims right over premises on basis of promissory lien - Mortgagor can let out mortgaged premises only as per mandate of S.65A - Petitioner is neither tenant nor lessee of mortgaged premises - Petitioner cannot claim any protection on basis of promissory lien.

AIR 2007 Madras 148 Ref. to. 	 [Para 8]

heading: Eviction
Maintainability
HeadNote.description:
Maharashtra Rent Control Act (1999), S.58(1)(b) - Eviction - Suit before Civil Court - Maintainability - Suit filed on 11-6-1997 on ground of breach of terms of lease agreement - Suit was pending till Maharashtra Rent Control Act came into force on 31-03-2000 by repealing earlier Rent Control Legislation - New ground of determination of lease by efflux of time arose on 31-12-2003 - Plaintiff sought amendment on 20-06-2005 - Amendment was allowed on 02-07-2005 - Held, effect of amendment was that it was suit instituted on 20-06-2005 for eviction on basis of cause of action which arose on 31-12-2003 - Since it is an open land not covered by new Rent Control Legislation, remedy would be Section 111(a) of T.P. Act - Suit will be decided by Civil Court.

Period of lease was of 61 years, commencing from 1-1-1943. Hence determination of lease by efflux of time after lapse of 61 years with effect from 31-12-2003, could not be at any point of time prior to expiry of lease period. Cause of action for filing suit for eviction and possession on such ground under S.111(a) of Transfer of Property Act, did not arise at any point of time prior to 31-12-2003, Rent Control Legislations were not in force, as it was repealed by provisions of S.58(1)(b) of Maharashtra Rent Control Act 1999, with effect from 31-3-2000.

Regular Civil Suit was filed for eviction and possession on 11-6-1997 on ground of breach of terms and conditions of lease agreement. Tenancy was thus terminable at option of lessor. Hence, such suit was not maintainable on 11-06-1997 without permission of Rent Controller under provision of Cl. 13(i)(a) of Rent Control Order, which was then in force. Suit as was formulated and filed, was required to be dismissed on that sole ground. However, fact remained that suit was not dismissed, but it remained pending till Maharashtra Rent Control Act was brought into force on 31-03-2000 by repealing earlier Rent Control Legislation, which was prevailing.

Plaintiff filed application for amendment on 20-06-2005, introduction new ground for determination of lease by efflux of time, in Regular Civil Suit. Application was allowed by Trial Court on 2-7-2005. In facts and circumstances of case effect of amendment was that it was suit instituted on 20-06-2005 for eviction and possession of suit property on basis of cause of action which arose on 31-12-2003. Obviously, for reasons stated in earlier para, only Civil Court had jurisdiction to entertain, try and decide such suit and neither proceedings under repealed Rent Control Legislations, nor under Maharashtra Rent Control Act could be instituted. Hence it is held that ordinary jurisdiction of Civil Court was available to pass decree in Regular Civil Suit for eviction and possession between respondent no. 1 landlord and appellant tenant in respect of open land on ground of lease coming to end by efflux of time, introduced by way of amendment on 2-7-2005.

2009 (1) ALL MR 602, 2002 (Suppl) Bom. C.R. 658, 1990 (1) Mh.L.J. 18 Ref. to. 			       		       [Para 11,12,13]

heading: Mutation entries
HeadNote.description:
Reasonable care by bona fide purchaser - Purchase of agricultural land by relying on mutation entries in the name of vendor who had only partial interest in land - Vendee is not entitled to protection under S.41.

Revenue records - Mutation entries - Value of.

Mutation entry of an agricultural land is only fiscal entry and is not a document of right and title and, therefore, if a person purchases agricultural land on the basis of a mutation entry, without further making enquiry about the title, it cannot be said that the purchaser had taken reasonable care before the purchase of the agricultural land. The mutation entry in the name of the vendor does not dispense with the duty of the vendee to make requisite and usual enquiry into the title of the vendor and unless the vendee is able to prove that he has made the usual enquiry into the title of the vendor, on the basis of verification of mutation entry, such vendee cannot be said to be entitled to protection under section 41 of the Transfer of Property Act.  [Para 5]

No person can dispose of an interest in the property that is not vested in him and the only exception is that if the purchaser has purchased the property bonafide after making usual enquiry into the title as a reasonable and prudent man of business would do, even if the property has been sold by that person who does not have full interest in the property, such purchaser can be protected. However, the onus lies on the purchaser to establish that he had acted in good faith and purchased the property after making full enquiries into the title of the vendor and all reasonable care was taken by him before the purchase.  [Para 9]

heading: Sale or lease
Construction
HeadNote.description:
Sale or lease - Construction of document Clauses inconsistent with context - Court will have to ascertain the intention of the parties - In earlier writ petition both the parties jointly pleaded that document was one of sale and not a lease - Held court below was right in decreeing the suit holding that the document was one of sale and not a lease.

Document - Construction - Whether document  is one of sale or lease.

heading: Mortgage in favour of lessee
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage in favour of lessee - No automatic merger of interest of lessee with that of mortgagee, in the absence of proof of surrender of the lease.

The question whether upon redemption of usufructuary mortgage a tenant -mortgagee was required to deliver actual or physical possession of the mortgage property to the lessor-mortgagor depends upon the intention of the parties at the time of the execution of the mortgage deed. There is no automatic merger of the interest of a lessee with that of a mortgagee when the same person is the lessee as well as the mortgagee, in the absence of proof of surrender of the lease. Unless there is merger of both rights on redemption of the mortgage the plaintiff is not entitled to recover physical possession of the property. The right of lessee to continue in possession would survive after redemption.

heading: Notice of termination of leases
HeadNote.description: Notice of termination of leases - Existence of two distinct and separate  leases in respect  of tenancy, not substantiated - Landlady terminating  tenancy with two separate notices in respect of two leases - Termination of tenancy is valid and suit for eviction is maintainable. (Para 6)

heading: Deed
Construction
Suit for possession
Interpretation
HeadNote.description:
Deed - Construction - Suit for possession - Portion of suit premises given to defendant for use and occupation as licensee under agreement for eleven months - One key of premises to remain with defendant and another with plaintiff by agreement - Defendant required to deposit certain amount as security with plaintiff - Held, agreement was leave and licence agreement and defendant was licensee.

J.T. 1993(6) SC 331 foll. 1981 Mah.L.J. 876 and 1990(1) Bom.C.R.529 Disting.

Deed - Interpretation - Agreement between parties for use and occupation of premises - Whether agreement was leave and licence agreement or agreement for lease. (Paras 9,10)

heading: Right of the buyer under sub-section (6) of Section 55 is a statutory charge on seller's interest
HeadNote.description:
Right of the buyer under sub-section (6) of Section 55 is a statutory charge on seller's interest - It is enforceable not only against the seller but also against all persons claiming under him - The buyer is entitled also to the interest on the amount of purchase money paid - Limitation for enforcement of the charge is 12 years from the date when the charge becomes enforceable - Such a charge can be enforced even on substituted security.

 In the absence of contract to contrary, the buyer will have a charge on the seller's interest in the property which is the subject matter of the sale agreement insofar as the purchase money and interest on such amount are concerned, unless the buyer has improperly declined to accept delivery. The charge is available against the seller and all persons claiming under him. This charge in favour of the buyer is the converse of the seller's charge under Section 55(4)(b). The buyer's charge under this section is a statutory charge and differs from a contractual charge which a buyer may be entitled to claim under a separate contract. No charge is available unless the agreement is genuine. The charge on the property under Section 55(6)(b) is enforceable not only against the seller but against all persons claiming under him. Before the amending Act of 1929, the words 'with notice of payment' occurred after the words "all the persons claiming under him." These words were omitted as they allowed a transferee without notice to escape. After the Amendment of 1929, notice to the purchaser has now become irrelevant.

 When the property upon which the charge is created gets converted into another form, the buyer will be entitled to proceed against the substituted security. This is a general principle of law and Section 73 of the Transfer of Property Act is only an example of the said principle. The above principle has been applied to enforce mortgage on substituted securities. The same principle which is applicable to mortgages applies to cases of statutory charge under Section 55(6)(b). If immovable property is charge and is converted into another property or money, then the charge will fasten on the property or money into which the subject matter of the agreement is converted.

The sub-section (6) of Section 55 also makes it clear that the buyer is entitled to interest on the amount of purchase money paid. Interest is payable from the date of payment of the purchase money to the seller till date of delivery of property to the purchaser or till the execution of the sale deed, whichever is earlier.   [Para 28,29,30]

heading: Lease or licence
Construction of deed
HeadNote.description:
Lease or licence - Construction of deed - Mere exclusive possession of premises - Cannot amount to licence.

The exclusive possession of premises by itself will not amount to creation of interest.  Exclusive possession by itself would not militate against the concept of a licence, if the circumstances negative any intention to create a tenancy.   [Para 16]

	In the instant case, the nomenclature or the label for the arrangement is unambiguous.  It is only a licence.  Clause (5) of the agreement specifically provides that nothing herein contained shall create or be construed to create any tenancy or to confer or be construed to confer upon the licensee any interest in the said cottage or any part thereof, and the said cottage shall continue or be deemed to continue to remain in the possession of the licensor.  Clause (6) provides that this licence is personal to the licensee and is not capable of and shall not be assigned by the licensee to any other person.  No right or interest whatsoever in the premises or any part thereof is created in favour of the defendant.  One thing is clear that the Bombay Rent Act was in existence ever since 1947.  The plaintiff as well as the defendant were aware and should be deemed to be aware of the prevailing state of law.  They chose to call the arrangement as a licence.  The initial period of licence was for 11 months and thereafter the licence was renewed from time to time till the period under the last licence agreement expired in 1969.  The exclusive possession by itself will not amount to creation of interest and it will not militate against the concept of a licence if the circumstances negative any intention to create any interest.  In the circumstances, it is not possible to accept the view taken by the Single Judge that the fact that the defendant was placed in exclusive possession indicates the intention of the parties to create a lease.  The fact that the defendant was a stranger to deceased licensor or that she was having another premises for her residence also would not militate against the concept of leave and licence.   [Para 17]

Further, the licence in favour of defendant expired in June, 1969.  Thus the licence in favour of the defendant was not subsisting on the relevant date and as such the defendant cannot be treated as deemed tenant under section 15A of the Bombay Rent Act.
 [Para 22]

heading: Unauthorized sale
HeadNote.description: Unauthorized sale - Effect of subsequent authorization - Suit land purchased by plaintiff on 6.1.1990 when it was declared surplus under ceiling law - Ceiling removed only on 14.9.1990 - Nothing on record to show that plaintiff, on date of purchase, had knowledge of suit land being covered by ceiling law - Rights and title of plaintiff protected by S.43 of TP Act - Neither original vendor nor his legal heirs ever challenged title of plaintiff - Defendant is an encroacher - There is already a finding against defendant's title - Plaintiff entitled to decree of possession and permanent injunction against defendant.	(Paras 7, 9, 10)

heading: Lease
Renewal
HeadNote.description:
Lease - Renewal - Terms and conditions of renewal vague and uncertain - No evidence of any verbal request for renewal after termination of lease - Lessor sending notice of termination of lease - Held in absence of clear cut terms and conditions of renewal, lease of lessee was liable to be evicted on expiry of lease.

The renewal clause in a lease deed is an important term of the agreement. Ordinarily the Court should be reluctant to ignore such a term of the lease, unless on a fair reading and reasonable construction no meaning can be attached to it. Since the renewal clause is not clear and specific regarding the terms of renewal the Court is to ascertain the intention of the parties from the materials on record. The lease deed read as a whole, does not indicate the manner in which the right of renewal is to be exercised by the parties and the terms and conditions of such renewal. It is not even stated in the document that the renewal will be subject to terms and conditions to-be decided by the parties by mutual discussion or according to any other procedure. There is no indication whether such discussion will at all be held or not. Renewal being an important condition of lease, could not have been dealt with in such careless and slipshod manner and would not have been left in such vague and uncertain condition if the parties were serious about the renewal of the lease. On appreciation of the evidence the Courts below having not believed the case of the defendants that some verbal requests for renewal of the lease were made by them to the plaintiff after expiry of the period of lease, the Courts have found that no attempt was made by the lessees to suggest the terms and conditions for renewal of the lease particularly the rent to be paid by them except offering the rent for two months at the old rate. In such circumstances, if the Courts below have found that the lessees had no enforceable right of renewal under the document and indeed had not taken any step for execution by any document on renewal of the lease, no exception can be taken to such findings. No fixed principle or straight jacket formula can be laid down regarding the question whether the condition of renewal of the lease, which is vague and uncertain should be enforced. The question is to be Judged on the facts and circumstances of each case.  [Para 12]

heading: Exercise of option
HeadNote.description:
Exercise of option - No particular form is prescribed by law - Appellant not indicating existence or exercise of option in his favour and that respondent had notice of the existence of the said option - He is not entitled to benefit of S.43.

AIR 1951 Nag. 241 Rel. on.	(Paras 14, 16)

heading: Notice to quit
HeadNote.description:
Notice to quit - Oral lease created for manufacturing purpose - Fifteen days' notice for terminating lease is valid - Lease cannot be deemed to be from year to year terminable by six months' notice.

In the present case though the appellant has claimed that it was a lease for manufacturing purpose, admittedly there was no registered written lease.  Therefore, rule of construction as envisaged in Section 106 would not be applicable as the statutory requirement of Section 107 of the Act has not been satisfied.  The plea of the appellant that 15 days' notice terminating the present tenancy is bad in law would not be sustainable.

AIR 1959 Cal. 181 and AIR 1965 ALL 187 Overruled.			 [Para 10]

heading: Power of attorney and gift deed
HeadNote.description: Power of attorney and gift deed - Prayer for cancellation of on ground of same having been obtained fraudulently - Power of attorney allegedly executed by flat owner in favour of his brother to give right to gift flat to son of brother - Contents of power of attorney shows that it was executed by owner of flat to safeguard his interest and enjoy right - If power of attorney was executed for safeguarding interest, owner would not have allowed brother to gift flat to his son - Owner was taxi driver having no other property except suit flat and also having his own children whereas his brother was doctor having three other properties - It does not appear that owner will gift flat to son of his brother - Further, even if owner wanted to gift flat to son of his brother, he would have gifted it himself directly instead of executing power of attorney - Power of attorney neither endorsed before Notary nor attested in due course - Owner of flat submitted that he has given suit flat to his brother for carrying on his medical practice and executed power of attorney for smooth running of medical practice of his brother in suit flat - No explanation offered by brother to remove suspicious circumstances in power of attorney and gift deed - Power of attorney and gift deed are not genuine and illegal. 		(Paras 14, 15, 16, 17, 19)

heading: Ambit
Appellants
HeadNote.description:
Charge for purchase money paid by purchaser - Ambit - Defendants-vendor failing to execute sale deed of land - Appellants - Purchaser terminating agreement as envisaged in clause 2.3. thereof and claiming refund of earnest money with interest at 21% p.a. in terms of agreement - Defendants refunding earnest money but not paying interest - Held, earnest money paid was actually part payment of purchase price only and, therefore, statutory charge envisaged in S.55(6)(b) will get attracted and encompass whole amount paid and interest due thereon.

The buyer's charge engrafted in clause (b) of paragraph 6 of Section 55 of the Transfer of Property Act would extend and ensure to the purchase-money or earnest money paid before the title passes and property has been delivered by the purchaser to the seller, on the seller's interest in the property unless the purchaser has improperly declined to accept delivery of property or when he properly declines to accept delivery - including for the interest on purchase money and costs awarded to the purchaser of a suit to compel specific performance of the contract or to obtain a decree for its rescission. The principle underlying the above provision is a trite principle of justice, equity and good conscience. The charge would last until the conveyance is executed by the seller and possession is also given to the purchaser and ceases only thereafter. The charge will not be lost by merely accepting delivery of possession alone. This charge is a statutory charge in favour of a buyer and is different from contractual charge to which the buyer may become entitled to under the terms of the contract, and in substance a converse to the charge created in favour of the seller under Section 55(4)(b). Consequently, the buyer is entitled to enforce the said charge against the property and for that purpose trace the property even in the hands of third parties and even when the property is converted into another form by proceeding against the substituted security, since none claiming under the seller including a third party purchaser can take advantage of any plea based even on want of notice of the charge. The said statutory charge gets attracted and attaches to the property for the benefit of the buyer the moment he pays any part of the purchase money and is only lost in case of purchaser's own default or his improper refusal to accept delivery. So far as payment of interest is concerned, the section specifically envisages payment of interest upon the purchase-money/price prepaid, though not so specifically on the earnest money deposit, apparently for the reason that an amount paid as earnest money simplicitor, as mere security for due performance does not become repayable till the contract or agreement got terminated and it is shown that the purchaser has not failed to carry out his part of the contract, and the termination was brought about not due to his fault, the claim of the purchaser for refund of earnest money deposit will not arise for being asserted. [Para 13]

heading: Notice under
Service of
Are joint tenants
Followed.	 [Para 10]
HeadNote.description:
Notice under - Service of - Legal representatives of original tenant - Are joint tenants - Notice of termination of tenancy can be served only on one of the heirs of deceased tenant who acted for and on behalf of other tenants.

AIR 1989 SC 1470 - Followed.	 [Para 10]

heading: Second notice
HeadNote.description: Waiver of notice to quit - Second notice - Simply because a landlord issues second notice it does not amount to waiver of the first notice - Tenant must prove that the landlord had an intention to treat the lease as subsisting and that he had expressly or impliedly consented - Intention of the parties will have to be gathered. 2004(2) ALL MR 154 and 2002(4) ALL MR 783 - Ref. to.	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Charge on property
Loan transaction
HeadNote.description:
Charge on property - Loan transaction - Mere undertaking that party will not dispose of property during currency of loan, will not create a charge on that property.

A conjoint reading of Section 100 with Section 59 of the TP Act makes it clear that if by act of parties, any immovable property is made security for the payment of money to another and it does not amount to mortgage, then all the provisions which apply to a simple mortgage, as far as may be, apply to such charge. Consequently, in view of Section 59 of the TP Act when there is a mortgage other than a mortgage by deposit of the title deeds, it can be effected only by a registered instrument. So far as the present case is concerned, no registered mortgage deed was executed by the first respondent and no title deed of the property was handed over by the first respondent to the Corporation. The mere undertaking that a person would not dispose of the properties mentioned, during the currency of the loan, would not confer any charge on the immovable properties mentioned therein. In other words, a mere undertaking to create a mortgage is not sufficient to create an interest in any immovable property.           [Para 11,13]

heading: Defence of
Suit for possession
HeadNote.description:
Part performance of contract - Defence of - Suit for possession - Defendant in possession pursuant to agreement for sale between him and Plaintiff's original transferee under an agreement for sale - As Plaintiff had no privity of contract with Defendant - Defendant not a transferee as contemplated u/s. 53A - Defendant not entitled to defence of equitable doctrine of part performance.


AIR 1927 Audh 482 - Rel. on.

There was no agreement between the plaintiff and the defendant in connection with the suit land. The doctrine of part performance stated in Section 53A, cannot be availed of by the defendant against the plaintiff with whom he had no privity of contract. The defendant is a third party and he has come in possession of the suit land on the basis of an agreement of sale executed not by the plaintiff but by Pishorilal. Therefore, the privity of contract is between Pishorilal and the defendant but not between the plaintiff and the defendant. The doctrine of part performance as contemplated by Section 53A can be availed of by the transferee and any person claiming under him, against the transferor or any person claiming under him. The defendant is not a transferee within the meaning of section 53A. Therefore, he does not have the equitable right to protect his possession as against the transferor i.e. the plaintiff.  [Para 9]

heading: Part performance
HeadNote.description: Part performance - Defendants can defend their possession only if it is found that there was a valid agreement between parties.			 (Para 3)

heading: Feeding grant by estoppel
HeadNote.description:
Feeding grant by estoppel - Applicability of doctrine explained.

Section 43 embodies a 'rule of feeding the estoppel' and enacts that a person who makes a representation shall not be heard to allege the contrary as against a person who acts thereupon and it is immaterial whether the transferor acts bona fide or fraudulently in making the representation. In order to get the benefit of the said provision, the conditions which must be satisfied are: (1) the contract of transfer was made by a person who was competent to contract; and (2) the contract would be subsisting at the time when a claim for recovery of the property is made. However, the provisions would have no application if the transfer was invalid as being forbidden by law or contrary to public policy, as envisaged under Section 23 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872. Thus, no estoppel can be pleaded contrary to the provisions of a statute. The 'rule of feeding the estoppel' shall apply in absence thereof. The doctrine of feeding the estoppel envisages that 'where a grantor has purported to grant an interest in land which he did not at the time possess, but subsequently acquires, the benefit of his subsequent acquisition, goes automatically to the earlier grantee, or as it is usually expressed, feeds the estoppel'. The principle is based on an equitable doctrine that a person who promised to perform more than he can perform must make good his contract when he acquires the power of performance. Section 43 enables the transferee to whom a transferor has made a fraudulent or erroneous representation to lay hold, at his option, of any interest which the transferor may subsequently acquire in the property, unless the right of any subsequent purchaser for value without notice is in effect.	 [Para 10,11,12,13,14]

heading: Mortgage
Interpretation of document
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage - Interpretation of document - If condition of reconveyance is enumerated in document itself, then it has to be regarded as mortgage as provided u/s.58(c) of the Transfer of Property Act - The question is always of intention of the parties - Extraneous evidence can be considered only when terms of the documents are vague - However, if the terms of the document are clear enough then it is not necessary to consider the other evidence.

If the condition of reconveyance is enumerated in document itself, then it has to be regarded as mortgage as provided under Section 58(c) of the Transfer of property Act, 1882.  The question is always of intention of the parties.  The extraneous evidence can be considered only when the terms of the documents are vague.  However, if the terms of the document are clear enough then it is not necessary to consider the other evidence.  In the present case, there was no concession granted as such.  What is explicit from the terms of the document is that if the mortgage amount is returned within period of five years, then mortgage will be redeemed and if it is not so done, then document itself would be treated as sale.  Obviously, understanding between parties to the document was clear.  They intended to bring about mortgage.  It is not a case where right of ownership was transferred in favour of said Vasantrao Neb or his father.  The amount was also referred as "mortgage amount" (i|²ee¢r j'kc). The condition incorporated in the document is to the effect that in case the mortgage money would not be paid within five years period, the document will be deemed as sale.  In other words, the transaction was not of out and out sale, when the document was brought about.  No right of ownership had passed in favour of the mortgagee.  Then, deceased Shankarrao had not recognized the fact that his interest in the property was relinquished due to such transaction.  The document clearly supports the condition which creates clog on redemption of the mortgage.  There is no substratum on record to reach conclusion that the parties intended to sell the suit house property by giving concession to deceased Shankarrao to repurchase the same on certain condition.  AIR 1985 P & H 189 & AIR 1965 S.C. 225 - Ref. to.	 [Para 7]

heading: Lease or licence
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Lease or licence - Determination of - Allotment of premises to carry out business - Premises was exclusive within domain of plaintiff - No interest created in respect of premises in defendant - Also as per S.107 of T.P. Act, lease can be created only by registered document - Agreement was not registered - Agreement /document is not lease - It is license.	(Paras 16, 17, 18, 19)

heading: Applicability
H.U.F. property
HeadNote.description: Applicability - H.U.F. property - Half share thereof transferred by one of the co-sharer's son fraudulently stating that his father/karta had expired at that time - Purchaser was also aware of this fact - Said transaction not saved by invoking S.43 of Transfer of Property Act.			(Paras 9, 10, 12, 14)

heading: Suit for specific performance at the instance of vendee
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance at the instance of vendee - Becoming barred by limitation - That cannot be a ground to deny the benefit of the plea of part performance of agreement of sale to the person in possession. 2002(2) ALL MR 267 (S.C.) Rel. on.	(Para 8)

heading: Lease
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Lease - Determination of - Plea of alleged tenant that premises in question were not let out to him but given by plaintiff for carrying on business to him in terms of family settlement - High Court proceeded on absolutely erroneous premise that there is no specific denial of relationship of landlord and tenant between the parties - True nature of relationship between the parties concerning occupation of subject premises by appellant alleged tenant was required to be ascertained from the family arrangement - Matter needs to be reconsidered by the High Court, inter alia, on the aspects as to whether under the family settlement a relationship of lessor or lessee came into existence between the parties and, if answer to the said question is in the affirmative, whether such lease is determinable. 	(Paras 10, 12, 13)

heading: Scope
Maintainable
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Suit simpliciter by prospective transferee in possession seeking decree for perpetual injunction restraining transferor from disturbing possession - Maintainable - It amounts to enforcement of bar under S.53-A and using shield to protect possession and does not amount to enforcement of any rights by transferee.

A suit simpliciter filed by a prospective transferee under S.53-A seeking a decree of perpetual injunction against the Defendant, who is transferor, restraining him from disturbing the possession of the Plaintiff is maintainable. When the transferee has complied with all the conditions necessary in terms of S.53-A of the T.P. Act, he is entitled to claim equity under S.53-A to protect his possession of the suit property. [Para 5,7,14]

Section 53-A disentitles the transferor from seeking possession from the proposed transferee in possession.  Therefore, if the transferor, though he has been denied that right by Section 53-A, tries to take possession forcibly, the proposed transferee in possession would be entitled to institute a suit to enforce the bar of Section 53-A against the transferor.  In such a situation, when the proposed transferee in possession comes to the court seeking a decree of perpetual injunction restraining the transferor from disturbing his possession, he does not come to the court for enforcement of any rights conferred on him, but he comes to the court for enforcement of the bar created by Section 53-A against the transferor.   [Para 11]

When it is said that the proposed transferee in possession can use Section 53-A as a shield, but not as a sword, it means that he can use Section 53-A either as a Plaintiff or as a Defendant to protect his possession, but he cannot use Section 53-A either for getting title or for getting possession if he is not actually in possession.  To put it in other words, when the transferee in possession comes to the court as a Plaintiff seeking a decree of perpetual injunction against the transferor he is using Section 53-A as a shield to protect his possession.  It is thus clear that the proposed transferee in possession cannot use Section 53-A to sue the transferor for a declaration of title, but he can avail of benefits of Section 53-A as a shield to retain his possession.	 [Para 11]

The question whether a suit of particular nature is maintainable or not has to be decided with reference to the provisions of Section 9 of CPC. No provision of law expressly bars the jurisdiction of the civil court to entertain such suit.	 [Para 13]

Even if it is assumed that the cause of action for instituting a suit for a decree of specific performance had accrued and the Plaintiff in that case omitted to institute the suit for specific performance, then also by virtue of the provisions of Order 2 Rule 2 of CPC the suit of the Plaintiff for a decree of specific performance would be barred, but his suit for a decree of perpetual injunction for protecting his possession would not be barred.  Occasion for a prospective purchaser in possession to institute a suit for perpetual injunction for protecting his possession may arise even when the cause of action for instituting the suit for specific performance has not arisen or where it is barred by the law of limitation.   [Para 13]

It is clear that in a situation where a suit for a decree for specific performance is barred by the Law of Limitation, the prospective purchaser in possession would not be in a position to institute a suit for decree of specific performance, but Section 53-A creates an equity in his favour, as a result of which he is entitled to continue in possession.  If it is held that though his possession is protected, he cannot institute a suit in case he finds that his possession has been threatened that would amount to denying a remedy for enforcing the equity which is created in his favour by Section 53-A.  In a case where the prospective purchaser has a live cause of action for instituting a suit for specific performance, he omits to institute such a suit, and instead files a suit only for perpetual injunction for protection of his possession, in that situation it is for the Court to consider whether to grant him a decree of perpetual injunction or not.  But that will be in the realm of exercise of the jurisdiction.  It will not be a case of absence of jurisdiction to entertain the suit.  Therefore, there is nothing in Specific Relief Act also which can be said to have barred the jurisdiction of the civil court to take cognizance of such a suit even by necessary implications.						  [Para 13]

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Interference with finding of fact - Redemption of mortgage of suit property - Execution of agreement for sale of property not proved - Held, decree for redemption of mortgage is bound to follow - No interference with finding of fact of Appellate Court in second appeal.	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description:
Relinquishment of interest in immovable property - Suit for possession - Surrender or relinquishment of right in immovable property is a transfer of property if it is made in favour of a person having no interest in it - In absence of registration, such oral surrender of immovable property is invalid.

A surrender or relinquishment of right in immovable property is a transfer of property if it is made in favour of a person having no interest in it. Any transfer of immovable property worth more than Rs.100/- requires registration. A relinquishment of share in the joint family property  of Hindu may not require registration whenever such surrender is effected at the time of partition, since it is a transfer of interest in favour of person having an interest in it. This perhaps is the only exception where a registration of relinquishment or surrender will not be required. In all other cases, registration would be required for it involves transfer of interest in immovable property in favour of a person having no interest in it. [Para 8,10,11]

heading: Gift-deed
Proof
HeadNote.description: Gift-deed - Proof - For proof of gift-deed, an attesting witness is required to be examined since gift is a document which is compulsorily attestable - It must be shown that it was duly executed by the executor of his own free Will.	(Paras 8, 10)

heading: Sale deed
Not in dispute
HeadNote.description:
Sale deed - Execution and registration of - Not in dispute - Parties intending that title to suit properties would pass to purchaser only after payment of full consideration as a condition precedent - Hence, title did not pass either on execution or registration of sale deed.

Normally, ownership and title to the property will pass to the purchaser on registration of the sale deed with effect from the date of execution of the sale deed. But this is not an invariable rule, as the true test of passing of property is the intention of parties. Though registration is prima facie proof of an intention to transfer the property, it is not proof of operative transfer if payment of consideration (price) is a condition precedent for passing of the property. The answer to the question whether the parties intended that transfer of the ownership should be merely by execution and registration of the deed or whether they intended the transfer of the property to take place, only after receipt of the entire consideration, would depend on the intention of the parties. Such intention is primarily to be gathered and determined from the recitals of the sale deed. When the recitals are insufficient or ambiguous the surrounding circumstances and conduct of parties can be looked into for ascertaining the intention, subject to the limitations placed by Section 92 of Evidence Act. In the present case, though the sale deed recites that the purchaser is entitled to hold, possess and enjoy the scheduled properties from the date of sale, neither the possession of the properties nor the title deeds were delivered to the purchaser either on the date of sale or thereafter. It is admitted that possession of the suit properties purported to have been sold under the sale deed was never delivered to the appellant and continued to be with the respondents. In fact, the appellant, therefore, sought a decree for possession of the suit properties from the respondents with mesne profits. If really the intention of the parties was that the title to the properties should pass to the appellant on execution of the deed and its registration, the possession of the suit properties would have been delivered to the appellant.  [Para 8,9]

heading: Doctrine of lis pendens
HeadNote.description: Doctrine of lis pendens - Doctrine applies only where the lis is pending before a Court - Suit for declaration of title and ownership over certain property - Entitlement of transferee pendente lite to be impleaded in suit - Transferee pendente lite of an interest in immovable property is a representative-in-interest of the party from whom he has acquired that interest - He is entitled to be impleaded in the suit or other proceedings - Where the transferee pendente lite is made a party to the litigation, he is entitled to be heard in the matter on merits of the case - Transferee pendete lite granted permission to be impleaded. AIR 2005 SC 2209 - Rel. on.	(Paras 10, 11)\

heading: Lease of open plot for 10 years
HeadNote.description:
Lease of open plot for 10 years - Tenant holding over after expiry of lease period as well as renewal period - Putting up and running a petrol pump - Not carrying out manufacturing process - Lease terminable on 15 days' notice.

The lessee of premises for purposes other than agricultural or manufacture holds over is a monthly tenant. In case of lease for the purpose other than manufacture, tenancy created by holding over under section 116 is a monthly tenancy terminable by either party by 15 days notice.   [Para 23]

An open plot was given on lease initially for a period of 10 years. There is nothing on record to show that option to renew lease was exercised at any point of time. Assuming that the lease was renewed for further period of ten years, even then that period also stood expired but the defendants continued as tenants of the suit plot. It is an admitted position that the suit plot of land was being used as petrol pump and no manufacturing process whatsoever was carrying on at the suit plot. Merely selling of petroleum products and/or pumping of petrol from the storage tank does not change the character of the petrol. There was no manufacturing process carried out on the suit plot. Thus the tenancy was terminable, by fifteen days' notice expiring with the end of a month of the tenancy.   [Para 22,25,26]

heading: Determination of lease under S.111
HeadNote.description: Determination of lease under S.111 - Can be effected by giving appropriate quit notice under S.106 of the Act. A.I.R. 1989 SC 1510 and A.I.R. 1989 SC 997 - Ref. to.	(Para 15)

heading: "Doctrine of lis pendens"
HeadNote.description:
"Doctrine of lis pendens" - The principles specified in S.52 of the Act are in accordance with the equity, good conscience, justice because they rest upon an equitable and just foundation that it will be impossible to bring an action or suit to a successful termination if alienations are permitted to prevail - A transferee is bound by the Decree just as much as he was party to the suit.

The principles specified in Section 52 of the Act are in accordance with the equity, good conscience, justice because they rest upon an equitable and just foundation that it will be impossible to bring an action or suit to a successful termination if alienations are permitted to prevail. A transferee is bound by the Decree just as much as he was party to the Suit. The principle of lis pendens embodied in Section 52 of the Act being a principle of public policy, no question of good faith or bona fide arises. The mere pendency of a suit does not prevent one of the parties from dealing with the property constituting the subject matter of the Suit. The Section only postulates a condition that the alienation will in no manner affect the rights of the other party under any decree which may be passed in the suit unless the property was alienated with the permission of the Court. 2007 AIR SCW 954 and AIR 2009 SC 1948 - Ref. to.  [Para 17]

heading: Scope of S.48
HeadNote.description: Saledeed in respect of suit land - Scope of S.48 - Transferor cannot prejudice the rights of transferee by any subsequent dealing with the property - S.48 of T.P. Act ordains to accept supremacy of the former saledeed in all the terms than the latter. 	(Para 9)

heading: Notice to quit
Waiver
HeadNote.description:
Notice to quit - Waiver - When can be inferred - Suit for recovery of arrears of rent and eviction - Landlord accepting payment during pendency of suit - Plea of waiver of quit notice by tenant - Landlord issuing second notice - Held did not amount to waiver of first notice - Payment received during pendency of suit - Landlord entitled to appropriate it towards arrears of Rent.

Contract Act (1872), S.59.

The fact of demand or acceptance of rent during pendency of a suit for eviction of tenant will not ipso facto constitute waiver of the earlier notice to quit or an intention to create fresh contractual tenancy and it will have to be viewed in the facts and circumstances of the case and conduct of the parties. [Para 14,15]

In the instant case a suit for recovery of arrears of rent and eviction was filed against the tenant after due service of notice to quit.  The tenant in his written statement denied that he was in arrears of rent and raised specific plea that the landlord accepted rent subsequent to notice and thus waived the of ejectment notice.  The landlord there after issued second notice to quit stating therein that the same is issued in view of raising the plea of waiver by the tenant and without prejudice to the landlord's right in the pending suit and the first notice to quit.

Held in the facts and circumstances of the case that the act of the landlord in issuing second notice did not result in waiver of the earlier ejectment notice.	 [Para 15,18]

In the present case the landlord pleaded that there existed the arrears of rent and prayed for a decree.  During pendency of the suit the tenant made payment through money order.  Oral evidence of the tenant does not specify any details such as any period for which the money orders were sent.  In view of the provisions of S.59 of the Contract Act a person receiving payment has a right to appropriate the amount towards the debt or dues of his choice. When admittedly there existed arrears and judicial seal has been put to it concurrently by lower courts, it was the absolute choice of the landlord to appropriate the dues or amount, towards the arrears and in this background also acceptance of rent it was not the rent being received towards current dues or towards immediate past duration of tenancy, and therefore, such payment was not in any circumstances liable to be treated as waiver of the first notice of quit.		 [Para 17]

heading: Agreement of sale
HeadNote.description: Agreement of sale - Suit for possession on ground that agreement of sale was void - Claim for protection on ground of part performance of contract - Contract to transfer suit property for consideration in writing and signed by parties - Both parties found to have performed respective parts of contract - Respondent in possession of suit property - Defendant, held, was entitled to protect possession under S.53-A.			(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Counter claim
Jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Presidency Small Causes Courts Act (1882), S.41 - Counter claim - Jurisdiction - Matter pertaining to taking back possession of leased immovable property from a tenant - Can be agitated as per S.41 of P.S.C.C. Act only in a Presidency Small Cause Court and not in other Court. A.I.R. 1980 Bom. 123 - Rel. on.	(Para 12)

heading: Benami transaction
HeadNote.description: Benami transaction - Determination of the question as to whether a transaction is benami one or not depends upon a large number of factors - Role and/or the motive on the part of person who had advanced amount of consideration plays an important role - Claim of daughter that properties standing in the name of her brothers were self acquired properties of her father - Court cannot decide whether they were benami without considering intention of father and totality of circumstances.	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Tenant of the suit property must show that he was in possession on the date of the order directing the parties to maintain status quo and that he was dispossessed in violation of the subsisting interim order
HeadNote.description:
Tenant of the suit property must show that he was in possession on the date of the order directing the parties to maintain status quo and that he was dispossessed in violation of the subsisting interim order - Plaintiff has to lay foundation for grant of an interim order of mandatory injunction in his favour - It is not appropriate to pass an order directing the parties to maintain status quo, without indicating what the status quo is.

Admittedly, the defendants are the owners of the building.  The plaintiff claiming having obtained possession on the basis of lease on 17-4-1998.  The lease was denied by defendants who had pleaded that plaintiff had been entrusted with some renovation work for which he was being paid and alleged document relied on by him was a concocted one.  The grant of mandatory injunction would necessarily depend upon plaintiff establishing before the court that on 19-6-98 when the court directed the parties to maintain status quo, he was in possession as a tenant of the plaint schedule property.  The burden in that behalf is clearly on the plaintiff, the claim he made, having been denied by the defendants.  Prima facie it is difficult to imagine that a building of substantial dimension located in commercially important part of the city would have been let out in such an informal manner and the transaction not being evidenced even by a rent deed executed by the lessor and the lessee in terms of Section 107 of the Transfer of Property Act.
