It is difficult to imagine that the letter-head of one company was used for dealing with the properties of another entity which appears to be a partnership as per the description contained in the letter.  Prima facie, the document does not satisfy the requirements of Section of Transfer of Property Act and though it acknowledges receipt of a sum of Rs.2 lakhs, there is no stamp affixed to indicate that it was intended to be a receipt for the said sum.  The genuineness of this document which is seriously disputed by the defendants, its admissibility in evidence and validity, have to be decided in the suit.  Therefore, one of the questions that has to be decided is whether this letter is genuine and if it is genuine, whether it is capable of bringing into existence a lease or accepted as evidencing a lease transaction between the parties.  Since this is the document on which the suit is based, the finding on the genuineness and validity of this document and the alleged transaction created by it will have a great bearing on the claim of possession by the plaintiff.  No doubt the signature of defendant No.1 found in the document is admitted but with an explanation that it is a got up document.  A suit has also been filed by the defendants challenging it.  [Para 6]

The plaintiff claiming that he had been put in possession as a tenant and that the defendants were attempting to dispossess him forcibly.  The plaintiff filed the suit for a declaration of his tenancy rights over the suit property and for a perpetual injunction restraining the defendants from interfering with his possession as a tenant.  Though the plaintiff filed an application for an interim injunction, the trial court did not pass an ad interim order of injunction, but only issued notices to the defendants calling upon them to show cause why the prayer for injunction shall not be granted.  Against this refusal of ad interim injunction ex-parte, plaintiff filed appeal.  Additional District Judge on 19-6-1998 passed ad interim ex-parte order directing both the parties to maintain status quo.  In an original suit of this nature, it was not appropriate for the Additional District Judge to pass an order directing the parties to maintain status quo, without indicating what the status quo was.  Simply directing parties to maintain status quo without incating what the status quo was, is not an order that should be passed at the initial stage of a litigation, especially when one court had found no reason to grant an ex-parte order of injunction and the appellate court was dealing with only the limited question whether an ad interim order of injunction should or should not have been granted by the trial court, since the appeal was only against the refusal of an ad interim ex-parte order of injunction and the main application for injunction pending suit, was still pending before the trial court itself.  Therefore, the Additional District Judge ought not to have passed an equivocal order like the one passed in the circumstances of the case.  But of course, that aspect has relevance only to the extent that before ordering an interim mandatory injunction or refusing it, the court has first to consider whether the plaintiff has proved that he was in possession on the date of suit and on the date of the order and he had been dispossessed the next day.  Unless a clear prima facie finding that the plaintiff was in possession on those dates is entered, an order for interim mandatory injunction could not have been passed and any such order passed would be one without jurisdiction. [Para 3,4]

heading: Redemption
Several mortgages
HeadNote.description: Redemption - Several mortgages - Appellant claiming possession of mortgaged land belonging to T - Land again mortgaged to H and S - Second mortgage deed providing for Rs.425/- as Amanat to be kept by H and S for payment of Appellant's dues- Mortgagor alleging receipt of Rs.425/- from mortgagees wherefor receipt allegedly granted on 20/02/1979 - Heirs of T applying to Collector for redemption - Collector directing redemption on 28/04/1992 - Purported receipt not produced - H unsuccessfully questioning Collector's direction - Heirs of T selling part of land - Purchasers seeking possession in terms of Collector's order dt.28/04/1992 - Appellant's objections for possession rejected till High Court - Appeal to Supreme Court - Conduct of parties showing redemption of first mortgage while creating purported second mortgage - Both mortgagees family members - Second mortgage deed registered - Collector's direction attained finality - Appellant having failed to produce receipt, it cannot be considered by Supreme Court - Order showing consideration of all aspects of the matter - Supreme Court found appellant raised unnecessary objection in execution of redemption order - Appellant's contention barred by principles of constructive res judicata - Appeal dismissed with costs.			(Paras 12, 13, 16 to 19)

heading: Money borrowed by appellant from respondent and deed executed
HeadNote.description:
Money borrowed by appellant from respondent and deed executed - Deed stated to be sale deed - Simultaneous document executed for reconveyance of lands on repayment of loan amount - It is not sale deed but it is purely towards security of loan amount - Suit for partition or ownership in the suit property is not maintainable by respondent - Respondent does not get ownership right.

The appellant borrowed a sum of Rs.8,000/- from respondent on 27-8-1952 and the parties executed two documents one being a sale deed in respect of Lands for the consideration of Rs.10,000/- and another being Kararnama for re-conveyance of the property to the appellant on repayment of the loan amount to the respondent.  Both the documents relate to the same property and were executed simultaneously on the same day.  The loan amount was required to be repaid by 6-6-1953 and thereafter the property was required to be re-conveyed.  The appellant, however, failed to pay the loan by 6-6-1953.  It was a specific case of the appellant that since the appellant was unable to repay the amount within stipulated period, there was an oral agreement entered between the parties under which the possession of the half of the suit property was delivered to the respondent on condition that he should enjoy the same for a period of 12 years and  thereafter the possession should be redelivered to the appellant and the income derived by the respondent during the said period of 12 years from the said part of the suit property should be appropriated towards the recovery of the loan amount payable by the appellant to the respondent.  The specific plea in that regard raised in the pleadings and duly corroborated by the testimony of the appellant has not been controverted or disproved by the respondent.

Held, that all the facts duly established by cogent evidence on record have been totally ignored by the lower courts and merely on presumption that whatever has been stated in the concerned document of 27-8-1952 discloses the real transaction, have proceeded to hold that by the said deed the property was conveyed in favour of the respondent and in that sense, the document is a sale deed.  The finding arrived at by both the courts being contrary to the records as well as the settled law applicable to the facts of the case, the same can not be sustained and is liable to be set aside and it is to be held that the deed in question was purely towards security for repayment of the loan which was borrowed by the appellant from the respondent.  Being so, there was no right of ownership acquired by the respondent to the suit property on the date when the suit was filed and therefore, respondent was not entitled to seek partition or ownership share in the suit property and therefore the suit was liable to be dismissed.    [Para 18]

The document in question i.e.  Deed dated 27-8-1952 is undoubtedly stated to be a sale deed and it is also registered document.  Being so certainly there is presumption as regards the document having been executed by the parties.  However, merely because a document is a registered document, and merely because it is referred to as a sale deed, there is no presumption regarding the correctness of the recitals in such document.  In a case where the correctness of recitals in such document is disputed, burden lies upon the party seeking to rely upon the correctness of the recitals in such document to establish the same with cogent evidence. FA 88/1967 dt.28-1-1998 (Bom) Revered.	 [Para 9]

heading: Agreement of sale
Registration of
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage by conditional sale - Agreement of sale - Registration of - Where transaction is not one of mortgage, the second document would not need registration, even if it is a part of the same transaction of sale - Held, in this case also the transaction was a mortgage by conditional sale and having regard to provisions of S.17 of Registration Act, the agreement of sale was not compulsorily registerable.

Proviso appended to Section 58(c) is clear and unambiguous.  A legal fiction is created thereby that the transaction shall not be held to be a mortgage by conditional sale, unless a condition is embodied in the document which effects or purports to effect the sale.  Where two documents are executed, the transaction in question would not amount to a mortgage by way of conditional sale.  In a case of this nature, ordinarily the same would be considered to be a deed of sale coupled with an agreement of reconveyance.

In the instant case, no relationship of debtor or creditor came into being.  No security was created and in fact conveyance of the title of the property by the respondent to the appellant was final and absolute.

If the transaction is really one of mortgage then the second deed would be inadmissible for want of registration; but where the transaction is not one of mortgage, the second document would not need registration, even if it is a part of the same transaction of sale.

In this case also the transaction is a mortgage by conditional sale and having regard to the provisions of Section 18 of the Indian Registration Act, the agreement of sale was not compulsorily registerable.  AIR 1926 Bom. 497, 2007 ALL SCR 39 and (2006)4 SCC 432 - Ref. to.  [Para 12,17,18]

heading: Usufructuary mortgage
HeadNote.description: Usufructuary mortgage - Concurrent findings regarding title of plaintiffs to suit house - Plaintiff's father was in possession of suit house given in possession to him for a loan of Rs.200/- - Loan not repaid within time fixed - Plaintiff's father thereby becoming owner of the house - Defendant had encroached on land in the absence of plaintiff and erected temporary shed without any authority on the suit land - Held, substantial questions of law were required to be answered against defendants and their challenge to decree was devoid of merits.			(Para 8)

heading: Suit for partition
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition - Necessary and proper parties - According to appellants they had purchased undivided shares of respondents nos.2, 3, 4 & 6 - High Court holding that appellants were not entitled to be impleaded since the right they may have cannot be larger than the right of their vendors - Held appellants having purchased the property from co-sharers were entitled to come on record in order to work out equity in their favour in the final decree proceedings - Preliminary decree passed by Trial court in absence of appellants set aside and suit restored.			(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Intention of parties
HeadNote.description: Licence or a lease - Intention of parties - For ascertaining whether a document creates a licence or a lease, what is to be seen is the substance of the document and it is the substance which must be preferred to the form and the real and dominant test being the intention of parties whether the parties intended to create a lease or a license - A lease is a transfer of right to enjoy the premises where as a license is a privilege to do something on the premises which otherwise would have been unlawful - The transaction is a lease if it grants an interest in the land and it is a license if it gives a personal privilege with no interest in the land. AIR 1959 SC 1262 and 1971(1) SCC 276.

heading: Mortgage by deposit of title deeds
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by deposit of title deeds - Whether for satisfying requirement of S.58(f), it is necessary to deposit documents showing complete title or good title and whether all the documents of title to the property are required to be deposited and whether in all such cases, property should have been acquired by reason of a registered document - Question being of far-reaching consequence referred to a larger Bench.			(Paras 26, 29, 48)

heading: Recovery of rent
Right of transferees
HeadNote.description: Recovery of rent - Right of transferees - Tenant cannot refuse to pay rent on the ground that transferee has not attorned tenancy - It is enough for transferee to prove his title and to inform tenant of the purchase of property.	(Para 7)

heading: Licence or lease
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Licence or lease - Determination - Document of agreement clearly showing that plaintiff had given to the defendant, business of her husband for conducting in the suit premises - There was thus a categorical intention to create a licence - No right, title or interest as a leasee was created - The relationship between the parties was that of licensor and licensee and not lessor and licensee.

Where the very contents of the suit document are sufficient to show that what was really intended by the original plaintiff was to give the business for conducting, as her husband was unable to look after the business anymore due to ill-health and, therefore, the document was executed categorically with intention to create a licence and no more right, title or interest as a leasee on behalf of the appellant.  Thus, it was held that the wording of the document itself is plain and clear and has to be given its plain meaning to it and cannot be read between the lines.  [Para 7]

heading: Enforcement of legal right
HeadNote.description: Enforcement of legal right - Bar under S.69 of Partnership Act - Bar would not apply to suit for enforcement of legal right under Ss.108(q) and 111(h) of Transfer of Property Act - Bar must apply for enforcement of right arising from a contract entered into by unregistered firm with a third party in the course of business dealings with such third party. 1998(7) SCC 184 & 2000(3) SCC 250 - Ref. to.	(Paras 9 & 10)

heading: Redemption of mortgage
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Redemption of mortgage - Limitation - No evidence to show that mortgage was for fixed period - Property can be redeemed at any time - Court will ignore any contract the effect of which is to deprive mortgagor of his right to redeem the mortgage. AIR 1958 SC 770 Foll. JT 1997(2) SC 577 Held per incuriam.	(Paras 7, 12)

heading: Auction sale
Confirmation of
Rel.on.						 [Para 15,17]
HeadNote.description:
Auction sale - Confirmation of - Title of property passes to purchaser - He cannot ask the seller to execute conveyance in favour of third party.

The obligation on the seller, to execute a proper conveyance is statutorily recognised in Section 55(1)(d) of T.P. Act. It is the duty of the buyer not only in the first instance to pay or tender the price, but also to propose a conveyance and tender it to the seller for execution. The words "proper conveyance" incorporated in S.55(1)(d) were used by the Division Bench of Bombay High Court in Rahimtulla Lowji Damani (AIR 1935 Bom 340) in the sense in which they would be understood in English Law as meaning a proper conveyance in favour of purchaser or as he shall direct. But In India on the date of confirmation of sale the title of property passes to the purchaser. In the instant case the situation would have been different had the applicant made request to the Court before confirmation of sale, to execute conveyance to assignee but after confirmation of sale by the Court, the applicant being owner of the property, cannot ask the seller to execute conveyance in favour of third party.  AIR 1935 Bom 340, (2005)4 SCC 572 - Rel.on.						 [Para 15,17]

heading: Jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Provincial Small Causes Courts Act (1887) , Ss.23, 26 - Jurisdiction - Suit or proceedings or application in Court of Small Causes - District Court can withdraw suit proceedings or application from Court of Small Causes and transfer it to Court of Civil Judge (Senior Division) and thereupon such transferee Court is deemed to be Court of Small Cause.	(Para 9)

heading: Transfer by ostensible owner
HeadNote.description:
Transfer by ostensible owner - This doctrine is attracted in case of voluntary transfer and not involuntary transfer by an unauthorised person.

In the present case, the counsel for the defendant nos.5 & 6, contended that the said defendants are purchasers of the suit property in good faith and for consideration. That the said defendants took all necessary steps to investigate the title of the suit property and since were satisfied that there was no claim of any other person, proceeded to purchase the property. That will be of no avail. For, if the defendant no.1 had no right of any nature to deal with the suit property after the execution of the Conveyance Deed in favour of Veer Bahadur dated 15.4.1988, in terms of section 19 of the Specific Relief Act, the defendant nos.5 and 6 cannot claim any higher right. To get over this position, the counsel for the defendant nos.5 & 6 would rely on section 41 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, which reads thus :-

"41. Transfer by ostensible owner.- Where, with the consent, express or implied, of the persons interested in immoveable property, a person is the ostensible owner of such property and transfers the same for consideration, the transfer shall not be voidable on the ground that the transferor was not authorised to make it: provided that the transferee, after taking reasonable care to ascertain that the transferor had power to make the transfer, has acted in good faith."

It was argued that insofar as these defendant nos.5 and 6 are concerned, that they had purchased the property from the defendant no.1 who was the ostensible owner of the suit property. For, the name of the defendant no.1 continues to appear in the Record of Rights as well as other relevant revenue records. In the first place, the defendant nos.5 and 6 will succeed only if they were to plead and prove that the transfer of property in their favour was with the express or implied consent of the persons interested therein. In other words, this doctrine is attracted in case of voluntary transfer and not involuntary transfer by an unauthorised person. (2007)2 SCC 404 - Rel. on.  [Para 15]

heading: Pre-emption
HeadNote.description:
Pre-emption - Suit for, on ground of vicinage - Maintainability of, when only an agreement for sale of property was entered into by defendant-1/appellant-3 with appellants 1 and 2 - Held, in terms of Section 54 a mere agreement to sell, creates no interest in suit property in favour of vendee - Unless title to suit property has passed in accordance with Act, no right to enforce pre-emption arises - Therefore, suit for pre-emption brought on basis of such an agreement was without any cause of action as there was no right of pre-emption in respondents which could be enforced under law - Mohammedan Law or any other personal law of transfer of property cannot override Act - Right of pre-emption, a weak right and not looked upon with favour by Courts and therefore courts cannot go out of their way to help pre-emptor.

Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act says that a contract for sale does not, of itself, create any interest in or charge on immoveable property.  Therefore, where the parties enter into a mere agreement to sell, it creates no interest in the suit property in favour of the vendee and the proprietary title does not validly pass from the vendors to the vendee and until that is completed no right to enforce pre-emption arises.  Therefore, the suit for pre-emption brought on the basis of such an agreement was without any cause of action as there was no right of pre-emption in the respondents which could be enforced under the law.  The transfer of property, where the Transfer of Property Act applies, has to be under the provisions of the Act only and Mohammedan Law or any other personal law of transfer of property cannot override the statute.  Therefore, unless title to the suit property has passed in accordance with the Act, no right to enforce pre-emption arises.  Therefore, in view of the admitted fact that merely agreement for sale was entered into by the appellant No.3 with the appellant Nos.1 and 2 in respect of the suit property, the question of exercising any right of pre-emption in the respondents could not arise at all, a suit for pre-emption brought on the basis of such an agreement for sale must be held to be without any cause of action as there was no right of pre-emption in the respondents which could be enforced under the law.  There are no equities in favour of a pre-emptor, whose sole object is to disturb a valid transaction by virtue of the rights created in him by statute.  It would be open to the pre-emptee, to defeat the law of pre-emption by any legitimate means, which is not fraud on the part of either the vendor or the vendee and a person is entitled to steer clear of the law of pre-emption by all lawful means.  That apart, it is now well settled that the right of pre-emption is a weak right and is not looked upon with favour by courts and therefore the courts cannot go out of their way to help the pre-emptor.  AIR 1960 SC 1368 - Rel on.   [Para 11,12]

Such being the position, the right of pre-emption was not available to the respondents.  If ultimately the sale deed is executed, it would be open for the respondents to apply for pre-emption of the suit property, if under the law they are permitted to maintain the suit for pre-emption.   [Para 13,15]

heading: Possession after redemption
Right of mortgagor
HeadNote.description:
Possession after redemption - Right of mortgagor - Mortgagee continuing in possession after termination of mortgage is clog on redemption - Entitlement to receive rent from tenants of mortgagee can by no stretch be considered as creating a tenancy between mortgagor and tenants of mortgagee. 
(1989) (1) SCC 458, 1969 (3) SCC 79, 2000 (4) SCC 326 Rel. on. 	(Para 8)

heading: Doctrine of part-performance
Protection under S.53-A
Agreement of sale
HeadNote.description: Doctrine of part-performance - Protection under S.53-A - Agreement of sale - Protection under S.53-A of Transfer of Property Act is not available to person who has failed to perform his part of contract.  2002(2) ALL MR 267 (S.C.) and 2004(4) ALL MR 20 Ref. to. 	(Para 23)

heading: Written instrument
Leading of evidence
Agreement of reconveyance
Agreement enforceable
HeadNote.description: Written instrument - Leading of evidence - Agreement of reconveyance - Agreement enforceable - Real transaction can be proved by brining independent evidence. (2003)6 SCC 595 and 2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 283 - Followed.	(Para 27)

heading: Auction sale
HeadNote.description: Auction sale - Court cannot be swayed merely by higher amount offered to Court that runs counter to the rights of the earlier contracting parties that crystalised upon the contract being successfully completed unless, of course, the encumbrances subject to which the contract was completed are not removed.	(Para 41)

heading: Waiver of notice to quit
HeadNote.description:
Waiver of notice to quit - Eviction decreed in respondent's suit by two courts below - Respondents instituted and prosecuted subsequent proceedings for permission to terminate tenancy - Whether waiver of first notice to quit can be inferred from said fact - Mere act of lessor showing an intention to treat lease as subsisting is not sufficient to constitute waiver - That action must have express or implied consent of lessee whose consent to the act must exist.

It is clear from S.113 that the notice of ejectment is waived not only by a subsequent act on the part of the person giving such a notice doing an act which shows an intention to treat the lease as subsisting, but only when such an act is accompanied by an express or implied consent of the tenant or the lessee.  In other words, the mere act of the lessor showing an intention to treat the lease as subsisting is not sufficient to constitute a waiver. That action must have the express or implied consent of the lessee whose consent to the act must exist.  [Para 6]

There is no doubt that the appellate authority has refused permission to the respondent to terminate the tenancy and the respondent had, therefore, challenged that order by a Writ Petition.  This was on the basis that there was a lease in existence.  However, what section 113 requires is an "intention to treat the lease as subsisting" i.e. something more than a mere acknowledgment of the mere existence of the lease. What is necessary is that the act must show an intention on the part of the lessor to treat the lease as subsisting. The respondent had initiated the proceedings before the quit notice which took effect from 31-8-1982. The rest of the proceedings were a mere continuation  and the Writ Petition must in this sense be treated as a continuation of the same proceedings. It does not apper that by the mere filing of the Writ Petition, the lessor intended to continue the lease to treat the lease as subsisting. Even otherwise, it is equally important that there was no consent on  the part of the appellant that the respondent's act of filing the Writ petition which is an act to show the intention to treat the lease as subsisting. Admittedly, the appellant-tenant has done no act such as the payment of rent by the appellant to show that the appellant intended to treat the lease as subsisting.   [Para 7]

Hence it is not possible in this case to infer consent on the part of the appellant to have the notice waived and treat the lease as subsisting.  The parties were not of one mind.  For such an inference, there must be a clearest - indication that the recipient of the notice intended and consented to have the notice given to him waived and an agreement on the part of both in respect of such waiver. Thus, to qualify for S.113 of the Act. (1978 Mh.L.J.850 Ref.)		 [Para 6,7,10,11]

heading: Quit notice
Waiver
HeadNote.description:
Quit notice - Waiver - Landlord accepting rent for period subsequent to notice - Though accepting rent, landlord also filing and prosecuting eviction suit - Waiver of notice and subsistence of lease cannot be inferred therefrom.

The question as to whether the person giving the notice has by his act shown an intention to treat the lease as subsisting is essentially a question of fact. In reaching a conclusion on this aspect of the matter, the Court must consider all relevant facts and circumstances, and the mere fact that rent has been tendered and accepted, cannot be determinative.   [Para 6]

In the instant case, two notices to quit were given on 10th February, 1979 and 17th March, 1979. The suit was filed on June 2, 1979. The tenant offered and the landlord accepted the rent for the months of April, May and thereafter. The question is whether this by itself constitute an act on the part of the landlord showing an intention to treat the lease as subsisting. In our view, mere acceptance of rent did not by itself constituted an act of the nature envisaged by section 113, Transfer of Property Act showing an intention to treat the lease as subsisting. The fact remains that even after accepting the rent tendered, the landlord did file a suit for eviction, and even while prosecuting the suit accepted rent which was being paid to him by the tenant. It cannot, therefore, be said that by accepting rent, he intended to waive the notice to quit and to treat the lease as subsisting. 2005(5) SCC 543 Rel on. AIR 1926 Cal 763 Overruled.   [Para 8]

heading: Specific performance
Suit for
HeadNote.description: Specific performance - Suit for - Registered agreement of sale of land, 1st floor - Notarised agreement of first floor - Oral and documentary evidence prove that plaintiff was in need of accommodation hence entered into agreement and paid amount indicated in document - Defendant's version that transaction was in fact hand loan, does not inspire confidence - Defendant's sons were witnesses of registered agreement, shows plaintiff had not ill intention - Sons did not step into witness box to prove defendant's version - Decree of specific performance of agreement to sell, upheld. 			(Paras 14 to 18)

heading: Plea of tenancy
Surrender of tenancy
Inference of
HeadNote.description: Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1948) - Plea of tenancy - Surrender of tenancy - Inference of - Lease of a property is a very valuable right and its implied surrender would not be readily inferred - Had the parties wanted to terminate their earlier relationship of landlord and tenant on the execution of a mortgage, then one would expect a clear statement or an indication to that effect in the document itself. (1995) 6 SCC 608 - Rel. on. 	(Para 12)

heading: Eviction order
HeadNote.description: Eviction order - Confirmed by Supreme Court by giving time to vacate - If tenant fails to vacate after expiry of time, he will be evicted by police force. 	(Para 4)

heading: Denial of title of landlord by tenant
HeadNote.description:
Denial of title of landlord by tenant - When denial of title is not bona fide, the denial forfeits the right of tenancy - S.111(g) of the Transfer of Property Act is not inconsistent with the scheme of the Bombay Rent Control Act.

Denial of title of landlord by tenant, when such denial of title is not bonafide, forfeits the right of tenancy.

As per Section 12(1) of the Bombay Rent Act, a landlord shall not be entitled to recovery of possession of any premises so long as the tenant pays, or is ready and willing to pay, the amount of the standard rent and permitted increases, if any, and observes and performs the other conditions of the tenancy, in so far as they are consistent with the provisions of the said Act. One of the conditions of tenancy or lease as per Section 111(g) of the Transfer of Property Act, is that the tenant shall not deny the title of the landlord or shall not renounce his character as tenant by setting up title in third person or in himself. Section 111(g) of the Transfer of Property Act is not inconsistent with the scheme of the Bombay Rent Control Act. 2006(6) Mh.L.J. 840 & AIR 1994 SC 227 - Ref. to. [Para 19,22]

heading: Costs of improvement
HeadNote.description: Costs of improvement - Refusal to ascertain by civil court - On ground that as per S.51 civil court has no jurisdiction to decide issue and it has to be decided by executing court - S.51 nowhere prohibits adjudication of cost of improvement by civil court, nor does it provide for such adjudication being made by executing court - It is civil court which decides all issues including issue of costs of improvement which is in nature of damages - Such exercise would better be done by civil court by framing an issue for levy of damages - Executing court can even make an assessment, but then adjudicatory process, even on assessment, deserves not to be delayed by leaving job to executing court - Order refusing to ascertain costs of improvement by civil court, not proper. 			(Para 7)

heading: Application of
HeadNote.description: Application of - Deceased husband of plaintiff no. 1 executed unregistered agreement to sell in favour of defendants - Deceased husband gave irrevocable power of attorney to defendants - Contents of general power of attorney show that property was in possession of deceased husband at relevant time - S.53 A is not attracted - Finding by Trial Court and High Court that defendants did not get possession by execution of agreement to sale - Finding not liable to be interfered with.			(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Unregistered lease deed
HeadNote.description:
Unregistered lease deed - Relationship of landlord and tenant not in dispute - Rent payable annually @ Rs.800/- not in dispute - Fact that rent was not right from 1971 was also not disputed - Held admission of a party either in pleadings or oral is the best evidence and same does not need any further corroboration and as such High Court ought to have upheld decree for payment of arrears of rent.

(2000) 6 SCC 394 Explained.

2010(3) ALL MR 477 (S.C.) Disting. (Paras 10, 12, 15)

heading: Deed
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with a condition of repurchase - Question whether a given transaction is a mortgage by conditional sale or a sale outright with a condition of repurchase is a vexed one and must be decided on its own facts - Intention of the parties is the determining factor - Deed - Construction.

The rule of law on this subject is one dictated by commonsense; that prima facie an absolute conveyance, containing nothing to show that the relation of debtor and creditor is to exist between the parties, does not cease to be an absolute conveyance and become a mortgage merely because the vendor stipulates that he shall have a right to repurchase. The converse also holds good and if, on the face of it, an instrument clearly purports to be a mortgage it cannot be turned into a sale by reference to a host of extraneous and irrelevant considerations. Difficulty only arises in the border line cases where there is ambiguity.	 [Para 5,7]

Under the Proviso to S.58(c). T. P. Act, if the sale and agreement to repurchase are embodied in separate documents, then the transaction cannot be a mortgage whether the documents are contemporaneously executed or not. But the converse does not hold good, that is to say, the mere fact that there is only one document does not necessarily mean that it must be a mortgage and cannot be a sale. If the condition of repurchase is embodied in the document that effects or purposes to effect the sale, then it is a matter for construction which was meant. The legislature has made a clear cut classification and excluded transactions embodied in more than one document from that category of mortgages, therefore, it is reasonable to suppose that persons who, after the amendment choose not to use two documents, do not intend the transaction to be a sale, unless they displace that presumption by clear and express words; and if the conditions of S.58(c) are fulfilled, then the deed should be construed as a mortgage. 	 [Para 8]

In this case, the document was to the following effect; Rs.634 principal with interest under a registered rehan bond (simple mortgage) dated the 6th May 1927 is justly due... by us the executants. Now we further require Rs.65-6-0 more to meet costs of the suit under S.40. (Bihar Tenancy Act).. and at present there is no other way in view rather it seems impossible and difficult to arrange for the money without selling the property let out in rehan (simple mortgage) under the above mentioned bond. Therefore, we the executants... declare... that we ... sold and vended the properties detailed below on condition (given below) for fair and just price of Rs.700 ... That we set off Rs. 634-10-0 against the consideration money .... payable under the aforesaid bond in favour of the said endue and receive Rs. 65-6-0 in cash from the said vender. In this way the entire consideration money was realised from the said vendee. And we put the said vendede in possession and occupation of the vended property detailed below and made him an absolute proprietor in our places. If we, the executants, shall repay the consideration money to the said vendee within two years... the property vended under this deed of conditional sale attached shall come in exclusive possession and occupation of us, the executants. If we do not pay the same, the said vendee shall remain in possession and occupation thereof, generation after generation, and he shall appropriate the produce thereof, we, the executants, neither have nor shall have any objection whosoever in respect of the vended property and the consideration money. Perchance if we do so it shall be deemed null and void in Court. And we declare also that the vended property is flawless in every way and that if in future any kind of defect whatsoever be found on account of which the said vendee be dispossessed of a portion or the entire property vended under this deed of conditional sale and will have to pay the loss or damage, in that event we, the executants (a) shall be liable to be prosecuted under the criminal procedure, and (b) we shall pay the entire consideration money together with loss and damage and interest at the rate of Rs.2 per mensem per hundred rupees from the date of the execution of this deed till the date of relisation from our person and other properties. (c) and we shall not claim the produce of the vended property for the period of vendee's possession against the said vendee or his heirs and representatives. Therefore we, the executants... have executed this deed of conditional sale so that it may be of use in future. Held, on construction of the document and taking everything into consideration that the deed was a mortgage by conditional sale under S.58(c), T. P. Act.	 [Para 20]

Where a document has to be construed, the intention must be gathered, in the first place, from the document itself. If the words are express and clear, effect must be given to them and any extraneous enquiry into what was thought or intended is ruled out. The real question in such a case is not what the parties intended or meant but what is the legal effect of the words which they used. If, however, there is ambiguity in the language employed, then it is permissible to look to the surrounding circumstances to determine what was intended.	 [Para 6]

heading: Joint transfer for consideration
HeadNote.description: Joint transfer for consideration - Absence of evidence as to interest in the fund or as to shares which the parties respectively advanced - S.45 has no application - Suit house mutated in name of plaintiff - None of the defendants ever tried to mutate his name - Although electric meter is in name of the defendant No.2, it could be due to the fact that defendants are residing in the suit house - Held, that is an insignificant circumstance.		(Para 13)

heading: Government dues
HeadNote.description:
Government dues - Payment of agricultural income tax - Such tax liability is not qua the land mortgaged but qua the owner of the land.

While the lands are in the possession of a mortgagee and thereby liable to pay the Government dues when it comes to the question of payment of agricultural income tax it cannot be held that such liability would come within the expression 'Government dues' in as much as such tax liability is not qua the land mortgaged but qua the owner of the land who was benefited by the produce of such lands which alone falls within the definition of 'Agricultural Income'. A tax on income whether agricultural or non-agricultural is unless otherwise stipulated in the Act itself will be a tax on monetory return whether actual or notional. To be more explicit, it is relevant to state that agricultural income tax payable by the mortgagor cannot be held to be an assessment of tax made with reference to the extent of land mortgaged by him. What was assessed by way of agricultural income tax was based on the total agricultural income derived by the land holder from and out of the entirety of the land held by him which may also include the lands mortgaged. It cannot, therefore, be held that merely because, what was sought to be recovered was Agricultural Income Tax, such liability should be held to be linked to the property mortgaged. Even going by Section 76(c) of the Transfer of Property Act it can be easily visualized that what is noted as Government dues are charges of a public nature, rent accruing during the period of possession of the land in question including arrears, if any, default of which may result in bringing the property for sale. Certainly such liabilities noted and contemplated to be cleared by the mortgagee cannot and will not include the income tax liability of an assessee which is purely personal and not of a public nature. Therefore, Section 76(c) can have limited application to the specific Government dues of public nature as well as those which are referable to the land and not to the personal statutory dues of the owner of the land.  [Para 16,19,26]

heading: Impleadment in suit
HeadNote.description:
Impleadment in suit - Petitioner is pendente lite transferee - Impleadment of petitioner as party in suit filed by respondent no.1, 2 - All rights claimed by respondent no.3, 4 over suit property have been allegedly transferred in favour of petitioner - Relief if granted would affect right claimed by petitioner over suit property - Petitioner entitled to be impleaded as party in suit. 

2006 (9) SCC 199 Rel. on. (Para 8)

heading: Interim injunction
HeadNote.description: Interim injunction - Defendant is required to show that irreparable loss will be caused to him during pendency of suit if he is not allowed to alter status quo. (Paras 13, 15)

heading: Mortgage by deposit of title deeds
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage by deposit of title deeds - Requires no registered instrument - Memorandum which is only evidential of transaction without recording any terms and conditions requires no registration under S.17 of Registration Act.

When the debtor deposits with the creditor title-deeds of the property for the purpose of security, it becomes mortgage in terms of Section 58(f) of the Transfer of Property Act and no registered instrument is required under Section 59 thereof as in other classes of mortgage. The essence of mortgage by deposit of title-deeds is handing over by a borrower to the creditor title-deeds of immovable property with the intention that those documents shall constitute security, enabling the creditor to recover the money lent. After the deposit of the title-deeds the creditor and borrower may record the transaction in a memorandum but such a memorandum would not be an instrument of mortgage. A memorandum reducing other terms and conditions with regard to the deposit in the form of a document, however, shall require registration under Section 17(1)(c) of the Registration Act, but in a case in which such a document does not incorporate any term and condition, it is merely evidential and does not require registration.	          [Para 14,17]

heading: Leased property
Assignment
Cancellation of permission
Legality
HeadNote.description: Leased property - Assignment - Cancellation of permission - Without any opportunity of personal hearing to petitioner i.e. proposed assignor - Legality - Impugned order adversely reflecting upon petitioner's reputation - Proposed assignee also likely to make a claim against petitioner for refund of consideration - Thus, petitioner likely to suffer several consequences as a result of impugned order - Hence Municipal Corporation directed to hear petitioner and consider the matter de novo.    (Paras 24, 25)

heading: Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Termination of tenancy - Defendant tenants denying title of plaintiff to property - Plaintiffs are found absolute owner of property under registered sale deed - Finding that defendant tenant forfeited right of tenancy, plaintiff is entitled for possession of suit premises - Finding is supported by evidence on record - This not being Court of appeal, evidence cannot be re-appreciated - Finding of Trial and 1st Appellate Court, upheld.
2006(6) Mh.L.J. 840, 2002 (3) SCC 375, 2002 (3) SCC 98 Ref. to. 	(Para 6)

heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - Locus standi of plantiff - Suit property initially leased out to plantiff's father on temporary occupation basis - Plaintiff himself inducted defendant in suit property after his father's demise - Plaintiff now claiming his title to suit property in occupation of defendant - However, plaintiff himself admitting that his father was evicted from suit property and put back in possession after sometime - Once said eviction took place, lease granted by Government got terminated - No evidence with regard to grant of fresh lease - Thus, suit structure belonged to Government - Hence, plaintiff had no locus standi to file suit against defendant.            (Para 21)

heading: Mortgage by conditional sale and sale with condition to repurchase
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage by conditional sale and sale with condition to repurchase - Sale document executed in 1967 with condition that if sale amount of Rs.3000/- is paid back within five years land was to be returned to vendor - Possession of land handed over and defendant was using it as absolute owner - After long lapse of 11 years plaintiff filed suit alleging that property was mortgaged in favour of defendant with condition to reconvey land - Held, first appellate court was right in concluding that there was no relationship of debtor and creditor and transaction was an absolute sale with a condition of repurchase and hence High Court was justified is not interfering in second appeal.
AIR 1992 SC 1236 Rel.on.	(Paras 19, 20)

heading: Sale
Proof of purchase
HeadNote.description:
Sale - Proof of purchase - Unless all the documents relating to the entire transaction are produced before the Court, the unique circumstances could not be shown to the Court - Production by petitioner of original receipts for payment of arrears of electricity as also for deposit of transfer to his name, held, are circumstantial evidence to prove his purchase and subsequent possession by the petitioner.

In the present case, the Defendant No.2 was really in tight circumstances.  He had already settled with the Plaintiff for Rs.5,00,000/-.  The Suit was disposed off.  Creditors were knocking at his door.  He had to pay off Thakur to whom he owned moneys.  He also owed moneys to other parties.  He was convicted in a criminal case.  He was committed to prison.  He had to be released on bail.  He sought to enter into certain agreements for sale of his premises during the period he was in jail.  One of that premises is the Suit premises.  (The other premises was to be sold to Thakur, who is stated to have discharged his various debts).  Whilst he was in jail these documents were got prepared.  They could not be executed during that time.  There was a stalemate when the Petitioner wanted to purchase the Suit premises.  For discharge of his liability Defendant No.2 had to surrender possession of the Suit premises.  He entered into a kind of tripartite agreement under which he would surrender the Suit premises to the owner/builder.  The owner would agree to hand over possession to the Petitioner, the Petitioner would make payment of consideration to the owner.  The owner would pay Thakur and the owner would hand over possession of the Suit premises to the Petitioner.  Unless all the documents relating to this entire transaction are produced before the Court, the unique circumstances could not be shown to the Court.  Once that is seen, the fact that the Defendant No.2 was in jail in fact lends credence to the execution of the documents of the kind that are produced by the Petitioner as having been executed by the Defendant No.2.  Similarly the fact that the Defendant No.2 was hospitalized shows how a similar agreement containing the same requirements as of the Deed of Cancellation came to be notarised along with the left hand thumb impression of the Defendant No.2.  The fact that the original agreement itself is produced by the purchaser as a further circumstantial evidence which lends credence to his case.  If the Defendant No.2 had continued in possession as contended by him and if the Petitioner was not a bonafide occupant of the Suit premises, he would not have had the original Agreement for Sale dated 1st May, 1997 showing the purchase of Suit premises by the Defendant No.2.  The production by the Petitioner of the original receipts of MSEB soon after the purchase of the Suit premises for payment of the arrears of electricity as also for deposit or transfer to his name are further circumstantial evidence to prove his purchase and the subsequent possession.  Similarly the complaint made by the Defendant No.2 to the Assistant Commissioner of Police sought to be relied upon by him in fact shows the number of Creditors who were demanding vast amounts from the Petitioner, a few days after which the Petitioner executed the Deed of Cancellation.

Upon seeing the documents hitherto suppressed the case of the Petitioner becomes clear.  It is unfortunate that at the time the Court Receiver's report came to be considered the Petitioner's case as the bonafide purchaser of the Suit premises for consideration could be fully appreciated.  The Petitioner had to get produced the documents not executed by him to prove his case, since this was a transaction of a unique nature as aforesaid. [Para 36,37]

heading: Foll.			(Paras 10, 15)
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgage and possession - Mortgagor and mortgagee originally were in relationship of landlord and tenant - On execution of mortgage deed original rent note was cancelled and fresh rent note was executed showing that parties intended to continue their relationship of landlord and tenant - It was further agreed that rent payable was to be appropriated towards interest payable on money - Plaintiff, purchaser of suit property seeking delivery of possession after redemption of mortgage - Held though property was redeemed plaintiff was not entitled to possession since landlord tenant relationship continued - Plaintiff ought to file eviction suit under Rent Act. AIR 1991 SC 2046 and AIR 2001 SC 2284 - Foll.			(Paras 10, 15)

heading: Sale deed
Validity
HeadNote.description: Sale deed - Validity - Plaintiff seeking possession of land on ground that saledeed in question is oral and not registered document - Land in question sold for consideration of Rs.90 - Since a party has right to sell property for consideration less than market value, mandate of registration would be required to be followed only when price exceeds Rs.100/- - Plaintiff under circumstances cannot avoid saledeed and is not entitled to possession - Moreso when circumstances on record show that oral saledeed was acted upon and during lifetime of plaintiffs mother (original owner) she never challenged it.	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Induction of tenant by mortgagor during subsistence of mortgage
HeadNote.description:
Induction of tenant by mortgagor during subsistence of mortgage - Various legal proceedings pending before various courts - Tenant is bound by the result of litigation - He is also not entitled to get protection of Maharashtra Rent Act.

(1981) 2 SCC 675, AIR 1988 SC 108, AIR 1989 SC 1110 Rel. on. 	 [Para 15,16]

heading: Redemption
HeadNote.description: Redemption - Portion of mortgaged property - Where one of the two mortgagors transferred his interest in the mortgaged property in favour of the mortgagee, held, the co-mortgagor is entitled to seek redemption to the extent of his own share on making payment of proportionate part of the amount. (1997)3 SCC 317 - Ref. to. (Paras 9, 10)

heading: Suit for eviction
Notice
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - Notice - Suit for eviction and recovery of possession was filed on ground of forfeiture of tenancy - Notice issued was simply a notice u/S.106 of T.P. Act and does not speak about forfeiture of tenancy - In absence of notice of forfeiture of tenancy, protection u/Cl.13 of Rent Control Order, attracted - Suit dismissed. 	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Gift deed
Execution of
Improper
HeadNote.description: Succession Act (1925), S.63 - Civil P.C. (1908), S.54 - Gift deed - Execution of - In a suit for partition, Trial Court granted 1/4th share each in suit property to plaintiff and defendants by relying on gift deed executed by original owner in favour of defendants - Without reversing finding of Trial Court that two attesting witnesses had proved gift deed, Appellate Court reversed decree in respect of defendants - On ground that gift deed was shrouded by suspicious circumstances - Improper - Once it is found that gift deed is registered and also signed by donor, it cannot be held to be invalid - Appellate Court committed error of law - Decree passed by Trial Court is restored.			(Para 4)

heading: Lease of land
Eviction
HeadNote.description: Portuguese Decree Nos.43, 525, Art.21 - Lease of land - Eviction - On ground of unauthorized sub-letting - Lease agreement expressly provided that sub-letting by lessee Society is not permissible for purpose other than education - It was alleged that Society illegally sub-let suit property to Trust - However, for creating sub-lease, there has to be a lessee in existence who should continue to remain as such - But, facts show that Society itself was dissolved and consequently, suit property handed over to the Trust - It was neither sub-letting nor transfer but a simple vesting - Besides, there is no evidence of any consideration or rent to be paid by alleged sub-lessee to the lessee i.e. by the Trust to the Society - No violation of lease agreement - Eviction, declined. 			(Paras 20, 21, 22)

heading: Right of transferee
Seven years after
HeadNote.description: Right of transferee - Land allotted to transferor by Improvement Trust - Transferor transferring it to appellant and Trust approving of such transfer - Seven years after - Trust cancelling allotment originally made in favour of transferor as she was not eligible for allotment - Held appellant did not acquire any independent right in the plot and he only acquired whatever rights transferor had therein, however, Trust directed to consider willingness of transferee to pay additional amount as may be levied by Trust for allotment of plot in his favour.	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Cancellation of sale deed - Validity - Plaintiffs alleged to have executed sale deed in respect of land in question in favour of defendant on failure to repay loan - Loan availed by plaintiffs does not find place in sale deed - Defendant also failed to produce any document showing payment of any amount as loan to plaintiffs - Plaintiffs claiming that defendant had obtained their signatures on sale deed in garb of getting grants disbursed to patients suffering from disease of leprosy - Evidence on record shows that husband of defendant took plaintiffs from their house on pretext of getting treatment and to get amount in form of grants - Finding of appellate court that signatures were obtained fraudulently, proper - Cancellation of sale deed, proper. 	(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Lis-pendens
HeadNote.description: Lis-pendens - Challenge to order registering lis pendens notice - Proceedings under S.138 of NI Act are subjudice - Held, proceeding u/s.138 of NI Act is not where right to immovable property is directly and specifically in question - Therefore, S.52 of TP Act is not applicable - No question arises of registering authority invoking S.18(ee) of Registration Act - Registration of notice is without jurisdiction and authority - Hence, not sustainable. (Paras 8, 9, 11, 12)

heading: Suit for redemption of property
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of property - Transaction whether a mortgage or conditional sale with stipulation of repurchase - Condition stipulated under the deed that if plaintiffs make repayment of Rs.10,000/- within a period 5 years, defendants would handover the suit property back to plaintiffs - Reflects that actual transaction between parties was of loan - Their relationship was of debtor-creditor - Therefore, said transaction is a mortgage by way of conditional sale. (Para 14)

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Concurrent findings of fact - Courts below concluding on basis of evidence that present appellant was not a bonafide purchaser of the suit lands for value without notice - No substantial question of law raised in second appeal - Appeal deserves to be dismissed.			(Para 4)

heading: Auction sale
Setting aside of
HeadNote.description: Auction sale - Setting aside of - On ground of invalidity of mortgage - Though issue as to validity of mortgage on basis of which loan was obtained, not raised at any point of time in any of earlier proceedings - High Court ought not to have gone into said question at belated stage - Moreover, auction purchaser is an innocent third party - He has obtained loan to pay the sale price - He is in possession of suit property since March 2016 and has spent considerable amount on renovation of the premises - Therefore, order of High Court setting aside sale proceedings held not tenable.	(Para 6)

heading: Lease with renewal clause
HeadNote.description: Lease with renewal clause - Oil Corporation, a lessee, exercising right of renewal under lease deed - But no fresh lease deed was executed - Resulting into month to month tenancy - Lessor can terminate lease on expiry of period of first renewal - Having exercised right of renewal once, Oil Corporation was not entitled to ask for second renewal under S.5(2) of 1976 Act. 	(Paras 19, 20, 23)

heading: Determination of
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with condition of repurchase - Determination of - Deed shows some ingredients of sale and some of mortgage - Deed stipulates that if plaintiff fails to pay amount within period of ten years then deed will be final sale deed - Plaintiff has not paid amount within period of ten years - Deed will be considered as sale deed - Plaintiff would not be entitled to possession of property. (Paras 10, 13, 16, 17)

heading: Notice to quit
Monthly tenancy
HeadNote.description: Notice to quit - Monthly tenancy - Computation of 15 days period of notice - To be computed from date of receipt of notice - Notice to quit served on 16.2.1991 and suit filed on 12.4.1991 - Held, more than sufficient period was available at disposal of tenant to comply with quit notice. 			(Paras 8, 9, 10)

heading: Transfer of property
HeadNote.description: Transfer of property - Sale deed whether constitutes a mortgage by conditional sale - Agreement to sale clearly states that if plaintiff pays back the loan amount then sale deed would be cancelled - Had it been intention of parties to sell suit property, parties would not have agreed for return of land on payment of loan amount - Inadequacy of sale consideration is another circumstance to indicate plaintiff's intention not to sell property - Sale deed does not embody any condition as stipulated in S.58(e) of TP Act - Hence, same would not constitute a mortgage by conditional sale. (Paras 7, 9, 11)

heading: Mortgage
Suit for redemption
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage - Suit for redemption - Contents of documents show that it was mortgage document - Defendant in his evidence admitted that plaintiff offered him money and requested to redeem suit land - However, defendant refused to do so - Decree of redemption of mortgage passed by trial court, confirmed by 1st appellate court, held proper - No interference warranted in findings of courts below. 
2008 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 90 Ref.to.	(Paras 10, 12)

heading: Transfer of lessor's rights
HeadNote.description: Transfer of lessor's rights - Attornment by tenant is not necessary - Notice u/S.106 by transferor landlord would be proper and so also suit for ejectment.

heading: Rights of occupant
HeadNote.description:
Lease of immovable property - Rights of occupant - Destruction of building on leased property - Tenancy rights continue to exist between parties. 

Immovable property means landed property and may include structures embedded in the earth such as walls or buildings for the permanent beneficial enjoyment. A lease of immovable property is a transfer of right to enjoy such property in consideration of price paid as per Section 105 of the T.P. Act. By way of lease, a right and interest is created which stands transferred in favour of the lessee. The immovable property, thereafter, only can be reverted back on determination of such right and interest in accordance with the provisions of the T.P. Act. Therefore, once the right of lease is transferred in favour of the lessee, the destruction of a house/building constructed on the lease property does not determine the tenancy rights of occupant which is incidental to the contract of the lease which continues to exist between the parties. Once a tenancy is created in respect of a building standing on the land it is the building and the land which are both components of the subject-matter of demise and the destruction of the building alone does not determine the tenancy when the land which is the site of the building continues to exist. This interpretation, as we find, is in accord with Section 108 of the Act.

(2003) 5 SCC 150 Followed.

2001(1) ALL MR 548 (S.C.) Overruled.          [Para 22,32]

In the present case, it is not in dispute that the respondent purchased the lessor's interest. The lease continued even thereafter and did not extinguish. The lease was subsisting when the shares of the land were purchased by the respondent. But the interest of the lessee was not purchased by the respondent. What has been purchased by the respondent is the right and interest of ownership of the property. The interest of the appellant as lessee has not been vested with the respondent. Therefore, the tenancy of the appellant cannot be said to have been determined consequent upon demolition and destruction of the tenanted premises.     [Para 33]

heading: Forfeiting tenancy
HeadNote.description: Forfeiting tenancy - Respondent is owner of property by virtue of decree of partition and separate possession - Petitioner was living as tenant in property on execution of lease agreement - Petitioner tenant did not pay rent arrears in spite of demand - Petitioner denying lease agreement and claiming to be owner of property - Decree of possession of suit property in favour of respondent liable to be upheld. (Para 4)

heading: Intention of parties
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale - Intention of parties - Document executed due to inability to discharge simple mortgage - Mortgaged land sold with right to repurchase within three years - Consideration for transaction was Rs.3000/- while the real value was Rs.12,500/- Patta was not transferred to defendant after execution of document - Kist for land was continued to be paid by plaintiff - Consideration for reconveyance was also fixed at Rs.3000/- only - Held intention of parties was well expressed in the deed itself and even without looking at attendant circumstances deed was one of mortgage by conditional sale.	(Paras 20, 21)

heading: Redemption of mortgage
Suit for
HeadNote.description: Redemption of mortgage - Suit for - Plaintiff mortgaged property to defendant by registered document of mortgage by conditional sale - Documents as well as evidence on record shows that it was mortgage and no adverse inference can be drawn against plaintiff u/s. 114 of the Act - Plaintiff entitled for redemption of mortgage. 		 	(Paras 12, 14, 15)

heading: Deed
Interpretation
HeadNote.description:
Deed - Interpretation - Suit by bank for recovery of loan - Fixed deposits taken as collateral security under loan agreement - Whether bank could adjust collateral security against instalments overdue as per its sole discretion.

Loan Agreement - Interpretation.

In the present case, the suit was filed by the respondent Bank for recovery of loan amount which was overdue. The loan was taken for personal use. In order to secure the repayment of the loan, the appellants had executed certain documents including the loan agreement. Fixed deposits were taken as collateral security under the agreement. The appellants paid a few instalments and thereafter stopped paying the Loan amount. The rate of interest payable on the loan amount varied from time to time. The appellants had in fact contested the suit mainly on the ground of rate of interest. The loan agreement clearly provided that if any amount remained unpaid after becoming payable, then in such an eventuality the Bank had absolute discretion to sell and realise the security/shares or any part thereof at such time and price without notice to the appellants and the said instalment could be realised by appropriating the sum from the Fixed Deposits. There was no impediment whatsoever to adjust the instalments payable out of the said collateral security nor the appellants raised any objection to do so. It was only after the filing of the suit that the collateral security amount along with interest was adjusted.

Held that the method of adjustment adopted by the Bank had adversely affected the appellants who, on account of non-application of the agreement by the Bank, were required to pay more interest on the loan than the one they earned on the Fixed Deposits. Therefore, keeping in view the provisions of the loan agreement, the Bank was required to adjust the instalment which was due every month from the collateral security which was available with the Bank.  [Para 8]

heading: Suit for recovery of possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of possession - Conducting assignment entered between parties allowing defendant to conduct plaintiffs hotel business for 3 years from date of agreement - Suit filed after agreement expired by efflux of time for recovery of premises - Defendant claiming that by seperate declaration/affidavit dt.21-9-1984 plaintiff agreed to assign his interest in suit premises to defendant for Rs.6,50,000/- inclusive of deposit amount of Rs.1,50,000/- given by him to plaintiff and that he was always ready and willing to make payment of consideration for agreement - Defendant was not put in possession in part performance of agreement but was in suit premises only as conductor of plaintiffs business - That not being juridical possession of defendant - S.53-A would not apply.			(Paras 28, 32, 33)

heading: Suit for possession
Not justified
HeadNote.description: Part performance of contract - Suit for possession - Parties entered into agreement of sale of fields - Appellants paid entire amount of consideration and thereafter took possession and had done some acts of cultivating fields in furtherance of contract - Appellants filed suit for specific performance of contract but it was dismissed for want of readiness and willingness (for not paying extra amount above agreed price) - Having lost said suit by appellants, decree of possession was passed in suit filed by respondents - Not justified - Appellants fully performed their part of contract - Requirement of S.53A of T.P. Act complied with - It was for respondents to thereafter execute sale deed but failed to do so - As held by Apex Court in (2002) 3 SCC 676, appellants would be entitled to protect their possession by way of shield. (2002) 3 SCC 676 Foll.	(Paras 6, 7, 8, 9)

heading: Right to redemption
HeadNote.description: Right to redemption - Plaintiffs being purchasers of equity of redemption claiming redemption of mortgage - Suit for redemption was filed after issuance of sale certificate and delivery of possession to auction purchaser - Neither auction sale nor sale certificate was challenged by plaintiffs - It extinguished right of redemption of mortgage - As there remained no property mortgaged to be redeemed - Right to redemption could not be claimed.  (2011) 6 SCC 780 Rel. on.			(Paras 12, 13, 14, 23)

heading: Sale of property
Second appeal
Attesting witness examined
HeadNote.description: Sale of property - Suit for recovery of unpaid amount - Decree of first Appellate Court directing defendant to pay remaining amount to plaintiff with interest - Second appeal - Sale deed executed for amount of Rs.1,50,000/-, while remaining amount of Rs.1,95000/- agreed to be paid later, by executing a separate agreement on same date - Attesting witness examined - Evidence of witness showing that price of property fixed at Rs.3,45,000/- - Defendant denied execution of any such agreement - However, no attempt on the part of defendant to send said agreement for Handwriting Expert's opinion - Conduct of defendant also needs to be considered - Execution of said agreement proved - Merely because it is not so specifically mentioned in sale deed, it does not take away the right of plaintiff to recover the unpaid amount - S.55(4)B of TP Act entitles seller to have legal recourse for the amount of purchase money, or any part thereof remaining unpaid and for interest on such amount, or part - Therefore, suit held maintainable - No substantial question of law made out - Second appeal dismissed. 		(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Decree of eviction
Challenge
Suit maintainable
HeadNote.description: Decree of eviction - Challenge - Ground that permission of Rent Controller under Rent Control Order (1949) was not obtained before filing suit for eviction - Suit was filed after issuing notice u/S.111(g) of TP Act - Defendant claiming adverse possession over suit property on basis of possession for last 22 years - Said claim of adverse possession was without any substance and afterthought - Defendant has already admitted his status as tenant in his reply to notice of plaintiff for payment of arrears of rent - Further, plaintiff's title over suit property was proved by various documents - No need to obtain prior permission of Rent Controller as defendant's tenancy stood forfeited u/S.111(g) of TP Act - Suit maintainable - Eviction held, proper. 			(Paras 12, 13, 14, 15, 16)

heading: Suit for redemption of mortgage and recovery of possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgage and recovery of possession - Based on simple mortgage - Defendant claiming to have been put in possession by a subsequent document dt.12/11/1960 - Though said document is unregistered, suit filed after 12 years after said document - Therefore, possession of defendant, held adverse to plaintiff - Dismissal of suit by Trial Court and by High Court, held proper. 1962 ALLMR ONLINE 200 (S.C.), (2006) 1 SCC 65 Rel. on. 	(Paras 2, 4, 10, 11, 14)

heading: Constitution of India, Art.254(2)
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.254(2) - Suit for eviction of tenant - Plaintiff purchased suit property from one "B" who stated to have purchased it from defendants and then defendants possessing it as tenants of "B" - Defendants claiming that "B" was a mere mortgagee in mortgage by conditional sale and also filed suit for redemption of mortgage - Property mortgaged by conditional sale on 28/11/1959 and in order to give effect to mortgage, agreement for sale was entered into on 7/12/1959 - Contention that as per proviso to S.58(c) of TP Act, in order to constitute a mortgage by conditional sale, condition of agreement to sell must have been incorporated in one document and not separately - However, as per S.37(a) of Bengal Money-Lenders Act, separate document for incorporating said condition, would not make any difference - Provisions of S.37(a) is traceable to Entry "Transfer of Property" in concurrent list and Art.254(2) saves the provision - Though there is inconsistency between both the said provisions of TP Act and State Act, in view of assent given by President, matter falls under Art.254(2) of Constitution - Therefore, despite inconsistency S.37(a) of State Act will prevail in the State - Therefore, decree in favour of defendants, held proper. 			(Paras 2, 5, 10, 18, 19)

heading: Redemption of mortgage
Validity
HeadNote.description: Redemption of mortgage - Rejection of suit for - Ground that right of mortgagor to redeem mortgage was extinguished by act of parties - Validity - Plea of mortgagor that mortgage can be extinguished only when there is Shera (endorsement) written on mortgage deed or acknowledgment in writing that mortgage is extinguished and got registered, not tenable in view of proviso to S.60 of TP Act - As per proviso to S.60, right of mortgagor to redeem mortgage can be extinguished by act of parties or by decree of Court - Record showing that mortgagee as per order of Court passed in suit for specific performance of agreement to sale in respect of mortgaged property has put defendant in possession of mortgaged property after receiving mortgage amount from him - By said act of parties, mortgage was extinguished - Rejection of suit, proper. 	(Para 5)

heading: Joint dwelling house
HeadNote.description:
Joint dwelling house - Property not divided by metes and bounds - All the entertainment areas such as hall, dining room, library, prayer room, garages etc being on ground floor house was also not capable of being divided - Held a stranger purchaser of a share of one of the co-owners of house could not be granted common possession with other members - It would cause irreparable loss to other joint members of family.
AIR 1990 SC 867 Refd. (Paras 8, 10, 11)

heading: Lease
HeadNote.description: Lease - Right to get back possession - Sought by Lessee against respondents who were strangers - On basis of allotment of suit property on lease by NIT - Respondents claimed that such allotment was cancelled subsequently - However, NIT has not come forward with any such case - Right to get back possession originates from lease and when existence of lease itself is questioned, issue of continuation or extinguishment of right of possession has assumed importance - Therefore, effect of cancellation of lease subsequently would require to be considered by adducing evidence - No illegality in remanding matter to trial Court. 2012 ALL SCR 1096 Ref. to. 			(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Intention of parties
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale - Intention of parties - Document executed due to inability to discharge simple mortgage - Mortgaged land sold with right to repurchase within three years - Consideration for transaction was Rs.3000/- while the real value was Rs.12,500/- Patta was not transferred to defendant after execution of document - Kist for land was continued to be paid by plaintiff - Consideration for reconveyance was also fixed at Rs.3000/- only - Held intention of parties was well expressed in the deed itself and even without looking at attendant circumstances deed was one of mortgage by conditional sale.	(Paras 20, 21)

heading: Redemption of mortgage
Suit for
HeadNote.description: Redemption of mortgage - Suit for - Plea of mortgagee that he was tenant of suit premises and after redemption of mortgage, his tenancy stands revived and he is entitled to remain in possession of suit premises - Mortgage deed was conspicuously silent about prior possession of mortgagee as tenant - On contrary, recitals in mortgage deed shows that on date of mortgage, possession of suit premises was delivered to him - Mortgagee failed to prove his possession over suit property prior to mortgage deed - Even if it was assumed that mortgagee was in possession of suit premises as tenant, however, terms and conditions of mortgage deed shows implied surrender of tenancy on execution of mortgage deed - On redemption of mortgage, tenancy would not revive and mortgagor becomes entitled to get possession of suit premises. 		(Paras 12, 16, 17, 20)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Doctrine of lis pendens - Applicability - Mere creation of contract of sale without execution does not amount to "transfer" u/S.52, but it does fall within expression "otherwise dealing with" - Hence mere creation of contract also falls within mischief which S.52 seeks to obviate.

	Broadly, two kinds of transactions, by the parties to the lis, without the authority of the court, during the pendency of the suit are affected by the operation of section 52 of the Act, i.e., (1) Transfer of the property involved in the suit or proceedings, (2) any mode of dealing with the property, which would adversely affect the rights of any other party thereto under any decree or order, which may be made in the suit or proceedings. The expression 'otherwise dealt with' by any party has a very wide meaning and any act or any mode of dealing with the subject-matter of the suit during the pendency of the suit or proceedings, which would adversely affect the rights of any other party thereto, under any decree or order that may eventually be passed in the suit, would fall under the said expression. In other words, any mode of dealing with the subject-matter of the suit, by any party to the lis, which would adversely affect the rights of any other party under any decree that may be passed, would be subject to the result of the suit. 	 [Para 14]

	In Wellingdon B. case (2014 (3) KHC 560), the Division Bench of this court has lost sight of the 2nd limb of section 52, "otherwise dealt with by any party to the suit or proceedings so as to affect the right of any other party thereto under any decree or order, which may be made therein". The said provision was not brought to the notice of the court, while rendering the judgment. So, the ratio laid down in Wellingdon B. case (supra) in respect of section 52 of the Act, is not a good law. Further, we also endorse the view expressed in Kubra Bibi's case (AIR 1917 Oudh 193) that creation of a contract capable of specific performance, though not an alienation by itself, is a mode of dealing with the property, pregnant with very mischief, which section 52 of the Act seeks to obviate.

AIR 1917 Oudh 193 Rel. on. 2014 (3) KHC 560 Overruled. 	 [Para 18]

heading: Suit for redemption of mortgage
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgage - Plaintiff alleging that there was mortgage by conditional sale between him and defendant - Plaintiff received amount from defendant as consideration for land owned by him and sale deed was executed in favour of defendant as he was already in possession of land - In separate agreement between parties, plaintiff agreed to repay said amount and secure reconveyance of property and on his failure to repay, deed will be considered as sale deed - Said document does not indicate any clause to demonstrate it as mortgage - Said document cannot be treated as mortgage by conditional sale - Further, on failure of plaintiff to repay amount, sale deed became absolute and defendant acquired absolute right to property - Order of High Court decreeing suit for redemption of mortgage, improper. 	(Paras 8, 9, 11, 12)

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description:
