Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with condition to repurchase - Determination - Executant-father of plaintiff alleged to have executed document titled "mortgage by conditional sale" for consideration of Rs. 2500/- as he needed money for marriage of his daughter - Record showing that executant already received Rs.700/- therefore, on date of execution of document he got only Rs. 1800/- - Said adjustment of Rs.700/- from total consideration of Rs.2500/- shows intention of parties to end debtor-creditor relationship with respect to sum of Rs.700/- and to create relationship of vendor and vendee by transfer of suit property for consideration of Rs.2500/- - Document on record showing that if amount is not repaid within period of five years, mortgage will be treated as absolute sale - Executant failed to repay amount within stipulated period - Executant never took any action during his life to get property reconveyed nor any immediate action was taken by his successor - Plaintiff produced receipt showing that Rs.800/- were paid to respondentdefendant - Said receipt was faded and bear incomplete thumb impression of issuer - No evidence adduced by plaintiff to prove receipt - Plaintiff failed to prove that receipt was genuine - It cannot be relied on - Document does not contain mention of rate of interest, right of foreclosure which are essential in deed of mortgage - Considering recitals of document, document is sale with condition to repurchase and not mortgage by conditional sale.

S.58(c) of the Transfer of Property Act contains the definition of “mortgage by conditional sale”. In a “mortgage by conditional sale”, the transfer is made as a security to a loan taken by the mortgagorowner; whereas in a “sale with a condition to repurchase”, the sale is made by the vendor-owner reserving with himself a right to repurchase it within a stipulated time. A sale with a condition of retransfer is not a mortgage since the relationship of debtor and creditor does not exist and there is no debt for which the transfer is made as a security. Whether the document is a “mortgage by conditional sale” or “sale with a condition to repurchase” is to be ascertained from the intention of the parties. As per proviso to Section 58(c), if the sale and agreement to repurchase are embodied in the separate documents then the transaction cannot be a “mortgage by conditional sale” irrespective of whether the documents are contemporaneously executed; but the converse does not hold good. Observing that the mere fact that there is only one document, it does not necessarily mean that it must be a mortgage and cannot be a sale. The question in each case is the determination of the real character of the transaction to be ascertained from the provisions of the deed viewed in the light of the surrounding circumstances. If the words are plain and unambiguous then in the light of the evidence of the surrounding circumstances, it must be given their true legal effect. If there is any ambiguity in the language employed, the intention is to be ascertained from the contents of the deed and the language of the deed is to be taken into consideration to ascertain the intention of the parties. Evidence of contemporaneous conduct of the parties is to be taken into consideration as the surrounding circumstances.

In the present case, owner of property executed document titled ‘mortgage by conditional sale’ for consideration of Rs. 2,500/- as he needed money for marriage of daughter. Owner already received Rs. 700/- therefore, on date of execution of document he get only Rs. 1,800/-. Said adjustment of Rs. 700/- from total consideration of Rs. 2,500/- shows intention of parties to end debtor-creditor relationship with respect to sum of Rs. 700/- and to create relationship of vendor and vendee by transfer of suit property for consideration of Rs. 2,500/-. Recital of document showing that if amount is not repaid within period of five years, mortgage will be treated as absolute sale. Owner failed to repay amount within stipulated period. Also during his life he never took any action to get property reconveyed nor any immediate action was taken by his successor. Further, document does not contain mention of rate of interest, right of foreclosure which are essential in deed of mortgage. Considering recitals of document, document is sale with condition to repurchase and not mortgage by conditional sale. (Paras 13, 14, 16, 17, 18, 19, 23, 25, 27)

heading: Will
HeadNote.description:
Will - Bar u/s.6(d) of T.P. Act - Will being not a transfer, bar contained in S.6(d) of T.P. Act will have no application.

A will being not a transfer, the bar contained in Section 6(d) of the Transfer of Property Act, will have no application.

A will denotes a testamentary document.  It means a legal declaration of the intention of a testator with respect to his property which he desires to be carried into effect after his death.  It is in its own nature ambulatory and revocable during his life.

A testator by his will, may make any disposition of his property subject to the condition that the same should not be inconsistent with the laws or contrary to the policy of the State.  A will of a man is the aggregate of his testamentary intentions so far as they are manifested in writing.  It is not a transfer but a mode of devolution.  AIR 2004 SC 1772 & AIR 1999 J & K 55 - Ref. to.					 [Para 19,21,34]

heading: Gift or Will
HeadNote.description:
Gift or Will - Document titled as Gift Deed of Immovable property - But contents indicating that it was to take effect after death of both the donors - Ownership of property retained with, donors during their life time - Document executed by donors and attested by two witnesses - Thus complying with requirements of Gift as well as Will - In view of effect being intended after death, ought to be treated as Will.

Gift is transfer inter vivos and ownership stands transferred immediately.  In case of immovable property the transfer of possession is not that relevant but acceptance of gift itself has to be shown.  In the present case, the pleadings or cause of action pointed by Ramji clearly shows that Ramji did not like the steps taken by the present appellants to obtain mutation of the suit property in their names as according to him the title to suit properties was to be transferred only after death of both of them.  Even language of document clearly stipulates that title is to be transferred only after death of Ramji and his wife Bhimabai which ever may occur later.  In view of this position, the courts below have correctly interpreted that document was not a document of gift but a Will deed.   [Para 10]

heading: Redemption of mortgage
Suit for
HeadNote.description: Redemption of mortgage - Suit for - Document entered into between parties styled as conditional sale - Merely because document styled as conditional sale would not determine it to be so - Document in question would clearly establish that loan being obtained and property being mortgaged in consideration of loan - It further shows that mortgager retained right of reconveyance on repayment of amount - Debt being subsisting and right of redemption being continued with debtor is a distinguishing factor which would not permit document to be construed as sale - Ascertaining the intention of parties document is mortgage by conditional sale - Plaintiff entitled for redemption of mortgage. 	(Paras 14, 20)

heading: Mortgage by conditional sale
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale - Plaintiff, mortgager took sum of Rs.3,000/- as loan from defendant for house hold expenses - Executed document titled as “conditional sale deed”, in respect of land, as security for loan amount - Same was to be returned and defendant was bound to retransfer land - On failure to pay loan amount within one year, document to be taken as permanent sale deed - Plaintiff requested defendant to reconvey suit land by accepting loan amount of Rs.3,000/- but defendant refused to do so - Advance of loan and return thereof are part of same document which creates relationship of debtor and creditor - Held, it would be covered by Proviso in S.58(c) - Therefore, order dismissing suit for redemption, liable to be set aside - Further, in absence of any positive evidence of any improvement and the cost incurred, defendants not entitled to recover anything more than mortgage amount - Suit filed for redemption after 20 years, would not be barred as suit for redemption can be filed within 30 years from date fixed for redemption. (Paras 12, 22, 24)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Recovery of mortgaged property - Limitation - As per decision of full Bench of High Court in Ram Kishan’s case, which was upheld by Supreme Court in Singh Ram [2014 ALL SCR 3747], there is no limitation period in case of usufructuary mortgage - “Once a mortgage always a mortgage” was the principle applied. 2014 ALL SCR 3747 Foll.	(Para 3)

heading: Validity of gift deed
HeadNote.description:
Validity of gift deed - Transfer of possession of immovable property - Not an essential requirement for making of a valid gift.

A conjoint reading of Sections 122 and 123 of the Act makes it abundantly clear that "transfer of possession" of the property covered by the registered instrument of the gift duly signed by the donor and attested as required is not a sine qua non for the making of a valid gift under the provisions of Transfer of Property Act, 1882. Judicial pronouncements as to the true and correct interpretation of Section 123 of the T.P. Act have for a fairly long period held that Section 123 of the Act supersedes the rule of Hindu Law if there was any making delivery of possession an essential condition for the completion of a valid gift.

AIR 1922 ALL 467 (FB) Rel. on.      [Para 11]

Section 123 of the T.P. Act is in two parts. The first part deals with gifts of immovable property while the second part deals with gifts of movable property. Insofar as the gifts of immovable property are concerned, Section 123 makes transfer by a registered instrument mandatory. This is evident from the use of word "transfer must be effected" used by Parliament in so far as immovable property is concerned. In contradiction to that requirement the second part of Section 123 dealing with gifts of movable property, simply requires that gift of movable property may be effected either by a registered instrument signed as aforesaid or "by delivery". The difference in the two provisions lies in the fact that in so far as the transfer of movable property by way of gift is concerned the same can be effected by a registered instrument or by delivery. Such transfer in the case of immovable property no doubt requires a registered instrument but the provision does not make delivery of possession of the immovable property gifted as an additional requirement for the gift to be valid and effective. If the intention of the legislature was to make delivery of possession of the property gifted also as a condition precedent for a valid gift, the provision could and indeed would have specifically said so. Absence of any such requirement can only lead to the conclusion that delivery of possession is not an essential prerequisite for the making of a valid gift in the case of immovable property.

2004(5) ALL MR 551 (S.C.) Rel. on.

(1997) 2 SCC 255 Disting.      [Para 15]

In this case the execution of registered gift deed and its attestation by two witnesses is not in dispute. It has also been concurrently held by all the three courts below that the donee had accepted the gift. The recitals in the gift deed also prove transfer of absolute title in the gifted property from the donor to the donee. What is retained is only the right to use the property during the lifetime of the donor which does not in any way affect the transfer of ownership in favour of the donee by the donor.      [Para 19]

heading: What constitutes
HeadNote.description: Bar on tenant to put up "Permanent structure" - What constitutes - No hard and fast rule can be laid down - Structure that lasts till end of tenancy can be treated as permanent structure - Tenant replacing tin roof by concrete slab and construction of brick-built passage for reaching the roof - Held, it was a permanent structure.

heading: Registration Act (1908), Ss.17, 49
HeadNote.description:
Registration Act (1908), Ss.17, 49 - Power of Attorney Act (1882) S 1A, 2 - Succession Act (1925), Ss.69, 70 - General Power of Attorney sales (GPA), Sale Agreement (SA) will Transfers - GPA/SA/ wills transfers are not legally valid modes of transfer - They do not convey any title nor create any interest in immovable property.

A SA/GPA/Will transaction does not convey any title nor create any interest in an immovable property. The observations by the Delhi High Court, in Asha M. Jain v. Canara Bank - 94 (2001) DLT 841, that the "concept of power of attorney sales have been recognized as a mode of transaction" when dealing with transactions by way of SA/GPA/WILL are unwarranted and not justified, unintendedly misleading the general public into thinking that SA/GPA/WILL transactions are some kind of a recognized or accepted mode of transfer and that it can be a valid substitute for a sale deed. Such decisions to the extent they recognize or accept SA/GPA/WILL transactions as concluded transfers, as contrasted from an agreement to transfer, are not good law.

We therefore reiterate that immovable property can be legally and lawfully transferred/conveyed only by a registered deed of conveyance. Transactions of the nature of 'GPA sales' or 'SA/GPA/WILL transfers' do not convey title and do not amount to transfer, nor can they be recognized as valid mode of transfer of immoveable property. The courts will not treat such transactions as completed or concluded transfers or as conveyances as they neither convey title nor create any interest in an immovable property. They cannot be recognized as deeds of title, except to the limited extent of section 53A of the TP Act. Such transactions cannot be relied upon or made the basis for mutations in Municipal or Revenue Records. What is stated above will apply not only to deeds of conveyance in regard to freehold property but also to transfer of leasehold property. A lease can be validly transferred only under a registered Assignment of Lease. It is time that an end is put to the pernicious practice of SA/GPA/WILL transactions known as GPA sales.

94 (2001) DLT 841 Held not good law.  [Para 15,16]

SA/GPA/Will transactions can continue to be treated as existing agreement of sale. Nothing prevents affected parties from getting registered Deeds of Conveyance to complete their title. The said 'SA/GPA/WILL transactions' may also be used to obtain specific performance or to defend possession under section 53A of TP Act. If they are entered before this day, they may be relied upon to apply for regularization of allotments/leases by Development Authorities. If the documents relating to 'SA/GPA/WILL transactions' has been accepted acted upon by DDA or other developmental authorities or by the Municipal or revenue authorities to effect mutation, they need not be disturbed, merely on account of this decision.   [Para 18]

The observations regarding SA/GPA/Will transactions are not intended to apply to bona fide/genuine transactions.   [Para 19]

heading: Judgement
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale - Judgement - debtor's property sold in execution of decree subject to an option to pay decretal amount and get back possession - Judgment-debtor selling property to a third party and simultaneously the third party executing another agreement in favour of judgement debtor that property will be resold back to judgement debtor after 10 years - Both deeds registered on the same day - Held transaction was one in the nature of a mortgage by conditional sale. (Para 12)

heading: Perpetual lease
HeadNote.description: Perpetual lease - Recovery of unearned increase (UEI) from lessee in event of "transfer" of plot - Consequent upon demerger of companies, Company Judge directed original lessee to transfer suit plot to newly established company/respondent no.2 - Thus, demerger order resulted into "transfer" - Appellant/Authorities have power to recover 50% UEI as stipulated in lease deed - Irrespective of fact that original lessee still retains control over respondent no.2 or that Directors in both companies are common and even if suit plot was transferred without any consideration - As per relevant office instructions, UEI is computed on difference between premium paid and market value of commercial plot - Consideration/value paid by transferee, has no relevance - Exemption from UEI available in event of conversion of partnership into private limited company - Respondent's case does not fit in exemption clause - Order for recovery of UEI, justified. 	(Paras 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17)

heading: Usufructuary mortgage
HeadNote.description:
Usufructuary mortgage - Right to redeem and recover possession - Commences when mortgage money is paid out of rents and profits or partly out of rents and profit and partly by payment or deposit by mortgagor - Until then limitation does not start - Mortgagee is not entitled to file suit merely on expiry of 30 years from date of mortgage.

In a usufructuary mortgage, right to recover possession continues till the money is paid from the rents and profits or where it is partly paid out of rents and profits when the balance is paid by the mortgagor or deposited in Court as provided under Section 62 of the T.P. Act.

Article 61 refers to right to redeem or recover possession. While right of mortgagor to redeem is dealt with under Section 60 of the T.P. Act, the right of usufructuary mortgagor to recover possession is specially dealt with under Section 62. Section 62 is applicable only to usufructuary mortgages and not to any other mortgage. The said right of usufructuary mortgagor though styled as 'right to recover possession' is for all purposes, right to redeem and to recover possession. Thus, while in case of any other mortgage, right to redeem is covered under Section 60, in case of usufructuary mortgage, right to recover possession is dealt with under Section 62 and commences on payment of mortgage money out of the usufructs or partly out of the usufructs and partly on payment or deposit by the mortgagor. This distinction in a usufructuary mortgage and any other mortgage is clearly borne out from provisions of Sections 58, 60 and 62 of the T.P. Act read with Article 61 of the Schedule to the Limitation Act. Usufructuary mortgage cannot be treated at par with any other mortgage, as doing so will defeat the scheme of Section 62 of the T.P. Act and the equity. This right of the usufructuary mortgagor is not only an equitable right, it has statutory recognition under Section 62 of the T.P. Act. There is no principle of law on which this right can be defeated. Any contrary view, which does not take into account the special right of usufructuary mortgagor under Section 62 of the T.P. Act, has to be held to be erroneous on this ground or has to be limited to a mortgage other than a usufructuary mortgage.

1985 (4) SCC 162 Disting.

2006(3) ALL MR 175 (S.C.), AIR 2012 (HP) 1 (FB) Overruled. [Para 10,12,15,16]

heading: Gift
Revocation/cancellation
HeadNote.description: Gift - Revocation/cancellation - 'R' trustee of Bhandaram executed deed of gift of property in favour of Bhandaram - 'R' or any other trustees of Bhandaram not shown to have repudiated gift - Shows that deed of gift was duly accepted by Bhandaram - Gift deed not providing for revision of suit property to donor in case of failure to pay maintenance to donor in terms of deed of gift - Therefore, 'R' was not competent to execute the deed of cancellation or the deed of transfer, as he had ceased to be owner of suit property - Since donor had no authority to revoke gift, subsequent documents were in themselves without authority and null and void. 	(Paras 25, 26, 27, 28, 31, 33)

heading: Agreement of sale
Effect
HeadNote.description: Agreement of sale - Absence of signature of purchaser - Effect - Agreement signed by seller revealing that he agreed to sell property to plaintiff-purchaser for due consideration - Followed by receipt of payment of earnest money, signed both by purchaser and seller - Agreement and receipt both were part of same transaction - Thus, plea that absence of signature of plaintiff purchaser on agreement, nullifies agreement altogether, not tenable.	(Para 12)

heading: Termination of lease
Notice -Validity
HeadNote.description: Termination of lease - Notice -Validity - Property under lease included a piece of land with structure thereon - Termination notice, however, mentioned only about piece of land - Held, notice would be valid even though no reference to structure was made therein - Naturally, lessee cannot continue possession of structure without the land beneath. AIR 1985 SC 136 Disting.		(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Document whether settlement of Will
HeadNote.description:
Document whether settlement of Will - Form or nomenclature is not conclusive - Document to be considered as a whole to ascertain the substance thereof.			(Paras 21, 24)

While interpreting an instrument to find out whether it is of a testamentary character, which will take effect after the life time of the executant or it is an instrument creating a vested interest in praesenti in favour of a person, the Court has to very carefully examine the document as a whole, look into the substance thereof, the treatment of the subject by the settlor/executant, the intention appearing both by the expressed language employed in the instrument and by necessary implication and the prohibition, if any, contained against revocation thereof. It has also been held that form or nomenclature of the instrument is not conclusive and the Court is required to look into the substance thereof.  1957 SCR 77, (1996)5 SCC 201, (2005)11 SCC 234 - Rel.on.						   [Para 13]

heading: Settlement of Will
HeadNote.description: Settlement of Will - Deed creating unequivocal right in favour of sixteen persons in praesenti - Title of document itself describing it as Settlement Deed - Settlor declaring that beneficiaries who were his relatives were to enjoy property along with him during his lifetime and after his death to get specified share - He was not to have any right to cancel settlement deed or to alter its terms - Mere fact that two beneficiaries and their heirs were to receive temple honours or that shares were to be divided after disposal of property cannot lead to interference that document was a "Will".	(Paras 21, 24)

heading: Mortgage by conditional sale
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale - Transaction of sale followed by agreement for retransfer of property - Not a transaction by way of mortgage by conditional sale - Condition of reconveyance is required to be embodied in document that purports to effect sale - Proviso to S.58(c) admits of no exception. AIR 1963 SC 1182 - Foll.			(Paras 12, 13, 14)

heading: English mortgage
HeadNote.description:
English mortgage - Essential conditions to be satisfied.

A plain reading of the above would show that for a transaction to constitute an English mortgage the following essential conditions must be satisfied:

(1)	The Mortgagor must bind himself to re-pay the mortgage money on a certain date.

(2)	The property mortgaged should be transferred absolutely to the Mortgagee.

(3)	Such absolute transfer should be made subject to proviso that the Mortgagee shall re-convey the property to the Mortgagor upon payment by him of the mortgage money on the date the Mortgagor binds himself to pay the same.   [Para 16]

heading: English mortgage
HeadNote.description: English mortgage - Sale deed not stipulating that seller shall pay mortgage money on certain date - Agreement for reconveyance effected on the same day as sale document was signed only by purchaser and not by seller - Seller thus cannot be said to have bound himself to repay money on certain date - Transaction cannot be said to be in the nature of English mortgage and suit in essence a suit for redemption of a mortgage.	(Para 17)

heading: Duration of lease
HeadNote.description: Duration of lease - Except lease of immovable property for agricultural or manufacturing purpose, lease for any other purpose would be deemed to be monthly lease. (Para 10)

heading: Lease how made
HeadNote.description: Lease how made - Creation of yearly tenancy has to be by registered  instrument - In absence of registered lease it would be a monthly tenancy. (Para 10)

heading: Monthly tenancy
Termination of
HeadNote.description: Monthly tenancy - Termination of - 15 days clear notice is necessary.  (Para 11)

heading: Lis Pendens
HeadNote.description:
Lis Pendens - Sale of suit land - Sale-deed executed by respondent / husband in breach of injunction order, held, cannot bind the appellant. 

AIR 1977 Bom 228 - Ref. to. (Paras 7, 11)

heading: Restraint on alienation
HeadNote.description:
Restraint on alienation - Gift deed executed in favour of minor grandson - Condition attached that donee or his younger brothers who may be born afterwards, would have no right to alienate said property - Condition hit by S.10 - Void.

AIR 1939 Allahabad 221, 2016(116) ALR 794 Ref. to. (Paras 14, 15, 16, 17)

HeadNote.description:
Applicability of S.13 - Gift deed executed in favour of 5 yrs. old grandson with condition that donee or his younger brothers (who may be born afterwards), would have no right of alienation - Gift was not in favour of any unborn person - Reference to unborn persons made only while attaching condition - Putting a condition is different from execution in favour of unborn person - S.13 would not apply.

(2004) 2 SCC 504 Ref. to. (Para 21)

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with condition of repurchase - Determination - Intention of parties is to be gathered for deciding character of document - Recitals of document clearly indicates intention of parties that it was mortgage by conditional sale - Documents is mortgage by conditional sale. heading: Suit for declaration and for share in suit property
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration and for share in suit property - Plaintiff claiming share in property of her mother - Mother was full owner of suit property - Plaintiff on basis of inheritance and succession claiming share in suit property - Defendant-brother of plaintiff claiming that suit property was sold by mother to him - Plaintiff claiming that period during which suit property was sold to his brother, mother had no title over it as she had already sold it to third party with right to repurchase it - Record showing that mother had not sold suit property but it was only mortgage by conditional sale - Mother also get suit property back by redemption of mortgage - Sale of property by mother to her son-defendant during period of mortgage, valid - Mother cannot be said to have no title at time of execution of sale in favour of her son - Plaintiff cannot claim share in suit property - Suit liable to be dismissed. 			(Paras 10, 11, 14, 15, 16)

heading: Gift of some amount in cash
HeadNote.description: Gift of some amount in cash - Does not require registration - Statutory requirements under Ss.122, 123 are not attracted.	(Para 24)

heading: Lis pendens
Applicability
HeadNote.description: Lis pendens - Applicability - Transfer before institution of suit - Defendant entering into contract with vendor subsequent to plaintiff without notice of previous contract between such vendor and plaintiff - S.19(b) of Specific Relief Act would become applicable - Transferee pendente lite steps in shoes of his vendor defendant and as such defences as are available to his vendor could be raised by him - He cannot point out any defences special or personal to him - He has to stand or fall with pleas open to original defendant with whom plaintiff has a contract which such plaintiff is seeking to specifically enforce.	(Para 25)

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description: Sale or mortgage by conditional sale - Determination - Document on record showing that property was agreed to be sold absolutely for consideration of Rs.35,000/- - Language employed in document is plain and unambiguous - Clause of sale deed also shows that intention of parties is to make transaction of sale - Transaction between parties is of sale. 	(Para 13)

heading: Sale
"Kararnama" not registered
HeadNote.description:
Bombay Stamp Act (1958), S.34 - Sale - "Kararnama" not registered - Same cannot be admitted in evidence even for collateral purpose as per S.49 of Registration Act.

Sale is defined under Section 54 of Transfer of Property Act, 1882 which contemplates that "sale" is a transfer of ownership in exchange for a price paid or promised or part-paid and part-promised. Sale how made - such transfer, in the case of tangible immoveable property of the value of one hundred rupees and upwards, or in the case of a reversion or other intangible thing, can be made only by a registered instrument.  In the case of tangible immoveable property of a value less than one hundred rupees, such transfer may be made either by a registered instrument or by delivery of the property.  Delivery of tangible immoveable property takes place when the seller places the buyer, or such person as he directs, in possession of the property.  Contract for sale - A contract for the sale of immoveable property is contract that a sale of such property shall take place on terms settled between the parties.  It does not, of itself, create any interest in or charge on such property. It is thus obvious that sale can be made only by a registered instrument.  The Article A Kararnama was not registered and, therefore,the same cannot be admitted in evidence even for collateral purpose, as per Section 49 of the Registration Act. Therefore, the appellant Court has obviously committed an apparent error of law by observing that this document can be admitted in evidence for collateral purposes.		 [Para 14,15]

heading: Dues of public nature
HeadNote.description: Dues of public nature - Mortgagee would not have any priority over dues of public nature - Mortgaged properties when brought to sale by public authorities for realizing debts of public nature, mortgagee has a right to claim residue of sale proceeds - Such a question, however, has to be decided before appropriate legal forum - Writ petition, not a proper remedy. Constitution of India, Art.226. (Para 15)

heading: Determination of lease
Validity
HeadNote.description: Determination of lease - Validity - Tenant who was Director of company alleging that on surrender of lease by company he entered into a fresh lease in his personal capacity - Held surrender by Company and acceptance thereof by landlord cannot be assumed.	(Para 9)

heading: Lease
Renewal
Documentation
HeadNote.description:
Lease - Renewal - Documentation - Renewal of lease requires execution of a document - There is no concept of automatic renewal of lease by mere exercise of option by lessee.

In order to give effect to the renewal of a lease, a document has to be executed evidencing the renewal of the agreement or lease, as the case may be, and there is no concept of automatic renewal of lease by mere exercise of option by the lessee. The law is well settled that the renewal of an agreement or lease requires execution of a document in accordance with law evidencing the renewal. The grant of renewal is also a fresh grant.   [Para 25]

heading: Suit for redemption of mortgaged property
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgaged property - Filed before expiry of term of mortgage - Suit dismissed as premature - High Court in appeal remitting suit on plaintiff undertaking not to seek delivery of possession before stipulated time - Proceedings continuing in trial court - Held since remand order by High Court itself was erroneous all further proceedings would be non est and liable to be set aside. AIR 1958 SC 770 Rel. on.			(Paras 15, 17)

heading: Suit for eviction
Notice
Agricultural tenancy
Ref.to.	 [Para 14]
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction - Notice - Agricultural tenancy - Service of notice under S.106 is not the strict requirement of the law in regard to agricultural tenancies, unless there is a special notification issued by the Government in this behalf.

In the present case, one cannot be oblivious of the fact that D. W. Vasant was then karta of the joint family. He represented the family. The service of notice U/s.106 of the T.P. Act on him must be regarded as legal and proper. He being representative of the entire joint Hindu family, inclusion of other heirs of the deceased tenant was not necessary. For, the decree would be binding on all the joint tenants. The service of notice U/s.106 of the T.P.Act is not the strict requirement of the law in regard to the agricultural tenancies, unless there is a special notification issued by the Government in this behalf. The provisions of Sections 105 to 116 of the T.P.Act contained in Chapter V are required to be harmoniously construed. The provisions of Section 117 of the T.P. Act would make it clear that Section 106 of the T.P. Act does not apply to leases for agricultural purpose. Still, however, the provisions of Section 106 would be applicable to the reasonable extent. The provisions contained in Chapter V of the T.P. Act are founded upon reason and equity and hence, are applicable to agricultural leases though not in strictosensu. Considering the letters and spirit of all these provisions, service of the notice of termination on the defendant No.1 is valid service for the purpose of determining the tenancy rights of not only himself but of all the other legal heirs left by the deceased tenant. AIR 1964 Bom. 96 and AIR 1963 SC 468 - Ref.to.	 [Para 14]

heading: Tenant inducted by land lady
HeadNote.description: Tenant inducted by land lady - Tenant cannot claim title to property by adverse possession - Tenant claiming title to property - It can be held that he is not ready and willing to pay rent - Landlady is entitled to get possession of suit premises. (Para 53)

heading: Tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Tenancy - Tenancy for a mixed purpose and tenancy for dual purpose - Distinction between.

Broadly speaking the premises are let out either for the purpose of residence or for a non-residential or commercial purpose. A legislation may classify the purpose of letting into several categories by adopting some other criterion just as the Bombay Act does (See, sub-section (1) of Section 6). In case of tenancy of type (a), for a composite or mixed purpose, the premises are let out for defined purposes, more than one, leaving the option open to the tenant to use the entire tenancy premises as one unit for either or both purposes. The tenancy premises are not divided or demarcated separately into two so as to specify which part of the tenancy premises will be used for what purpose. In other words, in case of tenancy for composite purpose, the two diverse purposes for user of the premises are so blended or mixed up that they cannot be separated by dissecting the tenancy premises into compartments. But, in case of tenancy of type (b), which is a single tenancy for dual purposes, .the contract of tenancy is no doubt an integrated one but the premises are demarcated or divided by reference to the purpose for which they will be separately used. The cases at hand are illustrations of the latter type, type (b), of an integrated contract of tenancy for dual purposes, where different portions are earmarked for different types of user. The contract of tenancy is one but it clearly sets out that out of the two rooms let out under one tenancy agreement, the tenant shall use the room in the front for non-residential purpose and the room in the backside for the purpose of residence. The entire tenancy premises cannot be used interchanging the users nor can the entire premises be subjected to simultaneous user as residence and commence - both, without defining which part of the premises shall be used for what purpose. Therefore, the purpose of letting, in the case at hand, falls under type (b) and is not composite or mixed. The legal implication is that in case of tenancy for composite or mixed purpose i.e. type (a) the need may arise for determining the dominant purpose of letting. However, the theory of dominant purpose or principle of predominant purpose of letting is irrelevant in the case of tenancies of type (b) when it is known, as previously agreed, that a particular portion of the premises shall be used for one purpose while another portion shall be used for another purpose.  [Para 6]

HeadNote.description:
Notice to quit Validity - Leased premises consisting of both land and buildings- Notice need not separately and specifically describe land and buildings.

1995(2) Mh.L.J. 449 - Rel on. (Para 6,8)

Applicability

(Paras 21, 22)

Entitlement to

HeadNote.sub_clause: S.52 as amended by 1939 and 1959 Acts
heading: His pendens
HeadNote.description:
His pendens - S. 52 as  amended  is not applicable to area purchase of land during pendency of tenancy proceed up - Principle of his pendens under S. 52 applies -

The amended provisions of S. 52 of T.P.Act are not in force in state of Bombay near Maharashtra  S. 52 as amended by Acts of 1939 and 1959 is Act of 1939 and 1959 is not applicable unless and until the notification is issued by the Government as provided in  proviso to  Sec.2 of Act of 1939 and as there is no notification issued, when the transaction in question has taken place in 1969, the question of his pendens' will have to be considered as per the provisions of the Central Act and not as per the provisions of the Bombay Amended Act of Transfer of Property Act.  Under the Central Act, it is not necessary to register the his pendens under section 18 of the Registration Act or under any other Act and, therefore, the purchase of the suit land by the purchasers, while the tenancy proceedings were pending, are affected by the principle of his pendens'.

No doubt, the conveyance will not be void, illegal, but the said conveyance  cannot affect the rights of the decree holder and, therefore,6 the said section provides  a bar that the parties to the said suit or proceedings cannot transfer the property involved in the said pending suit or proceedings, so as to affect the rights of any party thereto under a decree or order which is likely to be passed and, therefore, that transfer will not affect the rights of the party in whose favor the order or decree is passed  [Para 13]

heading: Total destruction of leased property by fire
HeadNote.description:
Total destruction of leased property by fire - Lessee's rights in leased property - Lease does not come to an end unless lessee exercises such an option.

The right of the lessee in the leased property subsists even if the leased property has been destroyed by fire, tempest or flood or violence of any army or of a mob or other irresistible force unless the lessee exercises his option that on happening of such events the lease has been rendered void. By necessary collollary, therefore, if the leased property is destroyed wholly by fire, the lease cannot be said to be extinguished, nor can it be said that lessee's right in the leased property has come to an end unless the lessee exercises such option. The express provision in clause (e) of Sec.108 leaves no manner of doubt that on destruction of leased property by fire, the lease cannot be said to be extinguished automatically and in this view of the matter the statement of law made in Article-592 of American Jurisprudence and para -2066 of Woodfall on landlord and tenant cannot be applicable in our country. The view of the Kerala High Court in Dr. V.Siddharthan's case is also not acceptable because of not proper construction given to Section-108(e) of the T.P.Act.

AIR 1973 Bom  358  foll. AIR 1984 Kerala 181 Dissented from.  [Para 16]

heading: Monthly tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Lease of premises for 11 months - Monthly tenancy - Tenancy month to commence from first day and end on last day of another - Tenant after expiry of period of tenancy holding over - Case is covered under S.106 and not S.110.

In the instant case, the period of tenancy was for 11 months and the tenancy was monthly tenancy as per the rent note and the tenancy month by agreement was to commence from the first day of every English calendar month and end on the last day of the same month and, therefore, it is obvious that after the expiry of the said period of tenancy, the defendant remained in possession as a tenant holding over on the same terms of tenancy. In view of this, the provisions of Section 110 of TP Act are not applicable to the facts of the case and the tenancy of the defendant being monthly tenancy according to the English calender month, the notice to quit terminating his tenancy since from midnight of 31-5-1988, i.e. ending with the last date of the month of tenancy was quite valid and legal. [Para 11,17]

heading: Protection of possession
HeadNote.description: Protection of possession - Two documents, one agreement to sell and another possession receipt - No explanation as to why two documents executed - Agreement to sell was not on sufficiently stamped paper and possession receipt not duly registered with appropriate authority - Defendant failed to show his readiness and willingness to perform his part of contract - Thus, defendant, held not entitled to invoke S.53A for benefit of protection of his possession in absence of compulsory registration of documents. (Paras 15, 16, 18)

heading: Specific Relief Act (1963), S.27A
Mortgage by conditional sale
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage by conditional sale - Different from outright sale in payment of debt - In mortgage by conditional sale, right of ownership is transferred subject to condition that on default of payment, sale shall become absolute - In any form of mortgage, transfer is of "some" interest and not of "whole" interest of mortgagor - Mortgagor does not cease to be owner - Equity of redemption still vests in him which gets lost only upon a final decree of foreclosure or sale in favour of mortgagee - Till such final decree, mortgagor retains his right of redemption.

	It is important to remember that mortgage is a transfer of interest in specific immovable property towards "security for repayment of a debt". The interest itself may be different in different forms of mortgage. In a simple mortgage, what is transferred is a power of sale, whilst in a usufructuary mortgage it is the right of the mortgagor to the enjoyment of the usufruct. In a mortgage by conditional sale or an English mortgage what is transferred is the right of ownership subject to a condition that on default of payment on a certain date the sale shall become absolute, or that on such payment being made the sale shall become void, or that on such payment being made the buyer shall transfer the property to the seller. Whatever be the form of mortgage, the transfer is of "some" interest only and not of the "whole" interest of the mortgagor. Unlike in the case of a sale in payment of a debt which extinguishes the debt, the debt always subsists in a mortgage. When a mortgagor mortgages his immovable property, he does not cease to be its owner; the equity of redemption still vests in him. This equity is lost unto him only when there is a final decree of foreclosure or sale in favour of mortgagee. This has always been our law and a mortgage by conditional sale is no exception to it.	 [Para 6]

	The statutory provisions, which are reflected in Sections 58, 60 and 67 of the Transfer of Property Act and Order XXXIV of the Code of Civil Procedure make this position clear. 

	Clause (a) of Section 58 of the Transfer of Property Act defines a mortgage as "transfer of an interest in specific immovable property for the purpose of securing the payment of money advanced or to be advanced by way of loan, an existing or future debt, or the performance of an engagement which may give rise to a pecuniary liability." Clause (c), deals with mortgage by conditional sale. It provides that where the mortgagor ostensibly sells the mortgaged property on a condition that on default of payment of the mortgage money on a certain date the sale shall become absolute, or on a condition that on such payment being made the sale shall become void, or on a condition that on such payment being made the buyer shall transfer the property to the seller, the transaction is called mortgage by conditional sale.

	Section 60 of the Transfer of Property Act provides for the mortgagor's right to redeem. At any time after the principal money has become due, the mortgagor has a right, on payment or tender of the mortgage money, at a proper time and place, to require the mortgagee to deliver to the mortgagor the mortgage deed and all documents relating to the mortgaged property which are in possession or power of the mortgagee and at the cost of the mortgagor either to retransfer the mortgaged property to him or to his nominee and to have registered an acknowledgement in writing that any right in derogation of his interest transferred to the mortgagee has been extinguished. Section 67 deals with the mortgagee's right to foreclosure or sale. In the absence of a contract to the contrary, the mortgagee has, at any time, after the mortgage money has become due to him and "before a decree has been made for the redemption of the mortgaged property" or before the mortgage money has been paid or deposited as provided in Section 67, a right to obtain from the court a decree that the mortgagor shall be absolutely debarred of his right to redeem the property or a decree that the property be sold. It is pertinent to note that the right to seek foreclosure is not available to any mortgagee other than a mortgagee by conditional sale or a mortgage under an anomalous mortgage by the terms of which he is entitled to foreclose. So also, the right to seek sale is not available to a usufructuary mortgagee or a mortgagee by conditional sale. What the scheme of this Section indicates is that the only remedy of a mortgagee by conditional sale is to apply for foreclosure and not for a decree of sale. Order XXXIV Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure proceeds for a preliminary decree in a foreclosure suit. By this preliminary decree, the Court orders an account to be taken of what is due to the plaintiff on the date of such decree towards principal, interest, costs, etc. and declares the amounts so due at that date and directs that if the defendant pays into court the amounts so declared as due on or before such date as the court may fix within six months of the court confirming and countersigning the account, the plaintiff shall deliver up to the defendant, or to such person as the defendant may appoint, all documents relating to the mortgage of the property and retransfer, if so required, the property to the defendant at his cost free from the mortgage (subrule (1) of Rule 2). Rule 3 of Order XXXIV provides for a final decree in a foreclosure suit. The rule provides that if, before a final decree debarring the defendant from all the right to redeem the mortgage has been passed, the defendant makes payment into the court of all amounts due to him under subrule (1) of Rule 2, the court shall, on application made by the defendant, pass a final decree ordering the plaintiff to deliver up the documents referred to the preliminary decree and, if necessary, to retransfer the mortgaged property as directed in the decree. Only if such payment is not made by the defendant that the court shall, on the application of the plaintiff, pass a final decree declaring that the defendant and all persons claiming through or under him are debarred from all right to redeem the mortgaged property. This scheme makes it clear that at all events, and in case of all mortgages, where a foreclosure decree can be passed, the mortgagor retains his right of redemption until a final decree of foreclosure is passed. 	 [Para 7]

heading: Mortgage by conditional sale
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale - Non-payment of mortgage money - Only remedy available to mortgagee is to apply for foreclosure and not for sale. 			(Para 7)

heading: Payment of interest
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale - Payment of interest - Payment of interest upto the date of suit is a matter of contract - Whereas interest pendente lite is a matter of law u/S.34 of CPC. 			(Para 9)

heading: Lease or license
Unregistered agreement
HeadNote.description: Lease or license - Unregistered agreement - East India Hotels Company taking a loan from syndicate Bank and entering into agreement stipulating twelve years duration to coinside with repayment facility under which license fee was adjusted against loan amount - Discretion to grant renewal or refuse the same reserved - Land on which building was raised taken on lease from government which did not allow sub-letting - Defendant agreeing not to change the lock of the main door without consent of plaintiff - Clause in the agreement providing that agreement did not create any interest or other right in favour of licensee in licensed promises or any part thereof - Right of inspection, repairs to lift and air conditioners reserved - Held the agreement was one of lease and license and not lease. (Para 25)

heading: Who is
Plaintiff expired
HeadNote.description:
'Member of undivided family' - Who is - Suit U/S.44 r/w S.4 challenging transfer of dwelling house of undivided family to outsiders - Plaintiff expired - Real brother of deceased unmarried plaintiff staying with her claiming as legatee under will - Held, Prima facie such legatee a member of undivided family of deceased - Entitled to prosecute suit.

AIR 1954, S.C. 52 Relied on.	(Para 10)

heading: Deed
Construction
HeadNote.description: Deed - Construction - Provision of operative part of deed of Conveyance, very clear - Therefore, no reliance could be placed on recitals either in agreement for sale or in Deed of Conveyance. 			(Para 59)

heading: Bonafide purchaser for valuable consideration
HeadNote.description: Bonafide purchaser for valuable consideration - Recitals of subsequent agreement mentioned about fact of existence and execution of prior agreement for sale and that it was nominal and  never intended to be executed - Subsequent purchaser did not enquire with prior purchaser about real nature of prior transaction - Subsequent purchase not bonafide or in good faith. (Para 8)

heading: Gift deed
Validity
HeadNote.description: Gift deed - Validity - Appellant claiming that suit property transferred by donor by way of gift was ancestral property - Record showing that suit property was acquired by donor by way of Will therefore, same was self-acquired property - Plea of appellant that gift deed is not valid as consideration of Rs.5,000/- was received for executing same, not tenable - Both gift deed as well as order of mutation indicates valuation of property as Rs.5,000/- only for purpose of stamp duty and for payment of fees for mutation - Mentioning of Rs. 5,000/- in first page of document for purpose of valuation, cannot be said to be consideration received by donor for executing gift deed - Gift deed is valid. 	(Paras 13, 14, 15)

heading: Mortgaged property
Priority in charge
HeadNote.description:
Maharashtra Ordinance No.11 & 1999, S.9 - Civil P.C. (1908), O.40 - Mortgaged property - Priority in charge - Court receiver appointed in civil suit - Sales tax arrears payable by defendant to Govt. - Govt. not a party to the suit - Application by Govt. for permission to lodge claim with Receiver for deciding the issue of priority of charges - Granted 
(1995) 2 SCC 19, (1974) 2 SCC 799 - Rel. on.  (Para 10)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Suit for return of business and premises - Defence that though defendant put in possession under conducting agreement later agreement for sale executed in its favour and thus possession protected U/S.53A - Defence not taken in written statement - Held, defence of part performance a mixed question of fact and law and must be pleaded - Moreover defendant had failed to pay consideration and perform his part of contract - Defendant had contended that contract was sham and bogus - Defence unsustainable.	(Para 19)

heading: Lease or licence
HeadNote.description: Lease or licence - Flat purchased by company - As it could not be a member of co-operative society, its one Director was made nominee in record of society - He was not even benamidar of company - Consideration for purchasing flat fully given by company - Flat shown as company's property in company record - Director permitting his newly married daughter to use flat for temporary period - Her husband (defendant) residing with her - Their relations getting strained - Wife leaving the flat, but husband continuing residing in it - Held plea of defendant husband that flat was given to him on lease by his father-in-law not sustainable - Since flat belonged to company, the father-in-law in his individual capacity had no competency to give it on lease - Defendant husband was liable to be evicted - Mesne profit @ Rs.700/- p.m. awarded.	 		(Paras 18, 19, 20)

heading: Lease
Extension
HeadNote.description: Lease - Extension - Stands on entirely different footing from renewal.	(Para 13)

heading: Lease
Renewal
Government land
HeadNote.description:
Lease - Renewal - Government land - Acceptance of rent by government after expiry of lease period - Does not imply renewal of lease - Would not operate as estoppel or relinquishment in absence of compliance with mandatory provisions of Art.299(1).

Constitution of India, Art.299.	(Para 19)

heading: Certain inherited property gifted by donor to donee, while retaining with herself its possession and management during her lifetime
HeadNote.description:
Certain inherited property gifted by donor to donee, while retaining with herself its possession and management during her lifetime - Held, gift deed not ineffectual on account of donor reserving to herself possession and enjoyment of property gifted.

The donor had very clearly transferred to the donees ownership and title in respect of her 1/8th share in properties.  It was open to the donor to transfer by gift title and ownership in the property and at the same time reserve its possession and enjoyment to herself during her lifetime. There is no prohibition in law that ownership in property cannot be gifted without its possession and right of enjoyment. Under  Section 6 of the Transfer of Property Act "property of any kind may be transferred" except those mentioned in clauses (a) to (i). Clause (d) of Section 6 is not attracted on the terms of the gift deed  herein because it was not a property, the enjoyment of which was restricted to the owner personally. She was absolute owner  of the property gifted and it was not restricted in its enjoyment to herself. She had inherited it from her maternal father as a full owner. The High Court was, therefore, apparently wrong in coming to the conclusion that the gift deed was ineffectual merely because the donor had reserved to herself the possession and enjoyment of the property gifted.   [Para 11,12]

heading: Lease
HeadNote.description: Lease - Defendant taking suit property on lease claiming that said tenancy was a yearly tenancy - Sale deed clearly mentioning that said tenancy was monthly mentioning rate per month - Oral agreement between parties to pay yearly rent even in case of monthly tenancy would not mean it was a yearly tenancy - Moreover, lease of immovable property from year to year is required to be registered as per S.107 - Tenancy held a monthly tenancy - Moreso, as defendant in his written statement admitted that rent was to be paid in advance regularly in beginning of each month.	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Termination of tenancy
Notice of
HeadNote.description: Termination of tenancy - Notice of - Defendant carrying on tailoring business in suit premises - He was not engaged in any manufacturing activity but was stitching clothes of customers on premises taken on lease - Tailoring being essentially used for doing job work of stitching in accordance with order of customers cannot be said to be a manufacturing activity - Considering facts and circumstances notice of six months for termination of tenancy/lease held not necessary. (1989)3 SCC 488 - Distinguished.		(Para 13)

heading: Fraudulent transfer
Proof
HeadNote.description:
Fraudulent transfer - Proof - Person who challenges validity of transaction must prove two facts (i) that the document was executed by the settlor, and (ii) that the said document was executed with clear intention to defraud or delay the creditor - How the intention is to be proved is a matter which would largely depend on facts and circumstances of each case.

Under section 53 of the T.P.Act a person who challenges the validity of the transaction must prove two facts - (1) that the document was executed by the settlor; and (2) that the said document was executed with clear intention to defraud or delay the creditor.  How the intention is to be proved is a matter which would largely depend on the facts and circumstances of each case.  One has to take into account that the document in question is on the stamp paper purchased in the name of one Unique Land Developer; who is not party to the document, who has nothing to do with the transaction in question.  Had it been the genuine transaction, the stamp paper would have been purchased in the name of either of the parties.  The very fact that the old stamp paper lying with somebody, other than the persons involved in the transaction, has been used is one of the strong indicators to suggest that possibility of the document being ante-dated cannot be ruled out.

The mode, manner and tenor of the document including the contents thereof; strongly suggest that the draftsman of the document is not other than of a legal brain.  It cannot be assumed that the draftsman of the agreement had no knowledge about the drafting of such document and requirement of registration thereof but he must have been handicapped because of the necessity to create document in a previous date so as to show that the transaction has been done much prior to the date of attachment before judgment.  The document in question contains factually incorrect recitals with respect to non-borrowing of loan and non-creation of any charge on the suit property even though these facts were well within the knowledge of the licensor, the defendant No.3, the original owner of the flat, obviously, to show the transaction as genuine and prior to the date of attachment order.  Apart from this, the document contains recital showing payment of Rs.1,20,000/= in cash.  There is no material available on record from which account the cash was withdrawn by the plaintiff and how such payment of huge amount was made in cash.  There is also no material on record to show that how such cash was really received by defendant No.3 and that he invested the same in some security or used for making certain payments.  All these facts and circumstances, if seen in its proper perspective, it would be clear that the document in question is nothing but a fraudulent document brought in existence to defeat the claim of the creditor/ defendant No.2 bank.	 [Para 19,20]

heading: Restriction on
S.10 is inapplicable
HeadNote.description: Rights of an owner - Restriction on - When owner's right of enjoyment is restricted to himself - Transfer by him prohibited - When a party accepts property with knowledge of restriction on transfer for limited period - S.10 is inapplicable - Restriction on transfer for limited period is valid.

heading: Agreement not terminated
HeadNote.description:
Lease for fixed period - Stipulation in agreement that on expiry of lease period, tenant shall pay damages for "use and occupation" at fixed rate per day - Protection under Rent Laws available to tenant - Agreement not terminated - Tenant's possession after expiry of lease is lawful - Suit for damages in civil court not tenable. C.P. and Berar Rent Control Order (1949), Cl.12.

In instant case, agreement of lease was entered into between landlord and tenant for a term of 5 years on the stipulated rent of Rs.350/- per month.  The agreement further provided that on expiry of the lease period, the tenant would pay Rs.20/- per day as damages for use and occupation of the premises.  The tenancy was governed by Rent Control laws.  The agreement of lease was not registered.  The tenancy was not terminated.

Held that, in the absence of any valid termination of the tenancy, the suit for damages for use and occupation is not permissible on the basis of lease agreement between the parties in the Civil Court, as special remedy under the special Act i.e Rent Control Act is available for the same. [Para 11]

The landlord cannot enhance the rate unilaterally.  The "use and occupation" of such premises can be claimed after terminating the tenancy by following the due procedure of law.  The claim of "damages" without obtaining and/or terminating the tenancy under rent control order, is impermissible.  Unless the tenancy is duly terminated the possession of the tenant cannot be said to be unauthorised and/or illegal.  Therefore, the suit for use and occupation charges towards such damage, in this background is not within the framework of laws.	 [Para 7,9]

heading: Not registered
HeadNote.description:
Lease agreement for period exceeding one year - Not registered - Can be looked into for collateral purposes of determining relationship of landlord and tenant and agreed rate of rent, in view of settled possession of tenant and regular payment of rent.

The lease agreement for 5 years was not registered.  However, in view of the settled possession and/or permissible possession by the tenant, apart from regular payment of rent towards the use of said premises as a tenant was in itself sufficient to create relationship of landlord and tenant for the purpose of C.P. & Berar Rent Control Order.  The bar of Section 49 and/or Section 17 of the Registration Act did not affect or take away the legal rights created in favour of such occupant/tenant.  The lease agreement even though not registered, still could be looked for the purpose of determination of the relationship of landlord and tenant, and also of agreed rate of rent.  Such lease agreement has evidential value for the purpose of deciding relationship of landlord and tenant, as well as, agreed rent between the parties.				 [Para 7]

heading: Lease deed
Construction
Premises. [Para 6,10,12]
HeadNote.description:
Lease deed - Construction - Words "leased out plot" and "premises" occurring in one clause of lease - They both carry same meaning i.e. open piece of land - Word "Premises" does not mean "piece of land after construction has been made thereon", in the context of use of that word in other clauses of the lease deed in instant case - Lessee was held liable to pay Municipal taxes.

Words and phrases - Premises. [Para 6,10,12]

heading: Suit for possession
Maintainability
Same remained unchallenged
Is proper
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Ground of heirship and right of preemption - Maintainability - Claim of plaintiff as to receipt of property by gift deed from his deceased uncle and of agreement of pre-emption - No proof of either contents or execution thereof - Sale deed as to said property in meanwhile by defendant to third parties - Same remained unchallenged - Alleged document of plaintiff also brought on record belatedly after 8 years - Concurrent findings of lower courts that plaintiff could not claim right of pre-emption or heirship in absence of proof - Is proper - Moreso as suit was barred by limitation.

heading: Hindu Law
HeadNote.description: Hindu Law - Sale of co-parcenary property - Failure of alienee to prove that sale was out of legal necessity or for the benefit of the estate - Moreover, sale deeds were without any consideration whatsoever - Therefore, said sale deeds would be illegal, null and void - Alienee having no valid and legal title to said property, could not have passed on better title to subsequent purchaser of property - Said subsequent sale, held, hit by doctrine of lis pendens. 			(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Termination of tenancy
Waiver of notice
HeadNote.description:
Termination of tenancy - Waiver of notice - Acceptance of rent by landlady after issuance of notice of termination - Acceptance amounts to waiver of notice - Finding of fact as to waiver of notice - Cannot be interfered with by High Court in Second Appeal under S.100 of C.P.C. Civil P.C. (1908), S.100.

In the instant case, the Appellate Court has rightly placed reliance on the illustration (a) given below section 113 of the Transfer of Property Act.  That the illustration makes it clear that if the landlady accepts the rent before hand, the landlady has accepted the rent after issuance of quit notice to the defendants.  In addition to that, the rent was accepted for a period of 4 years since after issuance of the notice.  The suit for recovery of possession was instituted after a period of 6 years since issuance of the notice terminating the tenancy.  These facts themselves establish that the notices issued by the landlady stood waived by acceptance of the rent by the landlady.  That is a finding of fact.  It is very difficult to interfere with the findings in Second Appeal under Section 100 of the C.P.C.  The findings recorded by the Appellate Court is based on evidence on record.  That is a finding of fact.  Therefore, it is very difficult to accept the submission of Mr. Bhandarkar Advocate that the Appellate Court has committed an error in holding that there was waiver on account of the acceptance of rent after issuance of notice of termination.   [Para 17]

heading: Monthly tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Monthly tenancy - Interval at which rent is recovered, i.e. quarterly, half yearly or yearly does not change its nature.

The intervals at which rent is recovered or paid does not render the tenancy as a tenancy for that interval.  The rent may be recovered quarterly, half yearly or yearly, but a tenancy which is a monthly tenancy does not on that count cease to be a monthly tenancy.   [Para 5]

The terms and conditions contained on the reverse of the rent receipts in instant case make it abundantly clear that the tenancy was in fact a monthly tenancy.  The first condition stipulates that the tenant must pay the rent in advance for every month.  The third Condition states that the tenant would have to pay the rent for the entire month even if the premises were vacated during the course of the month.  The fourth Condition states that if the premises are retained beyond the stipulated period, a notice of atleast one month must be furnished.  Thus the tenancy was not yearly but was monthly.   [Para 5,7,8]

heading: Registration Act (1908), S.17(1)(b)
HeadNote.description:
Registration Act (1908), S.17(1)(b) - Decree for specific performance - Does not extinguish contract for sale - Hence, it need not be compulsorily registered.

A decree for specific performance passed on the basis of an agreement to sale or a contract for sale, merely recognizes a claim for specific performance of contract, which is capable of being specifically enforced at the instance of a decree-holder. Even in respect of such a decree, the sale would be complete only upon the execution of the sale-deed in favour of the decree-holder either by the vendor/judgment-debtor or through the process of the Court. It is only upon the registration of such sale-deed upon payment of stamp duty under Item 20 of Schedule I of the Stamp Act, that any right, title and interest in such property shall validly pass on to the decree-holder, who is the purchaser of the suit property. Hence, mere passing a decree for specific performance of contract does not result in the transfer of property.  [Para 27,28]

Thus, the decree for specific performance of contract by itself, does not create right, title or interest in or charge on the immovable property in favour of a decree-holder. Hence, the provision of Section 17(1)(e) of Registration Act is not at all attracted. It cannot be said that a compromise decree is to be compulsorily registrable under the provisions of Section 17(2)(vi) of the Registration Act and by the same analogy a decree for specific performance of contract is also compulsorily registrable. The Executing Court has recorded the finding that H. was one of the plaintiffs and was having pre-existing right in the decree. Assuming this finding to be correct, the exemption under clause (vi) of Section 17(2) of the said Act would apply. Be that as it may, a decree for specific performance of contract, as has already been held, neither extinguishes right, title or interest in the immovable property, nor creates right, title or interest in immovable property and hence it is not compulsorily registrable under clauses (b) and (c) of Section 17(1) of the said Act. AIR 1996 SC 196 - Disting.  AIR 1941 Bombay 71 - Explained & Rel. on.  [Para 31,32,33]

It cannot also be said if the decree does not create any such right, title or interest in an immovable property, then it is the Deed at Exhibit 178, which creates right, title or interest in an immovable property in favour of the assignee and the same is, therefore, covered by Section 17(1)(b). If the decree itself does not create or purport to create any right, title or interest in or charge on the immovable property, then the question of conveying such right, title or interest in or charge on the immovable property by executing the deed of assignment, does not arise. Hence the provision of Section 17(1)(b) of the Registration Act is also not attracted.  [Para 34]

heading: Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with condition of repurchase
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with condition of repurchase - Distinction between. 

In order to consider as to whether the document is a document of mortgage by conditional sale or sale with condition of repurchase, the distinction between two transactions must be borne in mind. In the former there is debtor creditor relationship, transfer is by way of security whereas in the later case, there is condition of reconveyance in the event the amount equivalent to the consideration paid by the vendor to the purchaser. If the condition of repurchase is contained in a separate deed, the original sale deed can never be regarded as mortgage in view of the provisions of S.58(c) of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882.	 [Para 21]

The deed of transfer would be regarded as an out­and out sale and the condition contained in a separate document would only beregarded as separate agreement for reconveyance. In that event, the conditions for reconveyance including condition of time would be required to be strictly complied. In case of Agreement for Sale of immovable property, time is generally not an essence of Contract. However, the Agreement to reconvey is essentially entered by the purchaser with the vendor in the nature of concession, wherein time would ordinarily be regarded as an essence of contract. in that event, the original vendor would be required to strictly comply with the conditions including the condition of time, contained in the agreement of reconveyance.	 [Para 21]

heading: Separate agreement alleged
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with condition of repurchase - No provision in the sale deed to reconvey the property - Separate agreement alleged - Plaintiff not entitled to decree to direct defendant to execute recoveyance. 			(Para 22)

heading: Plea of protection u/s.53-A
HeadNote.description: Plea of protection u/s.53-A - Plea, held, not available during the period when the contractual obligations subsisted.	(Para 20)

heading: Charge
HeadNote.description: Charge - Proceedings under Hindu Adoptions and maintenance Act - Grant of Maintenance to wife - Wife wanting to create charge on property which was purchased and built upon by her father-in-law - No evidence to show that husband had contributed funds for construction of property - Creation of charge cannot be justified. (Paras 15,16)

heading: Doctrine of lis-pendens
HeadNote.description:
Doctrine of lis-pendens - Doctrine is based upon expediency and not upon notice - Therefore, held, a transferee is affected though he may take the transfer without notice of the lis.

The doctrine of lis-pendens embodied U/s.52 of the Transfer of Property Act, is intended to prevent one party to a suit from making an assignment inconsistent with the rights which may be established in the suit which might require a further party to be impleaded in order to make effectual the Court's decree. The doctrine upon which this Section is based is that it would plainly be impossible that any action or suit could be brought to a successful termination if alienation pendente lite were permitted to prevail. The doctrine of lis-pendens is based upon expediency and not upon notice. Therefore, a transferee is affected though he may take the transfer without notice of the lis. Section 52 of the Transfer of Property Act, has over-riding effect. The impact of the doctrine of lis-pendens on the sale transaction is to make it subject to the decree or order to be passed in the suit. The transferee pendente lite is a representative of the transferor and is bound by the decree. Section 52 of the Transfer of Property Act, continues to be attracted even after the decree is passed and till the rights under decree are fully exercised. In view of this principle when a decree for permanent injunction has been obtained by the plaintiff - decree holder, in such circumstances, the decree holder or even his legal representatives can execute such decree against the transferee of the judgment debtor as the said transferee is bound by lis-pendens to obey such a decree because a purchaser from the defendant pendente lite is deemed to be a representative in interest of the defendant and, therefore, a representative within the meaning of the provisions of the C.P.C..  [Para 10]

heading: Mortgage
Suit for redemption
HeadNote.description: Mortgage - Suit for redemption - Suit required to be valued according to principal money expressed to be secured by instrument of mortgage - Suit for possession is required to be valued under S.6(v) at the value of the land as on the date of filing of the suit.	(Para 23)

heading: Eviction
Co-owner's property
HeadNote.description:
Eviction - Co-owner's property - One co-owner can file suit for eviction - Suit by two co-owners jointly filed - One of them cannot withdraw consent midway to the prejudice of other co-owner.

It is well settled that one of the co-owners can file a suit for eviction of a tenant in the property generally owned by the co-owners. This principle is based on the doctrine of agency. One co-owner filing a suit for eviction against the tenant does so on his own behalf in his own right and as an agent of the other co-owners. The consent of other co-owners is assumed as taken unless it is shown that the other co-owners were not agreeable to eject the tenant and the suit was filed in spite of their disagreement. In the present case, the suit was filed by both the co-owners. One of the co-owners cannot withdraw his consent midway the suit so as to prejudice the other co-owner. The suit once filed, the rights of the parties stand crystallised on the date of the suit and the entitlement of the co-owners to seek ejectment must be adjudged by reference to the date of institution of the suit; the only exception being when by virtue of a subsequent event the entitlement of the body of co-owners to eject the tenant comes to an end by act of parties or by operation of law.

heading: Extinguishment of tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Extinguishment of tenancy - By merger of entire interest of landlord into that of tenant - When there is only partial transfer of interest there is no extinguishment of tenancy.

In order to bring the tenancy to an end the merger should be complete, i.e. the interest of the landlord in its entirety must come to vest and merge into the interest of tenant in its entirety. When part of the interest of the landlord or the interest of one out of many co- landlords-cum-co-owners comes to vest in the tenant, there is no merger and the tenancy is not extinguished.   [Para 7]

In this case "A" willingly joined with "B" in filing the suit. During the continuity of litigation "A" parted with her share in the property.  One out of two tenants purchased the share.  The tenancy was in the name of partnership firm and some of the partners have purchased the share of "B". They purchased only a share in the property and not the entire property .  Hence the applicability of doctrine of merger within the meaning of S.111(d) was not attracted.		 [Para 7]

heading: Sale of land
HeadNote.description: Sale of land - Society sold land purchased for scheme - Major portion of amount was contributed by Society and its members for purchase of land - Society is competent to take decision by majority of members to sale land - No interim relief is liable to be granted in suit challenging sale of land.	(Para 5)

heading: Registration of gift deed
HeadNote.description: Registration of gift deed - Dedication of immovable property to idol - Same does not require registration. AIR 1927 Mad. 636 - Rel. on.	(Para 14)

heading: Income Tax authorities
HeadNote.description: Title to immovable property - Income Tax authorities - Such authorities cannot decide or declare title of any immovable property - They have limited scope and jurisdiction under respective revenue laws.	(Para 20)

heading: Gift
Mohammedan law
Oral gift
Is permissible-in-law
HeadNote.description:
Gift - Mohammedan law - Oral gift - Is permissible-in-law - If oral gift is permissible, then, merely because it was recorded afterwords in writing that itself cannot take away the vigour of oral gift specially when all ingredients of valid oral gift are proved.

As the oral gift is permissible and by documents the said oral gifts have been reflected in writing and the parties in whose favour the said gift has been made and as they are living/residing in the said property, itself, no physical departure or formal entry is necessary. Such arrangement is, therefore, valid under the Mohamedan Law. Once oral Hiba (gift) is permissible and as declaration was given by the owner of the property, defendant no.1 and as the same has been accepted by the donee, this amounts to a valid oral gift and in absence of any specific bar under the Mohamedan Law. All essentials of the oral gifts under the Mohamedan Law have been complied with. The contention that such unregistered deed need not be accepted or creates no rights, is rejected. As it fulfills the essential conditions and, therefore, the oral gift of immovable property is proved and need to be accepted. The plaintiff failed to discharge its burden to prove otherwise. Once the oral gift is valid under the Mohamedan Law it need not require any writing or in documents. Therefore, only because it has been reflected in writing later on, that itself cannot destroy the oral gift or intention of the donor. AIR 1995 SC 1205 - Rel. on.  [Para 26]

heading: Transfer of co-owned property
HeadNote.description:
