Transfer of co-owned property - Co-owners have an undivided interest in property - They can divide that interest by sub-dividing the property and granting a part thereof to one of them.

When the property is co-owned, the co-owners have an undivided interest in the property. They can divide that interest by subdividing the property and granting a part thereof to one of them. That would tantamount to a transfer of interest in the property in whichever mode the transfer is effected. This may be under the family arrangement, by way of a partition, in a trust by way of a settlement or amongst co-owners by way of actual possession in addition to the five transfers contemplated under the Transfer of Property Act, including the lease. (1990)4 SCC 286 - Ref. to.  [Para 15]

heading: Transfer of property
HeadNote.description: Transfer of property - A transfer of an immovable property is by an owner to someone else - There cannot be a transfer to oneself because such a transfer is meaningless - It would not bring a change in the character of ownership of the property and, therefore, would not be a transfer.			(Para 19)

heading: Creation of tenancy
Proof
Rent receipt
HeadNote.description:
Creation of tenancy - Proof - Rent receipt - A mere reliance upon rent receipts to show the creation of tenancy and transfer of the title of applicant to another party, who is claimed to have been put in possession, held, is in vain.

A mere reliance upon the rent receipts to show the creation of a tenancy and a transfer of the title of the Applicant to another party, who is claimed to have been put in possession, is in vain. The property continues to remain of the ownership of the Applicant . The Applicant is seen to have derived the ownership from C.J.A. Castellino, presumably by inheritance (though the relationship between C.J.A. Castellino and himself is not specifically stated). There is no question of plot No.606 being co-owned by any other co-owner. It is an admitted position that the registered office of the Respondent is on plot No.606. The Applicant's son is one of the Directors. The Annual Reports show him to be a Director. The entire property is Garden Resort House. The rent receipts of Garden Resort are in respect of three shops and one office. It is not known which is the other part of Garden Resort House where the registered office of the Respondent is situate. The Applicant has not shown that Garden Resort House consists only of shop Nos.2, 3 4 and office. Hence, it would be inequitable to disallow the execution in respect of the part of Garden Resort House actually in possession of the Respondent as its registered office.

Of course, neither the Applicant nor the Respondent would show the documentation with regard to the domicile of the Company. But the Claimant has produced copies of the Annual Reports statutorily required to be filed by the Respondent under Sections 159 to 163 of the Companies Act in which the particulars, inter alia, with regard to the registered office of the Company are given. The Advocate for the Claimant argued that the Company deals in huge maritime contracts. It is not expected to have only a table space. The Respondent-Company has shown the said address in all the correspondence and in the litigation with the Claimant. It would now be too late in the day to allow or reject the claim of the Claimant to the immovable property of the Company where its registered office is situate, specially in view of the fact that the only other claim is shown to be in favour of the sole proprietary Concern of the Applicant by virtue of the rent receipts produced by the Applicant which on and from the date of the Execution Application in effect show no creation or interest of any legal right, title and interest in favour of Garden Resort. 1985 Bom.R.C. 18 - Ref. to.  [Para 21,22]

heading: Lease and agreement to lease
HeadNote.description: Lease and agreement to lease - Instrument to a lease if it contains words of present demise - It is executory agreement if agreement is to come into effect in future if certain things have to be done by lessor or lessee before lease is granted.	(Para 6)

heading: Foreclosure
HeadNote.description: Foreclosure - Order permitting foreclosure in terms of Order 34, Rule 8(3) can be passed only upon ascertaining the nature of the mortgage and the rights of the parties thereunder.	(Para 9)

heading: Right of redemption
HeadNote.description:
Right of redemption - Extinguishment of.

The two circumstances in which the right of redemption is extinguished by passing of a decree are: (i) a final decree in a suit for foreclosure under Order 34, Rule 3(2), CPC; and (ii) a final decree in a suit for redemption under Order 34, Rule 8(3) thereof.  2006(2) ALL MR (S.C.) 81 - Rel.on.   [Para 10]

heading: Suit for redemption
Amount deposited
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption - Decree directing plaintiff to deposit sum, being value of substantial improvements effected by mortgagee, within stipulated period - Time extended by Court - Order extending time neither objected to by defendants nor application for stay filed - Amount deposited - Defendants cannot raise their claim of foreclosure before Supreme Court. Evidence Act (1872), S.115.			(Paras 10, 12-14)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Applicability - Transferee pendente lite may be added as a proper party if his interest in the subject matter of the suit is substantial and not just peripheral.

Section 52 of the Transfer of Property Act is an expression of the principle "pending a litigation nothing new should be introduced". It provides that pendente lite, neither party to the litigation, in which any right to immovable property is in question, can alienate or otherwise deal with such property so as to affect his appointment (sic). This Section is based on equity and good conscience and is intended to protect the parties to litigation against alienations by their opponent during the pendency of the suit. In order to constitute a lis pendens, the following elements must be present:

1.	There must be a suit or proceeding pending in a Court of competent jurisdiction.

2.	The suit or proceeding must not be collusive.

3.	The litigation must be one in which right to immovable property is directly and specifically in question.

4.	There must be a transfer of or otherwise dealing with the property in dispute by any party to the litigation.

5.	Such transfer must affect the rights of the other party that may ultimately accrue under the terms of the decree or order.

The doctrine of lis pendens applies only where the lis is pending before a Court. Further pending the suit, the transferee is not entitled as of right to be made a party to the suit, though the Court has a discretion to make him a party. But the transferee pendente lite can be added as a proper party if his interest in the subject-matter of the suit is substantial and not just peripheral. A transferee pendente lite to the extent he has acquired interest from the defendant is vitally interested in the litigation, whether the transfer is of the entire interest of the defendant, the latter having no more interest in the property may not properly defend the suit. He may collude with the plaintiff. Hence, though the plaintiff is under no obligation to make a lis pendens transferee a party; under Order XXII, Rule 10 an alienee pendente lite may be joined as party. As already noticed, the Court has discretion in the matter which must be judicially exercised and an alienee would ordinarily be joined as a party to enable him to protect his interests. The Court has held that a transferee pendente lite of an interest in immovable property is a representative-in-interest of the party from whom he has acquired that interest. He is entitled to be impleaded in the suit or other proceedings where the transferee pendente lite is made a party to the litigation; he is entitled to be heard in the matter on the merits of the case.

heading: Suit for possession and mesne profits
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession and mesne profits - Plaintiffs claiming suit property by virtue of will allegedly executed in their favour by defendant's father - Property in question gifted by exclusive owner in favour of defendant who in turn became full owner of it - Defendant's father thus had no authority to execute will in respect of suit property - Neither suit property belonged to plaintiffs family nor they have become owner of said property by virtue of will - Order dismissing suit, held proper.	(Para 24)

heading: Lessor and lessee
HeadNote.description:
Lessor and lessee - Rights and liabilities of - Lessee acquiring rights of certain co-owner landlords - His position as tenant continues and he cannot successfully raise plea of determination of tenancy on ground of merger of his estate in that of the landlord - He is, therefore, bound to comply with requirements of Rent Control Act.

In this case, the lessee has acquired only the rights of certain co-owner landlords and may have the right to work out his rights against the others. The right to work out his rights would not enable him to plead that the two rights in the whole of the property has come to vest in him. What is involved in the present case is the question whether on the acquisition of the rights of some of the co-owner landlords by the tenant, there is an extinguishment of the tenancy by merger as postulated by Section 111 (d) of the Transfer of Property Act. A plain and grammatical interpretation of Section 111(d) of the Transfer of Property Act leaves no room for doubt that unless the interests of the lessee and that of the lessor in the whole of the property leased, become vested at the same time in one person in the same right, a determination of the lease cannot take place. On taking an assignment from some of the co-owner landlords, the interests of the lessee and the lessor in the whole of the property do not become vested at the same time in one person in the same right. Therefore, a lessee who has taken assignment of the rights of a co-owner lessor, cannot successfully raise the plea of determination of tenancy on the ground of merger of his lessee's estate in that of the estate of the landlord. It is, thus, clear that there is no substance in the contention that in the case on hand, it should have been held that the tenancy stood determined and the application of the landlord for a direction to the tenant to deposit the rent in arrears should have been dismissed. The position of the appellants as tenants continue and they are bound to comply with the requirements of the Rent Control Act under which the order for deposit has been passed against them.  [Para 35,36]

heading: Sub-tenant
HeadNote.description:
Rights and liabilities of lessor and lessees - Sub-tenant - Acquiring entire interest of the owner in the whole of the estate forming the subject matter of sub-tenancy, the sub-tenancy merges into ownership and the estate of sub-tenant stands enlarged into that of full owner.

Ownership of the property which is the subject-matter of tenancy is certainly a larger estate than the tenancy itself and naturally larger than the sub-tenancy. If the sub-tenant acquires the entire interest of the owner in the whole of the estate forming the subject-matter of sub-tenancy, the sub-tenancy merges into ownership and the estate of sub-tenant stands enlarged into that of a full owner. The sub-tenant cannot be the owner and the subtenant both at the same time. Of course, the situation would have been different if the sub-tenant would be acquired the entire estate of the owner or the ownership interest in the entire estate forming subject-matter of sub-lease. (1969)2 SCWR 967 Overruled.	 [Para 6]

heading: Landlord and tenant
Eviction
HeadNote.description:
Landlord and tenant - Eviction - Suit for delivery of vacant possession of plaint schedule property on payment of value of suit building and for mesne profits based on unregistered lease deeds - Notwithstanding fact that deeds are not registered it is permissible for plaintiffs to rely upon Clause (10) of lease deed which provided for premature eviction - Defendants cannot resist their eviction by taking plea under S.53-A - Plaintiffs, held entitled for a decree for eviction of defendants. Registration Act (1908), S.49. Civil P.C. (1908), S.100.

In case of sale, the person, inducted into possession of property, under an agreement, can insist that he is entitled to remain in possession of the property, to the complete exclusion of the transferor, provided he expresses his readiness and willingness to perform his part of the contract, and thereby, avail the benefit of Section 53-A. However, a person in possession of immovable property, under an agreement of lease, cannot insist that he is not liable to be evicted at all, by taking recourse to the plea of Section 53-A. On the extension of such benefit, the maximum that can happen is that, the transaction of lease, which hitherto was incomplete, can be brought about. Even where a lease in accordance with Section 107 of the Act emerges through specific performance, the obligation of the lessee to be evicted, does not cease. It is no doubt true, that the circumstances, under which a lessee can be evicted, would differ, from case to case, depending on the terms of lease. If no definite period of lease is stipulated, Section 106 can be pressed into service by the lessor, and if the lease is for a specific period, Section 111 of the Act would govern the field.	 [Para 25]

The terms of a lease can be those contained in the lease deed, or the general terms prescribed under Chapter V of the Transfer of Property Act. Even if Exs.B-12 and B-13 are to be treated as agreements of lease, they can be looked into only for collateral purposes in a transaction of lease. Except possession, no other purpose can be treated as collateral to the transaction of a lease. The other terms, such as duration of lease, mutual obligation as to renewal, fixation, or enhancement of rent etc., cannot be treated as collateral. Such terms can be contained only in a lease deed, which accords with Section 107. If for any reason, all the terms and conditions contained in Exs.B- 12 and B-13 can be looked into, notwithstanding the fact that the deeds are not registered, it becomes equally permissible for the plaintiffs to rely upon Clause (10), of Ex.B-12, which provided for premature eviction. Therefore, it has to be held that :  

(a) Exs.B-12 and B-13 did not bring about any lease, as provided for under the Act; and 

(b) that the defendants cannot resist their eviction by taking the plea under Section 53-A of the Act.  [Para 26,27]

The plaintiffs would be entitled for a decree for eviction of the defendants, but as a condition precedent, the value of the building must be assessed by appointing a Chartered Engineer, and so assessed, must be paid. The cost of the building, the plaintiffs are entitled for a decree, for the rents up to the date of filing of the suit, and for subsequent period, it    shall be open to them to file an application for appointment of a Commissioner, for ascertainment of the same. Since the plaintiffs are running an Educational Institution, they deserve to be granted reasonable time.  [Para 33]

heading: Landlord and tenant
Eviction
HeadNote.description: Landlord and tenant - Eviction - Nonissuance of statutory notice - Suit filed by tenants denying title of landlord and pleading adverse possession of disputed property - Landlord is relieved of obligation to issue statutory notice - Non-issuance of statutory notice, either a question of fact, or at least a mixed question of fact and law - For that specific plea must exist in pleadings and it has to be proved through cogent evidence - Cannot be permitted to be raised at stage of second appeal. (Para 16)

heading: Right to redeem
HeadNote.description: Right to redeem - Mortgage deed containing a term that mortgagee shall have a right of pre-emption in case mortgagor wishes to transfer property to a third person - Such a condition operates as a clog on the right of redemption of the Vendee from the mortgagor.	(Para 7)

heading: Tenant mortgage
Merger of Rights
HeadNote.description: Tenant mortgage - Merger of Rights - Mortgage deed specifically stipulating that mortgagee would continue as a lessee after redemption - Plaintiff cannot get possession on redemption of mortgage.			(Paras 8, 9, 13)

heading: Family arrangement
HeadNote.description: Family arrangement - MOU entered into actuated by a desire to resolve disputes - Court would not easily disturb such settlement.	(Para 35)

heading: Sale with condition of purchase or mortgage by way of conditional sale
HeadNote.description: Sale with condition of purchase or mortgage by way of conditional sale - Transaction was evidenced by one document and the scribe described it as one of mortgage and not sale - Amount of stamp duty by transferor - Transferee did not get his name mutated - Transferee was to maintain property in its present condition - However permission to reconstruct the structure was granted - If intention of parties was to convey property absolutely such stipulation was not required at all - Held, deed in question was mortgage and not sale.	(Paras 14 to 19)

heading: Sale deed
HeadNote.description: Doctrine of lis pendens - Sale deed - Two suits 'A' Vs. 'B' and 'C' Vs. 'B' for specific performance of agreement of sale of same property - Suit filed by 'C' Vs. 'B' decided by consent of the parties during the pendency of the suit filed by 'A' Vs. 'B' - Sale deed executed in terms of compromise between "C" and "B" - Held, the sale deed was not binding on "A" and would be hit by the doctrine of lis pendens - The said deed of sale would not come in the court's way in passing a decree in favour of 'A' - Its validity or otherwise would not be necessary to be considered as 'A' is not bound thereby.			(Paras 8, 9, 11, 16)

heading: Mortgage deed
Admissibility of document
HeadNote.description: Mortgage deed - Admissibility of document - Registered instrument signed by mortgagor and attested by two witnesses - Is a valid instrument - It is immaterial whether mortgagee was a signatory or not.		 (Paras 11, 20)

heading: Mortgage by landlord of tenanted premises to tenant
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by landlord of tenanted premises to tenant - Term for redemption fixed and liability to pay rent not kept alive - Implied surrender of tenancy can be inferred - Once the nature of possession of tenant changes resulting in change in his status, the same amounts to virtual taking of possession.			(Paras 26, 27, 31)

heading: Termination of tenancy by implied surrender
HeadNote.description: Termination of tenancy by implied surrender - Mortgage of tenanted premises to tenant - Term of redemption fixed at ten years - Tenant allowed to use ground floor in lieu of interest - Taxes to be paid by mortgagor - On expiry of ten years mortgagee to vacate premises by paying entire mortgage money - If amount advanced was not paid back mortgagee could recover it by auctioning the house - Held stipulations contained in mortgage deed were such that they would lead to an inference that tenancy was impliedly surrendered by the tenant. (Paras 21, 33)

heading: Leave to defend
Rejected.	(Paras 8, 9)
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Rent Control Act (1999), S.42 - Leave to defend - Application filed by landlord under S.42 seeking eviction of non-applicants from suit property - Plea of Oral gift deed of immovable suit property - Fact that no gift deed was executed and registered - Thus ground taken by non-applicants that they had become owner of suit property in view of oral gift - Cannot be allowed to be raised in view of S.123 of Transfer of Property Act and S.17 of Registration Act - Non-applicants having not raised any ground or defence which would disentitle petitioner from getting order for eviction - Application seeking leave to defend - Rejected.	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Word "consideration"
HeadNote.description: Word "consideration" - Has been used in a generic sense to include the price paid or promised or money, a share of crops, service or any other thing of value.	(Para 38)

heading: Part performance
HeadNote.description:
Part performance - Doctrine of part performance is based on equity - It is available as protection only to such a transferee, who has demonstrated equitable foundation for continuation of his possession.

The expression "any person claiming under him" needs to be interpreted so as to make Section 53-A workable.  A person claims under another person, when he is either an assignee from that person or his legal representative.  It cannot be lost sight of that Section 53-A is only a shield.  It protects a transferee, who is willing to perform his part of the agreement and has been let in possession in pursuance of the agreement of sale, from oppressive claim set up by the transferor.  The doctrine of part performance is based on equity.  It is available as protection only to such a transferee, who has demonstrated equitable foundation for continuation of his possession.  2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 1189 : (2004)8 SCC 614 - Rel. to.						   [Para 37]

heading: Mesne profits
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of possession - Mesne profits - A successful party, in whose favour decree for possession is passed, would be entitled to relief of mesne profits.			(Para 43)

heading: Dispute
HeadNote.description: Collusive and fraudulent proceeding - Development Agreement for consideration between Plaintiff Appellant and Respondent No.3 - Dispute - Award in favour of Appellant - Suit by Appellant for eviction of Respondent No.1, a tenant claiming oral gift prior to Development Agreement - Respondent No.1 never questioning validity of Award - Respondent No.3 not examined as witness for one or the other reason - Respondent No.3 evidently not interested in the property - Suit can not be dismissed being a collusive proceeding between Respondent - Defendant No.3 and Appellant.	(Paras 3, 28, 36)

heading: Protection of rights in respect of possession of premises
HeadNote.description: Protection of rights in respect of possession of premises - Agreement for sale between landlord and petitioners - Petitioners in possession of suit premises much before said agreement was made and are in possession since date of agreement - Part consideration paid immediately on date of agreement - However, nothing on record showing tenants expressed further willingness and readiness to make balance payments and never took any steps to file suit for specific performance - Moreover, petitioners never paid rents and throughout claimed to be owners of said premises - No demand for rent was made on part of defendant landlords except demand notice in question - Held, petitioners would be entitled to get protection in respect of possession of suit premises. 2002(2) ALL MR 267 (S.C.) - Foll.	(Para 14)

heading: Dispute
HeadNote.description: Collusive and fraudulent proceeding - Development Agreement for consideration between Plaintiff Appellant and Respondent No.3 - Dispute - Award in favour of Appellant - Suit by Appellant for eviction of Respondent No.1, a tenant claiming oral gift prior to Development Agreement - Respondent No.1 never questioning validity of Award - Respondent No.3 not examined as witness for one or the other reason - Respondent No.3 evidently not interested in the property - Suit can not be dismissed being a collusive proceeding between Respondent - Defendant No.3 and Appellant.	(Paras 3, 28, 36)

heading: Gift to unborn persons along with a living person
HeadNote.description:
Gift to unborn persons along with a living person - Is valid.

There is no ban on the transfer of interest in favour of an unborn person.  Section 20 permits an interest being created for the benefit of an unborn person who acquires interest upon his birth.  No provision has been brought, to our notice which stipulates that full interest in a property cannot be created in favour of unborn person.  Section 13 has no applicability to the facts and circumstances of the present case. In the present case, the donor gifted the property in favour of the appellant, then living, and also stipulated that if other male children are later born to her brother they shall be joint holders with the appellant.  Such a stipulation is not hit by Section 13 of the Act.  Creation of such a right is permissible under Section 20 of the Act.	 [Para 12]

heading: Sale deed
Proof
HeadNote.description: Sale deed - Proof - Document styled as sale deed - Its executant or scribe or attesting witnesses not examined - Document does not stand proved - Its contents is hearsay evidence - Document having been not proved, there is no question of construing it, though styled as sale deed.	(Para 10)

heading: Bonafide purchaser
HeadNote.description: Sale of house property - Bonafide purchaser - Defendant owner of suit property entering into agreement to sale with plaintiff - Plaintiff not taking any step to get sale deed executed - Subsequent sale of suit property for value without notice of earlier transaction - Findings of court showing that plaintiff was not willing and ready to perform his part of contract - In absence of any mutation entry recorded in City Survey subsequent purchaser was not aware of earlier agreement of sale - Considering facts finding of courts that subsequent purchaser was bonafide purchaser for value without notice - Held proper.	(Para 10)

heading: Ejectment after expiry of lease
HeadNote.description: Ejectment after expiry of lease - Renewal was required to be obtained by following specified procedure - Option of renewal not exercised before expiry of lease as per renewal clause - Lessee continuing to occupy leased premises and paying rent - Acceptance of rent cannot be said to be a conduct signifying "assent" to continuance of lease even after expiry of lease period - Order of ejectment not liable to be interfered with.	(Paras 17, 18, 22)

heading: Distinction between
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage by conditional sale and sale coupled with an agreement to recovery - Distinction between - What distinguishes the two transactions is the relationship of debtor and creditor and the transfer being a security for the debt.

In case of a mortgage by conditional sale the price is being charged on the property conveyed, and relationship of mortgagor and mortgagee is created.  In a sale coupled with an agreement to recovery, there is no relationship of debtor and creditor nor price is charged on the property conveyed but the sale is subject to an obligation to transfer the property within the period specified.  What distinguishes the two transactions is the relationship of debtor and creditor and the transfer being a security for the debt.  The document needs to be construed on touch stone of Section 58(c) of the Transfer of Property Act.  The document shows that about 12 months prior i.e. somewhere in September/October, 1962 an amount of Rs.275/- was obtained by the plaintiff from the defendant in order to purchase a sewing machine.  He further obtained Rs.125/- at the time of the execution of the document by way of hand loan.  Needless to say the terms of the document do not show that both these amounts were treated as payment towards consideration of the suit land.  The document itself does not show the agreed price of the suit land.  The terms of the document do not show that prior to the execution of document in question, there was an agreement to alienate the suit land under certain terms.  The terms of the document also do not show that immediately the ownership of the suit land was transferred and the defendant was allowed to enjoy the property as owner.  The mere fact that he was supposed to pay the land revenue is of no avail.  He was placed into possession of the suit land and was to enjoy the usufruct.  Obviously, he was required to pay the land revenue as a person in possession of the suit land.  AIR 1992 SC 1236 and 2006(1) Mh.L.J. 867 - Ref. to.						 [Para 10]

heading: Nature of transaction
Decisive factor
HeadNote.description: Nature of transaction - Decisive factor - Caption of the document or mere language used therein may not be decisive - The nature of the transaction is required to be determined on consideration of the intention of the parties which can be gathered from the attending circumstances and the terms of the document. AIR 1960 SC 301 - Ref. to.	(Para 17)

heading: Plea of tenancy
Suit for declaration
HeadNote.description:
Plea of tenancy - Suit for declaration - Court should not allow an issue of tenancy to be framed when the plea taken by the defendants is vague, vexatious or mala fide - The person who claims to be a tenant must necessarily give particulars as to who created the tenency, the terms of the tenancy and when the tenancy was created.

A court should not allow an issue of tenancy to be framed when the plea taken by the defendants is vague, vexatious or mala fide.  The person, who claims to be a tenant must necessarily give particulars as to who created the tenancy, the terms of the tenancy and when the tenancy was created.  It is also true that the court will consider whether the plea is mala fide and is taken up just to procrastinate the litigation.  The court will also have to take into account the possibility of the defendant succeeding in proving his plea.  If it is found that there is absolutely no chance or a remote possibility of the defendant succeeding in establishing his claim, in a given case, the court can disallow the application for framing such an issue. (2000)1 SCC 35 - Rel. on. [Para 11]

heading: Plea of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Plea of tenancy - Averments that Defendants cultivated land from or around a particular year at the instance of owner - Paid share of profit to Owner - Constitute sufficient pleadings to frame issue.			(Paras 13 to 15)

heading: Lease
HeadNote.description:
Lease - Essential ingredients.

The essential ingredients of a lease are : (a) There should be a transfer of a right to enjoy an immovable property ; (b) Such transfer may be for a certain term or in perpetuity; (c)  The transfer should be in consideration of a premium or rent ; (d) The transfer should be a bilateral transaction, the transferee accepting the terms of transfer.   [Para 7]

heading: Perpetual lease
No rent payable
HeadNote.description: Perpetual lease - Lease duration not specified - Lessee permitted to hold land forever subject to right of lessor to resume land by giving one month's notice and compensation for buildings erected on land - No rent payable - Lease, held, is not a lease in perpetuity.	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Plaintiff alleging forcible dispossession in 1975 - No evidence produced to show his dispossession or that of his tenant - Letters produced only spoke about compensation after resumption of leased land - Lands were resumed several years prior to 1975 without any protest and the suit was filed only in 1987 - Held apart from merits claim was also barred by limitation.		(Para 17)

heading: Doctrine of lis pendens
HeadNote.description: Doctrine of lis pendens - Defendant purchaser purchasing suit house during pendency of suit - Facts revealing that said defendant made full enquiry about suit house and only after she was satisfied that no prior agreement subsisted between defendant owner and plaintiff or any other person, she purchased suit house in her name - Said transaction not hit by doctrine of lis pendens. AIR 2001 SC 2920 and AIR 1999 SC 3248 - Distinguished.	(Para 12)

heading: Doctrine of part performance
HeadNote.description: Doctrine of part performance - Scope and applicability of - S.53-A of Transfer of Property Act could be invoked by defendant only in a case where the defendant was put in possession of the property in pursuance of an agreement of sale and the defendant was ready and willing to perform his part of the contract.	(Para 8)

heading: Scope and applicability of
HeadNote.description:
Scope and applicability of - S.53-A has nothing to do with the ownership of the transferor who remains full owner of the suit property till it is legally conveyed by executing a registered sale deed in favour of the transferee.

Section 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act merely disentitles the transferor from disturbing the possession of the proposed transferee who is put in possession of the property in pursuance of the agreement.  Section 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act has nothing to do with the ownership of the transferor who remains full owner of the suit property till it is legally conveyed by executing a registered sale deed in favour of the transferee.  Such was not the case here.  The defendants had claimed to be the owners of the suit property in pursuance of the registered sale deed which was executed in the year 1983.  Hence Section 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act did not come into play as under Section 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act, a proposed transferee is entitled to protect his possession against the true owner or any person claiming through him.  It cannot apply in the case where the person who is put in possession of the suit property is not the proposed transferee, but is, in fact, a person who claims that the property is already transferred in his favour.  In the absence of any pleadings in the written statement and in view of the fact that the plaintiff did not have an opportunity to prove that he was the bona fide purchaser for value without notice, the provisions of Section 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act cannot be invoked at least to protect the possession of the defendants, especially when the defendants are not the proposed transferees but claim title in themselves.  2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 1189 and AIR 2001 SC 1658 - Distinguished.							     [Para 8]

heading: Change of user
Purpose of letting
HeadNote.description: Change of user - Purpose of letting - Letting out or leasing out property for a particular named person cannot be the "purpose" of letting - Purpose of letting out would be residential or non-residential or for a particular business etc.	(Paras 25, 26)

heading: Lease or licence
Determination as to
HeadNote.description: Lease or licence - Determination as to - Nature of relationship between parties should be decided on basis of last agreement entered into between them having regard to earlier agreements and other attending circumstances. 	(Paras 14, 18)

heading: Grant of injunction
HeadNote.description:
Grant of injunction - Rule of lis pendens - In spite of rule of lis pendens, there could be occasions for grant of temporary injunction - Person claiming injunction in such a situation would have to show that protection under S.52 of the T.P. Act is not adequate.

There could always be cases where rule of lis pendens may be inadequate to prevent the mis-chief and a temporary injunction to prevent such would be warranted. This would imply that a person claiming injunction in such a situation would have to show that protection under Section 52 of the T.P. Act is not adequate. Merely because there is a power, its exercise could not be sought as a matter of course; or simply because its exercise is unlikely to hurt the defendant; for, while granting injunction the Court must see that plaintiff makes out a case of irreparable loss and it is not for the defendant to prove that he would suffer if an injunction is issued. After plaintiff proves irreparable loss comes the question of balance of convenience or rather balance of inconvenience, when the Court would enquire as to who would suffer greater inconvenience and decide whether injunction ought to be granted.  [Para 15]

A plaintiff need not at all worry about transfers pendente lite and so, occasions for invoking powers under Order 39, Rules 1 and 2 would arise only in rare cases where the plaintiff can demonstrate that rule of lis pendens is inadequate to protect plaintiff's interest. 16 Indian Cases 359 - Held per incuriam. 1907 Vol.IX BLR 1173 - Rel on.  [Para 22]

heading: Lis pendens
Grant of injunction
HeadNote.description:
Lis pendens - Grant of injunction - While considering balance of inconvenience and irreparable loss, civil courts would have to see as to what is the preventive relief sought or what mischief is sought to be prevented.

While considering balance of inconvenience and irreparable loss, Civil Courts would have to see as to what is the preventive relief sought or what mischief is sought to be prevented. Ordinarily, while seeking an injunction to restrain transfers during the pendency of a suit, it is submitted that if injunction is not issued, it will lead to multiplicity of proceedings, by being required to chase parties who may claim to be bona fide purchasers without notice.  [Para 18]

This should put at rest all apprehensions about multiplicity of proceedings or plaintiff being required to chase transferees. If such transferees cannot seek impleadment, plaintiff would be under no obligation to chase them or file proceedings against them. He could simply execute the decree which he obtains and such transferees pendente lite would not even be able to raise an obstruction. If there be any doubts in this regard - about transferee pendente lite being able to resist the decree - they are set at rest by judgment of the Supreme Court in Usha Sinha Vs. Dina Ram and others, reported in 2008 ALL SCR 776. 2007 ALL SCR 371 and 2008 ALL SCR 776 - Rel. on.  [Para 20]

heading: Lis pendens
Protection to parties
HeadNote.description:
Registration Act (1908), S.18 - Lis pendens - Protection to parties - S.52 of T.P. Act provides adequate protection to parties from transfers pendente lite and such transferees are neither required to be impleaded nor can claim impleadment - They cannot even resist execution proceedings.

(a)	Section 52 of the T.P. Act provides adequate protection to the parties from transfers pendente lite and such transferees are neither required to be impleaded nor can claim impleadment. They cannot even resist execution proceedings.

(b)	In Mumbai (as also elsewhere as and when amended provisions are made applicable) plaintiffs could (or rather ought to) have notices of their suits registered under Section 18 of the Indian Registration Act, in view of the amended provision of the T.P. Act and the Registration Act. They cannot seek to restrain adversary by an injunction by refusing to go in for registration of the lis.

(c)	Rule 1 of Order 39 of the Civil Procedure Code enabling Court to grant temporary injunctions to restrain transfers pendente lite is only an enabling provision, recognizing the power in the Court to issue such injunction and does not imply that because there is power, it must be exercised. The provision could be invoked only if protection provided by Section 52 of the T.P. Act is shown to be inadequate.

(d)	In the face of protection provided by Section 52 of the T.P. Act, Courts should be cautious in examining the claims by plaintiffs of irreparable loss if injunction to restrain alienations is refused.

(e)	In suits for specific performance/right to develop against the recorded/rightful owners, Courts may consider if an injunction would cause greater inconvenience to a rightful owner by being deprived the right to deal with his property for the sake of a claim which is yet to mature into right and which metamorphosis rests in the discretion of the Court and is not certain.

(f)	Courts may consider necessity of imposing suitable conditions to protect plaintiffs' interests short of granting injunction - like seeking undertaking that no equities would be claimed, on account of sale/development of properties; effecting sales only after putting transferees to notice that their rights would be subject to suit etc.. Interests of prospective purchasers would also be protected if plaintiffs in such cases register the lis, though it may be optional.  [Para 30]

heading: Validity of
HeadNote.description: Gift of immovable property - Validity of - Defendant donor executing declaration of gift in favour of his grandson (donee) in respect of property which was alloted to him by virtue of being a member of co-operative society - Said document not registered under Registration Act - Society transferring shares in name of donee - In absence of registration of said document transfer of shares in favour of donee is not valid. 1997(1) ALL MR 535 (S.C.) - Foll.(Para 13)

heading: Requirements
HeadNote.description:
Application for raising attachment - Requirements - Showing the payment of consideration of the price, held, is the seminal requirement in an application for raising an attachment.

Held, showing the payment of consideration of the price is, therefore, the seminal requirement in an Application for raising an attachment . Unless that is shown and substantiated by the Applicant, who is in the nature of a Plaintiff, the transfer by sale in favour of the Applicant cannot be seen. Without showing her title to the property, no claim for raising attachment can be made.  1990 Mh.L.J. 306 - Ref. to.	 [Para 7]

heading: Notice of forfeiture
Challenge to
Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Notice of forfeiture - Challenge to - Suit for possession - Tenant denying title of landlord as owner of the suit property - Notice of forfeiture, held, legal and valid - Tenancy of defendant was forfeited under S.111(g) of Transfer of Property Act - Plaintiff is entitled to possession of suit premises.	(Para 16)

heading: Conditional Sale or Mortgage
HeadNote.description: Conditional Sale or Mortgage - An answer to the question as to whether the transaction is a sale or a mortgage not only would depend upon the language used in the deed, but also the circumstances attending thereto.	(Para 6)

heading: Conditional Sale or Mortgage
HeadNote.description:
Conditional Sale or Mortgage - Oral evidence of loan - Market price of land higher than the loan amount - Appellant to have title for a period of five years, remain in possession for that period - Plaintiff entitled to tender amount at the expiry of period but even prior thereto - On tender, appellant required to execute a deed of reconveyance - Such a transaction cannot be construed to be a transaction of sale, it was a mortgage - A suit for redemption of mortgage maintainable - Appeal dismissed with costs.

Whether the transaction is a sale or a mortgage not only would depend upon language used in the deed, but also the circumstances attending thereto. The plaintiff deposed categorically that his father took a loan, evidence on record shows that the market price of the land was higher. When an absolute transfer of property is made, it cannot be limited to a period. The transaction shows that the appellant was to have title in the property for a period of five years, remain in possession thereof only for that period. Plaintiff was entitled to tender the amount not only at the expiry of the said period but even prior thereto. On tender of such document, appellant was required to execute a deed of reconveyance. Such a transaction cannot be construed to be a transaction of sale. It was a mortgage as has rightly been held by the High Court. A suit for redemption of mortgage was maintainable. Appeal dismissed with costs.  [Para 6,7,8,9]

heading: Mortgage
Usufructory mortgage
Mortgagor as tenant
Right of redemption
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage - Usufructory mortgage - Mortgagor as tenant - Right of redemption - Mortgagor continued in possession as tenant of mortgagee - Sale of mortgaged property in execution for recovery of arrears of rent - Mortgagee purchased property in court auction - High Court allowed appeal and decreed suit for redemption of mortgage - Further appeal, held relationship of mortgagee and mortgagor continued to subsist, mortgagee's purchase is only in trust for mortgagor - Right to redeem is not extinguished - Appeal dismissed.

Though the mortgagee purchased the mortgaged property pursuant to the decree the provisions of O.34, R.14, CPC and S.90 of the Indian Trusts Act, in the absence of recourse to R.14 of O.34, the relationship of mortgagor and mortgagee continues to subsist even thereafter, his purchase is only in trust for the mortgagor.  In view of the same, the right to redeem the mortgage is not extinguished and in the eye of law the purchase of the mortgaged property in pursuance of the decree for rent arrears must be deemed to have been made in trust for the mortgagor.  In such circumstances, the High Court was right in granting preliminary decree for redemption.   [Para 6,7,13,14]

heading: Redemption suit
Limitation
Redemption suit dismissed
Appeal allowed
Further appeal
HeadNote.description: Redemption suit - Limitation - Usufructuary mortgage on 19/02/1948 with redemption period of 5 years - Redemption suit dismissed - Appeal allowed - Further appeal - Held for mortgagor to redeem or recover possession of property mortgaged, limitation period is of 30 years when the right to redeem or to recover possession accrues - Mortgagee purchased mortgaged property in court auction on 11/09/1952, suit for redemption filed on 18/02/1983 was within the time prescribed, High Court can not be faulted for granting preliminary decree for redemption - Appeal dismissed.	(Paras 5, 13, 14)

heading: Exchange of properties
HeadNote.description:
Exchange of properties - Exchange by oral transaction - Not followed by possession - Defendants, held, have failed to prove case of ownership on basis of exchange.

The exchange of immoveable properties is required to be compulsorily registered unless followed by possession and since the alleged exchange in the instant case was admittedly by way of an oral transaction, and not by a registered instrument, without being accompanied or followed by possession, the defendants failed to prove their case of ownership of suit house on the basis of exchange.			     [Para 25]

The concept of oral family arrangement for transfer of interests in properties held jointly or in common not requiring any registration is valid in law. The transfer of properties held jointly or in common by oral family arrangement does not require any registration. This principle applies to only those properties which are joint family properties or where the properties are held in common and there is no separation of individual interests in the properties. The words "transfer of ownership of one thing for the ownership of another" themselves indicate that what is contemplated by the section is mutual transfer of two separate and mutually exclusive properties. In case of joint family property or property held in joint tenancy, each co-parcener or co-owner has some interest in the entire property and which is undivided with and not exclusive of the interests of the other co-parceners or co-owners. In partition, there occurs giving away of some undivided interest by one for that of another's some undivided interest and, therefore, it cannot be called an exchange under Section 118 of T.P. Act, although it is a transfer of property within the meaning of Section 5 of that Act. 	     [Para 18]

heading: Termination of tenancy
Notice
Contents
HeadNote.description: Termination of tenancy - Notice - Contents - Defendant was asked to vacate and deliver possession of entire suit premises - Though in plaint it was pleaded that defendant was tenant in respect of part of premises and tresspasser in respect of remaining premises - In effect notice terminated tenancy of defendant from entire suit premises - Notice held, was a valid notice.	(Para 14)

heading: Sale Deed
Validity, fraud alleged
Sale deed quashed
HeadNote.description: Sale Deed - Validity, fraud alleged - Appellant on 04/09/1982 sold 1 cent of land for Rs.18,000/-, on 11/07/1983 he sold to Respondent 3 cents of land for Rs.1,000/- Suit filed by appellant for declaring sale favouring Respondent as void - Necessary medical certificate showed that appellant not having sound mind, treated in Mental Hospital for Alcoholic Psychosis - Some fraud was played - Sale deed quashed - Appeal allowed.	(Paras 3, 7, 8)

heading: Sale Deed
Validity
HeadNote.description: Sale Deed - Validity - Doctrine of 'res ipsa loquitur', applicability of - Appellant on 04/09/1982 sold 1 cent of land for Rs.18,000/-, on 11/07/1983 he sold to Respondent 3 cents of land for Rs.1,000/- Suit filed by appellant for declaring sale favouring Respondent as void - Medical certificate showed that appellant not having sound mind, treated in Mental Hospital for Alcoholic Psychosis - No one in his senses would do such sale - Doctrine of res ipsa loquitur - Matter speaks for itself applies.	(Paras 3, 7, 8)

heading: Gift
Gift
Presumption of acceptance
HeadNote.description: Gift - Acceptance of a gift - Presumption of acceptance - Relationship between parties plays an important role - It is not necessary to prove any overt act as an express acceptance is not necessary to complete the transaction - Even silence may sometimes indicate acceptance.	(Para 16)

heading: Gift
HeadNote.description: Gift - Gift deed duly registered - Presumption arises in regard to correctness thereof - When such a presumption is raised coupled with recitals in regard to putting donee in possession, onus would be on the donor and not on the donee. (2006)5 SCC 353 - Ref. to.		(Para 20)

heading: Gift of property to son out of love and affection
HeadNote.description: Gift of property to son out of love and affection - Gift deed itself stating that property was handed over to son and he had accepted the same - Son was residing outside India for a long time - He did not bother to take possession of gift deeds, pay tax or get his name mutated - Father can celling gift deeds by stating that gift deed was executed on son promising to contribute Rs.1,00,000/- at the time of marriage of his sister but he failed to do so and that he had also not accepted the gifts - Cancellation challenged by the son - Held, trial Court was justified in holding that gift satisfied ingredients of Ss.122, 123 of Transfer of Property Act and same could not have been rescinded on change in the feelings of the father towards his son and the First Appellate Court and High Court erred in reversing the said finding opining that there had been no overt act of possession on the part of donee as he had not paid any tax, nor he got his name mutated in revenue records and the deeds of gift were also produced by the donor.			(Paras 24, 31, 32)

heading: Doctrine of marshalling
HeadNote.description: Doctrine of marshalling - Doctrine rests upon the principle that a creditor who has the means of satisfying his debt out of several funds shall not, by the exercise of his right, prejudice another creditor whose security comprises only one of the funds.			(Para 20)

heading: Doctrine of marshalling
Plea of
HeadNote.description: Doctrine of marshalling - Plea of - Plea of marshalling being pure question of law based upon decree obtained for specific performance, cannot simply be thrown out merely because the same was not specifically pleaded.	(Para 30)

heading: Doctrine of marshalling
HeadNote.description: Doctrine of marshalling - Doctrine cannot be permitted to become a device for destructing the sanctity of contract - The court will also not apply the doctrine of impossibility to assist a party which does not want to fulfill its obligations under the contract.	(Para 34)

heading: Validity of notice
HeadNote.description: Validity of notice - Suit filed after expiry of period in sub-section (1) - Suit is not invalid even if notice is short of period specified in sub-section (1).	(Para 16)

heading: Part performance
Lease
HeadNote.description:
Lease - Onus to exercise right of renewal - Renewal clause in indenture of lease, silent as to who should exercise said option - Held, right to renew to be exercised by lessee.

(1992) 17 IC 180 Rel. on.	 [Para 11]

heading: Lease
HeadNote.description:
Lease - Delay of two years in exercising right of renewal on the part of lessee - Lessor prior to expiry of term of lease filed a suit for eviction on ground of breach of lease terms by lessee - Yet lessee did not demand renewal prior to expiry of lease term - Even nothing on record to suggest that lessee's demand for renewal was in form of payment of rent - Lessee not entitled to renewal of said lease.

AIR 1984 AP 176, 1960 1 WLR 752 Disting.

(1992) 17 IC 180 Rel. on. 	 [Para 13,16]

heading: Sale during pendency of suit
HeadNote.description: Sale during pendency of suit - Defendant's mother purchased portion of suit land - Sale deed is not binding on plaintiff and cannot affect his rights.	(Para 18)

heading: Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Termination of tenancy - No reason is requied to be assigned for determining lease.	 (Para 20)

heading: "Lease" and "License"
"Lease" or "License"
HeadNote.description: "Lease" or "License" - Certain restrictions imposed on construction of buildings on land - Such restrictions are not decisive in considering whether document is lease or license.			(Para 34)

heading: Auction sale
HeadNote.description:
Auction sale - Liability of seller.

The seller is bound to pay all public charges due in respect of the property upto the date of sale, when a property is sold in auction. Section 55 refers to a contract only. Unless there is a contract to the contrary, the rights and obligations of the parties to a sale would be as indicated in Section 55. Such a contract to the contrary must be express and not implied, as a result whereof the meaning of term encumbrance would be expanded.   [Para 19]

heading: Determination of lease
HeadNote.description: Determination of lease - It may not be made in case of denial of title which is bona fide or innocent.	(Para 11)

heading: Sale of share in dwelling house to stranger
HeadNote.description: Sale of share in dwelling house to stranger - Whether dwelling house belonged to undivided family - Plaintiff alongwith his father holding suit property as tenants in common, in equal undivided half shares - Father transferred his share to his another son - No documents evidencing partition of suit house by metes and bounds - Held, dwelling house belonged to undivided family - Hence, prima facie, the sale by co-owner to stranger, would come within mischief of second para of S.44. (Paras 23, 24)

heading: Title of person
Municipal record
HeadNote.description: Title of person - Municipal record - Mere verification of municipal record to ascertain title of a person by itself is not sufficient - Municipal record is for the purpose of collecting property taxes. AIR 1965 SC 295 - Ref. to.	(Para 14)

heading: Pendent lite purchaser
HeadNote.description:
Pendent lite purchaser - Should be given opportunity to protect his rights by impleading him in the suit.

Section 52 of the Transfer of Property Act, (for short the 'T.P.Act') incorporates doctrine of lis pendens and it stipulates that during the pendency of any suit or proceeding in which any right to immovable property is, directly or specifically, in question, the property, which is the subject matter of such suit or proceeding cannot be "transferred or otherwise dealt with", so as to affect the rights of any other party to such a suit or proceeding. The effect of Section 52 is not to render transfers effected during the pendency of a suit by a party to the suit void; but only to render such transfers subservient to the rights of the parties to such suit, as may be, eventually, determined in the suit. In other words, the transfer remains valid subject, to the result of the suit. The pendente lite purchaser would be entitled to or suffer the same legal rights and obligations of his vendor as may be eventually determined by the Court.  [Para 16,17]

heading: Co-operative housing society
HeadNote.description:
Co-operative housing society - Bye-laws stipulating that property can be transferred back only to society or with prior permission to a person qualified to be a member of society - Such a bye-law is not in absolute restraint on alienation offending S.10 of T.P. Act.

Section 10 of the Transfer of Property Act relieves a transferee of immoveable property from an absolute restraint placed on his right to deal with the property in his capacity as an owner thereof. As per Section 10, a condition restraining alienation would be void. The Section applies to a case where property is transferred subject to a condition or limitation absolutely restraining the transferee from parting with his interest in the property. For making such a condition invalid, the restraint must be an absolute restraint. It must be a restraint imposed while the property is being transferred to the transferee. Here, respondent No.2 became a member of the Society on the death of his father. He subscribed to the bye-laws. He accepted Section 30 of the Act and the other restrictions placed on a member. Respondent No.2 was qualified to be a member in terms of the bye-laws. His father was also a member of the Society. The allotment of the property was made to appellant in his capacity as a member. There was really no transfer of property to respondent No.2. He inherited it with the limitations thereon placed by Section 31 of the Act and the bye-laws. His right to become a member depended on his possessing the qualification to become one as per the bye-laws of the Society. He possessed that qualification. The bye-laws provide that he should have the prior consent of the Society for transferring the property or his membership to a person qualified to be a member of the Society. These are restrictions in the interests of the Society and its members and consistent with the object with which the Society was formed. He cannot question that restriction. It is also not possible to say that such a restriction amounts to an absolute restraint on alienation within the meaning of Section 10 of the Transfer of Property Act. The restriction, if any, is a self-imposed restriction. It is a restriction in a contract to which the father of respondent No.2 was a party and to which respondent No.2 voluntarily became a party. It is difficult to postulate that such a qualified freedom to transfer a property accepted by a person voluntarily, would attract Section 10 of the Act. Moreover, it is not as if it is an absolute restraint on alienation. Respondent No.2 has the right to transfer the property to a person who is qualified to be a member of the Society as per its bye-laws. At best, it is a partial restraint on alienation. Such partial restraints are valid if imposed in a family settlement, partition or compromise of disputed claims. So, when a person accepts membership in a co-operative society by submitting himself to its bye-laws and secures an allotment of a plot of land or a building in terms of the bye-laws and places on himself a qualified restriction in his right to transfer the property by stipulating that the same would be transferred back to the society or with the prior consent of the society to a person qualified to be a member of the society, it cannot be held to be an absolute restraint on alienation offending Section 10 of the Transfer of Property Act. He has placed that restriction on himself in the interest of the collective body, the society. He has voluntarily submerged his rights in that of the society.   [Para 35,36]

The fact that the rights of a member or an allottee over a building or plot is attachable and saleable in enforcement of a decree or an obligation against him cannot make a provision like the one found in the bye-laws, an absolute restraint on alienation to attract Section 10 of the Transfer of Property Act. Of course, it is property in the hands of the member on the strength of the allotment. It may also be attachable and saleable in spite of the volition of the allottee. But that does not enable the Court to hold that the condition that an allotment to the member is subject to his possessing the qualification to be a member of the co-operative society or that a voluntary transfer by him could be made only to the society itself or to another person qualified to be a member of the society and with the consent of the society could straightway be declared to be an absolute restraint on alienation and consequently an interference with his right to property protected by Article 300-A of the Constitution of India.   [Para 37]

heading: Interpretation of Statute
HeadNote.description:
Interpretation of Statute - Provisions of S.6 (a) have to be read along with S.2 of the Act, which provides for repeal of Acts and saving of certain enactments, incidents, rights, liabilities etc. - Nothing in chapter II in which S.6 finds place, shall be deemed to affect any rule of Mohammedan Law - S.6 (a) was enacted in defence to customary law and law of inheritance prevailing among Mohammedans.

AIR 1973 SC 554 - Ref. to.	 [Para 17,19]

heading: Suit for redemption
HeadNote.description:
Suit for redemption - Mortgage debt getting statutorily discharged when Debt Relief Act came into force - Plaintiff entitled to final decree and taking of account - Usufructuary mortgagor cannot claim rendition of accounts but mesne profits for wrongful possession from date of discharge of mortgage debt.

It is no doubt true that a decree for redemption would include a direction for entire accounts between the parties in relation to the mortgage. But the question of directing accounts would arise only where it is necessary to find out what is due from the mortgagor to the mortgagee, or whether there is any over payment by the mortgagor to the mortgagee. In this case, the mortgage was an usufructuary mortgage, where the mortgagee was entitled to retain possession until the mortgage money was paid. When the mortgage debt got statutorily discharged, the mortgagee became liable to deliver back possession to the mortgagor. In such a situation, what the mortgagors-plaintiffs can claim from the mortgagee, is not rendition of accounts, but mesne profits for wrongful possession from the date of discharge of the mortgage debt. There is, therefore, no question of accounting either of the amounts due by the mortgagor to the mortgagee or of any accounting of over-payments or for refund of any over-payments by the mortgagee. In the suit, plaintiffs only sought rendition of accounts but did not claim mesne profits nor paid any court fee in regard to past mesne profits. Plaintiffs cannot, under the guise of a claim for accounts, seek a decree for mesne profits. After obtaining possession, it is open to them to sue for such mesne profits as is permissible in law.   [Para 29]

heading: Construction of Agreement
HeadNote.description: Lease or Leave and License - Construction of Agreement - Agreement styled as Deed of Leave and License entered into on 29th March, 1968 - Defendant using the building premises owned by the plaintiff for carrying out profession of medical practitioners - Agreement whether lease or license - Recitals in a deed may indicate only an intention but is not decisive - Crucial test is whether instrument intended to create or not to create interest in the property which is the subject matter of the agreement - What is not in the agreement could not be inferred.	(Paras 14, 18)

heading: Surrender of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Surrender of tenancy - A surrender is always an intervivos act - It cannot be unilateral - Landlord must come to know that the tenant has given-up the possession and the rights, at least, in an express surrender.	(Para 10)

heading: Surrender of tenancy
Proof
mortgagee, licensor
HeadNote.description:
Surrender of tenancy - Proof - No pleading by defendants as to whether surrender was express or implied - Defendants, therefore, held, barred from tendering any evidence to prove either.

A surrender is always an intervivos act.  It cannot be unilateral.  The landlord must come to know that the tenant has given-up the possession and the rights, at least, in an express surrender.  There is no pleading whether the surrender was express or implied.  Since there is no pleading as to whether the surrender was express or implied, the defendants were debarred from tendering any evidence to prove either.  Clause (e) of Section 111 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882 speaks of express surrender while (f) speaks of implied.  This question, therefore, will be a mixed question of facts and law.  It was for this reason that a clear pleading as to the nature of surrender was necessary.  That having been left vague, no amount of evidence is admissible.

When a lessee accepts new lease during continuance of the old, there is implied surrender of the original lease.  It is not even pleaded by the defendants that any other new relationship, such as mortgagor - mortgagee, licensor - licensee came into existence or there was any new contract of lease.  What is alleged is that the plaintiffs have vacated the premises and have gone to live elsewhere.  This does not and cannot amount to implied surrender at all.  Since there is no pleading of coming into existence of new relationship or new contract of lease, the case does not at all fall under clause (f) of S.111 of the Transfer of Property Act.  Although the courts below have not considered the case in this perspective, their finding that there was no implied surrender was factually correct.	 [Para 10]

heading: Termination of tenancy
Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description: Termination of tenancy - Suit for eviction - Plaint states defendant was using suit premises for bakery - Written statement do not state that premises is used for manufacturing purpose - In cross examination of tenant no suggestion was made regarding use of premises of manufacturing purpose - Lower appellate court concluded that premises is used for manufacturing purpose - Conclusion drawn merely on basis of use of word 'bakery' without any specific evidence - Finding liable to be set aside. (Para 8)

heading: Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Termination of tenancy - Plaint states that defendant was monthly tenant as per agreement, local usage - Evidence of tradition, custom usage was not challenged in cross examination - Contract, usage was clearly proved - Even if lease was for bakery, it was treated as monthly tenancy - Notice of termination under S.106 was valid. (Para 8)

heading: Sale
HeadNote.description: Sale - Transaction in question whether a sale outright or of loan in substance - Revenue record in respect of suit land was not relevant for consideration of question involved.			(Para 4)

heading: Part performance of contract
HeadNote.description: Part performance of contract - Claim for possession of property - Plaintiff not proving that he was in possession of property in terms of part performance of agreement to sell - He cannot claim protection of S.53-A. (Para 12)

heading: Acceptance of rent
HeadNote.description: Waiver of notice to quit - Acceptance of rent - Held, mere acceptance of the rent does not amount to waiver of notice to quit, unless there is any other evidence to prove or establish that the landlord intended to do so.  2006(3) ALL MR (S.C.) 211 - Ref. to.	(Paras 20 and 21)

heading: Eviction
HeadNote.description:
Maharashtra Rent Control Act (1999), S.25 - Eviction - Ejectment of tenant is on non-personal ground and concerns with premises - Landlord can sue tenant and sub-tenant together - Held, decree of eviction passed against tenant along with applicant sub-tenant is liable to be upheld.

If in suit against tenant other persons are joined as they are sub-tenants and if eviction is sought on personal grounds like non-payment of rent then a decree of eviction of tenant will confer direct tenancy rights on lawful sub-tenants.  Sub-tenants cannot be ejected in that suit on personal grounds.  If landlord seeks possession on grounds non-personal to tenant and which concern premises then landlord can plead and prove those grounds in same suit against tenant and his sub-tenants and seek their eviction.  Further if premises are let out to tenant for being in service of landlord and tenant has cease to be in service, landlord is entitled to recover possession.  In such case sub-tenant cannot become direct tenant of landlord on determination of his tenancy.  In this case decree of eviction passed against tenant alongwith applicant sub-tenant is liable to be upheld. AIR 1957 Bom. 195, AIR 1978 Bom. 234, AIR 1967 SC 1853 - Ref. to. 2000(1) ALL MR 335 (S.C.) - Rel. on.   [Para 40,41,42]

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Lease of residential premises - Notice of termination with immediate effect - Validity - 15 days time should have been given - However, keeping in view that suit for eviction was filed after expiry of 15 days, notice cannot be said to be invalid - Suit not to be dismissed on that ground.			(Para 11)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Lessor and lessee relationship admitted in written statement - Rent amount also admitted - Service of notice terminating tenancy admitted - That agreement was not duly registered and whether premises was let out for residential or commercial use was wholly immaterial - So also modifications in structure or re-construction made would not affect relationship between parties - Held, trial Court was justified in decreeing suit for possession on basis of admissions - Civil P.C. (1908), O.12 R.6. 	(Paras 9 to 11)

heading: Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Termination of tenancy - Month to month tenancy - Service of notice terminating tenancy admitted by defendant - Notice did not suffer from any illegality - Challenge to title of plaintiff was based on document anterior to commencement of tenancy - S.116 of Evidence Act estoppes tenant from doing so - Held, Trial Court was perfectly justified in decreeing suit for possession. (Paras 14, 15, 17)

heading: Purchase of property
Pendency of suit
HeadNote.description: Purchase of property - Pendency of suit - Purchaser-plaintiff purchasing property despite knowing pendency of suit for partition of the very same property - Transaction hit by section 52 - Purchaser would be bound by decree for partition. 			(Para 7)

heading: Termination of lease
HeadNote.description: Termination of lease - Issuance of notice for - Where lease is for definite term and it expires by efflux of time, there is no necessity of issuing notice u/S.106 of TP Act. (Para 8)

heading: Lease
Transfer of interest
HeadNote.description:
Lease - Transfer of interest - Lease is a transfer of interest in the property - Monthly lease which means a lease for a month renewable every month, would also be a transfer of interest in the property.

Section 105 of the Transfer of Property Act 1882, defines the lease of an immovable property as a transfer of a right to enjoy such property, made for a certain time, express or implied, or in perpetuity, in consideration of a price paid or promised, or of money, a share of crops, service or any other thing of value, to be rendered periodically or on specified occasions to the transferor by the transferee, who accepts the transfer on such terms. Lease undoubtedly is a transfer of interest in the property and so a monthly lease which means a lease for a month renewable every month, would also be a transfer in the interest in the property, that is transfer of a right to use the property for the unexpired period of the lease for a month. Clause (j) of section 108 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882 provides that a lessee may transfer absolutely or by way of a mortgage or sub lease the whole or any part of his interest in the property, and any transferee of such interest or part may again transfer it. Section 108(j) of the Transfer of Property Act thus recognizes the right of a lessee to transfer his leasehold interest in the property. Such transfer may be absolute, that is by way of an assignment or may be limited, that is, by way of a mortgage or sub lease. Ofcourse, section 108 of the Transfer of Property Act is subject to the contract to the contrary. The lessor and the lessee may, by an agreement, agree that the lessee shall not transfer his right either absolutely or even partially. But unless there is a contract between the lessor and the lessee prohibiting transfer a lessee is entitled to transfer his leasehold interest (including an interest as a monthly tenant) either absolutely or partially unless the contract between the parties prohibits such transfer. The legislature of Maharashtra, however, by enacting the Bombay Rent Act imposed a restriction on the right of a lessee to transfer his leasehold interest.  [Para 8]

heading: Fraud
HeadNote.description: Agreement to sale immovable property - Fraud - Must be specifically pleaded and proved - No fraud alleged in plaint - Vendor was in urgent need of money - Purchaser was made aware of encumbrances - Vendor was to clean encumbrance on receipt of purchase price from purchaser - Claim by purchases that vendor should have cleared all encumbrances before payment of last two instalments not borne out by evidence - Held case of fraud was not made out.		 	(Paras 40, 41)

heading: Condition for
HeadNote.description: Transfer of immovable property - Condition for - Transfer of immovable property by sale having value of Rs.100/- and upwards must be by a registered instrument of sale. 		(Para 11)

heading: Mortgage deed
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage deed - Validity - Mortgage deed in favour of deceased mother of appellant and respondent, who was 15 years of age at time of registration of mortgage deed as collateral security towards dowry amount - She was not represented by natural guardian to constitute document as valid as she was a minor - Held, mortgage deed is void ab-intio and appellant cannot claim any rights under it. 

The mortgage deed executed by the uncle of the appellant and the first respondent, in favour of the deceased mother of the appellant, is not a valid mortgage deed in respect of the property covered in the said document for the reason that the deceased mother at the time of execution and registration of the document was a minor, aged 15 years, and she was not represented by her natural guardian to constitute the document as valid as she has not attained majority according to law. As per the Contract Act, 1872, it is clearly stated that for an agreement to become a contract, the parties must be competent to contract, wherein age of majority is a condition for competency. A deed of mortgage is a contract and we cannot hold that a mortgage in the name of a minor is valid, simply because it is in the interests of the minor unless she is represented by her natural guardian or guardian appointed by the court. The law cannot be read differently for a minor who is a mortgagor and a minor who is a mortgagee as there are rights and liabilities in respect of the immovable property would flow out of such a contract on both of them. Therefore, the mortgage deed is void ab initio in law and the appellant cannot claim any rights under it.   [Para 9,10]

heading: Simple or usufructuary mortgage
HeadNote.description: Simple or usufructuary mortgage - Mortgage deed stating that mortgagor will not deliver possession as he was paying interest - No delivery of land as per mortgage deed - In absence of express recital to deliver possession of mortgaged property, mortgage was simple mortgage and not a usufructuary mortgage. (Para 11)

heading: Doctrine of lis pendens
HeadNote.description:
Doctrine of lis pendens - Applicability.

The doctrine applies, if the conditions laid down therein are satisfied, namely, (i) that the suit or proceeding must be pending, (2) that such suit or proceeding must not be collusive, (3) that the suit or proceeding must be one in which the right to immovable property is directly and substantially in question, and (4) a notice of pendency of the suit is registered (applicable under the Maharashtra Amendment). Once these conditions are satisfied, the property cannot be transferred or otherwise dealt with by any party to the suit or proceeding so as to affect any rights of the other party under any decree or order which may be passed therein. [Para 13]

heading: Lease or Licence
Determination of transaction
HeadNote.description:
Lease or Licence - Determination of transaction - Giving of exclusive possession of premises is prima facie considered to be lease transaction - Further, if terms of documents are not clear, conduct of parties have to be borne in mind to ascertain relationship between parties. 

In the instant case as per the plaintiff's own deposition in his examination-in-chief as well as in cross-examination, the defendants were put in exclusive possession of suit premises with their consent. Despite that plaintiffs raised the objection against the possession of defendants over the suit premises. It is to be noted that such objection was raised only after a long period of 9 years. Plaintiffs falsely averred in the plaint that the defendants were temporarily engaged by them to run the business of bar and restaurant on the suit premises and thus denied the legality of possession of suit premises by the defendants. Contrary to the above averments made in plaint, plaintiff in his own letter of consent written to the other parties, made reference  to collection of 'rent' which indicates the nature of transaction to be a Lease. There was no reference to collection of 'compensation or royalty' indicating the transaction of licence. 

Held, in the instant case, the inaction on the part of plaintiffs to take back possession for a long period of 9 years, read with their conduct in making false averments in the plaint as well as instructions in their letter to collect 'rent', lead to a conclusion that transaction relating to the suit premises, was a lease and not licence.        [Para 27,32]

heading: Termination of lease
Legality
Lease by conduct
HeadNote.description:
Termination of lease - Legality - Lease by conduct - No written lease deed executed between parties - Defendant, by way of a letter written in 1985 accepted the proposal of lease for 10 years - Thereafter, through another letter written in July 1995 defendant informed the plaintiff that it would pay rent with 20% enhancement for another 5 years and forwarded a cheque towards arrears of rent - Plaintiff merely encashed the cheque with no acceptance letter - Subsequently sent a notice of termination w.e.f. 31.10.1995 - In the circumstances, held, encashment of cheque by plaintiff would not mean lease agreement between parties stood renewed for next five years - In absence of any written and registered deed, it would be a month to month lease - Plaintiff landlord can terminate the lease at the expiry of any month with necessary notice and without any explanation - Hence, termination of lease cannot be said to be illegal.

(2000) 6 SCC 394, (1977) 2 SCC 646 Ref. to.	 [Para 36,37]

heading: Lis pendens
HeadNote.description:
Lis pendens - Applicability of the principle - What is important is pendency of suit or proceedings and not the decision rendered therein or its effect.
2013(5) ALL MR 919 (S.C.) Rel. on. (Para 27)

heading: Eviction
