HeadNote.description: Eviction - Exclusive use of premises - Defendant occupying premises of plaintiff - Evidence of prosecution witness states that W.C. was in occasional use of plaintiff - Further on objection of defendant plaintiff constructed new W.C. - Plaintiff's use of W.C. was only when he was in city - User of plaintiff though limited and occasional, it was permissive - Joint use of W.C. by parties does not negate exclusive possession of defendant in property - Finding of lower courts is liable to be upheld.  (Paras 10, 11)

heading: Protection under S.53A
HeadNote.description: Protection under S.53A - Defendant is in possession of property by virtue of document of lease from previous owner - Property was given on lease for 10 years on unregistered document - Instrument is invalid in view of S.107 of T.P. Act - Therefore, there cannot be any transfer of any interest under document to defendant - Protection under S.53A not available.(Para 29)

heading: Protection under S.53A
HeadNote.description: Protection under S.53A - Oral and documentary evidence show that from 1987 itself defendant stopped paying rent - Defendant was asked to pay rent even after sale of property to plaintiff by original owner - Defendant failed to pay rent - Defendant disputed title of plaintiff - Defendant claiming possession under agreement to sell with previous owner - However, defendant could not prove agreement - Defendant failed to prove that it was ready, willing to perform its part of contract - Defendant not entitled to protection under S.53A. (Para 33)

heading: Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Termination of tenancy - Various notices were given for asking to vacate premises - After many months of expiry of prescribed period under S.106 suit for possession was filed - In view of 2006(3) ALL MR 369, after 15 days period from date of receipt of notice, suit can be filed - It needs to hold that it was sufficient and valid notice - Therefore, even if it is presumed that defendant was lessee, lease was on month to month basis, there was termination of lease by notice under S.106. 
2006(3) ALL MR 369 Rel.on.  (Para 34)

heading: Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Termination of tenancy - There was no forfeiture of rights as under S.111 (g) - There was only notice of termination of lease as provided under S.106 - It can be said that lease came to end after expiration of this notice period as provided under S.111(h). 
1989 (4) SCC 732 Disting. (Para 36)

heading: Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Termination of tenancy - Defendant is tenant in property of society - Defendant claiming that Liquidator of Society entered into agreement of sale with him - No record shows that there was approval to so called proposal given by Liquidator - No enforceable agreement had come into existence - Further, when property belongs to society it is always desirable that property is sold by public auction - Refusal to relief of specific performance held proper.
AIR 1963 SC 1685 Disting. (Para 38)

heading: Termination of lease
HeadNote.description:
Termination of lease - Lease deed provided two months advance notice of intention to renew lease for a further period of twenty years - Such notice not sent by lessee though lessee continued to pay rent in respect of demised premises - Held, determination of tenancy by lessor was perfectly legal and valid.

(2007) 6 SCC 81 Rel. on. 	 [Para 23,25]

heading: Lessee continuing in possession after termination of lease
HeadNote.description: Lessee continuing in possession after termination of lease - Possession is that of a trespasser and he is liable to pay mesne profits by way of damages. (Para 23)

heading: Lessor mortgaging property
Mortgagee in possession
HeadNote.description: Notice of renewal on determination of lease - Lessor mortgaging property - Mortgagee in possession - He continued to be mortgagee till property was redeemed in his favour - Lessee sending notice of renewal of lease not to the mortgagee who had stepped into shoes of the owner of property but to the original lessor - Lessee is not entitled to renewal of lease.			(Para 23)

heading: Lease Agreement
HeadNote.description: Lease Agreement - Agreement required to be read as a whole.	(Para 30)

heading: Lease Agreement
Ambiguity
HeadNote.description: Lease Agreement - Ambiguity - When an ambiguity exists in the document, the surrounding circumstances are relevant for construction of a document. 2006(6) Mh.L.J. 257 - Ref. to.	(Para 32)

heading: Transfer pendente lite
HeadNote.description:
Transfer pendente lite - Pendente lite transfer without permission of the court is neither illegal nor void - S.52 does not put any restraint on a party to the suit from alienating the suit property but it provides for the legal effect of the transfer pendente lite. 

2011(1) ALL MR 462 - Ref. to. (Para 14)

heading: Transfer pendente lite
Prohibitory injunction
HeadNote.description: Transfer pendente lite - Prohibitory injunction - The effect of the order of prohibitory injunction restraining the alienation during the pendency of the suit is that any transaction or alienation made in violation of the said order is rendered illegal - The order of prohibitory injunction grants protection which is not available under S.52 in the event of a transfer pending a suit - Moreover, the party who breaches the order of temporary injunction may have to face the drastic consequences provided in Rr.2A & 11 of O.39 of Civil P.C. - The consequences are in the nature of an order of detention or striking out the defence. (Para 17)

heading: Scope of
HeadNote.description:
Scope of - Powers of civil court - Provisions of S.52 of T.P. Act do not in any manner put fetters on the powers of civil court conferred by O.39 Rr.1, 2 of Civil P.C.

2005(5) ALL MR 458 (S.C.) - Rel.on. (Paras 24, 26)

heading: Scope and applicability of
HeadNote.description: Scope and applicability of - Transaction between parties a plain and simple loan transaction - S.53-A of T.P. Act is not attracted.	(Para 16)

heading: Part performance of contract
HeadNote.description: Part performance of contract - Essential condition for exercise of S.53A - In order to attract it, there must be a contract in writing and terms of transaction must be capable of being ascertained from language of written document.	(Para 18)

heading: Telegraphic notice terminating tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Telegraphic notice terminating tenancy - Is not a valid notice as it does not satisfy requirement of signature of lessor - It would not have been sufficient by itself to terminate tenancy of tenant.
AIR 1990 AP 169 Foll.  (Paras 9, 11)

heading: Part performance
Agreement of sale
HeadNote.description: Part performance - Agreement of sale - Petitioner put in possession of suit field - Concurrent finding of courts below that petitioner failed to perform her part of contract - Held, petitioner not entitled to protection of S.53A - Decree for possession allowing counter claim, upheld.(Para 18)

heading: Contract to contrary
HeadNote.description: Contract to contrary - Contract for sale of Trust property - Laws of West Bengal where Trust was registered not requiring permission from Endowment Department for alienation of Trust property - Question of refusing a decree for specific performance of contract for sale could not arise at all on this ground alone.			(Para 13)

heading: Part performance
Protection under S.53-A
HeadNote.description: Part performance - Protection under S.53-A - Court may consider whether such protection could be granted to a party even in absence of specific pleadings, if such plea is made out on basis of evidence tendered during trial.	(Para 8)

heading: Entitlement to
HeadNote.description: Equitable relief under S.53-A - Entitlement to - Dormant litigant who did not express willingness to perform his part of the agreement of sale - Would not get benefit under S.53-A - He must plead and prove that he was ready and willing to perform his part of agreement of sale in order to get equitable relief under S.53-A.		(Para 12)

heading: Term 'willingness' used in S.53-A
HeadNote.description: Term 'willingness' used in S.53-A - Does imply 'readiness and willingness' used in S.16 of Specific Relief Act.	(Para 13)

heading: Protection under
HeadNote.description: Doctrine of 'Part performance' - Protection under - Appellant (defendant) failing to prove his readiness and willigness to perform his part of agreement of Sale from date of agreement till death of vendor - Deceased plaintiff had stepped into shoes of vendor due to purchase transaction depicted in sale deed - Under circumstances deceased plaintiff was entitled to claim possession of suit land on basis of his title - Appellant cannot claim legal protection under doctrine of part performance.			(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Non-registration of gift-deed
Effect
HeadNote.description:
Gift of immovable property - Non-registration of gift-deed - Effect - Unregistered document shall not have the effect of transfer of title.

In the instant case, defendant has claimed his title over suit property on the strength of an unregistered gift deed executed by plaintiff community court observed the following :-

By virtue of S.17 of Registration Act, unregistered instrument executed in favour of defendant by the plaintiff community will not vest any title in him and, furthermore, the document being not in consonance with S.123 of Transfer of Property Act, cannot be construed as evidence entitling defendant to claim the property.  Unregistered instrument of gift shall have no effect of transfer of title.  Thus it can be concluded that no title has been passed in favour of defendant by virtue of unregistered instrument of gift which is in conflict with the provisions of S.17 of Registration Act and S.123 of Transfer of Property Act.  [Para 8]

heading: Mortgage
Validity of
HeadNote.description: Mortgage - Validity of - Can be questioned only by parties to mortgage - Third party who has purchased mortgaged property during operation of interim order, has no right to question it. 	(Para 16)

heading: Equitable mortgage
HeadNote.description: Equitable mortgage - Created at Belgaum, is valid - As Belgaum is in list of notified places issued by State of Karnataka for deposit of title deeds - Merely because original gazette has not been placed before Court, would not mean that no equitable mortgage can be created at Belgaum. 	(Para 17)

heading: Essential ingredients of
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by deposit of title deeds - Essential ingredients of - Three essential ingredients are existence of debt, deposit of title deeds and an intention that deeds shall be security for debt. 	(Para 18)

heading: Perpetual lease
Bungalow also constructed
HeadNote.description: Perpetual lease - Land given on lease to factory - Bungalow also constructed - Terms of lease deed showed that it was for fixed period of 30 years without option of renewal - Allowing construction of bungalow was only ancillary to factory - Further sale-deed in favour of defendants clearly stated land is on fixed period of lease - Letter by defendants to lessor stating expiry of lease and asking for renewal - This shows defendants were aware of fixed period of lease - Hence, finding that lease is not perpetual is not liable to be interfered with. AIR 1962 SC 413, A.I.R. 1953 S.C. 153 - Followed.	(Para 11)

heading: Notice of termination
HeadNote.description: Notice of termination - Lease of land for fixed period of 30 years - Lease came to end by efflux of time - Notice under S.106 not necessary unless tenant is holding over - Suit cannot be bad for non-issuance of notice.	(Para 12)

heading: Inference as to
Suits for recovery
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by deposit of title deeds - Inference as to - Suits for recovery - Respondent guarantors denied claim of bank against them - However, documents on record shows that respondent guarantors deposited their title deeds with appellant bank on the very day on which loan transaction in question took place - Deposit of title deeds were accompanied by various agreements, affidavits as well as title verification certificates as required - Intention to create security for repayment of loan availed by principal debtor on part of respondent guarantors can be drawn - Same would be sufficient to culminate transaction into mortgage by deposit of title deeds - Plea of requirement of registration, unsustainable.	(Paras 24, 32)

heading: Registration Act (1908)
Registration
Requirement
HeadNote.description: Registration Act (1908) - Mortgage by deposit of title deeds - Registration - Requirement - Held, document fortifying "intention to create security" - Is neither an agreement to mortgage or a mortgage - Does not require registration.	(Para 24)

heading: Part performance
HeadNote.description: Part performance - Conflict of interest between occupant (who occupies property pursuant to part performance) and subsequent bonafide purchaser - Defendant occupied suit property pursuant to sale agreement of 1975 - However, despite repeated requests, sale deed not executed by owners - No efforts taken by defendant to enforce sale agreement by filing suit for specific performance - Readiness and willingness on his part, not established - On the other hand, suit property sold by owners to plaintiff in 1982 - At that time, plaintiff was told that defendant is occupying suit property as tenant - Soon after purchase, plaintiff filed suit for eviction of defendant - This itself indicates bonafides of plaintiff - Plaintiff proved that he had no notice of part performance - In view of failure of defendant to enforce sale agreement or to show that further performance was either prevented or waived by owners, he is not entitled to protection u/S.53A of T.P. Act - Sale deed of plaintiff is still valid and subsisting - Rejection of plaintiff's suit for declaration of title, improper. 			(Paras 24, 25, 29, 30, 31, 32)

heading: Part performance
HeadNote.description: Part performance - Mere delay in filing suit for specific performance of contract, would not bar a person to assert protection of S.53A of T.P. Act - Nevertheless, essential pre-requisites of (i) written agreement (ii) possession of property pursuant to part performance (iii) readiness and willingness to perform contract, must be established. 2002(2) ALL MR 267 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 19, 27)

heading: Scope of S.53A
HeadNote.description:
Scope of S.53A - Stated.

As per provision of S.53A it is not open for a licensee to set up title in himself or any other person once license is revoked by the licensor. It is the duty of the licensee to hand over possession or surrender possession of the property occupied by him as a licensee and seek his remedy separately if, according to him, he has acquired title to the property qua the licensor. Licensor is always entitled to proceed for recovery of possession when licensee fails to deliver possession of the property in question after termination of the licence. Only in exceptional cases wherein licensee may have claimed merger of his title with licensor's title, his possession may be protected.   [Para 13]

heading: Sale deed
Execution of
HeadNote.description: Sale deed - Execution of - Necessity of attesting witness - Execution of sale deed does not need attesting witness like gift deed - Also provisions of S.68 of Evidence Act which require examination of attesting witness to prove execution of document, does not apply to sale deed u/S.54 TP Act. 		(Para 20)

heading: Interim compensation
HeadNote.description: Interim compensation - For stay of execution of decree of eviction - Whether to be awarded from date of decree or from date of expiration of termination of lease notice - Tenant was found in wrongful possession of suit premises after expiry of period of termination of lease notice issued on 9th Jan, 2012 - Decree of eviction passed in May 2016 - As it being open plot and tenant did not get protection under MRC Act, 1999, he would be contractual tenant and tenancy between parties would be governed by T.P. Act - In view of S.106 r/w S.111(h) of T.P. Act, lease of immovable property not for agricultural or industrial purpose shall be terminable upon 15 days' notice either by lessee or lesser - Thus, tenant would be in wrongful possession of suit plot from 25th January, 2012 - Whether inquiry under O.20 R.12, CPC has been completed or otherwise, is immaterial - Interim compensation fixed by Court ought to have been from 1st Feb, 2012 till disposal of appeal. (2005) 1 SCC 705 Rel. on. 			(Paras 13, 15, 16. 17, 18)

heading: Agreement to lease immovable property
HeadNote.description:
Agreement to lease immovable property - Does not create any right in an immovable property - However "agreement of lease" creates right in immovable property.

Ownership of immovable property is a bundle of various rights. Obviously, one of such right is a "right to lease" such an immovable property. A right to sell is another such right from the aforesaid bundle of rights. Only to the aforesaid limited context a "right to sell" is something which is similar, if not higher, to a "right to lease" an immovable property. It is well-settled position of law that an "agreement to sell" does not create any legal interest in the immovable property. Though an agreement to sell is enforceable in law, such an agreement does not by itself create any right, title or interest in the immovable property. Certainly, an "agreement to sell" creates rights which are similar (if not higher) in nature as are created by an "agreement to lease". Therefore, if an agreement to sell does not create any right in an immovable property, obviously, an agreement to lease also does not create any right in an immovable property.  [Para 98,99]

heading: Lease or licence
HeadNote.description: Lease or licence - Plaintiff claimed that he was lessee - Lease agreement styled as agreement of licence - Plaintiff suddenly received notice to vacate suit shop on ground that liquor business being carried out from suit shop creates nuisance - Change of user of suit shop amounts to breach of condition of licence - Controversy between parties related to agreement 'Parwana Prapatra' whether it is lease or license - Agreement grants possession of suit shop with right to enjoy possession - Defendant/Corporation allowed plaintiff to obtain electricity meter - Also agreed to mutate the shop in name of legal heir, in event of death of occupier - Plaintiff even changed user of suit shop twice - Circumstances coupled with conditions in agreement show intention of party to grant lease and not license. (Paras 13, 14, 15, 16, 17)

heading: Leave
Validity
HeadNote.description: Leave - Notice to vacate property - Validity - Defendant Corporation granted lease of suit shop to plaintiff - By notice defendant granted just 3 days to vacate suit shop - Such notice is clear violation of S.106 T.P. Act.(Paras 17, 19)

heading: Sale
Undue influence
HeadNote.description: Sale - Undue influence - Appellant purchaser was employer of widows of deceased who was protected tenant in land - Being in dominant position and taking undue advantage of relationship, appellant forced widows to execute sale deed in his favour - Concurrent findings by both courts below - Sale liable to be set aside.  (Para 33)

heading: Sale
HeadNote.description: Sale - Appellants are not bonafide purchasers - Appellants misused their dominant position and used undue influence against vendor - Appellants acquired property without consideration and in absence of legal necessity - Respondent vendors must be compensated - Cost is liable to be imposed on appellant purchasers.  (Para 35)

heading: Property
Title
Lease
Opposite claims
Payment of rent
HeadNote.description: Property - Title - Lease - Opposite claims - Payment of rent - Although title in respect of an immovable property may have different concepts, it is fundamental that title of the same nature cannot be found to be existing in two different persons where their claims thereover are opposite - Payment or non-payment of rent does not create or extinguish title.	(Paras 23, 25)

heading: Nozul land
Existence of lease
Proof of
HeadNote.description: Nozul land - Existence of lease - Proof of - In a case involving the State and particularly when nature of land is said to be Nazul land, it was imperative on the part of the State to execute a deed of lease - As execution of such a document has not been proved, Trial Judge committed a manifest error in solely relying upon entries made in the revenue record of rights.	(Para 25)

heading: Lis pendens
Partition suit pending
HeadNote.description:
Lis pendens - Partition suit pending - Sale by respondent in favour of appellant hit by pending partition suit - Respondent, however, cannot avoid sale made by her on ground that she was held to be not exclusive owner in pending partition suit - Court ought to have decreed appellant's suit in part in regard to portion that fell to the share of respondent, instead of dismissing the suit.

The principle underlying Section 52 is clear. If during the pendency of any suit in a court of competent jurisdiction which is not collusive, in which any right of an immovable property is directly and specifically in question, such property cannot be transferred by any party to the suit so as to affect the rights of any other party to the suit under any decree that may be made in such suit. If ultimately the title of the pendente lite transferor is upheld in regard to the transferred property, the transferee's title will not be affected. On the other hand, if the title of the pendente lite transferor is recognized or accepted only in regard to a part of the transferred property, then the transferee's title will be saved only in regard to that extent and the transfer in regard to the remaining portion of the transferred property to which the transferor is found not entitled, will be invalid and the transferee will not get any right, title or interest in that portion. If the property transferred pendente lite, is allotted in entirety to some other party or parties or if the transferor is held to have no right or title in that property, the transferee will not have any title to the property. Where a co-owner alienates a property or a portion of a property representing to be the absolute owner, equities can no doubt be adjusted while making the division during the final decree proceedings, if feasible and practical (that is without causing loss or hardship or inconvenience to other parties) by allotting the property or portion of the property transferred pendente lite, to the share of the transferor, so that the bonafide transferee's right and title are saved fully or partially.   [Para 10]

In this case, a suit for partition filed by the first respondent against the second respondent in the year 1985 which included the suit property, was pending in a court of competent jurisdiction as on the date of sale (11.4.1990) by the second respondent in favour of the appellant. The partition suit was not collusive. Having regard to Section 52 of the Act, the sale by the second respondent in favour of the appellant did not in any way affect the right of the first respondent (plaintiff in the partition suit) or the decree made in her favour in the said partition suit. It is thus evident that the sale by second respondent in favour of the appellant though not void, did not bind the first respondent who was the plaintiff in the partition suit. On the other hand, the sale in favour of appellant was subject to the right declared or recognized in favour of the first respondent-plaintiff under the decree passed in the pending partition suit. The sale pendente lite would therefore be subject to the decree in the partition suit.   [Para 11]

heading: Lis pendens
HeadNote.description: Lis pendens - Difficulties in ascertaining whether any suit or proceeding is pending in respect of suit property - Amendment to S.52 on the lines of amendment made to S.52 by the State of Maharashtra or other suitable amendment should be considered by Law Commission and Parliament.			(Paras 13, 14, 15)

heading: Eviction of tenant
HeadNote.description: Eviction of tenant - Regd. A.D. Notice issued by landlord - Returned as not claimed - Notice also issued U.C.P. served on tenant - Copy of notice affixed on conspicuous place of tenanted premises - Issuance of notice is valid - It carries presumption of service - Tenant also not denying demand notice - Tenant is held to be defaulter in remittance of rent and liable to be evicted. Evidence Act (1872), S.114(e).		(Para 12)

heading: Lease of land
HeadNote.description:
Lease of land - Tenant constructing structure with permission of landlord but letting it out without permission of landlord - Decree of eviction against tenant - Sub-tenants cannot claim protection of S.14 or 15A of Rent Act.

AIR 1964 SC 1348, AIR 1980 SC 1605, 1986 Mh RCJ 376, 1987 Mh RCJ 701, AIR 1985 Bom 429 Rel on. 73 Bom LR 140 Not followed. (Para 24)

heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction - Receiver appointed during pendency of suit - Tenancy created by Receiver though he was not authorised to do so - Receiver not discharged by specific order when suit was decreed and he continued to collect rent - No tenancy rights are thereby conferred on persons paying rent.

Civil P.C. (1908), O.40, R.1.

AIR 1993 Bom 285, 1993(2) Bom CR 137, AIR 1991 SC 899 Rel on. (Para 26,27)

heading: Attornment of tenancy
Several tenants
HeadNote.description:
Attornment of tenancy - Several tenants - Letter addressed to one of them and asking them to pay rent to the landlord - It cannot amount to attornment of tenancy.

AIR 1967 SC 174 Rel on. (Para 29)

heading: Gift deed
Construction
HeadNote.description: Gift deed - Construction - Donor giving one of his properties to his wife by way of gift - Wife (donee) restrained from alienating the property - Clear stipulation in deed that expenses for daughters' marriage be done from gifted property - Deed further stipulating that donor can adopt son to properties other than gifted property - Wife also given similar right to adopt - Deed further stipulating that on donor's death whether there is adoption or no adoption the property would go to his daughters - Deed read as whole bring out concern of donor towards welfare of his wife and daughters and clear segregation of gifted property from other properties in case of adoption - In circumstances finding that daughters, after adoption of son by donor, are left with no interest in gifted property, is unjustified. 	(Paras 21, 22)

heading: Quit notice
HeadNote.description: Quit notice - Not to be construed strictly in favour of tenant - Language of notice clearly conveying intention of lessor that tenant should vacate premises - Period stated therein however falling short of notice period specified in S.106 - Even such mistake would not invalidate notice if eviction suit is filed after expiry of period specified. 	(Para 17)

heading: Quit notice
Validity
HeadNote.description: Quit notice - Validity - Notice clearly terminating tenancy and asking tenant to quit and vacate premises - Mention in notice of an earlier date on which tenancy stood terminated - Does not invalidate notice when suit was filed moths after notice. 	(Paras 19, 20)

heading: Eviction suit
HeadNote.description: Eviction suit - Specific plea about validity of quit notice - Ought to be raised in written statement - If not so raised objection shall be deemed to have been waived. 	(Paras 23, 24)

heading: Hindu Law
Bonafide purchaser
HeadNote.description: Hindu Law - Bonafide purchaser - Plaintiff No.1 mother, No.2 son objected sale of jointly acquired house by defendant No.2 son alone - Purchaser did not enter witness box to make out her claim - In another suit by Purchaser it is asserted that disputed house belonged to joint family - It is clear that purchaser had knowledge that property is owned jointly - Plaintiff No.1 mother, no.2 son and defendant no.2 son have equal share in jointly acquired house property - Purchaser who purchased house from defendant No.2 son alone is not bonafide purchaser - Second Appeal by purchaser is liable to be dismissed.	(Para 10)

heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction - Jurisdiction of Civil Court - Suit premises not coming within ambit of Rent Act on the date of filing of suit - But was included by a subsequent notification - Held, law applicable on the date of filing of suit will continue to apply until suit is disposed of or adjudicated - Therefore, Civil Court would not cease to have jurisdiction after Rent Act made applicable to suit premises - Principles of law laid down in this regard by Apex Court in certain cases, summarized.

i) 	Rights of the parties stand crystallised on the date of the institution of the suit and, therefore, the law applicable on the date of filing of the suit will continue to apply until suit is disposed of or adjudicated

ii) 	If during the pendency of the suit, Rent Act becomes applicable to the premises in question, that would be of no consequence and it would not take away the jurisdiction of civil court to dispose of a suit validly instituted.

iii) 	In order to oust the jurisdiction of civil court, there must be a specific provision in the Act taking away the jurisdiction of the civil court in respect of those cases also which were validly instituted before the date when protection of Rent Act became available in respect of the said area/premises/tenancy.

iv) 	In case aforesaid position is not accepted and the protection of the Rent Act is extended even in respect of suit validly instituted prior in point of time when there was no such protection under the Act, it will have the consequence of making the decree, that is obtained prior to the Rent Act becoming applicable to the said area/premises, inexecutable after the application of these Rent Act in respect of such premises. This would not be in consonance with the legislative intent. (1988) 4 SCC 284, (1984) 3 SCC 352, (1980) 3 SCC 452, (1998) 2 SCC 710 Foll.   [Para 16]

heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - Applicability of Rent Act - High Court divided cases in two categories - First, where Rent Act exempts from its applicability newly constructed properties for a period of 10 yrs. - Second category covers those cases where Rent Act was not applicable during pendency of suit for eviction - Such distinction is illusory - Principle of law that right of parties get crystallized on date of filing of suit and law applicable on date of filing of suit would continue to govern such suit, would equally apply to both categories.  (Para 18)

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description: Sale or mortgage by conditional sale - Determination - Language employed in deed is essential for determination - When language employed in deed is sufficiently clear, one has to ordinarily go by such language - Language of document shows that transfer of suit land was for period of two years for taking crops - After completion of two years and after taking crop for second year, transferor was entitled to redeem land by repaying sum of Rs.10,000/- paid by transferee to him at time of execution of document of conditional sale - Terms of document clearly shows that there was no absolute or outright sale of property with agreement for repurchase coupled with it as alleged by appellant - It also proves relationship of debtor and creditor between parties and not vendor and buyer - Document is of mortgage by conditional sale.	(Paras 6, 7, 10)

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description: Sale or mortgage by conditional sale - Determination - There cannot be any absolute proposition of law that whenever document of conditional sale provides for right of redemption i.e. to repurchase property, to transferor but no express right of foreclosure to transferee, document is an absolute sale and not mortgage by conditional sale - Crucial question always is, whether relationship between parties is that of debtor and creditor, or vendor and purchaser - If it is former, document is mortgage, whereas in case of latter, it is sale. 			(Para 6)

heading: Determination of
HeadNote.description: Sale or mortgage by conditional sale - Determination of - Language employed in deed is essential for determining nature of document - When language employed in deed is sufficiently clear, one has to ordinarily go by such language - As effort of Court was to ascertain effect of words used in document and not to find out what parties intended - However, if words are not clear it is permissible to look at surrounding circumstances to ascertain intent of documents. 	(Para 6)

heading: Applicability of Mohammedan Law
HeadNote.description: Applicability of Mohammedan Law - Exclusion of provisions of Chap.2 - Such exclusion is conditional upon existence of corresponding rule in Mohammedan law - Plea that principle of lis pendens u/S.52 of T.P. Act would not apply when parties to litigation are Muslims - Not tenable, unless it is shown that rules of Mohammedan law also contain provision as to lis pendens.  (Para 24)

heading: Lis pendens
Applicability of doctrine
HeadNote.description: Lis pendens - Applicability of doctrine - Proceedings whether pending at time of sale - Respondent claiming share in suit property on basis of sale deed of 1959 - Contended that between 1955 to 1962, there was no proceeding pending in respect of suit property - However, record shows that suit for partition in respect of said property was filed in 1935 - Due to change in legal position and abolition of certain courts, case was transferred to City Civil Court - In Jan. 1955, case was closed by said Court for non-availability of file - In Dec.1955, case was allowed to be reopened subject to payment of certain costs - As no such payment was made, court ordered dismissal of suit in Dec. 1955 itself - Said dismissal was set aside only in 1962 by High Court - High Court made it clear that case was only closed in Jan. 1955 and not dismissed, therefore imposition of costs and consequent dismissal in Dec. 1955 was based on misconception - In view of said finding, it cannot be said that there was no proceeding pending between 1955 to 1962 - Purchase by respondent is hit by doctrine of lis pendens.  (Para 32)

heading: Lis pendens
Effect of doctrine
HeadNote.description: Lis pendens - Effect of doctrine - Sale transaction (entered during pendency of suit) is not rendered void - Subject to the outcome of suit, said transaction is valid to the extent of share of vendor only - Meaning thereby, purchaser would be entitled to share of vendor in the suit property. 2010 ALL SCR 2356, 2012(4) ALL MR 481 (S.C.), 2013(3) ALL MR 408 (S.C.) Ref. to. (Para 36)

heading: Lis pendens
HeadNote.description: Lis pendens - Sale of suit property (to third party) during pendency of partition suit - Parties to the suit not required to file separate suit for cancellation of pendente lite sale - Section 52 of T.P. Act prevents multiplicity of proceedings. 2014(4) ALL MR 901 (S.C.) Ref. to.  (Para 40)

heading: Pendente lite sale
HeadNote.description: Pendente lite sale - Joint property sold by co-owner beyond his share in said property - Equity in favour of purchasers - Purchaser cannot claim entire property to be allotted to him - On equity, he will be entitled to property only to the extent of share of vendor - Further, in absence of requisite pleadings and evidence, purchaser cannot even be granted the share of vendor in other properties.  (Para 82)

heading: Lease
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Lease - Repudiation of title of lessor by lessee - Suit for possession by lessor - Maintainability - Defendant denounced title of plaintiff-lessor and claimed ownership by way of adverse possession - Thereby forfeited his rights of tenancy - Therefore, suit for possession by lessor held, maintainable.  (Para 25)

heading: Mortgage by conditional sale
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale - Where two agreements entered into between parties, one of sale and another of re-conveyance, agreement of re-conveyance could not be construed as mortgage by conditional sale - Transaction shall not be deemed to be mortgage by conditional sale unless condition for re-conveyance is contained in document purporting to effect sale. 2000 (3) SCC 536, 2006 SAR (Civil) 272 Rel. on. 	(Paras 48, 49, 51)

heading: Termination of tenancy
Governing provision
HeadNote.description: Termination of tenancy - Governing provision - In absence of registration of an agreement, what is deemed to be created is a month to month tenancy - Termination of which is governed by S.106 of TP Act. (2000) 6 SCC 394 Ref. to. 	(Para 11)

heading: Contract of tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Contract of tenancy - Phrase 'contract to the contrary' in S.106 of TP Act, cannot be read to mean that parties are free to contract out the express provisions of law, thereby defeating its very intent.

In the instant case While the unregistered agreement dated 07.08.2006 can be admitted in evidence and even relied upon by the parties to prove the factum of the tenancy, the terms of the same cannot be used to derogate from the statutory provision of Section 106 of the Act, which creates a fiction of tenancy in absence of a registered instrument creating the same. If the argument advanced on behalf of the respondents is taken to its logical conclusion, this lease can never be terminated, save in cases of breach by the tenant. Accepting this argument would mean that in a situation where the tenant does not default on rent payment for three consecutive months, or does not commit a breach of the terms of the lease, it is not open to the lessor to terminate the lease even after giving a notice. This interpretation of the clause 6 of the agreement cannot be permitted as the same is wholly contrary to the express provisions of the law. The phrase 'contract to the contrary' in Section 106 of the Act cannot be read to mean that the parties are free to contract out of the express provisions of the law, thereby defeating its very intent. 	 [Para 12]

heading: Transfer pendent lite
Permissibility
HeadNote.description: Transfer pendent lite - Impleadment of subsequent purchaser at the stage of second appeal - Permissibility - Suit for specific performance - Defendant sold suit property to third party - Subsequent purchaser has no privity of contract with plaintiff - Such subsequent purchaser not entitled to defeat otherwise sustainable decree in favour of plaintiff by seeking intervention in second appeal - Though he may have remedy against defendant to claim damages for breach of agreement. 	(Para 18)

heading: Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with condition of repurchase
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with condition of repurchase - Plaintiff took loan and to secure its repayment executed document styled as deed of conditional sale in favour of defendant - Document contains condition of repurchase on offering of loan amount without interest - As defendant was allowed to remain in possession of suit property and to enjoy fruit of land till amount is repaid - Document is mortgage by conditional sale.  2008 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 90 Rel. on. 2013 ALL SCR 2679 Held, per incuriam.	(Paras 25, 26, 27, 29, 30, 32)

heading: Suit for redemption of mortgage
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgage - Question as to whether transaction is sale with condition to repurchase or mortgage by conditional sale - Reading of original document showing that it is styled as sale deed - Recitals are specific that vendor was in need of money to run vehicle purchased by him on hire and was selling suit shop to raise money for said purpose - Also that if the amount was returned within 5 yrs., purchaser would execute sale deed in favour of vendor - No reference to any loan taken or mortgage created with regard to any immovable property as security for such loan - Document does not evince creation of a debtor-creditor relationship - Therefore, same was a sale deed with an option to repurchase and not a mortgage by conditional sale. 1963 Supp (2) SCR 82, 1993 Supp (1) SCC 295 Ref. to.  (Paras 7, 8, 10)

heading: Transfer of property
Determination
HeadNote.description: Transfer of property - Transaction whether sale with condition to repurchase or mortgage by conditional sale - Determination - True nature of document has to be determined in facts of each case - Dependent on nature of recitals in document, intention of parties coupled with other attendant surrounding circumstances - There can be no hard and fast rule for determining nature of document, devoid of these circumstances. (Para 5)

heading: Determination of
HeadNote.description: Sale or mortgage by conditional sale - Determination of - Mortgagor executed document as security for loan of Rs.1500/- - Land was not transferred absolutely - Mortgagor had right to repurchase suit land on repayment of Rs.1500/- within period of 10 years - Mortgagee was entitled to enjoy land for 10 years by taking crop on suit land - Document contained condition that only on failure of mortgagor to repay amount within period of 10 years document shall be treated as sale - Document is mortgage by conditional sale and not absolute sale. 2008 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 90 Rel. on. 			(Para 8)

heading: Suit for redemption of mortgage
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgage - Powers of Appellate Court - To order reconveyance of suit property to mortgagor - Plaintiff in suit for redemption of mortgage also claimed relief of possession of suit property - U/S.60 redemption of mortgage by conditional sale itself implies retransfer of mortgaged property to mortgagor at mortgagor's cost where suit property is in possession of mortgagee - Appellate court passed order of reconveyance of suit property to mortgagor as mortgage money was paid by mortgagor - Hence, order of reconveyance held, proper. 	(Para 13)

heading: Lease of premises for manufacturing bakery products
HeadNote.description:
Lease of premises for manufacturing bakery products - Lease for more than one year - Lease deed showing monthly tenancy, rent payable every month - Lease is terminable by one month's notice- S.106 does not apply.

The reading of first part of S.106 which relates to lease of immovable property for agricultural or manufacturing purpose, would show that in absence of a specific contract in this regard between the parties, such lease shall be deemed to be a lease from year to year, terminable by six months' notice.  The scheme of this part of the provision would come into effect only if there is no contract between the lessor and the lessee in respect of immovable property for agricultural or manufacturing purpose.  The contingency contemplated in this part of the provision takes effect only in absence of a contract for this purpose and not otherwise.  The intent of the provision is apparent that in absence of such contract and if the lease pertains to immovable property, which is for manufacturing purpose, deeming fiction is created and by virtue of such deeming fiction, such lease will be deemed to be a lease from year to year basis, and not otherwise.  In order to get the protection of the deeming provision, the requisite contingency is absence of contract.  It is, no doubt, true that the purpose for which the tenancy is created has a bearing in determining the nature of lease.  However, that would be available only in absence of the contract.  It will be difficult to hold that merely because the duration is more than one year and the lease is created for manufacturing purpose, one can jump to the conclusion that the same is from year to year without considering the other stipulations in such agreement.  Under the scheme of Section 106, such interpretation is permissible only in absence of the contract.  In the instant case the stipulations in deed of lease in no uncertain terms demonstrate that the intention of the parties was to create monthly tenancy though the period of lease was more than one year.  However, the tenancy was from month to month.  [Para 15,16,17]

There is no prohibition in law, factual or otherwise, for creation of lease for a period more than one year and by agreement of parties the rent may be payable every month.  Such document of contract of lease is perfectly sustainable in law.  The intention of the parties to the lease, whether to treat such lease to be a lease for year to year or month to month is required to be ascertained from the stipulation in such Agreement of Lease.  The contingency, which is contemplated in the first half of the portion of provisions of Section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act operates or comes into effect only in absence of a contract written or oral and not otherwise.  When there is a document of lease, all the aspects such as duration of lease, nature of lease, i.e., monthly or yearly, would be regulated totally by the stipulations in such document of lease, which demonstrates intention of the parties to the lease and in such situation, provisions of first part of Section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act cannot be said to be applicable.  [Para 21]

heading: Proceedings under Rent Control Order not complete and pending in L.P. Appeal before H.C.
HeadNote.description:
Proceedings under Rent Control Order not complete and pending in L.P. Appeal before H.C. - Issue of quit notice under S.106 and initiation of proceedings is not bad in law - Pendency of proceeding does not operate as stay of proceeding.

The pendency of proceedings does not, by itself, operate as stay of the impugned order unless the court in which such proceedings are pending by way of appeal, revision or otherwise grants a specific order of stay.  In the instant case, it is not in dispute that though the Letters Patent Appeal is pending before the Division Bench of this court, there is no order of interim stay granted by the Division Bench staying effect and operation of the order passed by the Single Judge.  In this view of the matter, the subsequent steps taken by the landlords in issuing the notice under Section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act and filing of suit cannot be said to be invalid in law. [Para 24]

heading: Gift deed
Cancellation of
HeadNote.description: Gift deed - Cancellation of - Gift deed was conditional subject to condition that donee would look after donor and her husband - Gift was also going to take effect after death of donor - There was no complete gift of property during lifetime of donor - Donor has right to cancel gift - Cancellation of gift, proper. 	(Paras 15, 17, 18, 19)

heading: Gift
HeadNote.description: Gift - Transfer of property by way of document in terms whereof executant of document retains possession and reserves right over property which is subject matter of document - Can be termed as gift deed if same is to be accepted by donee during lifetime of executant/donor. 2014(6) ALL MR 976 (S.C.) Rel.on.	(Paras 11, 17)

heading: Legality
HeadNote.description: Decree of redemption of mortgage - Legality - Suit property mortgaged with two mortgagees jointly - One of them subsequently purchased it from mortgagor - It amounts to extinguishment "by act of parties" - Right of said mortgagee extinguished and merged with sale - Decree for redemption could not have been passed - In any case, such a decree passed without following procedure prescribed under O.34 R.7 of CPC - Not sustainable. (2000) 4 SCC 326 Ref.to.	(Paras 31, 32, 33)

heading: Part performance
Agreement to sell
HeadNote.description: Part performance - Protection u/S.53A of TP Act - Agreement to sell - Protection u/S.53A of Act would be available to the person who claims to be in possession by virtue of an agreement to sell only upon satisfying the six conditions contained in S.53A of TP Act - Alleged agreement by father of plaintiff in favour of the defendant not produced - Second agreement by plaintiff in favour of defendant, produced, is merely an acknowledgement - Thus, defendants cannot seek protection u/S.53A of Act. 2002(2) ALL MR 267 (S.C.) Rel. on. 			(Para 18)

heading: Suit for partition and separate possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition and separate possession - In respect of jointly purchased property - By two brothers whose names are added on sale deed as purchasers - But, not as persons who executed document - Sale deed was executed by vendor - Signature of one brother is found as person who presented document for registration and as person in whose name stamp papers were purchased - That would not mean that he was only person in whose favour document was executed - No evidence to show as to extent of share or portion of consideration borne by both brothers - Presumption u/S.45 is applicable - In absence of any rebuttal, both brothers have equal half share in joint property. 2016 ALL SCR 379, 2017(4) ALL MR 448 (S.C.), 2009(3) ALL MR 447 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 13, 14, 15, 16, 17)

heading: Part performance
HeadNote.description: Part performance - Plaintiff claiming suit property based on sale agreement - Possession of property handed over to her - However, concurrent findings recorded by Courts that plaintiff was not ready and willing to perform her part - In absence of essential ingredients of S.53A, held, possession of plaintiff not protected. 			(Para 31)

heading: Sale pending maintenance case
HeadNote.description: Sale pending maintenance case - Charge created on properties of husband - Husband however sold suit property to his close friend i.e. plaintiff - Plaintiff not put in possession - Sale does not appear to be bona fide as it was made with clear intent to defeat wife's claim - No plea made by plaintiff in his application under O.21 R.90 that he was unaware of pendency of maintenance case - Being close friend, plaintiff was aware of long pendency of maintenance case - He is not a bona fide purchaser - Wife's right of maintenance enforceable against plaintiff. 		(Paras 31, 32)

heading: Waiver of forfeiture
Evidence and proof
HeadNote.description: Waiver of forfeiture - Evidence and proof - Landlord issued notice on 25.03.1998, claiming that they had forfeited tenancy - On 30.11.2003 landlord issued notice demanding arrears of rent for about 11 years and 5 months - This would certainly qualify under expression "any other act of lessor showing intention to treat lease as subsisting" - Therefore, there was clear waiver of forfeiture. 	(Para 23)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Doctrine of lis pendens - Applicability - Issue of lis pendens applies when the rights or interests are in question - Sale of minors property by de-facto guardian without legal necessity and without permission of Court - Purchaser got no rights by virtue of sale deed executed by de facto guardian as the same was void - When purchaser had no rights, the subsequent purchaser would have got no title or interest by virtue of sale deed executed in his favour - Doctrine of lis pendens, not applicable. 	(Para 24)

heading: Gift deed
Permissible
HeadNote.description: Gift deed - Execution pending order of status quo - Permissible - As status quo in relation to possession of property is not breached by execution of gift deed. 		(Para 25)

heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction - Whether a document is of leave and licence or of lease - Court has to ascertain the intention of the parties from its terms - Exclusive possession of premises is not the conclusive test - If terms of document are not clear, surrounding circumstances and conduct of parties have also to be borne in mind for ascertaining real relationship between the parties.

While deciding whether a document is of leave and licence or of lease, the court has to ascertain the intention of the parties from its terms.  The way parties choose to describe it is not always determinative of its nature. Exclusive possession of the premises is not the conclusive test.  Though it is an important circumstance in certain cases, other circumstance may disprove the existence of lease.  There is no simple litmus test to distinguish agreement of lease from that of leave and licence.  The intention has to be gathered from the terms of the agreement except where it is proved that the document is a camouflage.  If it is alleged that the document is a camouflage, the mask or veil is required to be removed for determining the true intent and purpose of the document.  If the terms of the document are not clear, the surrounding circumstances and the conduct of the parties have also to be borne in mind for ascertaining the real relationship between the parties. If these principles are applied to the present case, the inevitable conclusion that has to be drawn is that the parties intended to enter into a leave and licence agreement.  The terms of the agreement are very clear and admit of no confusion. AIR 1999 SC 2607 and 2002(3) Mh.L.J. 437 - Followed.   [Para 13,14]

heading: Suit for eviction
Finding not perverse
HeadNote.description:
Suit for eviction - Findings of courts below as to whether document is of leave and licence or of lease - Finding not perverse - Court exercising writ jurisdiction cannot interfere with such findings.

Constitution of India, Art.226. (1988)1 SCC 155 and (1994)6 SCC 271 - Followed.			(Para 26)

heading: Suit for possession
Title of Plaintiff
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Title of Plaintiff - Even if title of landlord is defective, the defendant tenant cannot take advantage of that to raise a contention to non suit the Plaintiff, so long as the defendant has been inducted as tenant by the Plaintiff.	(Para 15)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description:
Bombay Rent Control Order (1949), Cl. 13(1)(a) - Suit for possession - Permission under Rent Control Order - Permission not necessary before terminating tenancy in a case where the lessee renounces his character as such by setting up title in third person or in himself.

Permission under Rent Control Order is not necessary before terminating the tenancy in a case where the lessee renounces his character as such by setting up title in the third person or in himself.  The suit for ejectment after giving the notice of forfeiture of tenancy is maintainable in such a case without permission under Rent Control Order."  This court found that the provisions of clause 13(1)(a) of the Rent Control Order  would come in the way of giving notice without obtaining the permission of the Controller only in respect of classes covered by conditions (1) and (3) of clause (g) of section 111 of the Transfer of Property Act and since the present case falls in the latter category, permission of the Rent Controller would not be necessary for giving notice determining the lease as contemplated by clause (g) of Section 111 of the Transfer of Property Act.  The suit was therefore, maintainable even without obtaining permission of the Controller.  1986 Mh.L.J. 699 - Followed.   [Para 27]

heading: Suit for possession
Forfeiture of tenancy
Disclaimer
HeadNote.description:
Suit for possession - Forfeiture of tenancy - Disclaimer - Mere denial on the part of defendant tenant of Plaintiffs title and ownership vis-a-vis suit property will not amount to disclaimer incurring forfeiture of tenancy.

In the instant case mere denial on the part of the defendant of plaintiff's title and ownership vis-a-vis suit flat, will not amount to disclaimer incurring forfeiture of tenancy.  In addition to this in a strict sense defendant has not renounced his claim as a tenant vis-a-vis suit flat.  As we know from the provisions under section 111(g) of the Transfer of Property Act and more so in condition (2), it is only denial of factum of lease and consequent renouncement of title as a tenant of lease - demised premises and claiming title with himself by adverse possession, the forfeiture to tenancy is incurred.  Therefore, viewed from this angle, there is no forfeiture of tenancy in case of defendant.  1990 Mh.L.J. 18 - Referred to.   [Para 30]

heading: Lease deed
Non-registration
HeadNote.description:
Lease deed - Non-registration - Does not prevent Court from looking into it to ascertain what has happened between parties in respect of property - And in absence of registration a monthly lease has to be deemed to have created between parties.

 2016 ALL SCR 2080 Rel. on. 	(Para 14)

heading: Lease
HeadNote.description: Lease - Whether between landlord and partnership firm or between landlord and one partner in his individual capacity - Unregistered lease deed showing that lease was in favour of one partners in his individual capacity - Deposit and rent however paid from joint account of partners - Business of firm also carried out from demised premises - Such facts do not lead to conclusion that lease was with firm - More so when on death of lessee-partner his heirs had surrendered rights in favour of landlord - And landlord has immediately denied claim of firm and has also returned the cheques sent by firm. 	(Paras 19, 20)

heading: Sham and fraudulent transfer
HeadNote.description: Sham and fraudulent transfer - Leaseholders alienation which was attached - Transfer intended to defect and delay claim of petitioner Bank arising out of two recovery certificates against leaseholders - Development agreements by leaseholders cannot be protected by S.53. (Para 34)

heading: Perpetual lease
HeadNote.description: Perpetual lease - Section applies to permanent or temporary lease - Condition which restrains lessee from alienating lease-hold property is not in any way illegal or void.	(Para 17)

heading: Prior notice of termination of lease in writing
HeadNote.description: Prior notice of termination of lease in writing - Lease deed executed prior to enforcement of T.P.(Amendment) Act, 1929 - Not necessary.	(Para 18)

heading: Perpetual lease
Forfeiture clause
HeadNote.description: Perpetual lease - Partial alienation by lessee - Forfeiture clause - Express condition accepted by lessee not to alienate leasehold property - Lessee transferring only a portion of leased property - Does not constitute violation of express condition - Lessor cannot invoke forfeiture clause.			(Paras 21,22)

heading: Perpetual lease
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Perpetual lease - Determination - Necessary parties.

For determining the lease the lessees are necessary parties. Principle is - privity of contract is between the lessor and lessee and not between the lessor and the transferees. If there is breach of contract, that is to say, express condition of lease, then it gives option to the lessor to determine the lease and re-enter the properties let out. For that purpose, lessee is a necessary party and transferees would be only proper parties. But without the presence of lessees, lease cannot be determined and decree for possession of the property cannot be passed in favour of the lessor.

AIR 1948 Bom 349 Ref.		 [Para 27]

heading: Undivided share
HeadNote.description: What may be transferred - Undivided share - Under the T.P. Act, there is no bar to an heir disposing of his undivided share in the estate of a deceased.	(Para 62)

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgage - Whether, document is mortgage by conditional sale or sale deed with re-conveyance - Determination - Document on record discloses that due to financial constraint, land was sold for limited time as 'mudat kharedi' - Agreement discloses that amount was to be repaid within five years as compulsory period and further period of five years as discretionary - It was loan transaction which was friendly loan and not money lending business - Term regarding re-conveyance is incorporated in documents itself - No concept of temporary sale and permanent sale, but sale is always absolute - Documents on record fulfils all conditions and language used in term incorporated in documents that it was mortgage by conditional sale and not sale with re-conveyance.	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgage - Limitation - Issue is not about calculation of period, but determination of starting point - Deed of re-conveyance provides that amount was to be repaid within 5 years, but by end of phalgun months, which is year-end of phalgun calendar from 1964 - Thus, initial payment became due by end of phalgun of 1969 - No pleading and evidence to show that subsequent period of extension of 5 years was claimed and granted - Even if it is considered, still mortgage amount becomes due and payable by end of phalgun in 1974 - If suit for redemption was to be filed within 30 years, it should have been filed in month of phalgun which ended on 20th March, 2004 - However, suit was filed on 06.04.2004 - No provision for condonation of delay of single day - Hence, suit barred by limitation. 1925 Allahabad 138 Ref. to. 			(Paras 15, 17, 20, 21)

heading: Lease deed
HeadNote.description: Lease deed - Cannot be executed without the signature/ thumb impression of the lessee. (Paras 69)

heading: Part performance
HeadNote.description:
Part performance - What constitutes. 

Section 53-A contemplates effectuating the English doctrine of what is called "part performance" under which when the possession is obtained by a transferee in part performance of the contract or when the transferee has already been put in possession prior to his performance of the other part of the contract, the possession is safeguarded under the doctrine. It envisages several conditions precedent. The transferee has to show that he had taken or continued in possession of the property, that he was willing to perform his part of the contract and has undertaken some action in part performance of the contract. Since a transferee in possession would require essentially only to pay the balance consideration, he has to show that he has paid up the full purchase price or that he was ready and willing and able at all times to make payment of the entire purchase price.
AIR 1957 Bom. 138 Rel. on.               [Para 28]

heading: Part performance
Benefit of
Defendant in possession
HeadNote.description: Part performance - Benefit of - Defendant in possession - Defendant continuing in possession after leave and license agreement expired by efflux of time - Subsequent agreement for purchase of flat - Apart from initial payment at time of agreement further payments on due dates not made - Time was essence of contract for sale as three post dated cheques were received which were dishonored on presentation - Their professing readiness and willingness was an empty formality - Held, in the circumstances that contract necessarily came to an end and defendants were liable to hand over possession and pay compensation by way of mesne profits from the date of the suit.      (Paras 39, 42, 43, 44)

heading: Eviction
Suit for
HeadNote.description: Eviction - Suit for - Landlord-Trust filed suit for eviction against NTC - Central Govt. became protected or statutory tenant in respect of suit property after enforcement of Textile Undertaking Act 1995 w.e.f. 1-4-1994 - Fact that NTC was carrying on activities in suit property - Would not extricate landlord-Trust from initiating eviction proceedings against real tenant i.e. Central Govt. - Such eviction proceedings could be maintained before jurisdictional Rent Court - However, trust instituted suit for eviction under provisions of TP Act - It culminated with decree of eviction, affirmed upto Supreme Court - Held, said eviction decree by Civil Court against NTC, was without jurisdiction and unenforceable against Union of India - Moreso after enforcement of Textile undertakings (Amendment and Validation) Act, 2014 - Further, fact that after expiry of lease, tenant, continued to enjoy "lease hold right" of protected or statutory tenant under Rent Act, plea of holding over or tenant at sufferance, not tenable - Tenant thus could only be evicted under Bombay Rent Act (1947), S.1. 			(Paras 37, 43, 44, 47, 48, 49, 55)

headline: 2018 ALL SCR (ONLINE) 256 . Rent Act Matters : Others

heading: Essentials of
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage by conditional sale - Essentials of - Stated.

	The essentials of an agreement, to qualify as a mortgage by conditional sale, can succinctly be broadly summarised. An ostensible sale with transfer of possession and ownership,but containing a clause for reconveyance in accordance with Section 58 (c) of the Act, will clothe the agreement as a mortgage by conditional sale. The execution of a separate agreement for reconveyance, either contemp or aneously or subsequently, shall militate against the agreement being mortgage by conditional sale. There must exist a debtor and creditor relationship. The valuation of the property, and the transaction value, along with the duration of time for reconveyance, are important considerations to decide the nature of the agreement. There will have to be a cumulative consideration of these factors, along with the recitals in the agreement, intention of the parties, coupled with other attendant circumstances, considered in a holistic manner. 	 [Para 14]

heading: Determination of
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with option to repurchase - Determination of - Plaintiff sold land to defendant for Rs.3500/- on failure to pay borrowed amount of Rs.700/- - Said agreement for sale contained condition of re-conveyance - Defendant also demanded sum of Rs.3500/- with interest for re-conveyance - It shows relationship of debtor and creditor - Also defendant was aware of limited nature of right conveyed and had agreed to conditional sale along with obligation to return land if amount was repaid - Agreement is of mortgage by conditional sale. 1993 Supplement (1) SCC 295 Disting. 			(Paras 15, 17, 18)

heading: Suit for
HeadNote.description: Declaration as to joint ownership - Suit for - Suit property purchased for total consideration of Rs.9,500/- - Son contributed 1/3rd amount of consideration whereas mother contributed 2/3rd amount - Even though sale deed was executed in favour of son showing him as purchaser of property - Son failed to show that he paid entire consideration - Mother also co-purchaser of suit property - Mother entitled to declaration of co-ownership along with her son.			(Paras 9, 11)

heading: Doctrine of merger
HeadNote.description:
Doctrine of merger - Doctrine contemplates (i) confluence of interest of lessee and interest of lessor; (ii) for the whole of the property; (iii) at same time; (iv) for one person, and (v) for the same right.

Doctrine of merger contemplates (i) confluence of the interest of the lessee and interest of lessor; (ii) for the whole of the property; (iii) at the same time; (iv) for one person; and (v) for the same right. So, where there is complete union of whole interest of the lessor and the lessee so as to enable the lesser interest of the leasehold rights to get merged into larger interests of the lesser i.e. Ownership rights in favour of the lessee, the lease would stand extinguished. For the lessee cannot be at the same time both, a landlord as well as a tenant. In the present case, since the Flat No.5 was being occupied by deceased B.R.B. Vakil and Meherji Vakil as joint tenants, soon after the purchase transaction in favour of the latter and the plaintiff No.1, the ownership rights were acquired by them. With the result, the joint tenancy had merged into the larger interest, namely, the right of ownership, in their favour. [Para 14]

heading: Joint tenancy
HeadNote.description: Joint tenancy - Tenancy inherited by heirs after death of original tenant - Tenancy, held, would be the joint tenancy and not tenancy in common. (1995)1 SCC 537 - Rel. on.	(Para 16)

heading: Partition deed
HeadNote.description: Partition deed - Executed between two brothers - Plaintiff selling property allotted to him and utilising proceedings himself - Fact that two brothers even after partition continued business jointly, stayed together and acquired properties out of their business in the names of either of them or the fact that for debt incurred after partition property allotted to plaintiff was given as security would not show that partition was nominal - It was complete, effective and irrevocable.			(Paras 14, 15, 17, 18)

heading: Benami transaction
Onus of proof
HeadNote.description:
Benami transaction - Onus of proof - Is on claimant.

It is well-established that burden of proving that a particular sale is benami lies on the person who alleges the transaction to be a benami. The essence of a benami transaction is the intention of the party or parties concerned and often, such intention is shrouded in a thick veil which cannot be easily pierced through. But such difficulties do not relieve the person asserting the transaction to be benami of any part of the serious onus that rests on him, nor justify the acceptance of mere conjectures or surmises, as a substitute for proof. 1974(1) SCC 3, 1977(1) SCC 816, 1980(3) SCC 72, 1996(4) SCC 490 Ref. 		  [Para 13]

heading: Benami transaction
Benami transaction
Proof
HeadNote.description: Benami transaction - Proof - Husband purchasing property in name of wife - Intention was to screen property from creditors of his brother - Their names not disclosed and no other evidence of and claim by creditors on brother at relevant time - Sale consideration was paid by some third party - He was not examined - Failure of plaintiff to examine relevant witnesses completely demolishes his case - Held benami nature of transaction was not proved.			(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Termination of tenancy - Proof as to existence of tenancy - Suit filed for eviction and possession of suit property from tenant along with claim of arrears - Dismissal of suit by Trial Court holding that tenancy between parties not proved - Appellate Court reversed said finding by placing reliance on agreement of lease - Landlord was not alive to prove it and his daughter-in-law could not depose about its execution - Attesting witness deposed that tenant had signed agreement in his presence - Tenant did not enter witness box to refute document - Stand of tenant that he has surrendered tenancy and thereafter his father has become tenant, not considered by Appellate Court having found father-son relationship between them - No perversity in finding of Appellate Court holding that relationship of "Landlord and Tenant" between parties established. 	(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Sale of property by ostensible owner - Purchaser whether entitled to protection u/S.41 of T.P. Act - Plaintiffs had created only a life interest in suit land in favour of their adoptive mother who sold it to defendant by executing a sale deed - Plaintiff was also attesting witness to said sale deed - Contention that defendant in his cross examination admitted that he did not make any enquiry as to title of transferor before getting sale deed executed, thereby failed to take reasonable care to ascertain that transferor had power to make transfer - Not acceptable - Once real owner of suit property by their own conduct as per S.115 Evidence Act, intentionally caused defendants to believe that transferor is true owner for which they have no objection - Then transaction in favour of defendants has to be presumed as bona fide with consent of plaintiffs - Defendants entitled to protection u/S.41 of TP Act. 	(Para 39)

heading: Notice terminating tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Notice terminating tenancy - Lease deed defining premises to include both land and buildings and notice describing premises in the same manner as in the lease deed - Held when lessor terminated the lease of the land he terminated the lease in respect of the buildings standing on the land also.

What is to be terminated is the lease and in the notice to terminate the lease, suffice it would be if the lessor gives the description of the property, the lease in respect of which he intends to determine. He has not to give a catalogue or a list of items of property standing on the land which is the subject matter of the lease and to say specifically in respect of each item that he terminates the lease with respect to that item or property. If a parcel of land is the subject matter of the lease, and at the time of the lease, on a portion of that land, there was a building and what was leased to the lessee was the land together with the building, if the lessor terminated the lease of the land he must be held to have terminated the lease in respect of the building standing on the part of the land also. It is not necessary for him to terminate the lease area wise or structurewise.  [Para 13]

heading: Notice terminating tenancy
HeadNote.description: Notice terminating tenancy - Notice issued by Bombay Port Trust - Notice not alleged to be arbitrary, unreasonable, malafide or not informed by public interest - Held not having laid any such foundation notice could not be invalidated for not disclosing any reason to terminate the tenancy. Constitution of India, Arts 12, 14. AIR 1989 S.C. 1642 Rel.on. (Para 21)

heading: Notice under
HeadNote.description:
Notice under - Notice need not state ground on which tenancy is terminated as is required to be done in notice under S.4 of Public Premises (Eviction of Unauthorised Occupants) Act, 1971.

Under the Public Premises Act there are clear provisions which entitle the person who is sought to be evicted from the public premises to receive a notice specifying the ground on which he is sought to be evicted from the premises in question and he is also entitled to show cause against the proposed eviction. The addressee of the notice under Section 4 of the Public Premises Act has a right to appear before the Estate Officer in response to the notice under Section 4 of the Public Premises Act and to adduce evidence which he intends to produce in support of the cause that he might intend to show against the proposed eviction and he has also been given a right of  personal hearing if he so desired. Nothing of this sort is to be found anywhere in the Transfer of Property Act in general, in relation to the lessor-lessee relationship, and under Sections 106 and 111 of the Transfer of Property Act in particular. AIR 1992 Bom. 375 Distinguished.  [Para 23]

headline:
(A) Transfer of Property Act, 1882 - S.58(c) - When recital in document clearly states that property sold by Respondent with condition to repay within two years, said amount taken from Appellant in lieu of enjoyment of said property for the stipulated time (2 years), and upon repayment, Appellant will execute re-conveyance to Respondent; however upon failure of repayment within stipulated time (2 years) in document, such document will become an absolute sale deed giving absolute ownership rights to Appellant and then his successors.  Such document held not to be a mortgage but a conditional sale deed (transaction of sale with condition to repurchase)

(B) Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 - S.100 - Second Appeal - Concurrent Findings - High Court not to interfere  unless it finds decision of First Appellate/ Trial Court unless it finds such decision to be (i) contrary to mandatory provisions of the applicable law; or (ii) contrary to the law as pronounced by Apex Court, (iii) based on in-admissible evidence or no evidence.

heading: Proof
HeadNote.description: Mortgage or mortgage by conditional sale - Proof - Document "Mudat Kharedi Khat" shows that mortgagor was in need of amount of Rs.50,000/- for mitigating loan sold the property to mortgagee and had given same in possession for two years - On failure to give that amount within stipulated period same document should be treated as absolute sale deed - On contrary, if said amount is paid within two years, mortgagee would execute re-conveyance deed in favour of mortgagor - Period of two years stipulated for return of amount would amount to transaction of sale with condition to re-purchase - Mere word "Gahan" used in document, will not make that document as 'mortgage transaction'. 1992 ALLMR ONLINE 569, 1962 ALLMR ONLINE 424 (S.C.), 2013 ALL SCR 2679.		(Paras 16, 17)
