heading: Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgage - Maintainability - Mortgagor was in need of amount of Rs.50,000/- for mitigating loan sold the property to mortgagee by way of document "Mudat Kharedi Khat" and had given same in possession for two years - On failure to give that amount within stipulation period of two years same document should be treated as absolute sale deed - Transaction would amount to sale with condition to repurchase - Mortgagor was failed to repay amount of Rs.50,000/- to mortgagee within stipulated period - Mortgagor is not entitled for redemption of mortgage. 	(Para 15)

heading: Unregistered exchange deed
Admissibility as evidence
HeadNote.description: Registration Act (1908), S.49 - Unregistered exchange deed - Admissibility as evidence - Unregistered deed of exchange is in relation to immovable property of value more than Rs.100/- - Not admissible in evidence in view of S.91 of TP Act. 			(Paras 18, 20, 22)

heading: Availability
HeadNote.description: Benefit of S.53A of TP Act - Availability - To avail benefit of S.53A party has to plead that he has taken possession of property in part performance of contract - Defendants have not raised such plea in their pleadings - Defendants cannot claim benefit of S.53A. 	(Para 23)

heading: Determination of
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with condition of repurchase - Determination of - It is to be decided on basis of interpretation of document - Intention of parties is determining factor which has to be gathered from document - If words are express and clear, effect must be given to them - However, if there is any ambiguity in language employed, then it is permissible to look into surrounding circumstances to determine what was intended. (1955) 1 SCR 174 Ref. to. 	(Para 7)

heading: Determination of
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with condition of repurchase - Determination of - Plaintiff's father alleged to have sold suit property to defendant to repay debts, with condition of repurchase within 5 years - It was also alleged that he continued in possession of property till his death as tenant - Defendant could not prove rental agreement nor there was any evidence regarding payment of rent - Evidence shows that notices received from Electricity Department in name of father of plaintiff - There was no mutation in name of defendant - There was no condition in deed that sale will become absolute after expiry of 5 years - Condition in document for reimbursement of loss suffered by transferor due to non-transfer of property on re-payment, establishes that amount given under document is debt and there is relationship of debtor and creditor - Document is mortgage by conditional sale. 		(Paras 16, 17, 18)

heading: Registered sale deed
Challenge to
HeadNote.description:
Registered sale deed - Challenge to - Onus of proof upon defendant to show that the said deed was, in fact, not executed or otherwise does not reflect the true nature of transaction.

The deed of sale being a registered one and apparently containing stipulations of transfer of right, title and interest by the vendor in favour of the vendee, the onus of proof was upon the defendant to show that the said deed was, in fact, not executed or otherwise does not reflect the true nature of transaction. Evidently, with a view to avoid confrontation in regard to his signature as an attesting witness as also that of his father as vendor in the said sale deed, he did not examine himself. An adverse inference, thus, should have been drawn against him by the Trial Court.  AIR 2007 SC 2191 - Rel. on  [Para 15,21]

heading: Registered sale deed
Title of property
HeadNote.description:
Registered sale deed - Title of property - Right of possession over a property is a facet of title - As soon as a deed of sale is registered, the title passes to the vendee.

Right of possession over a property is a facet of title. As soon as a deed of sale is registered, the title passes to the vendee. The vendor, in terms of the stipulations made in the deed of sale, is bound to deliver possession of the property sold. If he does not do so, he makes him liable for damages. The indemnity clause should have been construed keeping in view that legal principle in mind.  [Para 21]

heading: Suit for possession based on title
HeadNote.description:
Suit for possession based on title - Onus is on plaintiff to prove his title.

In a suit for declaration of title and possession, the onus is upon the plaintiff to prove his title. Further, not only is the onus on the plaintiff, he must prove his title independently, and a decree in his favour cannot be awarded for the only reason that the defendant has not been able to prove his title.     [Para 19]

heading: Acceptance of gift
HeadNote.description:
Gift in favour of deity - Acceptance of gift - Proof.

The gift is a voluntary gratuitous transfer. Such a gift could also be in favour of deity. In such cases, the only thing required for completion of gift is that some person has to accept the gift on behalf of deity. Gift in favour of deity is complete when there is evidence to the effect that the donor intended to donate and divest himself of the property without there being element of retaining. Some overt act on the part of the trustee managing the temple is sufficient to presume acceptance of the gift. 			    [Para 11]

headline: Transfer of Property Act (1882), S. 58(c) – Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with option of repurchase – Valuation of property and transaction value along with duration of time for reconveyance, are important considerations to decide nature of agreement.

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description: Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with option of repurchase - Determination - Plaintiffs purchased daily necessities from shop of defendant on credit and dues were repayable in three yearly installments - Plaintiffs executed conditional sale deed in favour of defendant on failure to pay first installment - Agreement provided that plaintiffs entitled to reconveyance of land on payment of dues by third year - On failure of plaintiffs to pay dues within three years, defendant obtained mutation of land in his name - Submission of defendant that no objection of plaintiff to mutation shows that agreement was sale deed, not acceptable, in view of poor financial condition of plaintiffs and on finding that plaintiffs were in possession of land - Further, agriculturist cannot easily dispose his agricultural land merely for purchase made by him on credit - Material on record also established debtor and creditor relationship between plaintiff and defendant - Agreement between parties was mortgage by conditional sale.		(Paras 7, 12)

headline: Transfer of Property Act (1882), S. 58(c) – Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with option of repurchase – Valuation of property and transaction value along with duration of time for reconveyance, are important considerations to decide nature of agreement.

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage by conditional sale or sale with option of repurchase - Determination - Valuation of property and transaction value along with duration of time for reconveyance, are important considerations to decide nature of agreement.

	Whether an agreement is a mortgage by conditional sale or sale with an option for repurchase is a vexed question to be considered in the facts of each case. The essentials of an agreement, to qualify as a mortgage by conditional sale, can succinctly be summarised. An ostensible sale with transfer of possession and ownership, but containing a clause for reconveyance in accordance with Section 58(c) of the Act, will clothe the agreement as a mortgage by conditional sale. The execution of a separate agreement for reconveyance, either contemporaneously or subsequently, shall militate against the agreement being mortgage by conditional sale. There must exist a debtor and creditor relationship. The valuation of the property, and the transaction value, along with the duration of time for reconveyance, are important considerations to decide the nature of the agreement. There will have to be a cumulative consideration of these factors, along with the recitals in the agreement, intention of the parties, coupled with other attendant circumstances, considered in a holistic manner. The language used in the agreement may not always be conclusive.	 [Para 10]

heading: Exchange of Property
Validity of
HeadNote.description: Exchange of Property - Validity of - Held, an exchange of property as contemplated under S.118 of Transfer of Property Act must be effected by a registered instrument - Such transfer would be valid only when it is effected likewise that of a sale as contemplated under S.54 of the Act. AIR 1997 SC 2719 - Ref. to.			(Para 29)

heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - Entitlement of plaintiff to file suit - Suit property originally belonged to 'A' who transferred same to 'Z' by way of gift deed - 'Z' sold it to plaintiff by way of sale deed - Transferor continued to collect rent of suit property from tenant with consent of transferee-plaintiff after execution of sale deed, until transferee took over affairs of suit property - Same will not debar transferee from filing suit for eviction against tenant - Thus, plaintiff entitled to file suit for eviction. 2015(4) ALL MR 408 (S.C.) Ref. to. (Para 27)

heading: Transfer of property
HeadNote.description: Transfer of property - Rights of transferee in respect of subsisting tenancy - No requirement under TP Act that transfer of rights of landlord can take effect only if tenant attorns to him - Attornment of tenant is not necessary to confer validity of transfer of landlord's rights.  2015(4) ALL MR 408 (S.C.) Rel. on.  (Para 27)

heading: Termination of lease
HeadNote.description: Termination of lease - Land leased by Govt. - Breach of condition of lease - Notice issued by Competent Authority and proceedings initiated - Thus, even if lease rental received, the same is saved under second proviso to S.112 - Further, payment of rental made to Govt. would in any event be accepted as different functions are performed by different offices and any amount tendered will be received - That cannot give any advantage to lessee merely because rent was tendered in Govt. office and same was innocuously accepted without there being specific reference to waiver - Mere acceptance of rent after expiry of period of lease did not signify assent to continuance of lease. (Paras 19, 20)

heading: Termination of lease
Breach of condition
Not tenable
HeadNote.description: Termination of lease - Land leased by Govt. - Clause 14 prohibiting lessee from sub-letting or assigning interest in lease except with previous permission in writing of lessor - Breach of condition - Transfer of land by lessee from land leased - Breach was not of nature which was contemplated for rectification as provided under Clause 12 of lease deed - Therefore, plea by respondent-lessee that there was non-compliance of Clause 12 before exercise of right of lessor to terminate lease as provided under Clause 14 - Not tenable - Further, plea that even if breach is held against lessee, entire lease cannot be forfeited in view of provision in S.111(g), also not tenable - Breach being of not adhering to assurance given to lessor in respect of property belonging to lessor, be it whole or part of it - Held, such breach cannot be condoned. (Paras 24, 26, 30)

headline: Jurisdiction of Waqf Tribunal to entertain suit for declaration, determined.

heading: Surrender of tenancy
HeadNote.description: Surrender of tenancy - Even if male member of joint family taken premises on rent, he is tenant in his individual capacity - And not as Karta of Hindu Undivided Family in absence of any evidence that Karta was doing business for and on behalf of Joint Hindu Family - Joint Hindu Family cannot be presumed to be in existence only on basis of Ration Card unless there is evidence that funds of joint Hindu Family were invested in business in tenanted premises - Payment of rent or Ration Card do not prove that tenant was carrying business as Joint Hindu Family Business - It was contract of tenancy which was inherited by grandfather of plaintiff - Even if great grandfather was maintaining family out of income generated from hotel business, that itself would not make other family members as coparceners in hotel business - Tenancy was individual right vested with grandfather of plaintiff who was competent to surrender it to landlord - Moreover, act of surrender of tenancy was for benefit of Joint Hindu family.			(Paras 29, 31, 32, 35, 37)

heading: Causing damage to building
HeadNote.description: Causing damage to building - Damage contemplated by S.108(a) must be wilful damage and of major nature - Damage of minor nature resulting from doing same thing which is necessary for proper user of property cannot fall within clutches of S.108(O).

heading: Scope of
HeadNote.description: Scope of - Erection of permanent structure - Commission of any act destructive of tenanted premises or permanently injurious thereto is prohibited by S.108(o) of Transfer of Property Act - The same is covered under S.16(1)(a) of Rent Act.	(Para 15)

heading: Commission of act injurious or destructive of premises
HeadNote.description: Commission of act injurious or destructive of premises - Erection of wooden/aluminium cabin and cement flooring in premises leased out for step and godown - Initial burden is on landlord to show that it was injurious and in absence of such evidence decree on that count under S.16(1)(a) and (b) could not have been granted.	(Para 19)

heading: Hindu Law
Dispute regarding partition
HeadNote.description: Hindu Law - Civil P.C. (1908), S.35-A - Dispute regarding partition - Defendant/seller sold her share in joint property - Purchasers stating that seller was sole owner by virtue of partition - Joint owners/plaintiffs denying partition and objecting sale - Plaintiff's witness admits his signature as attesting witness on partition deed - Witness also admits signatures of executants of partition deed - Sale-deed executed by seller of her share bears signature of plaintiffs as consenting parties - Sale-deed contains recital of partition - Partition is proved and sale of her share by seller is valid - Plaintiffs are entitled to compensatory costs for raising false plea of denying partition.			(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Lease
HeadNote.description: Lease - There can be oral lease accompanied by delivery of property - No registered document or any lease deed is required as per the S.5 of H.T. & A.L. Act.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Rent Act would operate prospectively
HeadNote.description: Rent Act would operate prospectively - Plaintiff terminated tenancy of defendant in the suit house in CIDCO at Aurangabad on 5th April, 1982 and filed suit for eviction on 3rd November, 1982 - CIDCO came in municipal limits on 3rd December, 1982 and Rent Act, 1954 became applicable - Held, Rent Act would operate prospectively and as such it was not applicable to suit filed on 3rd November, 1982. 	(Paras 12 to 17)

heading: Hindu Law
Joint family property
HeadNote.description: Hindu Law - Joint family property - Joint family consisting of Plaintiffs and defendant No.2 do not possess any ancestral income giving property - No nucleus available from which house in dispute could have been purchased - Property is not joint family property - Parties have grocery store as joint business - Defendant-son opened another shop with monetary help of his mother/plaintiff - In another suit against defendant/son he has admitted of carrying joint family business - House property in dispute is purchased from income out of joint business - It is jointly acquired property.(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Hindu Law
HeadNote.description: Hindu Law - Sale of joint property - Joint Hindu family running joint family business - House property acquired from earnings of joint business - Every member of joint family has equal share in jointly acquired property - Sale of such property by single member without consent of other members is not sustainable.	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Suit for partition
Transfer pendente lite
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition - Transfer pendente lite - Defendant father allegedly gifted the suit property to his another son (defendant no.2) during pendency of suit - Gift invalid as it was relating to joint family property - Even otherwise, plaintiff son and daughter in law were living in suit property at that time - As such, gift deed could not have been acted upon - Said transfer is also hit by S.52 of Transfer of Property Act - Further, defendant father having been died during pendency of suit itself, Sec.8 of Hindu Succession Act would come into play - Suit property would devolve upon all children of defendant in equal share. 			(Paras 22, 24, 25)

heading: Mohammedan Law
HeadNote.description: Mohammedan Law - Levy of stamp duty - On oral gift made by a Mohammedan - Merely because same was reduced in writing on stamp paper and mutated, stamp duty cannot be imposed - No provision in Registration Act for levying stamp duty on such gift - S.129 of T.P. Act not applicable to Mohammedan. 2011(3) ALL MR 981 (S.C.), 2014(6) ALL MR 900 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Para 4)

heading: Gift
Registration of
HeadNote.description:
Gift - Registration of - Relinquishment of flat in question without receiving any consideration therefor - That relinquishment acted upon by the society - It comes within the purview of Gift within meaning under S.122 of Transfer of Property Act - Such gift has to be registered so that in law transfer will take effect.

In the present case, it is seen that the Judgment Debtor No.3 submitted an application to the society expressing that they were relinquishing their right in the said flat in favour of applicant without receiving any consideration therefor. On the basis of this application, Society has acted upon and then recorded change in the share certificate which now mentions only the name of the applicant. The applicant has accepted that position. The act of relinquishment was in relation to the interest in the immovable property though that occurs due to the transfer of shares. In other words, the applicant has accepted the transfer of interest in the immovable property effected by way of relinquishment by the co-owners. If it is so, it would fall within the definition of Gift of immovable property within the section 122 of Transfer of Property Act. Indeed, expression relinquishment is not defined in the Transfer of Property Act but dictionary meaning thereof is abandonment of right or abatement of right. The concomitant of abandonment or relinquishment of right of one devolves that corresponding right in favour of the other which has the effect of transfer by way of gift within the expansive definition under section 122 of the Transfer of Property Act. Such gift has to be registered so that in law transfer will take effect. (1998)9 SCC 194 and 1990(3) Bom.C.R. 389 - Referred to.  [Para 5]

heading: Civil P.C. (1908), S.72
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), S.72 - Right of auction purchaser - Where auction purchaser has deposited entire sale consideration and objections to the sale have been dealt with and disposed of in accordance with law and the Competent Authority has confirmed the sale, held, an absolute right vests in the auction purchaser - He is entitled to issue of sale certificate - Judgment debtor/petitioners cannot defeat this claim by making a mere averment across the bar that they are willing to deposit the entire decretal amount. (1991)3 SCC 588 and 2008 ALL SCR 1340 - Ref. to.			(Paras 11, 13)

heading: Unregistered lease
Admissibility
HeadNote.description: Unregistered lease - Admissibility - Clause in lease deed that premises were let out to a particular named officer of the Company and cannot be allotted to any other officer - It is an important clause in lease deed and cannot be looked into even for collateral purposes.	(Paras 24, 28)
